original: “Yathā rukkho tathā rājā, yathā sākhā tathā ahaṃ;
analyzed: yathā rukkhaḥ tathā rājā yathā sākhā tathā aham
translated: “As the tree, so the king; as the branch, so I am;

original: Yathā chāyūpago poso, evaṃ tvamasi sārathi;
analyzed: yathā chāyūpagaḥ poso evam tvam asi sārathi
translated: As the man who goes to the shade, so you are, charioteer;

original: Adhammaṃ sārathi kayirā, maṃ ce tvaṃ nikhaṇaṃ vane”ti.
analyzed: adhammam sārathi mam ce tvam nikhaṇam vana iti
translated: The charioteer has done an unrighteous deed, in that he has buried me in the forest.”

original: Tattha nihaññasīti nihanissasi. Yaṃ tvaṃ ettha nihanissāmīti saññāya kāsuṃ khaṇasi,
analyzed: tattha nihaññasi iti nihanissasi yam tvam ettha nihanissāmi iti saññāya kāsum khaṇasi
translated: “Here you will be killed,” means “here you will be slain.” “What you think you will slay here,” means “what you think you will kill here.”

original: so ahanti dīpeti. So “rājaputto aha”nti vuttepi na saddahatiyeva, madhurakathāya🔽panassa bajjhitvā dhammaṃ suṇanto aṭṭhāsi. Mittadubbhoti paribhuttachāyassa rukkhassa
analyzed: saḥ ahanti dīpeti saḥ rāja puttaḥ ahanti vutte pi na saddahatiyā iva madhura kathāya  panassa bajjhitvā dhammam suṇanto aṭṭhāsi mitta dubbhaḥ ti paribhutta chāyassa rukkhassa
translated: “I am he,” means “I am he.” Although he said, “I am the prince,” he did not believe him. But he was captivated by his sweet voice,

original: pattaṃ vā sākhaṃ vā aṅkuraṃ vā bhañjanto mittaghātako hoti lāmakapuriso, kimaṅgaṃ
analyzed: pattam vā sākham vā aṅkuram vā bhañjantaḥ mitta ghātakaḥ hoti lāmaka puriso kim aṅgam
translated: and stood listening to the Dhamma. “He who destroys a friend,” means he who breaks off a leaf or a branch of a tree which has given him shade, is a destroyer of friends, a wicked man. How much more so is he who destroys his master’s son?

original: pana sāmiputtaghātako. Chāyūpagoti paribhogatthāya chāyaṃ upagato puriso viya rājānaṃ🔽nissāya jīvamāno tvanti vadati.
analyzed: pana sāmi putta ghātako chāyūpago ti paribhoga atthāya chāyam upagataḥ puriso viya rājānam  nissāya jīvamānaḥ tvanti vadati
translated: “He who has gone to the shade for his own use,” means he who lives in dependence on the king, as a man who has gone to the shade for his own use.

original: So evaṃ kathentepi bodhisatte na saddahatiyeva. Atha mahāsatto “saddahāpessāmi na”nti
analyzed: saḥ evam kathente pi bodhisatte na saddahatiyā iva atha mahāsattaḥ saddahāpessāmi
translated: Although he spoke thus, the Bodhisatta did not believe him. Then the Great Being thought, “I will make him believe.”

original: devatānaṃ sādhukārena ceva attano ghosena ca vanaghaṭaṃ unnādento dasa mittapūjagāthā nāma ārabhi –
analyzed: devatānam sādhukārena ca iva ghosena ca vana ghaṭam unnādentaḥ dasa mittapūjagāthāḥ nāma ārabhi
translated: And he began to utter the ten verses on the worship of friends, called the “Forest-cry,” with the approval of the deities and with his own voice, making the forest resound.🔽“He becomes one who has much food,

original: “Pahūtabhakkho bhavati, vippavuṭṭho sakaṃgharā;
analyzed: pahūta bhakkhaḥ bhavati vippavuṭṭhaḥ sa kaṃgharā
translated: and is freed from his own house.

original: Bahū naṃ upajīvanti, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: bahū nam upajīvanti yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: Many people depend on him, he who does not deceive his friends.

original: “Yaṃ yaṃ janapadaṃ yāti, nigame rājadhāniyo;
analyzed: yam yam janapadam yāti nigame
translated: Wherever he goes, to a village, town or city,

original: Sabbattha pūjito hoti, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: sabbattha pūjitaḥ hoti yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: he is everywhere honored, he who does not deceive his friends.

original: “Nāssa corā pasāhanti, nātimaññanti khattiyā;
analyzed: na assa corā pasāhanti na atimaññanti khattiyā
translated: Thieves do not attack him, nor do nobles despise him;

original: Sabbe amitte tarati, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: sabbe amitte tarati yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: he overcomes all his enemies, he who does not deceive his friends.

original: “Akkuddho sagharaṃ eti, sabhāyaṃ paṭinandito;
analyzed: a kkuddhaḥ sa gharam eti sabhāyam paṭinanditaḥ
translated: He returns home without anger, welcomed in the assembly;

original: Ñātīnaṃ uttamo hoti, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: ñātīnam uttamaḥ hoti yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: he is the best of relatives, he who does not deceive his friends.

original: “Sakkatvā sakkato hoti, garu hoti sagāravo;
analyzed: sakkatvā sakkataḥ hoti garu hoti sa gāravo
translated: Honoring others, he is honored; respected, he is revered;

original: Vaṇṇakittibhato hoti, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: vaṇṇa kitti bhataḥ hoti yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: he is praised for his beauty and fame, he who does not deceive his friends.

original: “Pūjako labhate pūjaṃ, vandako paṭivandanaṃ;
analyzed: pūjakaḥ labhate pūjam paṭivandanam
translated: He who worships receives worship; he who pays homage receives it in return;

original: Yasokittiñca pappoti, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: yasokittiñca pappoti yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: he gains fame and praise, he who does not deceive his friends.

original: “Aggi yathā pajjalati, devatāva virocati;
analyzed: aggi yathā pajjalati devatā ava virocati
translated: Like a blazing fire, he shines like a god;

original: Siriyā ajahito hoti, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: siriyāḥ a jahitaḥ hoti yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: he is not abandoned by glory, he who does not deceive his friends.

original: “Gāvo tassa pajāyanti, khette vuttaṃ virūhati;
analyzed: gāvaḥ tassa pajāyanti khette vuttam virūhati
translated: Cattle are born to him; what is sown in his field grows;

original: Vuttānaṃ phalamasnāti, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: vuttānam phalam a snāti yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: he enjoys the fruit of what is said, he who does not deceive his friends.

original: “Darito pabbatāto vā, rukkhato patito naro;
analyzed: daritaḥ pabbatātaḥ vā rukkhataḥ patitaḥ naro
translated: “A man who falls from a mountain or a cliff or a tree,

original: Cuto patiṭṭhaṃ labhati, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: cutaḥ patiṭṭham labhati yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: Gets a foothold if he does not let go of his friends.

original: “Virūḷhamūlasantānaṃ, nigrodhamiva māluto;
analyzed: virūḍha mūla santānam nigrodham iva māluto
translated: “A friend who is like a tree with roots that go deep,

original: Amittā nappasāhanti, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhatī”ti.
analyzed: amittāḥ na pasāhanti yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati iti
translated: Is not overcome by enemies if he does not let go of his friends.”

original: Tattha sakaṃ gharāti sakagharā, ayameva vā pāṭho. Na dubbhatīti na dussati. Mittānanti
analyzed: tattha sakam gharā ati sakagharā ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ na dubbhati iti na dussati mittānam ti
translated: Herein, his own house is his own home. The reading is also “na dubbhati.” He does not let go of his friends.

original: buddhādīnaṃ kalyāṇamittānaṃ na dubbhati. “Sabbattha pūjito hotī”ti idaṃ sīvalivatthunā
analyzed: buddha ādīnam kalyāṇa mittānam na sabbattha pūjitaḥ hoti iti idam sīvali vatthunā
translated: He does not let go of his good friends, the Enlightened One, etc. “He is everywhere honoured” should be illustrated by the story of Sivali.

original: vaṇṇetabbaṃ. Na pasāhantīti pasayhakāraṃ kātuṃ na sakkonti. Idaṃ saṃkiccasāmaṇeravatthunā
analyzed: vaṇṇetabbam na pasāhanti iti pasayhakāram kātum na sakkonti idam saṃkicca sāmaṇera vatthunā
translated: “They do not overcome him” should be illustrated by the story of the novice Saṅkicca.

original: dīpetabbaṃ. “Nātimaññanti khattiyā”ti idaṃ jotikaseṭṭhivatthunā dīpetabbaṃ. Taratīti
analyzed: dīpetabbam na atimaññanti khattiyā ti idam jotika seṭṭhi vatthunā dīpetabbam tarati iti
translated: “The nobles do not despise him” should be illustrated by the story of the merchant Jotika. He crosses over.🔽He goes beyond. His own house is his own home.

original: atikkamati. Sagharanti attagharaṃ. Mittānaṃ dubbhanto attano gharaṃ āgacchantopi
analyzed: atikkamati atta gharam mittānam attanaḥ gharam āgacchantaḥ api
translated: One who lets go of his friends, even when he comes to his own house,

original: ghaṭṭitacitto kuddhova āgacchati, ayaṃ pana akuddhova sakagharaṃ eti. Paṭinanditoti
analyzed: ghaṭṭita cittaḥ kuddhaḥ uva āgacchati ayam pana a kuddhaḥ uva saka gharam eti paṭinanditaḥ iti
translated: comes with a troubled mind, as if angry. But this one comes to his own house without anger. He is welcomed.

original: bahūnaṃ sannipātaṭṭhāne amittadubbhino guṇakathaṃ kathenti, tāya so paṭinandito hoti pamuditacitto.🔽Sakkatvā sakkato hotīti paraṃ sakkatvā sayampi parehi sakkato hoti. Garu hoti sagāravoti🔽paresu sagāravo sayampi parehi garuko hoti. Vaṇṇakittibhatoti bhatavaṇṇakitti, guṇañceva
analyzed: bahūnam sannipāta ṭṭhāne amitta dubbhinaḥ guṇa katham kathenti tāya so paṭinanditaḥ hoti pamudita citto  sakkatvā sakkataḥ hoti iti param sakkatvā sayam pi parehi sakkataḥ hoti garu hoti sa gāravā iti  paresu sa gāravaḥ sayam pi parehi garukaḥ hoti vaṇṇa kitti bhataḥ ti bhata vaṇṇa kitti guṇam ca iva
translated: In an assembly of many people, he speaks in praise of those who are not his friends; he is pleased and delighted by that.🔽He is honoured and respected by others: he is honoured and respected by others after honouring them. He is esteemed and revered:

original: kittisaddañca ukkhipitvā caranto nāma hotīti attho. Pūjakoti mittānaṃ pūjako hutvā🔽sayampi pūjaṃ labhati. Vandakoti buddhādīnaṃ kalyāṇamittānaṃ vandako hutvā punabbhave
analyzed: kitti saddam ca ukkhipitvā carantaḥ nāma hoti iti attho pūjakaḥ iti mittānam pūjakaḥ hutvā  sayam pi pūjam labhati vandakaḥ uti buddha ādīnam kalyāṇa mittānam vandakaḥ hutvā punabbhave
translated: he is esteemed by others after esteeming others. He is praised and acclaimed: he is praised and acclaimed after praising and acclaiming others. He is worshipped: he is worshipped after worshipping his friends.

original: paṭivandanaṃ labhati. Yasokittiñcāti issariyaparivārañceva guṇakittiñca pappoti.
analyzed: paṭivandanam labhati yasokittim ca ati issariya parivāram ca iva guṇa kittim ca pappoti
translated: He is revered: he is revered after revering good friends such as the Buddha. He gains fame and renown: he gains both lordship and retinue and the fame of his good qualities.

original: Imāya gāthāya cittagahapatino vatthu kathetabbaṃ.
analyzed: imāya gāthāya citta gahapatino vatthu kathetabbam
translated: The story of the householder Citta should be told here.🔽He blazes: he blazes with lordship and retinue. He is not abandoned by glory: here,

original: Pajjalatīti issariyaparivārena pajjalati. Siriyā ajahito hotīti ettha anāthapiṇḍikassa
analyzed: pajjalati iti issariya parivārena pajjalati siriyā a jahitaḥ hoti iti ettha anāthapiṇḍikassa
translated: Anāthapiṇḍika

original: vatthu kathetabbaṃ. Asnātīti paribhuñjati. “Patiṭṭhaṃ labhatī”ti idaṃ cūḷapadumajātakena🔽dīpetabbaṃ. Virūḷhamūlasantānanti vaḍḍhitamūlapārohaṃ. Amittā nappasāhantīti ettha
analyzed: vatthu kathetabbam a snāti iti paribhuñjati patiṭṭham labhati iti idam cūḷapaduma jātakena  dīpetabbam virūḍha mūla santānanti vaḍḍhita mūla pāroham amittāḥ na pasāhanti iti ettha
translated: The story should be told. “He uses what has not been given” means he uses what has not been given to him. “He gets a footing” should be illustrated by the story of Cūḷapaduma. “His roots grow and spread” means his roots grow and increase. “Enemies do not overcome him” means that he is not overcome by enemies.

original: kuraraghariyasoṇattherassa mātu gehaṃ paviṭṭhacoravatthu kathetabbaṃ.
analyzed: kuraraghariyasoṇa therassa mātu geham paviṭṭha cora vatthu kathetabbam
translated: The story of the Elder Kuraraghariyasoṇa’s mother’s house, which was entered by thieves, should be told here.

original: Sunando sārathi ettakāhi gāthāhi dhammaṃ desentampi taṃ asañjānitvā “ko nu kho aya”nti
analyzed: sunandaḥ sārathi ettakāhi gāthāhi dhammam desentam pi tam a sañjānitvā kaḥ nu kho ayanti
translated: The charioteer Sunanda, not recognizing the Bodhisatta, who was teaching the Dhamma with these verses, thought, “Who is this?”

original: āvāṭakhaṇanaṃ pahāya rathasamīpaṃ gantvā tattha tañca pasādhanabhaṇḍañca ubhayaṃ
analyzed: āvāṭa khaṇanam pahāya ratha samīpam gantvā ubhayam
translated: Abandoning the digging of the pit, he went to the chariot. Not seeing either the Bodhisatta or the equipment for bathing,

original: adisvā puna āgantvā olokento taṃ sañjānitvā tassa pādesu patitvā añjaliṃ paggayha
analyzed: a disvā punar āgantvā olokento tam sañjānitvā tassa pādesu patitvā añjalim paggayha
translated: he returned and looked again. Recognizing him, he fell at his feet, raised his joined palms in reverent salutation,

original: yācanto imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: imam gātham āha
translated: and, beseeching him, spoke this verse:

original: “Ehi taṃ paṭinessāmi, rājaputta sakaṃ gharaṃ;
analyzed: ehi tam paṭinessāmi rāja putta sakam gharam
translated: “Come, I will take you back, prince, to your own home.

original: Rajjaṃ kārehi bhaddante, kiṃ araññe karissasī”ti.
analyzed: rajjam kārehi bhaddante kim araññe karissasi iti
translated: Rule the kingdom, good sir, what will you do in the forest?”

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: Then the Great Being said:

original: “Alaṃ me tena rajjena, ñātakehi dhanena vā;
analyzed: alam me tena rajjena ñātakehi dhanena vā
translated: “I have no need of that kingdom, nor of relatives, nor of wealth;

original: Yaṃ me adhammacariyāya, rajjaṃ labbhetha sārathī”ti.
analyzed: yam me adhamma cariyāya rajjam labbhetha sārathī iti
translated: “If I were to get a kingdom, charioteer, by living a life of unrighteousness,

original: Tattha alanti paṭikkhepavacanaṃ.
analyzed: tattha alam ti paṭikkhepa vacanam
translated: “Alā, alā!” is a word of refusal.

original: Sārathi āha –
analyzed: sārathi āha
translated: The charioteer said:

original: “Puṇṇapattaṃ maṃ lābhehi, rājaputta ito gato;
analyzed: puṇṇa pattam mam lābhehi rāja puttaḥ itas gataḥ
translated: “Give me a full reward, prince, when you have gone from here;

original: Pitā mātā ca me dajjuṃ, rājaputta tayī gate.
analyzed: pitā mātā ca me rāja putta tayī gate
translated: My father and mother will give me, prince, when you have gone.

original: “Orodhā ca kumārā ca, vesiyānā ca brāhmaṇā;
analyzed: orodhā ca kumārā ca vesiyānā ca brāhmaṇā
translated: “The princes and the young men, the courtesans and the brahmans,

original: Tepi attamanā dajjuṃ, rājaputta tayī gate.
analyzed: te pi atta manāḥ rāja putta tayī gate
translated: They too will give me, prince, when you have gone.

original: “Hatthārohā anīkaṭṭhā, rathikā pattikārakā;
analyzed: hattha ārohā anīkaṭṭhā rathikā patti kārakā
translated: “The elephant-riders and the cavalry, the charioteers and the infantry,

original: Tepi attamanā dajjuṃ, rājaputta tayī gate.
analyzed: te pi atta manāḥ rāja putta tayī gate
translated: They too will give me, prince, when you have gone.

original: “Bahudhaññā jānapadā, negamā ca samāgatā;
analyzed: bahu dhaññāḥ jānapadāḥ negamā ca samāgatā
translated: “The country people and the townspeople who have come together,

original: Upāyanāni me dajjuṃ, rājaputta tayī gate”ti.🔽Tattha puṇṇapattanti tuṭṭhidāyaṃ. Dajjunti sattaratanavassaṃ vassantā viya mama ajjhāsayapūraṇaṃ
analyzed: upāyanāni me rāja putta tayī gatā iti  tattha tuṭṭhi dāyam satta ratana vassam vassantāḥ viya mama ajjhāsaya pūraṇam
translated: They will give me presents, prince, when you have gone.”

original: tuṭṭhidāyaṃ dadeyyuṃ. Idaṃ so “appeva nāma mayi anukampāya gaccheyyā”ti cintetvā
analyzed: dadeyyuṃ idam saḥ appā iva nāma mayi anukampāya gaccheyya iti cintetvā
translated: Herein, a full reward is a reward to one’s satisfaction. Give me is give me to the extent of satisfying my wish, as if they were to rain down the seven kinds of precious stones. This is what he said thinking “Perhaps he will go out of compassion for me.”

original: āha. Vesiyānā cāti vessā ca. Upāyanānīti paṇṇākārāni.
analyzed: āha vesiyānā ca ati vessā ca upāyanāni iti paṇṇa ākārāni
translated: The courtesans and the brahmans: the brahmans and the courtesans. Presents: gifts.

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: The Great Being said:

original: “Pitu mātu cahaṃ catto, raṭṭhassa nigamassa ca;
analyzed: pitu mātu ca aham catto raṭṭhassa nigamassa ca
translated: “I am the son of my father and mother, of the kingdom and the city,

original: Atho sabbakumārānaṃ, natthi mayhaṃ sakaṃ gharaṃ.
analyzed: atho sabba kumārānam natthi mayham sakam gharam
translated: And of all the princes; I have no home of my own.

original: “Anuññāto ahaṃ matyā, sañcatto pitarā mahaṃ;
analyzed: anuññātaḥ aham matyā sañcattaḥ pitarā maham
translated: “I was permitted by my mother, and well-instructed by my father,

original: Ekoraññe pabbajito, na kāme abhipatthaye”ti.
analyzed: ekoraññe pabbajitaḥ na kāme abhipatthayeti
translated: I went forth in the forest, and do not desire the pleasures of sense.”

original: Tattha pitu mātu cāti pitarā ca mātarā ca ahaṃ catto. Itaresupi eseva nayo. Matyāti
analyzed: tattha pitu mātu ca ati pitarā ca mātarā ca aham catto itaresu pi esā iva nayaḥ matyā ati
translated: Herein, I am the son of my father and mother means I am the son of my father and of my mother. The same method of explanation applies to the rest.

original: samma sārathi, ahaṃ sattāhaṃ rajjaṃ paricchinditvā varaṃ gaṇhantiyā mātarā anuññāto
analyzed: samma sārathi aham sattāham rajjam paricchinditvā varam gaṇhantiyā mātarā anuññātaḥ
translated: By my mother means by my mother who, after having ruled the kingdom for seven days, was taking a boon.🔽Well-instructed means well-permitted.

original: nāma. Sañchattoti suṭṭhu catto. Pabbajitoti pabbajitvā araññe vasanatthāya nikkhantoti attho.
analyzed: nāma sañchattaḥ ti suṭṭhu catto pabbajitoti pabbajitvā araññe vasana tthāya nikkhanto ti attho
translated: I went forth means I went forth in order to dwell in the forest.

original: Evaṃ mahāsattassa attano guṇe kathentassa pīti uppajji, tato pītivegena udānaṃ udānento āha –
analyzed: evam mahāsattassa attanaḥ guṇe kathentassa pīti uppajji tatas pīti vegena udānam udānentaḥ āha
translated: Thus, as the Great Being was speaking of his own virtues, he experienced joy. Then, with the force of that joy, he uttered this exalted utterance:

original: “Api ataramānānaṃ, phalāsāva samijjhati;
analyzed: api a taramānānam samijjhati
translated: “Even for those who do not cross over, the fruit of their desire is successful.

original: Vipakkabrahmacariyosmi, evaṃ jānāhi sārathi.
analyzed: vipakka brahmacariyaḥ asmi evam jānāhi sārathi
translated: I am one whose holy life is complete; know this, charioteer.

original: “Api ataramānānaṃ, sammadattho vipaccati;
analyzed: api a taramānānam sammadatthaḥ vipaccati
translated: “Even for those who do not cross over, their right aim is successful.

original: Vipakkabrahmacariyosmi, nikkhanto akutobhayo”ti.🔽Tattha phalāsāvāti ataramānassa mama soḷasavassehi katavāyāmassa samiddhaṃ ajjhāsayaphalaṃ
analyzed: vipakka brahmacariyaḥ asmi nikkhantaḥ akutobhayaḥ ti  tattha a taramānassa mama soḷasa vassehi kata vāyāmassa samiddham ajjhāsaya phalam
translated: I have fulfilled the life of a monk, I have gone forth, free from all fear.”

original: dassetuṃ evamāha. Vipakkabrahmacariyosmīti niṭṭhappattamanoratho. Sammadattho vipaccatīti
analyzed: dassetum evam āha vipakka brahmacariyaḥ asmi iti niṭṭhappatta manoratho sammadattho vipaccati iti
translated: Herein, he said, “I have fulfilled the fruit of the life of a monk,” to show that he had attained the fruit of the life of a monk, which he had desired for sixteen years.🔽“I have fulfilled the life of a monk” means that he had attained his desire.

original: sammā upāyena kāraṇena kattabbakiccaṃ sampajjati.
analyzed: sammā upāyena kāraṇena kattabba kiccam sampajjati
translated: “The right aim is fulfilled” means that the right aim is fulfilled by the right means.

original: Sārathi āha –
analyzed: sārathi āha
translated: The charioteer said:

analyzed: nihaññamānaḥ bhūmiyā tam me akkhāhi sārathi
translated: Was he killed on the ground? Tell me, charioteer.”

original: “Kathaṃ hatthehi pādehi, mūgapakkho vivajjayi;
analyzed: katham hatthehi pādehi mūga pakkhaḥ vivajjayi
translated: “How did he, with hands and feet, dumb and lame,

original: Nihaññamāno bhūmiyā, taṃ me akkhāhi pucchito”ti.
analyzed: nihaññamānaḥ bhūmiyā tam me akkhāhi pucchito ti
translated: avoid being killed on the ground? Tell me, asked.”

original: Tattha mātāti temiyakumārassa mātā. Pathabyā bhūmivaḍḍhanoti so mama putto bhūmivaḍḍhano
analyzed: tattha mātā ati temiya kumārassa mātā pathabyā bhūmi vaḍḍhano ti so mama putto bhūmi vaḍḍhano
translated: There, mother means the mother of Prince Temiya. Pathabya bhūmivaḍḍhano means my son, having been a land-enhancer,

original: hutvā pathabyā nihato nūna. Rodantī paripucchi nanti taṃ rathaṃ ekamantaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: hutvā pathabyā nihataḥ nūna rodantī paripucchi nanti tam ratham ekamantam ṭhapetvā
translated: was surely killed on the ground. Weeping, asked means having stopped the chariot on one side,

original: mahātalaṃ abhiruyha candādeviṃ vanditvā ekamante ṭhitaṃ sārathiṃ paripucchi. Kinnūti
analyzed: mahā talam abhiruyha candā devim vanditvā eka mante ṭhitam sārathim paripucchi kinnu uti
translated: having ascended the great terrace, having worshipped Queen Candā, standing on one side, she asked the charioteer. Kinnū means what?

original: kiṃ nu so mama putto mūgo eva pakkho eva. Tadāti yadā naṃ tvaṃ kāsuyaṃ pakkhipitvā
analyzed: kim nu saḥ mama puttaḥ mūgaḥ eva pakkhaḥ eva tadā ati yadā nam tvam kāsuyam pakkhipitvā
translated: Was my son indeed dumb, indeed lame? Tadā means when you put him in a sack and

original: kuddālena matthake pahari, tadā. Nihaññamāno bhūmiyāti tayā bhūmiyaṃ nihaññamāno
analyzed: kuddālena matthake pahari tadā nihaññamānaḥ bhūmiyā ati tayā bhūmiyam nihaññamānaḥ
translated: When he was being killed on the ground,🔽why did he cry out? Tell me all that without leaving anything out.

original: kiṃ nu vilapi. Taṃ meti taṃ sabbaṃ aparihāpetvā me akkhāhi. Vivajjayīti “apehi sārathi,
analyzed: kim nu vilapi tam mā iti tam sabbam a parihāpetvā me akkhāhi vivajjayi iti apehi sārathi
translated: When he was being driven away,

original: mā maṃ mārehī”ti kathaṃ hatthehi pādehi ca phandanto taṃ apanudi, taṃ me kathehīti attho.
analyzed: mā mama mārehi iti katham hatthehi pādehi ca phandantaḥ tam apanudi tam me kathehi iti attho
translated: what did he do with his hands and feet? Tell me that.”

original: Tato sārathi āha –
analyzed: tatas sārathi āha
translated: Then the charioteer said:🔽“I will tell you, my lady,

original: “Akkheyyaṃ te ahaṃ ayye, dajjāsi abhayaṃ mama;
analyzed: akkheyyam te aham ayye dajjāsi abhayam mama
translated: if you will grant me immunity;🔽what I have heard or seen

original: Yaṃ me sutaṃ vā diṭṭhaṃ vā, rājaputtassa santike”ti.🔽Tattha dajjāsīti sace abhayaṃ dadeyyāsi, so idaṃ “sacāhaṃ ‘tava putto neva mūgo na🔽pakkho madhurakatho dhammakathiko’ti vakkhāmi, atha ‘kasmā taṃ gahetvā nāgatosī’ti
analyzed: yam me sutam vā diṭṭham vā rāja puttassa santike iti  tattha dajjāsi iti sace abhayam dadeyyāsi saḥ idam sacā aham tava putto na iva mūgaḥ na  pakkhaḥ madhura kathaḥ dhamma kathiko ti vakkhāmi atha kasmā tam gahetvā na āgataḥ asi iti
translated: in the presence of the prince.”

original: rājā kuddho rājadaṇḍampi me kareyya, abhayaṃ tāva yācissāmī”ti cintetvā āha.
analyzed: rājā kuddhaḥ rāja daṇḍam pi me kareyya abhayam tāva yācissāmi iti cintetvā āha
translated: There, if you will grant me immunity, he thought, “If I say, ‘Your son is neither dumb nor deaf, he is sweet-spoken and a preacher of the Dhamma,’ then the king, being angry, will punish me with the royal punishment, thinking, ‘Why did you bring him back?’ I will ask for immunity first.”

original: Atha naṃ candādevī āha –
analyzed: atha nam candādevī āha
translated: Then Queen Candā said:

original: “Abhayaṃ samma te dammi, abhīto bhaṇa sārathi;
analyzed: abhayam samma te dammi abhītaḥ bhaṇa sārathi
translated: “I grant you immunity, my good man;🔽be fearless, charioteer, and speak.

original: Yaṃ te sutaṃ vā diṭṭhaṃ vā, rājaputtassa santike”ti.
analyzed: yam te sutam vā diṭṭham vā rāja puttassa santike iti
translated: What you have heard or seen, in the presence of the prince.”

original: Tato sārathi āha –
analyzed: tatas sārathi āha
translated: Then the charioteer said:

original: “Na so mūgo na so pakkho, visaṭṭhavacano ca so;
analyzed: na saḥ mūgaḥ na saḥ pakkhaḥ visaṭṭha vacano ca so
translated: “He is not dumb, he is not deaf, he is not slow of speech;

original: Rajjassa kira so bhīto, akarā ālaye bahū.
analyzed: rajjassa kira saḥ bhītaḥ akarā ālaye bahū
translated: He is afraid of kingship, and has made many lairs.

original: “Purimaṃ sarati so jātiṃ, yattha rajjamakārayi;
analyzed: purimam sarati saḥ jātim yattha rajjam akārayi
translated: “He remembers his former birth, where he ruled as king;

original: Kārayitvā tahiṃ rajjaṃ, pāpattha nirayaṃ bhusaṃ.
analyzed: kārayitvā rajjam nirayam bhusam
translated: Having ruled there, he went to a terrible hell.

original: “Vīsatiñceva vassāni, tahiṃ rajjamakārayi;
analyzed: vīsatim ca iva vassāni tahim rajjam akārayi
translated: “He ruled there for twenty years,

original: Asītivassasahassāni, nirayamhi apacci so.
analyzed: asīti vassa sahassāni nirayamhi so
translated: and for eighty thousand years he cooked in hell.

original: “Tassa rajjassa so bhīto, mā maṃ rajjābhisecayuṃ;
analyzed: tassa rajjassa saḥ bhītaḥ mā mama rajjā abhisecayum
translated: “He is afraid of that kingship, lest they anoint me as king;

original: Tasmā pitu ca mātucca, santike na bhaṇī tadā.
analyzed: ca santike na tadā
translated: therefore he did not speak in the presence of his father and mother.

original: “Aṅgapaccaṅgasampanno, ārohapariṇāhavā;
analyzed: aṅga paccaṅga sampannaḥ āroha pariṇāhavā
translated: “Endowed with limbs and secondary limbs, with height and breadth,

original: Visaṭṭhavacano pañño, magge saggassa tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: visaṭṭha vacanaḥ paññaḥ magge saggassa tiṭṭhati
translated: with clear speech, wise, he stands on the path to heaven.

original: “Sace tvaṃ daṭṭhukāmāsi, rājaputtaṃ tavatrajaṃ;
analyzed: sace tvam daṭṭhu kāmā asi rāja puttam tavatrajam
translated: “If you wish to see the prince, your own son,

original: Ehi taṃ pāpayissāmi, yattha sammati temiyo”ti.
analyzed: ehi tam pāpayissāmi yattha sammati temiyā uti
translated: come, I will lead you to where the one who is to be anointed is.”

original: Tattha visaṭṭhavacanoti apalibuddhakatho. Akarā ālaye bahūti tumhākaṃ vañcanāni bahūni
analyzed: tattha visaṭṭha vacanā ti apalibuddha kathaḥ akarā ālaye bahu iti tumhākam vañcanāni bahūni
translated: Herein, the word “scattered” means “unrestricted talk.” “Many are the ways of cheating in the house” means that there are many ways of cheating you.

original: akāsi. Paññoti paññavā. Sace tvanti rājānaṃ dhuraṃ katvā ubhopi te evamāha. Yattha
analyzed: akāsi pañño ti paññavā sace tvanti rājānam dhuram katvā ubhau api te evam āha yattha
translated: “There is no need to talk much,” means: he did not want to talk much. “You have made many lairs,” means: you have made many deceptions.

original: sammati temiyoti yattha vo putto mayā gahitapaṭiñño hutvā acchati, tattha pāpayissāmi,
analyzed: sammati temiyo ti yattha vaḥ puttaḥ mayā gahita paṭiññaḥ hutvā acchati tattha pāpayissāmi
translated: “If you are wise,” means: if you are wise. “Where he will stay,” means: where your son will stay after he has accepted my terms, there I will take him.

original: idāni papañcaṃ akatvā lahuṃ gantuṃ vaṭṭatīti āha.
analyzed: idāni papañcam a katvā lahum gantum vaṭṭati iti āha
translated: Now, without making any fuss, it is proper to go quickly.

original: Kumāro pana sārathiṃ pesetvā pabbajitukāmo ahosi. Tadā sakko tassa manaṃ ñatvā tasmiṃ
analyzed: kumāraḥ pana sārathim pesetvā pabbajitu kāmo ahosi tadā sakko tassa manaṃ ñatvā tasmin
translated: But the prince wanted to go forth after sending the charioteer back. Then Sakka, having understood his mind,

original: khaṇe vissakammadevaputtaṃ pakkosāpetvā “tāta vissakammadevaputta, temiyakumāro pabbajitukāmo,
analyzed: khaṇe vissakammadeva puttam pakkosāpetvā tāta vissakammadeva putta temiya kumāraḥ pabbajitu kāmo
translated: summoned Vissakamma at that moment and said: “Dear Vissakamma, Prince Temiya wants to go forth,

original: tvaṃ tassa paṇṇasālañca pabbajitaparikkhārañca māpetvā ehī”ti pesesi. So “sādhū”ti
analyzed: tvam tassa paṇṇa sālañca pabbajita parikkhārañca māpetvā ehi iti pesesi saḥ sādhu iti
translated: you make a leaf-hut and the requisites for one who has gone forth and come.” He agreed, saying: “Very well,”

original: sampaṭicchitvā vegena gantvā tiyojanike vanasaṇḍe attano iddhibalena ramaṇīyaṃ assamaṃ
analyzed: sampaṭicchitvā vegena gantvā ti yojanike vana saṇḍe attanaḥ iddhi balena ramaṇīyam assamam
translated: and quickly went and in a forest-thicket three leagues long made a delightful hermitage by his own psychic power,

original: māpetvā rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānañca pokkharaṇiñca āvāṭañca akālaphalasampannaṃ rukkhañca
analyzed: māpetvā ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhānañca pokkharaṇiñca āvāṭañca akāla phala sampannam rukkhañca
translated: and had a tank and a well and a tree bearing fruit out of season made.

original: katvā paṇṇasālasamīpe catuvīsatihatthappamāṇaṃ caṅkamaṃ māpetvā antocaṅkame ca phalikavaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: katvā paṇṇasāla samīpe catuvīsati hattha ppamāṇam caṅkamam māpetvā antar caṅkame ca phalika vaṇṇam
translated: And he had a walk made near the leaf-hut, twenty-four cubits long, and in the walk he had sand of the colour of silver

original: ruciraṃ vālukaṃ okiritvā sabbe pabbajitaparikkhāre māpetvā “ye pabbajitukāmā, te🔽ime gahetvā pabbajantū”ti bhittiyaṃ akkharāni likhitvā caṇḍavāḷe ca amanāpasadde
analyzed: ruciram vālukam okiritvā sabbe pabbajita parikkhāre māpetvā ye pabbajitu kāmā te  ime gahetvā pabbajantu iti bhittiyam akkharāni likhitvā caṇḍa vāḷe ca amanāpa sadde
translated: strewn, and he had all the requisites for the homeless life made, and he wrote on the wall, “Let those who wish to go forth🔽take these and go forth,” and he drove away all the deer and birds with unpleasant sounds,

original: sabbe migapakkhino ca palāpetvā sakaṭṭhānameva gato.
analyzed: sabbe miga pakkhino ca palāpetvā saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ
translated: and went to his own place.

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe mahāsatto taṃ disvā sakkadattiyabhāvaṃ ñatvā, paṇṇasālaṃ pavisitvā vatthāni🔽apanetvā, rattavākacīraṃ nivāsetvā ekaṃ pārupitvā ajinacammaṃ ekaṃse katvā jaṭāmaṇḍalaṃ
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe mahāsatto tam disvā sakkadattiya bhāvam ñatvā paṇṇa sālam pavisitvā vatthāni  apanetvā rattavāka cīram nivāsetvā ekam ajina cammam eka aṃse katvā jaṭā maṇḍalam
translated: At that moment the Great Being, seeing this, knew that it was Sakka’s doing, and he entered the leaf-hut, and taking off his clothes,🔽he put on a red deer-skin, and made a tiger-skin his upper garment, and binding a circle of matted hair on his head,

original: bandhitvā kājaṃ aṃse katvā kattaradaṇḍamādāya paṇṇasālato nikkhamitvā pabbajitasiriṃ
analyzed: bandhitvā kājam aṃse katvā kattara daṇḍam ādāya paṇṇa sālataḥ nikkhamitvā pabbajita sirim
translated: and putting a water-pot on his shoulder, and taking a staff of Kattara wood, he went out of the leaf-hut, and taking the glory of the homeless life,

original: samubbahanto aparāparaṃ caṅkamitvā “aho sukhaṃ, aho sukha”nti udānaṃ udānento paṇṇasālaṃ
analyzed: samubbahantaḥ apara aparam caṅkamitvā aho sukham aho sukhanti udānam udānentaḥ paṇṇa sālam
translated: As he was walking up and down, he exclaimed, “Oh, what happiness! Oh, what happiness!” and then entered his leaf-hut.

original: pavisitvā kaṭṭhattharaṇe nisinno pañca abhiññā aṭṭha samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā sāyanhasamaye
analyzed: pavisitvā kaṭṭhattharaṇe nisinno pañca abhiññāḥ aṭṭha samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā sāyanha samaye
translated: There he sat down on a wooden bench and attained the five super-knowledges and the eight attainments.

original: paṇṇasālato nikkhamitvā caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ ṭhitakārarukkhato paṇṇāni gahetvā, sakkadattiyabhājane🔽aloṇake atakke nidhūpane udake sedetvā amataṃ viya paribhuñjitvā cattāro brahmavihāre
analyzed: paṇṇa sālataḥ nikkhamitvā caṅkamana koṭiyam ṭhita kāra rukkhataḥ paṇṇāni gahetvā sakkadattiya bhājane  a loṇake a takke nidhūpane udake sedetvā amatam viya paribhuñjitvā cattāraḥ brahmavihāre
translated: In the evening he came out of his leaf-hut, took some leaves from a tree standing on the edge of the walk,🔽and after washing them in a bowl which he had brought with him, and which contained water without any living creatures in it, and which was neither salted nor sour, he ate them as his supper.

original: bhāvetvā tattha vāsaṃ kappesi.
analyzed: bhāvetvā tattha vāsam kappesi
translated: Then he developed the four divine abodes, and remained there for the night.

original: Kāsirājāpi sunandasārathissa vacanaṃ sutvā mahāsenaguttaṃ pakkosāpetvā taramānarūpova gamanasajjaṃ kāretuṃ āha –
analyzed: kāsi rājā api sunanda sārathissa vacanam sutvā mahāsena guttam pakkosāpetvā taramāna rūpā uva gamana sajjam kāretum āha
translated: The king of Kāsi, having heard the words of Sunanda the charioteer, sent for Mahāsenagutta, and ordered him to make ready for a speedy departure, saying,

original: “Yojayantu rathe asse, kacchaṃ nāgāna bandhatha;
analyzed: yojayantu rathe asse kaccham nāgāna bandhatha
translated: “Yoke the horses to the chariot, and harness the elephants;

original: Udīrayantu saṅkhapaṇavā, vādantu ekapokkharā.
analyzed: udīrayantu saṅkha paṇavāḥ vādantu eka pokkharā
translated: Let the conches and the kettle-drums be blown and sounded; let the single-stringed lutes be played.

original: “Vādantu bherī sannaddhā, vaggū vādantu dundubhī;
analyzed: vādantu bherī sannaddhā vaggū vādantu dundubhī
translated: “Let the drums be beaten, let the cymbals be played;

original: Negamā ca maṃ anventu, gacchaṃ puttanivedako.
analyzed: negamā ca mam anventu gaccham putta nivedako
translated: Let the people follow me as I go to announce my son.

original: “Orodhā ca kumārā ca, vesiyānā ca brāhmaṇā;
analyzed: orodhā ca kumārā ca vesiyānā ca brāhmaṇā
translated: the courtesans and brahmans,

original: Khippaṃ yānāni yojentu, gacchaṃ puttanivedako.
analyzed: khippam yānāni yojentu gaccham putta nivedako
translated: quickly harness the chariots, for I am going to announce my son.

original: “Hatthārohā anīkaṭṭhā, rathikā pattikārakā;
analyzed: hattha ārohā anīkaṭṭhā rathikā patti kārakā
translated: “Let the elephant-riders, the cavalry, the charioteers, and the infantry,

original: Khippaṃ yānāni yojentu, gacchaṃ puttanivedako.
analyzed: khippam yānāni yojentu gaccham putta nivedako
translated: quickly harness the chariots, for I am going to announce my son.

original: “Samāgatā jānapadā, negamā ca samāgatā;
analyzed: samāgatāḥ jānapadāḥ negamā ca samāgatā
translated: “Let the people from the provinces and the people from the towns,

original: Khippaṃ yānāni yojentu, gacchaṃ puttanivedako”ti.
analyzed: khippam yānāni yojentu gaccham putta nivedakā iti
translated: quickly harness the chariots, for I am going to announce my son.”

original: Tattha udīrayantūti saddaṃ muñcantu. Vādantūti vajjantu. Ekapokkharāti ekamukhabheriyo.🔽Sannaddhāti suṭṭhu naddhā. Vaggūti madhurassarā. Gacchanti gamissāmi. Puttanivedakoti
analyzed: tattha udīrayantu iti saddam muñcantu vādantu iti vajjantu eka pokkharāti eka mukha bheriyo  sannaddhā ati suṭṭhu naddhā madhurassarā gacchanti gamissāmi putta nivedakā ti
translated: Herein, let them make a sound means let them make a noise. Let them play means let them make music. Single-headed drum means a single-faced drum.

original: puttassa nivedako ovādako hutvā gacchāmi. Taṃ ovaditvā mama vacanaṃ gāhāpetvā tattheva
analyzed: puttassa nivedakaḥ ovādakaḥ hutvā gacchāmi tam ovaditvā mama vacanam gāhāpetvā tattha iva
translated: Well-equipped means well-harnessed. Fine means sweet-sounding. I am going means I am going. To announce my son means I am going as one who announces my son, as one who instructs him. Having instructed him and made him accept my words, I am going to place him right there

original: taṃ ratanarāsimhi ṭhapetvā abhisiñcitvā ānetuṃ gacchāmīti adhippāyenevamāha. Negamāti
analyzed: tam ratana rāsimhi ṭhapetvā abhisiñcitvā ānetum gacchāmi iti adhippāyena ivam āha negama ati
translated: in the jewel-heap and consecrate him. The meaning is that I am going to bring him back. People from the towns means

original: kuṭumbikajanā. Samāgatāti sannipatitā hutvā.
analyzed: kuṭumbika janā samāgatā ati sannipatitā hutvā
translated: householders. Having assembled means having gathered together.

original: Evaṃ raññā āṇattā sārathino asse yojetvā rathe rājadvāre ṭhapetvā rañño ārocesuṃ. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: evam raññā āṇattā sārathinaḥ asse yojetvā rathe rājadvāre ṭhapetvā raññaḥ ārocesuṃ tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: At the king’s command the charioteers harnessed the horses, placed the chariot at the palace gate, and informed the king. Expounding the matter, the Master said:

original: “Asse ca sārathī yutte, sindhave sīghavāhane;
analyzed: asse ca sārathī yutte sindhave sīgha vāhane
translated: “The charioteers harnessed the horses, the fleet-foot steeds,

original: Rājadvāraṃ upāgacchuṃ, yuttā deva ime hayā”ti.🔽Tattha asseti sindhave sindhavajātike sīghavāhane javasampanne asse ādāya. Sārathīti
analyzed: rājadvāram upāgacchum yuttāḥ devaḥ ime  tattha assa iti sindhave sindhava jātike sīgha vāhane java sampanne asse ādāya sārathī iti
translated: And came to the palace gate, saying, ‘Your majesty, the horses are harnessed.’“

original: sārathino. Yutteti rathesu yojite. Upāgacchunti te rathesu yutte asse ādāya āgamaṃsu,
analyzed: sārathinaḥ yutta iti rathesu yojite upāgacchunti te rathesu yutte asse ādāya āgamaṃsu
translated: Herein, the charioteers, taking the horses, the fleet-foot steeds, the fleet-foot steeds of the Sindhu breed, the fleet-foot steeds endowed with speed, came to the palace gate, saying, “Your majesty, the horses are harnessed.”

original: āgantvā ca pana “yuttā, deva, ime hayā”ti ārocesuṃ.
analyzed: āgantvā ca pana yuttāḥ deva ime hayāti ārocesuṃ
translated: Having come, they informed the king, saying, “Your majesty, the horses are harnessed.”

original: Tato sārathīnaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā rājā upaḍḍhagāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas sārathīnam vacanam sutvā rājā upaḍḍha gātham āha
translated: Then, having heard the charioteers’ words, the king spoke the first half of the stanza:

original: “Thūlā javena hāyanti, kisā hāyanti thāmunā”ti.
analyzed: thūlāḥ javena hāyanti kisāḥ hāyanti
translated: “The fat horses lose by speed, the lean horses lose by endurance.”

original: Taṃ sutvā sārathinopi upaḍḍhagāthamāhaṃsu –
analyzed: tam sutvā sārathinaḥ api upaḍḍha gātham āhaṃsu
translated: Having heard that, the charioteers spoke the second half of the stanza:

original: “Kise thūle vivajjetvā, saṃsaṭṭhā yojitā hayā”ti.
analyzed: kise thūle vivajjetvā saṃsaṭṭhā yojitā

translated: “Hatthānīkaṃ rathānīkaṃ, asse pattī ca vammino;

translated: So he had a carriage prepared, placed her therein, and sent her home, saying, “Go, my dear, and tell my mother and father that I have a younger sister and that they must perform all the ceremonies necessary for her.”

original: Te gantvā brāhmaṇiyā kathesuṃ. Atha naṃ brāhmaṇīpi uṇhodakena nhāpetvā sayanaṃ paññāpetvā
analyzed: te gantvā brāhmaṇiyā kathesuṃ atha nam brāhmaṇī pi uṇha udakena nhāpetvā sayanam paññāpetvā
translated: They went and told the Brahman. Then the Brahman’s wife had her bathed with warm water, prepared a couch for her, and said to her, “My dear, you must not be angry with your brother.

original: nipajjāpesi. Atha brāhmaṇopi nhātvā āgato bhojanakāle “bhaginiṃ me pakkosathā”ti
analyzed: nipajjāpesi atha brāhmaṇaḥ api nhātvā āgataḥ bhojana kāle bhaginim me pakkosatha ati
translated: and had her bathe and lie down. Then the brāhmaṇa, after bathing, came back, and at meal-time said: “Call my sister.”

original: pakkosāpetvā tāya saddhiṃ ekato bhuñjitvā antonivesaneyeva taṃ paṭijaggi.
analyzed: pakkosāpetvā tāya saddhim ekatas bhuñjitvā antar nivesanā iya iva tam paṭijaggi
translated: After calling her, he ate with her, and he looked after her in the inner quarters.

original: Sā na cirasseva suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ puttaṃ vijāyi, “mahājanakakumāro”tissa ayyakasantakaṃ🔽nāmamakāsi. So vaḍḍhamāno dārakehi saddhiṃ kīḷanto ye taṃ rosenti, te asambhinnakhattiyakule
analyzed: sā na cirassa iva suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam puttam vijāyi mahājanaka kumārotissa ayyaka santakam  nāmam akāsi saḥ vaḍḍhamānaḥ dārakehi saddhim kīḍantaḥ ye tam rosenti te asambhinna khattiya kule
translated: She, not long after, gave birth to a son of golden complexion, and her brother gave him the name Mahājanaka.🔽He, growing up, playing with the boys, if they were angry with him, because he was born in a pure royal family,

original: jātattā mahābalavatāya ceva mānathaddhatāya ca daḷhaṃ gahetvā paharati. Tadā te mahāsaddena
analyzed: jāta ttā mahā balavatāya ca iva ca daḷham gahetvā paharati tadā te mahā saddena
translated: he, because of his great strength and his pride, seized them firmly and beat them. Then they, crying with a great noise,

original: rodantā “kena pahaṭā”ti vutte “vidhavāputtenā”ti vadanti. Atha kumāro cintesi “ime
analyzed: rodantā kena pahaṭā iti vutte vidhavā puttena ati vadanti atha kumāraḥ cintesi ime
translated: said: “By whom were we beaten?” When it was said: “By the son of the widow,” they said: “The son of the widow.” Then the prince thought: “These people

original: maṃ ‘vidhavāputto’ti abhiṇhaṃ vadanti, hotu, mama mātaraṃ pucchissāmī”ti. So ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: mam vidhavā putto ti abhiṇham vadanti hotu mama mātaram pucchissāmi iti saḥ eka divasam
translated: say: ‘The son of the widow’ again and again, well, I will ask my mother.” He, one day,

original: mātaraṃ pucchi “amma, ko mayhaṃ pitā”ti? Atha naṃ mātā “tāta, brāhmaṇo te pitā”ti
analyzed: mātaram pucchi amma kaḥ mayham pitā ati atha nam mātā tāta brāhmaṇaḥ te pitā ati
translated: asked his mother: “Mother, who is my father?” Then his mother said: “Dear, the brāhmaṇa is your father.”

original: vañcesi. So punadivasepi dārake paharanto “vidhavāputto”ti vutte “nanu brāhmaṇo me🔽pitā”ti vatvā “brāhmaṇo kiṃ te hotī”ti vutte cintesi “ime maṃ, brāhmaṇo te kiṃ hotī’ti🔽abhiṇhaṃ vadanti, mātā me idaṃ kāraṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ na kathesi, sā attano manena me🔽na kathessati, hotu, kathāpessāmi na”nti. So thaññaṃ pivanto thanaṃ dantehi ḍaṃsitvā
analyzed: vañcesi saḥ puna divase pi dārake paharantaḥ vidhavā putto ti vutte nanu brāhmaṇaḥ me  pitā ati vatvā brāhmaṇaḥ kim te hoti iti vutte cintesi ime mama brāhmaṇaḥ te kim hoti iti  abhiṇham vadanti mātā me idam kāraṇam yathābhūtam na kathesi sā me  na kathessati hotu kathāpessāmi nanti saḥ thaññam pivantaḥ thanam dantehi ḍaṃsitvā
translated: and he deceived them. The next day, when he was again being beaten, he said, “My father is a brahman.”🔽“What does a brahman matter to you?”🔽He thought, “They keep on asking me, ‘What does a brahman matter to you?’ My mother did not tell them the truth about my father. She will not tell them out of her own will. Well, I will make them ask.”🔽While he was drinking milk, he bit his lip with his teeth and pretended to be in pain.

original: “amma, me pitaraṃ kathehi, sace na kathessasi, thanaṃ te chindissāmī”ti āha. Sā puttaṃ🔽vañcetuṃ asakkontī “tāta, tvaṃ mithilāyaṃ ariṭṭhajanakarañño putto, pitā te polajanakena
analyzed: amma me pitaram kathehi sace na kathessasi thanam te chindissāmi iti āha sā puttam  vañcetum a sakkontī tāta tvam mithilāyam ariṭṭhajanakarañño putto pitā te polajanakena
translated: and he deceived him. The next day, when the man struck him, he said, “You are the son of a widow.” “But my father is a brahmin.” “What does it matter to you that he is a brahmin?” At this he thought, “They keep asking me, ‘What does it matter to you that he is a brahmin?’ My mother has not told me the truth about this matter. She will not tell me of her own accord. Well, I will make her tell me.” Sucking his finger, he bit it with his teeth and said, “Mother, tell me about my father. If you do not, I will break off your finger.”

original: mārito, ahaṃ taṃ anurakkhantī imaṃ nagaraṃ āgatā, ayaṃ brāhmaṇo maṃ bhaginiṭṭhāne🔽ṭhapetvā paṭijaggatī”ti kathesi. So taṃ sutvā tato paṭṭhāya “vidhavāputto”ti vuttepi na kujjhi.
analyzed: māritaḥ aham tam anurakkhantī imam nagaram āgatā ayam brāhmaṇaḥ mam bhaginiṭṭhāne 🔽ṭhapetvā paṭijaggati iti kathesi saḥ tam sutvā tatas paṭṭhāya vidhavā putto ti vutte pi na kujjhi
translated: Unable to deceive her son any longer, she said, “Dear, you are the son of King Ariṭṭha of Mithilā. Your father was killed by King Pola. I came to this city to protect you. This brahmin has taken me as his sister and supports me.” When he heard this, he no longer became angry when he was called “the son of a widow.”

original: So soḷasavassabbhantareyeva tayo vede ca sabbasippāni ca uggaṇhi, soḷasavassikakāle
analyzed: saḥ tayaḥ vede ca sabba sippāni ca uggaṇhi soḷasa vassika kāle
translated: In less than sixteen years he had mastered the three Vedas and all the sciences. When he was sixteen years old,

original: pana uttamarūpadharo ahosi. Atha so “pitu santakaṃ rajjaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti cintetvā
analyzed: pana uttama rūpa dharaḥ ahosi atha saḥ pitu santakam rajjam gaṇhissāmi iti cintetvā
translated: he was a young man of the most perfect beauty. Then he thought to himself, “I will take over the kingdom that is my father’s.”

original: mātaraṃ pucchi “amma, kiñci dhanaṃ te hatthe atthi, udāhu no, ahaṃ vohāraṃ katvā
analyzed: mātaram pucchi amma kiñci dhanam te hatthe atthi udāhu no aham vohāram katvā
translated: He asked his mother, “Mother, have you any money, or have you none? If I have any, I will take it and make a fortune with it;

original: dhanaṃ uppādetvā pitu santakaṃ rajjaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti. Atha naṃ mātā āha – “tāta, nāhaṃ
analyzed: dhanam uppādetvā pitu santakam rajjam gaṇhissāmi iti atha nam mātā āha tāta na aham
translated: if I have none, I will take over the kingdom that is my father’s.” His mother replied, “Son, I did not come here empty-handed;

original: tucchahatthā āgatā, tayo me hatthe dhanasārā atthi, muttasāro, maṇisāro, vajirasāroti,
analyzed: tuccha hatthā āgatā tayaḥ me hatthe dhana sārāḥ atthi muttasāraḥ maṇisāraḥ vajirasāraḥ ti
translated: I have three treasures in my keeping, a treasure of pearls, a treasure of gems, and a treasure of cat’s eyes,

original: tesu ekeko rajjaggahaṇappamāṇo, taṃ gahetvā rajjaṃ gaṇha, mā vohāraṃ karī”ti. “Amma,
analyzed: tesu ekekaḥ rajja ggahaṇa ppamāṇo tam gahetvā rajjam gaṇha mā vohāram kari iti amma
translated: each of which is sufficient to take over the kingdom. Take them and take over the kingdom; do not make a fortune.” “Mother,

original: idampi dhanaṃ mayhameva upaḍḍhaṃ katvā dehi, taṃ pana gahetvā suvaṇṇabhūmiṃ gantvā
analyzed: idam pi dhanam mayham eva upaḍḍham katvā dehi tam pana gahetvā suvaṇṇa bhūmim gantvā
translated: give me half of this treasure, and I will take it and go to Suvaṇṇabhūmi and make a fortune there;

original: bahuṃ dhanaṃ āharitvā rajjaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti. So upaḍḍhaṃ āharāpetvā bhaṇḍikaṃ katvā
analyzed: bahum dhanam āharitvā rajjam gaṇhissāmi iti saḥ upaḍḍham āhara apetvā bhaṇḍikam katvā
translated: then I will take over the kingdom.” He had half of the treasure brought to him, and having it packed in a bundle,

original: suvaṇṇabhūmiṃ gamikehi vāṇijehi saddhiṃ nāvāya bhaṇḍaṃ āropetvā puna nivattitvā mātaraṃ🔽vanditvā “amma, ahaṃ suvaṇṇabhūmiṃ gamissāmī”ti āha. Atha naṃ mātā āha – “tāta, samuddo
analyzed: suvaṇṇa bhūmim gamikehi vāṇijehi saddhim nāvāya bhaṇḍam āropetvā puna nivattitvā mātaram  vanditvā amma aham suvaṇṇa bhūmim gamissāmi iti āha atha nam mātā āha tāta samuddaḥ
translated: and he took his goods and went on board a ship with some merchants who were bound for Suvaṇṇabhūmi. When he had returned, he saluted his mother,

original: nāma appasiddhiko bahuantarāyo, mā gaccha, rajjaggahaṇāya te dhanaṃ bahū”ti. So “gacchissāmeva
analyzed: nāma appasiddhikaḥ bahu antarāyaḥ mā gaccha rajja ggahaṇāya te dhanam bahu iti saḥ gacchissāma eva
translated: and said to her, “Mother, I am going to Suvaṇṇabhūmi.” His mother said to him, “My son, the ocean is a place of ill omen, full of many dangers; do not go. I have much wealth; take it and engage in trade here.” He replied, “I will go, mother,

original: ammā”ti mātaraṃ vanditvā gehā nikkhamma nāvaṃ abhiruhi.🔽Taṃ divasameva polajanakassa sarīre rogo uppajji, anuṭṭhānaseyyaṃ sayi. Tadā satta🔽jaṅghasatāni nāvaṃ abhiruhiṃsu. Nāvā sattadivasehi satta yojanasatāni gatā. Sā aticaṇḍavegena🔽gantvā attānaṃ vahituṃ nāsakkhi, phalakāni bhinnāni, tato tato udakaṃ uggataṃ, nāvā
analyzed: ammā ati mātaram vanditvā gehā nikkhamma nāvam abhiruhi  tam divasam eva polajanakassa sarīre rogaḥ uppajji anuṭṭhāna seyyam tadā satta  jaṅgha satāni nāvam nāvā satta divasehi satta yojana satāni gatā sā ati caṇḍa vegena  gantvā attānam vahitum na asakkhi phalakāni bhinnāni tatas tatas udakam uggatam nāvā
translated: and after saluting his mother, he left the house and went on board the ship.

original: samuddamajjhe nimuggā. Mahājanā rodanti paridevanti, nānādevatāyo namassanti. Mahāsatto
analyzed: samudda majjhe nimuggāḥ mahā janāḥ rodanti paridevanti nānā devatāyaḥ namassanti mahāsatto
translated: On that very day a disease broke out in the body of Polajanaka, and he lay down on his bed and took to his rest. At that time seven hundred men went on board the ship. The ship went seven hundred leagues in seven days. It went with such violent speed that it could not be controlled. The planks were broken, the water came in from all sides, and the ship sank in the middle of the ocean. The people cried and lamented, and worshipped various deities. The Great Being

original: pana neva rodati na paridevati, na devatāyo namassati, nāvāya pana nimujjanabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pana nā iva rodati na paridevati na devatāyaḥ namassati nāvāya pana nimujjana bhāvam
translated: but he neither wept nor lamented, nor did he pray to the gods. But knowing that the ship was sinking,

original: ñatvā sappinā sakkharaṃ omadditvā kucchipūraṃ khāditvā dve maṭṭhakasāṭake telena
analyzed: ñatvā sappinā sakkharam omadditvā kucchi pūram khāditvā dve maṭṭhaka sāṭake telena
translated: he took some sugar-cane, moistened it with ghee, and ate it till his belly was full. Then he soaked two coarse garments in oil,

original: temetvā daḷhaṃ nivāsetvā kūpakaṃ nissāya ṭhito nāvāya nimujjanasamaye kūpakaṃ abhiruhi.
analyzed: temetvā daḷham nivāsetvā kūpakam nissāya ṭhitaḥ nāvāya nimujjana samaye kūpakam
translated: put them on, and stood by the side of the ship. When the ship sank, he climbed up on the mast.

original: Mahājanā macchakacchapabhakkhā jātā, samantā udakaṃ aḍḍhūsabhamattaṃ lohitaṃ ahosi.
analyzed: mahā janāḥ maccha kacchapa bhakkhāḥ jātā samantā udakam aḍḍhūsabha mattam lohitam ahosi
translated: The people, having become food for the fishes and alligators, the water all around was knee-deep in blood.

original: Mahāsatto kūpakamatthake ṭhitova “imāya nāma disāya mithilanagara”nti disaṃ vavatthapetvā🔽kūpakamatthakā uppatitvā macchakacchape atikkamma mahābalavatāya usabhamatthake pati.
analyzed: mahāsatto kūpaka matthake imāya nāma disāya mithila nagaranti disam  kūpaka matthakā uppatitvā maccha kacchape atikkamma mahā balavatāya usabha matthake pati
translated: The Great Being, standing on the mast, determined the direction, saying: “In this direction is the city of Mithilā.”🔽Then he jumped from the mast, and passing over the fishes and alligators, by reason of his great strength he fell on the back of a bull.

original: Taṃ divasameva polajanako kālamakāsi. Tato paṭṭhāya mahāsatto maṇivaṇṇāsu ūmīsu parivattanto
analyzed: tam divasam eva polajanakaḥ kālam akāsi tatas paṭṭhāya mahāsattaḥ maṇi vaṇṇāsu ūmīsu parivattanto
translated: On that very day the owner of the bull died. From that time the Great Being, turning round in the waves, which were of the colour of jewels,

original: suvaṇṇakkhandho viya samuddaṃ tarati. So yathā ekadivasaṃ, evaṃ sattāhaṃ tarati,
analyzed: suvaṇṇa kkhandhaḥ viya samuddam tarati saḥ yathā eka divasam evam sattāham tarati
translated: crossed the ocean as if he were a golden column. As he crossed in one day, so he crossed in seven days,

original: “idāni puṇṇamīdivaso”ti velaṃ pana oloketvā loṇodakena mukhaṃ vikkhāletvā uposathiko hoti.🔽Tadā ca “ye mātupaṭṭhānādiguṇayuttā samudde marituṃ ananucchavikā sattā, te uddhārehī”ti
analyzed: idāni puṇṇamī divasaḥ ti velam pana oloketvā loṇa udakena mukham vikkhāletvā uposathikaḥ hoti  tadā ca ye mātu paṭṭhāna ādi guṇa yuttā samudde maritum an anucchavikā sattā te uddhārehi iti
translated: “To-day is the day of the full moon,” and looking at the time, he washed his mouth with salt water, and became a Uposathika.

original: catūhi lokapālehi maṇimekhalā nāma devadhītā samuddarakkhikā ṭhapitā hoti. Sā satta
analyzed: catūhi lokapālehi maṇimekhalā nāma deva dhītā samudda rakkhikā ṭhapitā hoti sā satta
translated: And then the four Lokapalas, the guardians of the world, appointed a celestial maiden named Manimekhalā to be the guardian of the sea, saying, “Take out of the sea those beings who are not worthy to die in the sea, such as those who are devoted to the care of their mothers, and so on.”

original: divasāni samuddaṃ na olokesi, dibbasampattiṃ anubhavantiyā kirassā sati pamuṭṭhā.
analyzed: divasāni samuddam na olokesi dibba sampattim anubhavantiyā kirassā sati pamuṭṭhā
translated: For seven days she did not look at the sea, and it is said that her mind was bewildered by the enjoyment of her heavenly glory.

original: “Devasamāgamaṃ gatā”tipi vadanti. Atha sā “ajja me sattamo divaso samuddaṃ anolokentiyā,
analyzed: deva samāgamam vadanti atha sā ajja me sattamaḥ divaso samuddam anolokentiyā
translated: They say that she went to a meeting of the gods. Then she thought, “To-day is the seventh day that I have not looked at the sea.

original: kā nu kho pavattī”ti olokentī mahāsattaṃ disvā “sace mahājanakakumāro samudde nassissa,
analyzed: kā nu kho pavatti iti olokentī mahāsattam disvā sace mahājanaka kumāraḥ samudde nassissa
translated: What is going on there?” Looking, she saw the Great Being, and thought, “If Prince Mahājanaka is lost in the sea,

original: devasamāgamapavesanaṃ na labhissa”nti cintetvā mahāsattassa avidūre alaṅkatena sarīrena
analyzed: deva samāgama pavesanam na labhissanti cintetvā mahāsattassa avidūre alaṅkatena sarīrena
translated: he will not be admitted to the meeting of the gods.” So she stood in the air not far from the Great Being, her body adorned with ornaments,

original: ākāse ṭhatvā mahāsattaṃ vīmaṃsamānā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ākāse ṭhatvā mahāsattam vīmaṃsamānā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and looking at him, she spoke the first stanza:—

original: “Koyaṃ majjhe samuddasmiṃ, apassaṃ tīramāyuhe;
analyzed: koyam majjhe samuddasmin apassam tīram āyuhe
translated: “Who is this in the midst of the sea, not seeing the shore, yet striving?

original: Kaṃ tvaṃ atthavasaṃ ñatvā, evaṃ vāyamase bhusa”nti.
analyzed: kam tvam atthavasam ñatvā evam vā āyamase bhusanti
translated: What is the reason that you know, that you thus strive so mightily?”

original: Tattha apassaṃ tīramāyuheti tīraṃ apassantova āyūhati vīriyaṃ karoti.
analyzed: tattha a passam tīram āyuheti tīram a passantaḥ uva āyūhati vīriyam karoti
translated: Herein, not seeing the shore, yet striving means: not seeing the shore, yet striving, exerting energy.

original: Atha mahāsatto tassā vacanaṃ sutvā “ajja me sattamo divaso samuddaṃ tarantassa, na me dutiyo satto diṭṭhapubbo, ko nu maṃ vadatī”ti ākāsaṃ olokento taṃ disvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha mahāsatto tassāḥ vacanam sutvā ajja me sattamaḥ divasaḥ samuddam tarantassa na me dutiyaḥ satto diṭṭha pubbo kaḥ nu mama vadati iti ākāsam olokento tam disvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being, having heard her words, thought: “Today is the seventh day of my crossing the sea. I have not seen a second being. Who is speaking to me?” Looking up into the sky, he saw her and spoke the second stanza:

original: “Nisamma vattaṃ lokassa, vāyāmassa ca devate;
analyzed: nisamma vattam lokassa vāyāmassa ca devate
translated: “Having considered the conduct of the world, and the advantage of striving, O Goddess,

original: Tasmā majjhe samuddasmiṃ, apassaṃ tīramāyuhe”ti.
analyzed: tasmai majjhe samuddasmin apassam tīram āyuheti
translated: Therefore, in the midst of the sea, not seeing the shore, I strive.”

original: Tattha nisamma vattaṃ lokassāti ahaṃ lokassa vattakiriyaṃ disvā upadhāretvā viharāmīti
analyzed: tattha nisamma vattam lokassa ati aham lokassa vatta kiriyam disvā upadhāretvā viharāmi iti
translated: Herein, having considered the conduct of the world means: I live, having considered, having reflected upon, the performance of the duties of the world.

original: attho. Vāyāmassa cāti vāyāmassa ca ānisaṃsaṃ nisāmetvā viharāmīti dīpeti. Tasmāti
analyzed: atthaḥ vāyāmassa ca ati vāyāmassa ca ānisaṃsam nisāmetvā viharāmi iti dīpeti tasmā iti
translated: This is the meaning. And the advantage of striving means: having considered, having reflected upon, the advantage of striving, I live. Thus he shows. Therefore,

original: yasmā nisamma viharāmi, “purisakāro nāma na nassati, sukhe patiṭṭhāpetī”ti jānāmi,
analyzed: yasmai nisamma viharāmi purisakāraḥ nāma na nassati sukhe patiṭṭhāpeti iti jānāmi
translated: because I live, having considered, I know: “The manly effort is not lost, it establishes one in happiness.”

original: tasmā tīraṃ apassantopi āyūhāmi vīriyaṃ karomi, na ukkaṇṭhāmīti.
analyzed: tasmā tīram a passantaḥ api āyūhāmi vīriyam karomi na ukkaṇṭhāmi iti
translated: Therefore, though I see no shore, I strive, I exert myself, I do not despair.”

original: Sā tassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā uttari sotukāmā hutvā puna gāthamāha –
analyzed: sā tassa dhamma katham sutvā uttari sotu kāmā hutvā puna gātham āha
translated: Having heard this discourse on the Law, the goddess, desirous of hearing more, spoke this verse:

original: “Gambhīre appameyyasmiṃ, tīraṃ yassa na dissati;
analyzed: gambhīre appameyyasmim tīram yassa na dissati
translated: “In the deep, immeasurable sea, whose shore is not to be seen,

original: Mogho te purisavāyāmo, appatvāva marissasī”ti.
analyzed: moghaḥ te purisa vāyāmaḥ a patvā ava marissasi iti
translated: Thy human effort will be vain; thou shalt die without having reached the shore.”

original: Tattha appatvāti tīraṃ appatvāyeva.
analyzed: tattha appatvā ti tīram appatvāya iva
translated: Herein, without having reached the shore means without having reached the shore.

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto “devate, kiṃ nāmetaṃ kathesi, vāyāmaṃ katvā marantopi garahato muccissāmī”ti vatvā gāthamāha –

analyzed: tesam paccuggamana ṭṭhāne nidhinā bhavitabbanti tatas rājā tesu paccekabuddhesu
translated: Therefore there must be treasure in the place where they rise.” So the king asked, “When those Private Buddhas

analyzed: āgacchantesu paccuggamanam karonto kataram ṭhānam gacchati iti pucchitvā asuka ṭṭhānam
translated: come, in what place do you go forth to meet them?”🔽“In such and such a place, your majesty.”

original: nāma devā”ti vutte “taṃ ṭhānaṃ khaṇitvā nidhiṃ nīharathā”ti nidhiṃ nīharāpesi. “Gamanakāle🔽anugacchanto kattha ṭhatvā uyyojesī”ti pucchitvā “asukaṭṭhāne nāmā”ti vutte “tatopi
analyzed: nāma deva iti vutte tam ṭhānam khaṇitvā nidhim nīharatha ati nidhim gamana kāle  anugacchantaḥ kattha ṭhatvā uyyojesi iti pucchitvā asuka ṭṭhāne nāma ati vutte tatas pi
translated: “Dig up that place and bring out the treasure.” So saying, he caused the treasure to be brought out.🔽“When they go away, in what place do you see them off?”🔽“In such and such a place, your majesty.”

analyzed: nidhi iti vutta ttā sūriya atthaṅgamana disā ayam khaṇantāḥ vicariṃsu idam pana dhanam  idha iva hoti aho acchariyanti pīti somanassam pavattayiṃsu antonidhi iti rāja gehe

analyzed: ekatas amacca maṇḍalam ekatas brāhmaṇa gaṇo ekatas seṭṭhi ādayaḥ nisīdiṃsu  ekatas uttama rūpa dharāḥ nāṭakitthiyaḥ nisīdiṃsu brāhmaṇāḥ api sotthi kārena mukha maṅgalikāni

analyzed: kathenti nacca gīta ādīsu kusalāḥ nacca gīta ādīni aneka satāni tūriyāni

translated: Then the royal palace resounded with a great noise, like the ocean when it is violently agitated by the Yugandhara wind.

original: Olokitolokitaṭṭhānaṃ kampati.
analyzed: olokita ulokita ṭṭhānam kampati
translated: Every place that was looked at trembled.

original: Atha mahāsatto setacchattassa heṭṭhā rājāsane nisinnova sakkasirisadisaṃ mahantaṃ
analyzed: atha mahāsatto setacchattassa heṭṭhā rāja āsane nisinnaḥ uva sakka siri sadisam mahantam
translated: Then the Great Being, sitting on the royal throne under the white parasol, beholding the great pomp and splendour like the glory of Sakka,

analyzed: sirivilāsam oloketvā attanaḥ mahā samudde kata vāyāmam anussari tassa vīriyam nāma
translated: recollected his exertions in the great ocean. He thought: “Vigour, indeed, is the root of all prosperity.

original: kattabbayuttakaṃ, sacāhaṃ mahāsamudde vīriyaṃ nākarissaṃ, na imaṃ sampattiṃ alabhissa”nti
analyzed: kattabba yuttakam sacā aham mahā samudde vīriyam na akarissam na imam sampattim a labhissanti
translated: ‘If I had not exerted myself in the great ocean, I should not have gained this good fortune.’

original: taṃ vāyāmaṃ anussarantassa pīti uppajji. So pītivegena udānaṃ udānento āha –
analyzed: tam vāyāmam anussarantassa pīti uppajji saḥ pīti vegena udānam udānentaḥ āha
translated: As he thus recalled his efforts, joy sprang up in him. And as he was filled with joy, he uttered this verse of joy:

original: “Āsīsetheva puriso, na nibbindeyya paṇḍito;
analyzed: āsīsetha iva purisaḥ na nibbindeyya paṇḍitaḥ
translated: ‘A man should strive, not yield to dejection;

original: Passāmi vohaṃ attānaṃ, yathā icchiṃ tathā ahu.
analyzed: passāmi voham attānam yathā icchim tathā ahu
translated: I see myself as I wished to be.

original: “Āsīsetheva puriso, na nibbindeyya paṇḍito;
analyzed: āsīsetha iva purisaḥ na nibbindeyya paṇḍitaḥ
translated: ‘A man should strive, not yield to dejection;

original: Passāmi vohaṃ attānaṃ, udakā thalamubbhataṃ.
analyzed: passāmi vo ham attānam udakā thalam ubbhatam
translated: I see myself as I am, risen from the water.

original: “Vāyametheva puriso, na nibbindeyya paṇḍito;
analyzed: vāyametha iva purisaḥ na nibbindeyya paṇḍitaḥ
translated: ‘A man should strive, not yield to dejection;

original: Passāmi vohaṃ attānaṃ, yathā icchiṃ tathā ahu.
analyzed: passāmi voham attānam yathā icchim tathā ahu
translated: I see myself as I wished to be.

original: “Vāyametheva puriso, na nibbindeyya paṇḍito;

translated: ‘A man should strive, not yield to dejection;

original: Passāmi vohaṃ attānaṃ, udakā thalamubbhataṃ.
analyzed: passāmi vo ham attānam udakā thalam ubbhatam
translated: I see myself as I am, risen from the water.

original: “Dukkhūpanītopi naro sapañño, āsaṃ na chindeyya sukhāgamāya;
analyzed: dukkha upanītaḥ api naraḥ sa paññaḥ āsam na chindeyya sukha āgamāya
translated: ‘Even if a wise man’s path is hard, he should not abandon hope of attaining happiness.

original: Bahū hi phassā ahitā hitā ca, avitakkitā maccumupabbajanti.
analyzed: bahū hi phassāḥ ahitā hitā ca a vitakkitāḥ maccum upabbajanti
translated: For many contacts, good and bad, come to one who does not give up hope.

original: “Acintitampi bhavati, cintitampi vinassati;
analyzed: a cintitam pi bhavati cintitam pi vinassati
translated: ‘What is not thought of comes to pass,🔽and what one thinks of perishes.

original: Na hi cintāmayā bhogā, itthiyā purisassa vā”ti.🔽Tattha āsīsethevāti āsāchedakammaṃ akatvā attano kammaṃ āsaṃ karotheva. Na nibbindeyyāti
analyzed: na hi cintā mayāḥ bhogāḥ itthiyā purisassa vāti  tattha āsīsetha iva ati āsā cheda kammam a katvā attano kammam āsam karotha iva na nibbindeyya ati
translated: For neither women nor men have wealth that comes from thinking.

original: vīriyaṃ karonto na nibbindeyya na alaseyya. Yathā icchinti yathā rājabhāvaṃ icchiṃ,
analyzed: vīriyam karontaḥ na nibbindeyya na alaseyya yathā yathā rāja bhāvam icchim
translated: Herein, he should not despair: he should not despair, should not be lazy, while doing the work. As he wishes: as he wishes for the state of a king.

original: tatheva rājā jātomhi. Ubbhatanti nīhaṭaṃ. Dukkhūpanītoti kāyikacetasikadukkhena phuṭṭhopīti
analyzed: tathā iva rājā jātaḥ amhi ubbhata nti nīhaṭam dukkha upanītaḥ ti kāyika cetasika dukkhena phuṭṭhaḥ api iti
translated: Just so: just as he is born a king. Taken: carried off. Afflicted with pain: touched by bodily and mental pain, is the meaning.

original: attho. Ahitā hitā cāti dukkhaphassā ahitā, sukhaphassā hitā. Avitakkitāti avitakkitāro🔽acintitāro. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – tesu phassesu ahitaphassena phuṭṭhā sattā “hitaphassopi
analyzed: atthaḥ ahitā hitā ca ati dukkha phassā ahitā sukha phassā hitā avitakkitā ati avitakkitāro  acintitāro idam vuttam hoti tesu phassesu ahita phassena phuṭṭhāḥ sattāḥ hita phassaḥ api
translated: Unbeneficial and beneficial: painful contact is unbeneficial, pleasant contact is beneficial. Not considering: not considering.

original: atthīti vīriyaṃ karontā taṃ pāpuṇantī”ti acintetvā vīriyaṃ na karonti, te imassa
analyzed: atthi iti vīriyam karontā tam pāpuṇanti iti a cintetvā vīriyam na karonti te imassa
translated: The meaning is that, not considering thus ‘Beings touched by unbeneficial contact who do the work and make an effort reach the beneficial,’ they do not make an effort.

original: atthassa avitakkitāro hitaphassaṃ alabhitvāva maccumupabbajanti maraṇaṃ pāpuṇanti,
analyzed: atthassa a vitakkitāraḥ hita phassam a labhitvā ava maccum upabbajanti maraṇam pāpuṇanti
translated: They do not consider this meaning. Without reaching the beneficial, they go forth to death, they reach death.

original: tasmā vīriyaṃ kattabbamevāti.
analyzed: tasmai vīriyam kattabbam eva ati
translated: Therefore the work should be done.

original: Acintitampīti imesaṃ sattānaṃ acintitampi hoti, cintitampi vinassati. Mayāpi hi “ayujjhitvāva🔽rajjaṃ labhissāmī”ti idaṃ acintitaṃ, “suvaṇṇabhūmito dhanaṃ āharitvā yujjhitvā pitu
analyzed: a cintitam pi iti imesam sattānam a cintitam pi hoti cintitam pi vinassati mayā api hi a yujjhitvā ava  rajjam labhissāmi iti idam a cintitam suvaṇṇabhūmitaḥ dhanam āharitvā yujjhitvā
translated: “Even what is not thought of”: even what is not thought of by these beings comes to be; and what is thought of is destroyed. For even what I thought of, namely, “Without fighting I will get the kingdom,” did not come to be; and what I did not think of, namely, “Having brought wealth from the golden land, having fought, my father will be killed and I will get the kingdom,” came to be.

original: santakaṃ rajjaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti pana cintitaṃ, idāni me cintitaṃ naṭṭhaṃ, acintitaṃ🔽jātaṃ. Na hi cintāmayā bhogāti imesaṃ sattānañhi bhogā cintāya anipphajjanato cintāmayā
analyzed: santakam rajjam gaṇhissāmi iti pana cintitam idāni me cintitam naṭṭham a cintitam  jātam na hi cintā mayāḥ bhogā ati imesam sattānam hi bhogā cintāya a nipphajjanataḥ cintā mayāḥ
translated: What is not thought of will happen: what is not thought of will happen to these beings, and what is thought of will be destroyed. For I thought: “I will get the kingdom without fighting.” But what I thought of, namely, “I will get the kingdom by fighting after bringing wealth from the Golden Land,” has been destroyed, and what I did not think of has happened.

original: nāma na honti, tasmā vīriyameva kattabbaṃ. Vīriyavato hi acintitampi hotīti.
analyzed: nāma na honti tasmā vīriyam eva kattabbam vīriyavataḥ hi a cintitam pi hoti iti
translated: Wealth is not born of thought: for these beings wealth is not born of thought, since it is not produced by thinking. Therefore one must make an effort. For what is not thought of will happen to one who makes an effort.

original: So tato paṭṭhāya dasa rājadhamme akopetvā dhammena samena rajjaṃ kāresi, paccekabuddhe
analyzed: so tatas paṭṭhāya dasa rājadhamme a kopetvā dhammena samena rajjam kāresi paccekabuddhe
translated: From that time on, he ruled righteously, without violating the ten royal virtues, and he served the paccekabuddhas.

original: ca upaṭṭhāsi. Aparabhāge sīvalidevī dhaññapuññalakkhaṇasampannaṃ puttaṃ vijāyi, “dīghāvukumāro”tissa
analyzed: ca upaṭṭhāsi aparabhāge sīvali devī dhañña puñña lakkhaṇa sampannam puttam vijāyi dīghāvu kumārotissa
translated: Later Queen Sivali gave birth to a son who had the auspicious marks of merit. They gave him the name Prince Dīghāvu.

original: nāmaṃ kariṃsu. Tassa vayappattassa rājā uparajjaṃ datvā sattavassasahassāni rajjaṃ
analyzed: nāmam kariṃsu tassa vayappattassa rājā uparajjam da tvā satta vassa sahassāni rajjam
translated: When he grew up, the king gave him the position of crown prince and ruled for seven thousand years.

original: kāresi. So ekadivasaṃ uyyānapālena phalāphalesu ceva nānāpupphesu ca ābhatesu tāni
analyzed: kāresi saḥ eka divasam uyyāna pālena phalāphalesu ca iva nānā pupphesu ca tāni
translated: and he had it well-tended. One day, when the gardener had gathered the various fruits and flowers,

original: disvā tuṭṭho hutvā tassa sammānaṃ kāretvā “samma uyyānapāla, ahaṃ uyyānaṃ passissāmi,
analyzed: disvā tuṭṭhaḥ hutvā tassa sammānam kāretvā samma uyyāna pāla aham uyyānam passissāmi
translated: he was pleased with the beauty of the garden, and he gave the gardener a reward, saying, “My good gardener, I am going to see the garden.

original: tvaṃ alaṅkarohi na”nti āha. So “sādhu, devā”ti sampaṭicchitvā tathā katvā rañño paṭivedesi.
analyzed: tvam alaṅkarohi nanti āha saḥ sādhu deva ati sampaṭicchitvā tathā katvā raññaḥ paṭivedesi
translated: Make it ready for me.” The gardener replied, “Very well, your majesty,” and he did as he was told, and then informed the king.

original: So hatthikkhandhavaragato mahantena parivārena nagarā nikkhamitvā uyyānadvāraṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: saḥ hatthi kkhandha vara gataḥ mahantena parivārena nagarā nikkhamitvā uyyāna dvāram pāpuṇi
translated: The king mounted his elephant and, accompanied by a great retinue, left the city and reached the gate of the garden.

original: Tatra ca dve ambā atthi nīlobhāsā. Eko aphalo, eko phaladharo. So pana atimadhuro,
analyzed: tatra ca dve ambā atthi ekaḥ aphalaḥ ekaḥ phaladharo so pana ati madhuraḥ
translated: There were two mango trees, one of which was bearing fruit, the other not. The fruit of the tree that was bearing was very sweet,

original: raññā aggaphalassa aparibhuttattā tato koci phalaṃ gahetuṃ na ussahati. Rājā hatthikkhandhavaragatova
analyzed: raññā agga phalassa a paribhutta ttā tatas koci phalam gahetum na ussahati rājā hatthi kkhandha vara gataḥ iva
translated: but no one dared to pick any, because the king had not yet tasted the fruit. The king, riding on his elephant,

original: tato ekaṃ phalaṃ gahetvā paribhuñji, tassa taṃ jivhagge ṭhapitamattameva dibbojaṃ
analyzed: tatas ekam phalam gahetvā paribhuñji tassa tam jivhagge ṭhapita mattam eva dibbojam
translated: picked a mango and ate it. The moment it touched his tongue,

original: viya upaṭṭhāsi. So “nivattanakāle bahū khādissāmī”ti cintesi. “Raññā aggaphalaṃ paribhutta”nti🔽ñatvā uparājānaṃ ādiṃ katvā antamaso hatthimeṇḍaassameṇḍādayopi phalaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjiṃsu.
analyzed: viya upaṭṭhāsi so nivattana kāle bahū khādissāmi iti cintesi raññā agga phalam paribhuttanti  ñatvā uparājānam ādim katvā antamasaḥ hatthi meṇḍa assa meṇḍa ādayaḥ api phalam gahetvā paribhuñjiṃsu
translated: and it was as though it were waiting on him. He thought, “When I return, I shall eat a lot of fruit.”🔽Knowing that the king had eaten the best fruit, the princes began to eat it, and in the end even the grooms and keepers of the elephants and horses took fruit and ate it.

original: Aññe phalaṃ alabhantā daṇḍehi sākhaṃ bhinditvā nipaṇṇamakaṃsu. Rukkho obhaggavibhaggo
analyzed: aññe phalam a labhantā daṇḍehi sākham bhinditvā nipaṇṇam akaṃsu rukkhaḥ obhagga vibhaggaḥ
translated: Others, not getting any fruit, broke off the branches with their sticks and trampled the fallen fruit. The tree was broken and torn

original: aṭṭhāsi, itaro pana maṇipabbato viya vilāsamāno ṭhito.🔽Rājā uyyānā nikkhanto taṃ disvā “idaṃ ki”nti amacce pucchati. “Devena aggaphalaṃ🔽paribhuttanti mahājanena vilumpito devā”ti āhaṃsu. “Kiṃ nu kho bhaṇe, imassa pana
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi itaraḥ pana maṇi pabbataḥ viya vilāsamānaḥ ṭhitaḥ  rājā uyyānā nikkhantaḥ tam disvā idam kinti amacce pucchati devena agga phalam  mahājanena vilumpitaḥ devāti āhaṃsu kim nu kho bhaṇe imassa pana
translated: and stood as though it were split in two. But the other tree stood shining like a mountain of gems.🔽When the king came out of the garden, he saw it and asked his ministers, “What is this?” “Your Majesty, the tree was stripped by the people because Your Majesty ate the best fruit.”

original: neva pattaṃ, na vaṇṇo khīṇo”ti? “Nipphalatāya na khīṇo, devā”ti. Taṃ sutvā rājā saṃvegaṃ
analyzed: na iva pattam na vaṇṇaḥ khīṇaḥ ati nipphala tāya na khīṇaḥ deva ati tam sutvā rājā saṃvegam
translated: “What is this, my good men? Is it that the tree has not lost its leaves and its color?” “It has not lost them because it has no fruit, Your Majesty.” Hearing this, the king was deeply moved.

original: paṭilabhitvā “ayaṃ rukkho nipphalatāya nīlobhāso ṭhito, ayaṃ pana saphalatāya obhaggavibhaggo
analyzed: paṭilabhitvā ayam rukkhaḥ nipphala tāya nīla ubhāsaḥ ṭhitaḥ ayam pana sa phala tāya obhagga vibhaggaḥ
translated: “This tree stands with a dark color because it has no fruit, but this other tree is broken and torn because it has fruit.

original: ṭhito. Idampi rajjaṃ saphalarukkhasadisaṃ, pabbajjā pana nipphalarukkhasadisā. Sakiñcanasseva
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ idam pi rajjam sa phala rukkha sadisam pabbajjā pana nipphala rukkha sadisā sa kiñcanassa iva
translated: I am still young. This kingdom is like a tree bearing fruit; the life of a monk is like a tree bearing no fruit.

original: bhayaṃ, nākiñcanassa. Tasmā ahaṃ phalarukkho viya ahutvā nipphalarukkhasadiso bhavissāmi,
analyzed: bhayam na akiñcanassa tasmai aham phala rukkhaḥ viya a hutvā nipphala rukkha sadisaḥ bhavissāmi
translated: Only he who has something to lose has fear; he who has nothing to lose has no fear. Therefore I will not be like a tree bearing fruit, but will be like a tree bearing no fruit.

original: imaṃ sampattiṃ cajitvā nikkhamma pabbajissāmī”ti daḷhaṃ samādānaṃ katvā manaṃ adhiṭṭhahitvā🔽nagaraṃ pavisitvā pāsādadvāre ṭhitova senāpatiṃ pakkosāpetvā “mahāsenāpati, ajja🔽me paṭṭhāya bhattahārakañceva mukhodakadantakaṭṭhadāyakañca ekaṃ upaṭṭhākaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: imam sampattim cajitvā nikkhamma pabbajissāmi iti daḷham samādānam katvā manaṃ adhiṭṭhahitvā  nagaram pavisitvā pāsāda dvāre ṭhitaḥ uva senāpatim pakkosāpetvā mahā senāpati ajja  me paṭṭhāya bhatta hārakam ca iva mukha udaka danta kaṭṭha dāyakam ca ekam upaṭṭhākam ṭhapetvā
translated: I will renounce this glory and go forth into the homeless state.” Having made this firm resolve, he set his heart on it,🔽and entering the city, he stood at the palace gate and sent for the commander-in-chief. “General,” said he, “from this day forth let no one see me except the one who brings me my food and the one who gives me water to wash my face and my tooth-cleaner.

original: aññe maṃ daṭṭhuṃ mā labhantu, porāṇakavinicchayāmacce gahetvā rajjaṃ anusāsatha,
analyzed: aññe mam daṭṭhum mā labhantu porāṇaka vinicchayā amacce gahetvā rajjam anusāsatha
translated: Take the old judges and rule the kingdom.

original: ahaṃ ito paṭṭhāya uparipāsādatale samaṇadhammaṃ karissāmī”ti vatvā pāsādamāruyha
analyzed: aham itas paṭṭhāya upari pāsāda tale samaṇa dhammam karissāmi iti vatvā pāsādam āruyha
translated: From this day forth I will practice the religion of the monks on the upper terrace of the palace.” So saying, he ascended the palace and🔽practiced the religion of the monks all alone.

original: ekakova samaṇadhammaṃ akāsi. Evaṃ gate kāle mahājano rājaṅgaṇe sannipatitvā mahāsattaṃ
analyzed: ekakaḥ iva samaṇa dhammam akāsi evam gate kāle mahā janaḥ rājaṅgaṇe sannipatitvā mahāsattam
translated: After the lapse of some time the people assembled in the royal court and said to the king,

original: adisvā “na no rājā porāṇako viya hotī”ti vatvā gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: na naḥ rājā porāṇakaḥ viya hoti iti vatvā gāthā dvayam āha
translated: Not seeing him, they said, “Our king is not as he used to be,” and they spoke this verse:

original: “Aporāṇaṃ vata bho rājā, sabbabhummo disampati;
analyzed: aporāṇam vata bho rājā sabba bhummaḥ
translated: “The king is not as he used to be, the lord of all the land and sea;

analyzed: najja nacce nisāma iti na gīte kurute manaḥ
translated: He does not now enjoy the dance, nor does he take delight in song.

original: “Na mige napi uyyāne, napi haṃse udikkhati;
analyzed: na mige napi uyyāne napi haṃse udikkhati
translated: “He does not look at deer or parks, nor does he look at swans;

original: Mūgova tuṇhimāsīno, na atthamanusāsatī”ti.🔽Tattha migeti sabbasaṅgāhikavacanaṃ, pubbe hatthī yujjhāpeti, meṇḍe yujjhāpeti, ajja🔽tepi na oloketīti attho. Uyyāneti uyyānakīḷampi nānubhoti. Haṃseti pañcapadumasañchannāsu
analyzed: mūgaḥ uva tuṇhim āsīnaḥ na attham anusāsati iti  tattha miga iti sabba saṅgāhika vacanam pubbe hatthī yujjhāpeti meṇḍe yujjhāpeti ajja  te pi na oloketi iti attho uyyāna iti uyyāna kīḷam pi na anubhoti haṃsa iti pañca paduma sañchannāsu
translated: Like one who is dumb, he sits in silence, and does not give advice.”

original: uyyānapokkharaṇīsu haṃsagaṇaṃ na oloketi. Mūgovāti bhattahārakañca upaṭṭhākañca pucchiṃsu
analyzed: uyyāna pokkharaṇīsu haṃsa gaṇam na oloketi mūga uvāti bhatta hārakam ca upaṭṭhākam ca pucchiṃsu
translated: Here, “deer” is a word that includes all; formerly he used to yoke elephants and horses, but today he does not even look at them. “Parks” means he does not enjoy playing in the parks. “Swans” means he does not look at the flock of swans in the park ponds covered with five lotuses. “Like one who is dumb” means they asked the food server and the attendant,

original: “bho rājā, tumhehi saddhiṃ kiñci atthaṃ mantetī”ti. Te “na mantetī”ti vadiṃsu. Tasmā evamāhaṃsu.
analyzed: bho rājā tumhehi saddhim kiñci attham manteti iti te na mantā iti iti vadiṃsu tasmai evam āhaṃsu
translated: “Sir, does the king consult with you about any matter?” They said, “He does not consult,” so they said this.

original: Rājā kāmesu anallīyantena vivekaninnena cittena attano kulūpakapaccekabuddhe anussaritvā
analyzed: rājā kāmesu viveka ninnena cittena attano kulūpaka paccekabuddhe anussaritvā
translated: The king, with a mind inclined to seclusion, not delighting in sensual pleasures, remembered the paccekabuddhas who were his dependents,

analyzed: kaḥ nu kho me tesam sīla ādi guṇa yuttānam akiñcanānam vasanaṭṭhānam ācikkhissati iti

translated: and he uttered three stanzas of rejoicing:

analyzed: sukha kāmā rahosīlā vadha bandhā upāratā
translated: “They who desire happiness, who are of secret virtue, who are free from killing and binding,

analyzed: dhīrāḥ namaḥ tesam mahesinam
translated: “They who have passed beyond the forest, the wise, to them be homage, the great seers,

translated: Who in this world that is full of toil, live in ease.
