analyzed: te chetvā maccunaḥ jālam tatam māyāvinaḥ daḷham
translated: “They who have cut the net of Death, the strong net of the wily one,

analyzed: gacchanti kaḥ tesam gatim āpaya iti
translated: Having cut the bonds of the house, they go away: who will lead them to their goal?”

analyzed: tattha pahīna taṇhāḥ mahesinanti mahante sīlakkhandha ādayaḥ guṇe

analyzed: tassa pāsādeya iva samaṇa dhammam karontassa cattāro māsāḥ atītāḥ athassa ativiya pabbajjāya
translated: Tassa pāsādeyeva samaṇadhammaṃ karontassa cattāro māsā atītā. Athassa ativiya pabbajjāya🔽cittaṃ nami, agāraṃ lokantarikanirayo viya khāyi, tayo bhavā ādittā viya upaṭṭhahiṃsu.

analyzed: so pabbajja abhimukhena cittena kadā nu kho imam sakka bhavanam viya alaṅkata paṭiyattam

original: Atha mahāsatto “devi, kiṃ kathesi, yesaṃ kiñcanaṃ atthi, tesaṃ taṃ ḍayhati, mayaṃ pana akiñcanā”ti dīpento gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha mahāsattaḥ devi kim kathesi yesam kiñcanam atthi tesam tam ḍayhati mayam pana akiñcana ati dīpentaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being, in order to show that he was speaking the truth, saying, ‘What are you saying, Queen? Those who have wealth, their wealth is burning. But we are without wealth,’ spoke this verse:

original: “Susukhaṃ vata jīvāma, yesaṃ no natthi kiñcanaṃ;
analyzed: su sukham vata jīvāma yesam no natthi kiñcanam
translated: ‘Oh, how happily we live, we who have nothing at all!

original: Mithilā ḍayhamānāya, na me kiñci aḍayhathā”ti.
analyzed: mithilā ḍayhamānāya na me kiñci aḍayhathāti
translated: Though Mithilā is burning, nothing of mine is burning.’

original: Tattha kiñcananti yesaṃ amhākaṃ palibuddhakilesasaṅkhātaṃ kiñcanaṃ natthi, te mayaṃ
analyzed: tattha kiñcananti yesam amhākam palibuddha kilesa saṅkhātam kiñcanam na atthi te mayam
translated: Herein, nothing at all means we who have nothing at all called the defilements, the hindrances.🔽We live happily indeed because of that state of having nothing at all. For that reason,

original: tena akiñcanabhāvena susukhaṃ vata jīvāma. Teneva kāraṇena mithilāya ḍayhamānāya
analyzed: tena akiñcana bhāvena su sukham vata jīvāma tena iva kāraṇena mithilāya ḍayhamānāya
translated: though Mithilā is burning,

original: na me kiñci aḍayhatha, appamattakampi attano bhaṇḍakaṃ ḍayhamānaṃ na passāmīti vadati.
analyzed: na me kiñci a ḍayhatha appamattakam pi attanaḥ bhaṇḍakam ḍayhamānam na passāmi iti vadati
translated: “I see nothing burning, not even a small piece of my own property.”

original: Evañca pana vatvā mahāsatto uttaradvārena nikkhami. Tāpissa sattasatā bhariyā nikkhamiṃsu.
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā mahāsatto uttara dvārena nikkhami tā api satta satā bhariyāḥ nikkhamiṃsu
translated: Having said this, the Great Being went out by the northern gate, and his seven hundred wives went out with him.

original: Puna sīvalidevī ekaṃ upāyaṃ cintetvā “gāmaghātaraṭṭhavilumpanākāraṃ viya dassethā”ti
analyzed: puna sīvali devī ekam upāyam cintetvā gāma ghāta raṭṭha vilumpana ākāram viya dassetha ati
translated: Then Queen Sirima thought of a plan, and said, “Act as if you were plundering the kingdom and destroying the villages.”

original: amacce āṇāpesi. Taṃkhaṇaṃyeva āvudhahatthe purise tato tato ādhāvante paridhāvante
analyzed: amacce āṇāpesi taṃ khaṇaṃyā iva āvudha hatthe purise tatas tatas ādhāvante paridhāvante
translated: And she ordered the ministers to do so. Immediately men with weapons came running hither and thither,

original: vilumpante viya sarīre lākhārasaṃ siñcitvā laddhappahāre viya phalake nipajjāpetvā🔽vuyhante mate viya ca rañño dassesuṃ. Mahājano upakkosi “mahārāja, tumhesu dharantesuyeva
analyzed: vilumpante viya sarīre lākhā rasam siñcitvā laddha pahāre viya phalake  vuyhante mate viya ca raññaḥ dassesum mahā janaḥ upakkosi mahā rāja tumhesu dharantesu yeva
translated: plundering and destroying. They sprinkled red dye over their bodies, and then laid them out on planks as if they had been beaten,🔽and carried them about as if they were dead, and showed them to the king. The multitude cried out, “Great king, while you are ruling,

original: raṭṭhaṃ vilumpanti, mahājanaṃ ghātentī”ti. Atha devīpi rājānaṃ vanditvā nivattanatthāya gāthamāha –
analyzed: raṭṭham vilumpanti mahājanam ghātenti iti atha rājānam vanditvā nivattana tthāya gātham āha
translated: they are plundering the kingdom and destroying the people.” Then the queen also paid obeisance to the king, and in order to turn him back, she spoke this verse:

original: “Aṭaviyo samuppannā, raṭṭhaṃ viddhaṃsayanti taṃ;
analyzed: aṭaviyaḥ samuppannāḥ raṭṭham viddhaṃsayanti tam
translated: “The forest-bands have arisen, and are destroying the kingdom.

original: Ehi rāja nivattassu, mā raṭṭhaṃ vinasā ida”nti.
analyzed: ehi rāja nivattassu mā raṭṭham vinasā idanti
translated: Come, King, turn back, lest thou destroy the realm.

original: Tattha aṭaviyoti mahārāja, tumhesu dharantesuyeva aṭavicorā samuppannā samuṭṭhitā, taṃ tayā dhammarakkhitaṃ tava raṭṭhaṃ viddhaṃsenti.
analyzed: tattha aṭaviyā iti mahā rāja tumhesu aṭavi corā samuppannā samuṭṭhitā tam tayā dhamma rakkhitam tava raṭṭham viddhaṃsenti
translated: Herein, ‘forest’ means that while thou art ruling, forest brigands have arisen and are plundering thy realm which thou hast protected righteously.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “mayi dharanteyeva corā uṭṭhāya raṭṭhaṃ viddhaṃsentā nāma natthi, sīvalideviyā kiriyā esā bhavissatī”ti cintetvā taṃ appaṭibhānaṃ karonto āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā mayi dharanteyā iva corāḥ uṭṭhāya raṭṭham viddhaṃsentā nāma natthi sīvalideviyā kiriyā esā bhavissati iti cintetvā tam appaṭibhānam karontaḥ āha
translated: Hearing this, the king thought, ‘While I am ruling, brigands have not arisen and are not plundering the realm. This must be the work of Queen Sivani,’ and he said this to her, making light of her:

original: “Susukhaṃ vata jīvāma, yesaṃ no natthi kiñcanaṃ;
analyzed: su sukham vata jīvāma yesam no natthi kiñcanam
translated: ‘How happy we are, we who have nothing!

original: Raṭṭhe vilumpamānamhi, na me kiñci ahīratha.
analyzed: raṭṭhe vilumpamānamhi na me kiñci
translated: While the realm is being plundered, nothing of ours is taken.

original: “Susukhaṃ vata jīvāma, yesaṃ no natthi kiñcanaṃ;
analyzed: su sukham vata jīvāma yesam no natthi kiñcanam
translated: ‘How happy we are, we who have nothing!

original: Pītibhakkhā bhavissāma, devā ābhassarā yathā”ti.
analyzed: pīti bhakkhāḥ bhavissāma devāḥ ābhassarāḥ yathā ati
translated: We shall live on joy, like the Ābhassara gods.’

original: Tattha vilumpamānamhīti viluppamāne. Ābhassarā yathāti yathā te brahmāno pītibhakkhā hutvā samāpattisukhena vītināmenti, tathā vītināmessāmāti.
analyzed: tattha vilumpamānamhi iti viluppamāne ābhassarāḥ yathā ati yathā te brahmānaḥ pīti bhakkhāḥ hutvā samāpatti sukhena vītināmenti tathā vītināmessāma ati
translated: Herein, ‘while the realm is being plundered’ means while it is being plundered. ‘Like the Ābhassara gods’ means as they live on joy and spend their time in the happiness of attainment, so shall we spend our time.

original: Evaṃ vuttepi mahājano rājānaṃ anubandhiyeva. Athassa etadahosi “ayaṃ mahājano nivattituṃ
analyzed: evam vutte pi mahā janaḥ rājānam anubandhiyā iva atha assa etat ahosi ayam mahā janaḥ nivattitum
translated: But the people still followed him. Then he thought, “This crowd will not turn back.

original: na icchati, nivattessāmi na”nti. So aḍḍhagāvutamattaṃ gatakāle nivattitvā mahāmagge
analyzed: na icchati nivattessāmi saḥ gata kāle nivattitvā mahā magge
translated: But the people still followed him. Then he thought, “These people will not turn back. I will turn back myself.” He went a half-league and then turned back.🔽Standing on the main road, he asked his ministers, “Whose kingdom is this?”

original: ṭhitova amacce “kassidaṃ rajja”nti pucchitvā “tumhākaṃ, devā”ti vutte “tena hi imaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ uva amacce kassa idam rajjanti pucchitvā tumhākam deva ati vutte tena hi imaṃ
translated: “Yours, your majesty.”

original: lekhaṃ antaraṃ karontassa rājadaṇḍaṃ karothā”ti kattaradaṇḍena tiriyaṃ lekhaṃ ākaḍḍhi.
analyzed: lekham antaram karontassa rāja daṇḍam karotha ati kattara daṇḍena tiriyam lekham ākaḍḍhi
translated: “Then punish anyone who violates this decree.” And he drew a line across the ground with his sword.

original: Tena tejavatā raññā kataṃ lekhaṃ koci antaraṃ kātuṃ nāsakkhi. Mahājano lekhaṃ ussīsake
analyzed: tena tejavatā raññā katam lekham koci antaram kātum na asakkhi mahā janaḥ lekham ussīsake
translated: No one dared violate the line drawn by the powerful king. The people put the line on their heads

original: katvā bāḷhaparidevaṃ paridevi. Devīpi taṃ lekhaṃ antaraṃ kātuṃ asakkontī rājānaṃ
analyzed: katvā bāḷha paridevam paridevi tam lekham antaram kātum a sakkontī rājānam
translated: and wailed bitterly. The queen, too, was unable to violate the line.

original: piṭṭhiṃ datvā gacchantaṃ disvā sokaṃ sandhāretuṃ asakkontī uraṃ paharitvā mahāmagge
analyzed: piṭṭhim da tvā gacchantam disvā sokam sandhāretum a sakkontī uram paharitvā mahā magge
translated: As she followed the king, giving him her back, she saw him going away. Unable to bear the grief, she beat her breast and fell

original: tiriyaṃ patitvā parivattamānā agamāsi. Mahājano “lekhasāmikehi lekhā bhinnā”ti vatvā
analyzed: tiriyam patitvā parivattamānā agamāsi mahā janaḥ lekha sāmikehi lekhā bhinnā iti vatvā
translated: to the ground on her face and rolled back and forth. The people said, “The line has been violated by the owners of the line.”

original: deviyā gatamaggeneva gato. Atha mahāsattopi uttarahimavantābhimukho agamāsi. Devīpi
analyzed: deviyāḥ gata maggena iva gataḥ atha mahāsattaḥ api uttara himavanta abhimukhaḥ devī pi
translated: and followed the Queen’s path. Then the Great Being also went towards the Northern Himalayas, and the Queen

original: sabbaṃ senāvāhanaṃ ādāya tena saddhiṃyeva gatā. Rājā mahājanaṃ nivattetuṃ asakkontoyeva
analyzed: sabbam senāvāhanam ādāya tena saddhim yā iva gatāḥ rājā mahājanam nivattetum a sakkontaḥ yā iva
translated: taking all the army and vehicles went with him. The King, unable to turn back the great multitude,

original: saṭṭhiyojanamaggaṃ gato.
analyzed: saṭṭhi yojana maggam gataḥ
translated: went along the sixty leagues of the road.

original: Tadā nārado nāma tāpaso himavante suvaṇṇaguhāyaṃ vasitvā pañcābhiñño jhānasukhena
analyzed: tadā nāradaḥ nāma tāpasaḥ himavante suvaṇṇaguhāyam vasitvā pañca abhiññaḥ jhāna sukhena
translated: At that time a certain ascetic named Nārada, who dwelt in a golden cave in the Himalayas, who was endowed with the five super-knowledges,

original: vītināmetvā sattāhaṃ atikkāmetvā jhānasukhato vuṭṭhāya “aho sukhaṃ, aho sukha”nti
analyzed: vītināmetvā sattāham atikkāmetvā jhāna sukhataḥ vuṭṭhāya aho sukham aho sukhanti
translated: having spent seven days in the bliss of meditation, after the lapse of seven days, having emerged from the bliss of meditation, uttered a cry of joy, saying: “Oh, what bliss! Oh, what bliss!”

original: udānaṃ udānesi. So “atthi nu kho koci jambudīpatale idaṃ sukhaṃ pariyesanto”ti dibbacakkhunā🔽olokento mahājanakabuddhaṅkuraṃ disvā “rājā mahābhinikkhamanaṃ nikkhantopi sīvalidevippamukhaṃ
analyzed: udānam udānesi saḥ atthi nu kho koci jambudīpa tale idam sukham pariyesanto ti dibba cakkhunā  olokentaḥ mahā janaka buddha aṅkuram disvā rājā mahā abhinikkhamanam nikkhantaḥ api sīvali devi ppamukham
translated: He, looking with his divine eye, (thinking): “Is there anyone on the surface of the earth who is seeking this bliss?”🔽seeing the great multitude with Queen Sīvalī at the head, (thought): “The King, although he has gone forth on a great renunciation, is not able to turn back the great multitude,

original: mahājanaṃ nivattetuṃ na sakkoti, antarāyampissa kareyya, idāni gantvā bhiyyoso mattāya
analyzed: mahājanam nivattetum na sakkoti antarāyam pi sa kareyya idāni gantvā bhiyyosaḥ mattāya
translated: he will make an obstacle for him, now having gone, I will make an obstacle for him, and having made an obstacle for him, I will go to the Himālaya.”

original: daḷhasamādānatthaṃ ovādaṃ dassāmī”ti cintetvā iddhibalena gantvā rañño purato ākāse
analyzed: daḷha samādāna attham ovādam dassāmi iti cintetvā iddhi balena gantvā rañño puratas ākāse
translated: “I will give him advice to strengthen his resolve.” So he went by his psychic power and stood in the air in front of the king.

original: ṭhitova tassa ussāhaṃ janetuṃ imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ uva tassa ussāham janetum imam gātham āha
translated: Then he spoke this verse to arouse his enthusiasm:

original: “Kimheso mahato ghoso, kā nu gāmeva kīḷiyā;
analyzed: kimhesaḥ mahataḥ ghosaḥ kā nu gāma iva kīḍiyā
translated: “What is this great noise? What is the game in the village?

original: Samaṇa teva pucchāma, kattheso abhisaṭo jano”ti.
analyzed: samaṇa tā iva pucchāma katthā isaḥ abhisaṭaḥ janoti
translated: We ask you, recluse, why this crowd is so excited?”

original: Tassa taṃ sutvā rājā āha –
analyzed: tassa tam sutvā rājā āha
translated: When the king heard it, he said:

original: “Mamaṃ ohāya gacchantaṃ, ettheso abhisaṭo jano;
analyzed: mamam ohāya gacchantam etthā isaḥ abhisaṭaḥ janaḥ
translated: “This crowd is so excited because I am going away,

original: Sīmātikkamanaṃ yantaṃ, munimonassa pattiyā;
analyzed: sīmātikkamanam yantam munimonassa pattiyā
translated: Crossing the border, to attain the sage’s state.

original: Missaṃ nandīhi gacchantaṃ, kiṃ jānamanupucchasī”ti.
analyzed: missam nandīhi gacchantam kim jānam anupucchasi iti
translated: I am going with Nandī, so why do you ask?”

original: Tattha kimhesoti kimhi kena kāraṇena eso hatthikāyādivasena mahato samūhassa ghoso.
analyzed: tattha kimhi iso ti kimhi kena kāraṇena eso hatthi kāya ādi vasena mahato samūhassa ghoso
translated: Herein, what is this great noise? For what reason is there this noise of a great crowd consisting of an army of elephants and so on?

original: Kā nu gāmeva kīḷiyāti kā nu esā tayā saddhiṃ āgacchantānaṃ gāme viya kīḷi. Katthesoti
analyzed: kā nu gāma iva kīḷiyā ati kā nu esā tayā saddhim āgacchantānam gāme viya kīḷi katthesi uti
translated: What is the game in the village? What is this that is going along with you as though it were a game in the village? Why is this crowd so excited?

original: kimatthaṃ esa mahājano abhisaṭo sannipatito, taṃ parivāretvā āgacchatīti pucchi.
analyzed: kimattham esa mahā janaḥ abhisaṭaḥ sannipatito tam parivāretvā āgacchati iti pucchi
translated: Why is this great crowd assembled and coming along surrounding it?

original: Mamanti yo ahaṃ etaṃ janaṃ ohāya gacchāmi, taṃ maṃ ohāya gacchantaṃ. Etthāti etasmiṃ🔽ṭhāne eso mahājano abhisaṭo anubandhanto āgato. Sīmātikkamanaṃ yantanti tvaṃ pana
analyzed: mamanti yaḥ aham etam janam ohāya gacchāmi tam mama ohāya gacchantam ettha ati etasmin  ṭhāne esaḥ mahā janaḥ abhisaṭaḥ anubandhantaḥ āgataḥ sīmātikkamanam yantanti tvam pana
translated: ‘Mamanti’ means ‘I am going away, leaving this people behind’, ‘Ettha’ means ‘in this place’. ‘This great crowd has come, following and pursuing me’. ‘Yantanti’ means ‘you are going beyond the boundary’.

original: taṃ maṃ kilesasīmaṃ atikkamma anagāriyamuniñāṇasaṅkhātassa monassa pattiyā yantaṃ,
analyzed: tam mam kilesa sīmam atikkamma anagāriya muni ñāṇa saṅkhātassa monassa pattiyā yantam
translated: “I am going away, leaving this people behind,” I who am going away, leaving them behind. “Here” : in this place. This great crowd has come, following and pursuing me. “You are going beyond the boundary” : you are going, leaving behind that boundary of defilements, in order to attain the state of a monk, which is called “the state of a recluse.”

original: “pabbajito vatamhī”ti nandiṃ avijahitvā khaṇe khaṇe uppajjamānāhi nandīhi missameva
analyzed: pabbajitaḥ vatamhi iti nandim a vijahitvā khaṇe khaṇe uppajjamānāhi nandīhi missam eva
translated: “I am gone forth,” and without abandoning that delight, you are going, mixed with the delights that arise moment by moment.

original: gacchantaṃ kiṃ jānanto pucchasi, udāhu ajānanto. Mahājanako kira videharaṭṭhaṃ chaḍḍetvā
analyzed: gacchantam kim jānanto pucchasi udāhu a jānanto mahājanako kira videha raṭṭham chaḍḍetvā
translated: Do you ask, knowing that? Or do you ask not knowing? It seems that a great crowd has left the country of the Videhas and gone forth.

original: pabbajitoti kiṃ na sutaṃ tayāti.
analyzed: pabbajito ti kim na sutam tayā iti
translated: Have you not heard that?

original: Athassa so daḷhasamādānatthāya puna gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa saḥ daḷha samādāna atthāya puna gātham āha
translated: Then, in order to strengthen his resolve, the Buddha spoke this verse:

original: “Māssu tiṇṇo amaññittha, sarīraṃ dhārayaṃ imaṃ;
analyzed: mā assu tiṇṇaḥ amaññittha sarīram dhārayan imam
translated: “Do not think that you have crossed over, while still carrying this body around.

original: Atīraṇeyya yamidaṃ, bahū hi paripanthayo”ti.
analyzed: yam idam bahū hi
translated: This is not to be crossed over, for there are many obstacles.”

original: Tattha māssu tiṇṇo amaññitthāti imaṃ bhaṇḍukāsāvanivatthaṃ sarīraṃ dhārento “iminā
analyzed: tattha māssu tiṇṇaḥ amaññittha ati imam sarīram dhārentaḥ iminā
translated: Here, “Do not think that you have crossed over” : carrying around this body, which is clothed in a skin and covered with flesh,

original: pabbajitaliṅgaggahaṇamatteneva kilesasīmaṃ tiṇṇo atikkantosmī”ti mā amaññittha. Atīraṇeyya🔽yamidanti idaṃ kilesajātaṃ nāma na ettakena tīretabbaṃ. Bahū hi paripanthayoti saggamaggaṃ
analyzed: pabbajita liṅga ggahaṇa mattena iva kilesa sīmam tiṇṇaḥ atikkantaḥ asmi iti mā amaññittha  yam idam ti idam kilesa jātam nāma na ettakena bahū hi paripanthayaḥ ti sagga maggam
translated: Do not think that you have crossed over the boundary of the defilements by merely taking on the outward form of a monk.🔽The defilements are not to be crossed over by such a little thing as that.🔽There are many obstacles in your way.

original: āvaritvā ṭhitā tava bahū kilesaparipanthāti.
analyzed: āvaritvā ṭhitā tava
translated: There are many defilements standing in the way of your going to heaven.

original: Tato mahāsatto tassa vacanaṃ sutvā paripanthe pucchanto āha –
analyzed: tatas mahāsatto tassa vacanam sutvā paripanthe pucchantaḥ āha
translated: Then the Great Being, having heard his words, asked him about the obstacles, saying:

original: “Ko nu me paripanthassa, mamaṃ evaṃvihārino;
analyzed: kaḥ nu me paripanthassa mamaṃ evaṃvihārinaḥ
translated: “Who is the obstacle in the way of me, who am thus abiding,

original: Yo neva diṭṭhe nādiṭṭhe, kāmānamabhipatthaye”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ na iva diṭṭhe na a diṭṭhe kāmānam abhipatthaya iti
translated: Who does not seek for sensual pleasures either in the seen or the unseen?”

original: Tattha yo neva diṭṭhe nādiṭṭheti yo ahaṃ neva diṭṭhe manussaloke, nādiṭṭhe devaloke kāmānaṃ abhipatthemi, tassa mama evaṃ ekavihārino ko nu paripantho assāti vadati.
analyzed: tattha yaḥ na iva diṭṭhe na a diṭṭhe iti yaḥ aham na iva diṭṭhe manussa loke na a diṭṭhe deva loke kāmānam abhipatthemi tassa mama evam ekavihārinaḥ kaḥ nu paripanthaḥ assa ati vadati
translated: Here he says: “Who is the obstacle in the way of me, who am thus abiding alone, who does not seek for sensual pleasures either in the seen world of men or in the unseen world of the gods?”

original: Athassa so paripanthe dassento gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa saḥ paripanthe dassentaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then he, showing him the obstacles, spoke this verse:

original: “Niddā tandī vijambhitā, aratī bhattasammado;
analyzed: niddā tandī vijambhitā aratī bhatta sammadaḥ
translated: “Drowsiness, sloth, yawning, discontent, heaviness of the body,

original: Āvasanti sarīraṭṭhā, bahū hi paripanthayo”ti.
analyzed: āvasanti sarīraṭṭhāḥ bahū hi paripanthayaḥ ti
translated: Many obstacles abide in the body.”

original: Tattha niddāti kapiniddā. Tandīti ālasiyaṃ. Aratīti ukkaṇṭhitā. Bhattasammadoti bhattapariḷāho.
analyzed: tattha niddā ati kapiniddā tandī iti ālasiyam arati iti ukkaṇṭhitā bhatta sammado ti bhatta pariḷāho
translated: Herein, sleep is the sleep of a monkey. Lethargy is laziness. Discontent is dissatisfaction. The pain of indigestion is the burning in the stomach.

original: Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “samaṇa, tvaṃ pāsādiko suvaṇṇavaṇṇo rajjaṃ pahāya pabbajito”ti
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti samaṇa tvam pāsādikaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ rajjam pahāya pabbajito ti
translated: This is what is being said: “Ascetic, when it is said that ‘you are pleasing, golden-skinned, and have gone forth after renouncing a kingdom,’

original: vutte tuyhaṃ paṇītaṃ ojavantaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ dassanti, so tvaṃ pattapūraṃ ādāya yāvadatthaṃ🔽paribhuñjitvā paṇṇasālaṃ pavisitvā kaṭṭhattharaṇe nipajjitvā kākacchamāno niddaṃ
analyzed: vutte tuyham paṇītam ojavantam piṇḍapātam dassanti saḥ tvam patta pūram ādāya yāvadattham  paribhuñjitvā paṇṇa sālam pavisitvā kaṭṭhattharaṇe nipajjitvā kākacchamānaḥ niddam
translated: they will give you fine, nutritious almsfood. You will take as much as you need and🔽eat it. Then you will enter your leaf hut, lie down on your bed of wood chips, and fall asleep

original: okkamitvā antarā pabuddho aparāparaṃ parivattitvā hatthapāde pasāretvā uṭṭhāya cīvaravaṃsaṃ
analyzed: okkamitvā antarā pabuddhaḥ apara aparam parivattitvā hattha pāde pasāretvā uṭṭhāya cīvara vaṃsaṃ
translated: after yawning. Then, waking up in the middle of the night, you will turn over, stretch your arms and legs, get up,

original: gahetvā laggacīvaraṃ nivāsetvā ālasiyo hutvā neva sammajjaniṃ ādāya sammajjissasi,
analyzed: gahetvā lagga cīvaram nivāsetvā ālasiyaḥ hutvā na iva sammajjanim ādāya sammajjissasi
translated: take hold of the bamboo robe rack, put on your robe, and become lazy. You will not take the rubbing-board and rub your body,

original: na pānīyaṃ āharissasi, puna nipajjitvā niddāyissasi, kāmavitakkaṃ vitakkessasi, tadā
analyzed: na pānīyam āharissasi puna nipajjitvā niddāyissasi kāma vitakkam vitakkessasi tadā
translated: nor will you fetch water and drink it. You will lie down again and fall asleep. You will think lustful thoughts. Then

original: pabbajjāya ukkaṇṭhissasi, bhattapariḷāho te bhavissatīti. Āvasanti sarīraṭṭhāti ime
analyzed: pabbajjāya ukkaṇṭhissasi bhatta pariḷāhaḥ te bhavissati iti āvasanti sarīraṭṭhā ti ime
translated: you will become dissatisfied with the life of a monk, and you will have the pain of indigestion.” “You will stay” means that you will stay in the monastery.

original: ettakā paripanthā tava sarīraṭṭhakā hutvā nivasanti, sarīreyeva te nibbattantīti dasseti.
analyzed: ettakā paripanthā tava sarīraṭṭhakāḥ hutvā nivasanti sarīreya iva te nibbattanti iti dasseti
translated: He shows that these are obstacles to you, that they live in your body, and that they are produced in your body.

original: Athassa mahāsatto thutiṃ karonto gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa mahāsattaḥ thutim karontaḥ gātham āha
translated: Then the Great Being, praising him, spoke this verse:

original: “Kalyāṇaṃ vata maṃ bhavaṃ, brāhmaṇa manusāsati;
analyzed: kalyāṇam vata mam bhavam brāhmaṇa manusāsati
translated: “Excellent, indeed, is the instruction, O Reverend Sir, that you give me, O Brahman.

original: Brāhmaṇa teva pucchāmi, ko nu tvamasi mārisā”ti.
analyzed: brāhmaṇa tā iva pucchāmi kaḥ nu tvam asi mārisa ati
translated: I ask you, O Brahman, who are you, O Master?”

original: Tattha brāhmaṇa manusāsatīti brāhmaṇa, kalyāṇaṃ vata maṃ bhavaṃ anusāsati.
analyzed: tattha brāhmaṇa m anusāsati iti brāhmaṇa kalyāṇam vata mam bhavam anusāsati
translated: Therein, Brahman, excellent, indeed, is the instruction, O Reverend Sir, that you give me.

original: Tato tāpaso āha –
analyzed: tatas tāpasaḥ āha
translated: Then the ascetic spoke:

original: “Nārado iti me nāmaṃ, kassapo iti maṃ vidū;
analyzed: nāradaḥ iti me nāmam kassapaḥ iti mama vidū
translated: “My name is Narada, and the wise know me as Kassapa.

original: Bhoto sakāsamāgacchiṃ, sādhu sabbhi samāgamo.
analyzed: bhoto sakāsam āgacchim sādhu sabbhi samāgamaḥ
translated: I have come into the presence of your reverence. Excellent is the meeting with all.

original: “Tassa te sabbo ānando, vihāro upavattatu;
analyzed: tassa te sabbaḥ ānandaḥ vihāraḥ upavattatu
translated: “May all your joy,

original: Yaṃ ūnaṃ taṃ paripūrehi, khantiyā upasamena ca.
analyzed: yam ūnam tam paripūrehi khantiyāḥ upasamena ca
translated: and what is lacking may you fill up, and by patience and by peace.

original: “Pasāraya sannatañca, unnatañca pasāraya;
analyzed: pasāraya sannatam ca unnatam ca pasāraya
translated: “Stretch out your hand to the humble, and stretch out your hand to the proud.

original: Kammaṃ vijjañca dhammañca, sakkatvāna paribbajā”ti.
analyzed: kammam vijjañca dhammañca sakkatvāna paribbajāti
translated: Having honoured deeds, knowledge, and the Dhamma, wander about.

original: Tattha vidūti gottena maṃ “kassapo”ti jānanti. Sabbhīti paṇḍitehi saddhiṃ samāgamo
analyzed: tattha vidu iti gottena mam kassapa iti jānanti paṇḍitehi saddhim samāgamaḥ
translated: Therein, the wise know me by my clan as Kassapa. With all means with the wise.

original: nāma sādhu hotīti āgatomhi. Ānandoti tassa tava imissā pabbajjāya ānando tuṭṭhi somanassameva
analyzed: nāma sādhu hoti iti āgataḥ amhi ānandaḥ ti tassa tava imissā pabbajjāya ānando tuṭṭhi somanassam eva
translated: It is good, I have come. Ānanda, let there be joy, delight, gladness in you about this going-forth of yours, do not be discontented.

original: hotu mā ukkaṇṭhi. Vihāroti catubbidho brahmavihāro. Upavattatūti nibbattatu. Yaṃ
analyzed: hotu mā ukkaṇṭhi vihāraḥ iti catubbidhaḥ brahmavihāraḥ upavattatu uti nibbattatu yam
translated: Vihāra: the four divine abidings. May it arise: may it be produced.

original: ūnaṃ tanti yaṃ te sīlena kasiṇaparikammena jhānena ca ūnaṃ, taṃ etehi sīlādīhi pūraya.🔽Khantiyā upasamena cāti “ahaṃ rājapabbajito”ti mānaṃ akatvā adhivāsanakhantiyā ca
analyzed: ūnam yam te sīlena jhānena ca ūnam tam etehi sīla ādīhi pūraya  khantiyā upasamena ca ati aham rāja pabbajito ti mānam a katvā adhivāsana khantiyā ca
translated: What is lacking: whatever is lacking in you by way of virtue, kasiṇa-device, and jhāna, fill that out by means of virtue, etc.🔽By patience and by peace: be endowed with the patience of enduring and with the peace of the subsiding of defilements, without making conceit by thinking “I have gone forth under the King of the Dhamma.”

original: kilesūpasamena ca samannāgato hohi. Pasārayāti mā ukkhipa mā patthara, pajahāti attho.
analyzed: kilesūpasamena ca samannāgataḥ hohi pasāraya ati mā ukkhipa mā patthara pajaha ati attho
translated: Do not throw out, do not spread out: the meaning is, do not abandon.

original: Sannatañca unnatañcāti “ko nāmāha”ntiādinā nayena pavattaṃ omānañca “ahamasmi jātisampanno”tiādinā
analyzed: sannatam ca unnatam ca ati kaḥ nāma aham iti ādinā nayena aham asmi jāti sampannaḥ iti ādinā
translated: The low and the high: the low is the conceit that occurs in the way beginning, “Who is named?” The high is the conceit that occurs in the way beginning, “I am possessed of birth.”

original: nayena pavattaṃ atimānañca. Kammanti dasakusalakammapathaṃ. Vijjanti pañcaabhiññā-aṭṭhasamāpattiñāṇaṃ.
analyzed: nayena pavattam atimānam ca kammanti dasa kusala kamma patham vijjanti pañca abhiññā aṭṭha samāpatti ñāṇam
translated: Action: the ten profitable courses of action. Knowledge: the five kinds of direct-knowledge and the eight knowledges of the jhānas.

original: Dhammanti kasiṇaparikammasaṅkhātaṃ samaṇadhammaṃ. Sakkatvāna paribbajāti ete guṇe
analyzed: dhammanti kasiṇa parikamma saṅkhātam samaṇa dhammam sakkatvāna paribbajāti ete guṇe
translated: The Dhamma is the ascetic practices, such as the kasiṇas, etc. “Having honoured, go forth.”

original: sakkatvā vattassu, ete vā guṇe sakkatvā daḷhaṃ samādāya paribbaja, pabbajjaṃ pālehi,
analyzed: sakkatvā vattassu ete vā guṇe sakkatvā daḷham samādāya paribbaja pabbajjam pālehi
translated: Honour these virtues, and having taken them well to heart, go forth, go forth and keep to the homeless life.

original: mā ukkaṇṭhīti attho.
analyzed: mā ukkaṇṭhi iti attho
translated: Do not be discontented.

original: Evaṃ so mahāsattaṃ ovaditvā ākāsena sakaṭṭhānameva gato. Tasmiṃ gate aparopi migājino
analyzed: evam saḥ mahāsattam ovaditvā ākāsena saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ tasmin gate aparaḥ api miga ajino
translated: Having thus admonished the Great Being, he went back through the air to his own place. After he had gone, another ascetic, named Migajina,

original: nāma tāpaso tatheva samāpattito vuṭṭhāya olokento bodhisattaṃ disvā “mahājanaṃ nivattanatthāya
analyzed: nāma tāpaso tathā iva samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya olokentaḥ bodhisattam disvā mahā janam nivattana tthāya
translated: arose from his trance and looking about saw the Bodhisatta. “In order to turn back the multitude,”

original: tassa ovādaṃ dassāmī”ti tatthevāgantvā ākāse attānaṃ dassento āha –
analyzed: tassa ovādam dassāmi iti tattha iva āgantvā ākāse attānam dassentaḥ āha
translated: he thought, “I will give him my admonition.” So he came there and showing himself in the air, he spoke thus:🔽“Many elephants and horses,

original: “Bahū hatthī ca asse ca, nagare janapadāni ca;
analyzed: bahū hatthī ca asse ca nagare janapadāni ca
translated: and cities and provinces,

original: Hitvā janaka pabbajito, kapāle ratimajjhagā.
analyzed: hitvā janaka pabbajitaḥ kapāle rati majjhagā
translated: having renounced, O father, thou hast gone forth to seek delight in the skull.🔽“Have the people of the provinces,

original: “Kacci nu te jānapadā, mittāmaccā ca ñātakā;
analyzed: kacci nu te jānapadāḥ mitta amaccā ca ñātakā
translated: thy friends and companions and kinsmen,

original: Dubbhimakaṃsu janaka, kasmā tetaṃ aruccathā”ti.
analyzed: janaka kasmai te itam aruccatha ati
translated: caused thee to be afflicted with a double affliction? Why dost thou not like it?”

original: Tattha kapāleti mattikāpattaṃ sandhāyāha. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – mahārāja, tvaṃ evarūpaṃ
analyzed: tattha kapāla iti mattikā pattam sandhāya āha idam vuttam hoti mahā rāja tvam evarūpam
translated: Herein, he said “pot” with a clay bowl in mind. This is what he meant: “Your majesty,

original: issariyādhipaccaṃ chaḍḍetvā pabbajito imasmiṃ kapāle ratiṃ ajjhagā adhigatoti pabbajjākāraṇaṃ🔽pucchanto evamāha. Dubbhinti kiṃ nu ete tava antare kiñci aparādhaṃ kariṃsu, kasmā
analyzed: issariya adhipaccam chaḍḍetvā pabbajitaḥ imasmin kapāle ratim ajjhagāḥ adhigataḥ iti pabbajjā kāraṇam  pucchantaḥ evam āha dubbhinti kim nu ete tava antare kiñci aparādham kariṃsu kasmai
translated: Herein, the word kapāla is used to denote the earthenware bowl. The meaning is this: “Great king, you have gone forth, having renounced such sovereignty and power as this, and you have found delight in this kapāla.”🔽In asking the reason for his going forth, he said this.

original: tava evarūpaṃ issariyasukhaṃ pahāya etaṃ kapālameva aruccitthāti.
analyzed: tava evarūpam issariya sukham pahāya etam kapālam eva
translated: “Have they done you some wrong, that you should have renounced such happiness of sovereignty as this and taken delight in this kapāla?”

original: Tato mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: tatas mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: Then the Great Being said:

original: “Na migājina jātucche, ahaṃ kañci kudācanaṃ;
analyzed: na aham kañci kudācanam
translated: “Never, O Migajina Jatuccha, have I conquered a kinsman unjustly,

original: Adhammena jine ñātiṃ, na cāpi ñātayo mama”nti.🔽Tattha na migājināti ambho migājina jātucche ekaṃseneva ahaṃ kañci ñātiṃ kudācanaṃ
analyzed: adhammena jine ñātim na ca api ñātayaḥ mamanti  na ambhaḥ migājina jātucche ekaṃsena iva aham kañci ñātim kudācanaṃ
translated: Nor have my kinsmen ever conquered me.”🔽Herein, never, O Migajina Jatuccha means, O Migajina Jatuccha, by no means have I ever at any time unjustly conquered a single kinsman.

original: kismiñci kāle adhammena na jināmi. Tepi ca ñātayo maṃ adhammena na jinanteva, iti
analyzed: kismiñci kāle adhammena na jināmi te pi ca ñātayaḥ mama adhammena na jinanta iva iti
translated: Nor have my kinsmen ever conquered me unjustly. Thus

original: na koci mayi dubbhiṃ nāma akāsīti attho.
analyzed: na koci mayi dubbhim nāma akāsi iti attho
translated: no one has done me any wrong.

original: Evamassa pañhaṃ paṭikkhipitvā idāni yena kāraṇena pabbajito, taṃ dassento āha –
analyzed: evam assa pañham paṭikkhipitvā idāni yena kāraṇena pabbajitaḥ tam dassentaḥ āha
translated: Having thus answered his question, the Exalted One now said what he had gone forth to do, saying:

original: “Disvāna lokavattantaṃ, khajjantaṃ kaddamīkataṃ;🔽Haññare bajjhare cettha, yattha sanno puthujjano;🔽Etāhaṃ upamaṃ katvā, bhikkhakosmi migājinā”ti.
analyzed: disvāna lokavattantam khajjantam kaddamīkatam  haññare bajjhare ca ittha yattha sanno puthujjanaḥ  etā aham upamam katvā bhikkhakaḥ asmi miga ajinā ati
translated: Having thus answered the question, he now said, “Disvāna lokavattantaṃ,” etc., showing the reason for his going forth.

original: Tattha disvāna lokavattantanti vaṭṭānugatassa bālalokassa vattaṃ tantiṃ paveṇiṃ ahamaddasaṃ,
analyzed: tattha disvāna vaṭṭa anugatassa bāla lokassa vattam tantim paveṇim aham addasam
translated: Herein, disvāna lokavattantaṃ means I saw the round of the world, the round of the foolish worldling.

original: taṃ disvā pabbajitomhīti dīpeti. Khajjantaṃ kaddamīkatanti kilesehi khajjantaṃ teheva🔽ca kaddamīkataṃ lokaṃ disvā. Yattha sanno puthujjanoti yamhi kilesavatthumhi sanno
analyzed: tam disvā pabbajitaḥ asmi iti dīpeti khajjantam kaddamīkatanti kilesehi khajjantam tehi iva  ca kaddamīkatam lokam disvā yattha sanno puthujjano ti yamhi kilesa vatthumhi sanno
translated: Having seen that, I went forth, is what is shown. Khajjantaṃ kaddamīkataṃ means the world, which is being devoured by defilements and which is being made into a morass by them.

original: laggo puthujjano, tattha laggā bahū sattā haññanti ceva andubandhanādīhi ca bajjhanti.
analyzed: laggo puthujjano tattha laggāḥ bahū sattāḥ ca iva andu bandhana ādīhi ca bajjhanti
translated: Having seen the world, yattha sanno puthujjano means in the object of defilement, the foolish worldling, who is attached, many beings are killed and bound with fetters, etc.

original: Etāhanti ahampi sace ettha bajjhissāmi, ime sattā viya haññissāmi ceva bajjhissāmi
analyzed: etāhanti aham pi sace ettha bajjhissāmi ime sattāḥ viya haññissāmi ca iva bajjhissāmi
translated: Etāhaṃ means if I were to be bound here, I would be killed and bound like those beings.

original: cāti evaṃ etadeva kāraṇaṃ attano upamaṃ katvā kaddamīkataṃ lokaṃ disvā bhikkhako
analyzed: ca ati evam etat eva kāraṇam attanaḥ upamam katvā kaddamīkatam lokam disvā bhikkhakaḥ
translated: “So” : thus he made that very reason his own simile, and seeing the world as if covered with mud, he became a bhikkhu,

original: jātoti attho. Migājināti taṃ nāmena ālapati. Kathaṃ pana tena tassa nāmaṃ ñātanti?
analyzed: jātaḥ ti atthaḥ tam nāmena ālapati katham pana tena tassa nāmam ñātan ti
translated: a beggar, is the meaning. “Hunter” : he addressed him by his name. But how did he come to know his name?

original: Paṭisanthārakāle paṭhamameva pucchitattā.
analyzed: paṭisanthāra kāle paṭhamam eva pucchita tā
translated: Because he asked it first of all at the time of the reception.

original: Tāpaso taṃ kāraṇaṃ vitthārato sotukāmo hutvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tāpasaḥ tam kāraṇam vitthārataḥ sotu kāmaḥ hutvā gātham āha
translated: The devotee, being desirous of hearing that reason in detail, spoke the stanza:

original: “Ko nu te bhagavā satthā, kassetaṃ vacanaṃ suci;
analyzed: kaḥ nu te bhagavā satthā kassa itam vacanam suci
translated: “What is your master, Lord? Whose is this pure speech?

original: Na hi kappaṃ vā vijjaṃ vā, paccakkhāya rathesabha;
analyzed: na hi kappam vā vijjam vā paccakkhāya rathesabha
translated: Not having rejected the doctrine of the kappiya or the doctrine of the vijja,

original: Samaṇaṃ āhu vattantaṃ, yathā dukkhassatikkamo”ti.🔽Tattha kassetanti etaṃ tayā vuttaṃ sucivacanaṃ kassa vacanaṃ nāma. Kappanti kappetvā🔽kappetvā pavattitānaṃ abhiññāsamāpattīnaṃ lābhiṃ kammavādiṃ tāpasaṃ. Vijjanti āsavakkhayañāṇavijjāya
analyzed: samaṇam āhu vattantam yathā dukkhassa tikkamaḥ ti  tattha kassa itanti etam tayā vuttam suci vacanam kassa vacanam nāma kappanti kappetvā  kappetvā pavatti tānam abhiññā samāpattīnam lābhim kamma vādim tāpasam vijjanti āsava kkhaya ñāṇa vijjāya
translated: O charioteer’s son, they say that the ascetic is one who is thus beyond suffering.”

original: samannāgataṃ paccekabuddhaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – rathesabha mahārāja, na hi kappasamaṇaṃ
analyzed: samannāgatam paccekabuddham idam vuttam hoti rathesabha mahā rāja na hi kappa samaṇam
translated: Herein, whose is this pure speech spoken by you? The doctrine of the kappiya is the doctrine of the ascetic who has attained the higher knowledge and the attainments and who is a teacher of kamma. The doctrine of the vijja is the doctrine of the paccekabuddha who is endowed with the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers. This is what is meant: O charioteer’s son, O great king, not having rejected the doctrine of the kappiya ascetic,

original: vā vijjāsamaṇaṃ vā paccakkhāya tassovādaṃ vinā evaṃ paṭipajjituṃ sakkā. Yathā dukkhassa
analyzed: vā vijjāsamaṇam vā paccakkhāya tassa uvādam vinā evam paṭipajjitum sakkā yathā dukkhassa
translated: or a brahmin, or a naked ascetic, or a one-sided ascetic, or a wanderer, or a recluse, or a speculative theorist, and then to practice accordingly. As to suffering,

original: atikkamo hoti, evaṃ vattantaṃ samaṇaṃ āhu. Tesaṃ pana vacanaṃ sutvā sakkā evaṃ paṭipajjituṃ,
analyzed: atikkamaḥ hoti evam vattantam samaṇam āhu tesam pana vacanam sutvā sakkā evam paṭipajjitum
translated: or a recluse who has knowledge, and then to practice in such a way that one may transcend suffering. Such a one is called a recluse. But having heard their words, one may practice in such a way that one may transcend suffering.

original: tasmā vadehi, ko nu te bhagavā satthāti.
analyzed: tasmai vadehi kaḥ nu te bhagavā satthā ati
translated: Therefore tell me, who is your teacher, O Blessed One?”

original: Mahāsatto āha –
analyzed: mahāsattaḥ āha
translated: The Great Being replied:

original: “Na migājina jātucche, ahaṃ kañci kudācanaṃ;
analyzed: na aham kañci kudācanam
translated: “O deer-skin-clad ascetic, I have never at any time,

original: Samaṇaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ vāpi, sakkatvā anupāvisi”nti.
analyzed: samaṇam brāhmaṇam vā api sakkatvā anupāvisinti
translated: Having honored any recluse or brahmin, sat down in his presence.”

original: Tattha sakkatvāti pabbajjāya guṇapucchanatthāya pūjetvā. Anupāvisinti na kañci anupaviṭṭhapubbosmi,🔽na mayā añño koci samaṇo pucchitapubboti vadati. Iminā hi paccekabuddhānaṃ santike
analyzed: tattha sakkatvā ti pabbajjāya guṇa pucchana tthāya pūjetvā anupāvisin ti na kañci an upaviṭṭha pubbaḥ asmi  na mayā aññaḥ koci samaṇo pucchita pubbaḥ iti vadati iminā hi paccekabuddhānam santike
translated: Here, having honored means having worshipped in order to ask about the virtues of the going forth. Sat down in his presence means I have never sat down in the presence of anyone,

original: dhammaṃ suṇantenapi na kadāci odissakavasena pabbajjāya guṇo pucchitapubbo, tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: dhammam suṇantena api na kadāci odissaka vasena pabbajjāya guṇo pucchita pubbaḥ tasmai evam āha
translated: I have never asked any other recluse before. For he has never asked about the virtues of the going forth with a view to going forth, even while listening to the Dhamma in the presence of the Paccekabuddhas. Therefore he said thus.

original: Evañca pana vatvā yena kāraṇena pabbajito, taṃ ādito paṭṭhāya dīpento āha –
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā yena kāraṇena pabbajitaḥ tam āditas paṭṭhāya dīpentaḥ āha
translated: Having said this, he began to explain the reason for his going forth from the beginning.

original: “Mahatā cānubhāvena, gacchanto siriyā jalaṃ;🔽Gīyamānesu gītesu, vajjamānesu vaggusu.

translated: “Unclaimed” means “unowned.” “Dirty” means “smeared with dust.” “Unlovely” means “ugly.”

analyzed: tuṭṭha mānasaḥ hutvā sakala sarīram mātā pitaraḥ vanditvā vihāram gantvā  bhagavantam pabbajjam yāci satthā ekam bhikkhum pakkosāpetvā imam kumāram pabbājehi iti
translated: When the young man heard this, he was delighted. He bowed down before his parents, and going to the monastery,🔽he asked the Teacher to admit him to the Order. The Teacher summoned a certain monk and commanded him, saying, “Go admit this young man to the Order.”

original: āṇāpesi. So taṃ pabbājesi. Tassa pabbajitakālato paṭṭhāya mahālābhasakkāro nibbatti.
analyzed: āṇāpesi so tam pabbājesi tassa pabbajita kālataḥ paṭṭhāya mahā lābha sakkāro nibbatti
translated: The monk admitted him to the Order. From the time of his admission to the Order, he received abundant gifts and offerings.

original: So ācariyupajjhāye ārādhetvā laddhūpasampado pañca vassāni dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā
analyzed: saḥ ācariya upajjhāye ārādhetvā laddha upasampadaḥ pañca vassāni dhammam pariyāpuṇitvā

original: “ahaṃ idha ākiṇṇo viharāmi, na me idaṃ patirūpa”nti vipassanādhuraṃ pūretukāmo hutvā
analyzed: aham idhas ākiṇṇaḥ viharāmi na me idam vipassanā dhuram pūretu kāmaḥ hutvā
translated: “I am living here in a crowded place. It is not suitable for me,” and desiring to fill himself with the burden of insight,

analyzed: upajjhāyassa santike kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā upajjhāyam vanditvā jetavanā nikkhamitvā  ekam paccanta gāmam nissāya araññe vihāsi saḥ tattha vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā dvādasa
translated: he took a meditation subject from his preceptor, paid homage to him, and left Jeta’s Wood.🔽He lived in a forest near a certain border village. There he developed insight and reached the stage of conformity .

original: vassāni ghaṭento vāyamantopi visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ nāsakkhi. Mātāpitaropissa gacchante🔽gacchante kāle duggatā ahesuṃ. Ye hi tesaṃ khettaṃ vā vaṇijjaṃ vā payojesuṃ, te “imasmiṃ
analyzed: vassāni ghaṭentaḥ vā āyamantaḥ api visesam nibbattetum nā asakkhi mātā pitaraḥ upi ssa gacchante  gacchante kāle duggatāḥ ahesum ye hi tesam khettam vā vaṇijjam vā payojesum te imasmin
translated: But even though he strove and struggled for twelve years, he was unable to produce any distinction. His parents🔽also became destitute as time went on. Those who had employed their son or brother were saying, “In this family

original: kule putto vā bhātā vā iṇaṃ codetvā gaṇhanto nāma natthī”ti attano attano hatthagataṃ
analyzed: kule puttaḥ vā bhātā vā iṇam codetvā gaṇhantaḥ nāma natthi iti attano attano hattha gatam

original: gahetvā yathāruci palāyiṃsu. Gehe dāsakammakarādayopi hiraññasuvaṇṇādīni gahetvā palāyiṃsu.
analyzed: gahetvā yathāruci palāyiṃsu gehe dāsa kammakara ādayaḥ api hirañña suvaṇṇa ādīni gahetvā palāyiṃsu
translated: Even the slaves and servants in the house took the gold and silver and ran away.

original: Aparabhāge dve janā kapaṇā hutvā hatthe udakasiñcanampi alabhitvā gehaṃ vikkiṇitvā
analyzed: aparabhāge dve janā kapaṇā hutvā hatthe udaka siñcanam pi a labhitvā geham vikkiṇitvā
translated: Later on, the two of them became so poor that they could not even get water to drink. They sold the house and

original: agharā hutvā kāruññabhāvaṃ pattā pilotikaṃ nivāsetvā kapālahatthā bhikkhāya cariṃsu.
analyzed: agharāḥ hutvā kāruñña bhāvam pattāḥ pilotikam nivāsetvā kapāla hatthāḥ bhikkhāya cariṃsu
translated: and became poor and miserable. They put on their robes and took their bowls and went out for alms.

original: Tasmiṃ kāle eko bhikkhu jetavanato nikkhamitvā anupubbena tassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: tasmin kāle ekaḥ bhikkhu jetavanataḥ nikkhamitvā anupubbena tassa vasana ṭṭhānam agamāsi
translated: At that time a certain monk left Jetavana and gradually reached the place where they lived.

original: So tassa āgantukavattaṃ katvā sukhanisinnakāle “bhante, kuto āgatatthā”ti pucchitvā
analyzed: so tassa āgantuka vattam katvā sukha nisinna kāle bhante kutas āgatattha ati pucchitvā
translated: He performed the duties of hospitality to them, and when they were seated at ease, asked, “Reverend Sirs, whence do you come?”

original: “jetavanā āgato āvuso”ti vutte satthuno ceva mahāsāvakādīnañca ārogyaṃ pucchitvā
analyzed: jetavanā āgataḥ āvuso ti vutte satthuno ca iva mahāsāvaka ādīnam ca ārogyam pucchitvā
translated: “We come from Jetavana, brother.” “Are the Teacher and the Elder Disciples in health?”

translated: “And how is it with your parents?” “Reverend Sir, is the merchant of such and such a name in Savatthi in health?”

translated: “It seems that there is a son in that family who has gone forth in the religion of the Buddha.

original: paṭṭhāya etaṃ kulaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ, idāni dve janā paramakāruññabhāvaṃ pattā bhikkhāya
analyzed: paṭṭhāya etam kulam parikkhīṇam idāni dve janā parama kāruñña bhāvam pattā bhikkhāya
translated: Ever since he went forth, that family has been ruined. Now there are only two persons left, who have become poor and miserable and go out for alms.

original: carantī”ti. So tassa vacanaṃ sutvā sakabhāvena saṇṭhātuṃ asakkonto assupuṇṇehi nettehi🔽rodituṃ ārabhi. “Āvuso, kiṃ rodasī”ti? “Bhante, te mayhaṃ mātāpitaro, ahaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: caranti iti so tassa vacanam sutvā saka bhāvena saṇṭhātum a sakkontaḥ assu puṇṇehi nettehi  roditum ārabhi āvuso kim rodasi iti bhante te mayham mātā pitaraḥ aham tesam
translated: “They are living in such and such a place.” Hearing this, the novice, unable to bear up under the shock,

analyzed: saḥ aham dvādasa vassāni ghaṭentaḥ vā āyamantaḥ api maggam vā phalam vā nibbattetum na asakkhim
translated: “For twelve years I strove and struggled, and yet I could not produce the path or the fruit.

original: abhabbo bhavissāmi, kiṃ me pabbajjāya, gihī hutvā mātāpitaro posetvā dānaṃ datvā🔽saggaparāyaṇo bhavissāmī”ti cintetvā araññāvāsaṃ tassa therassa niyyādetvā punadivase🔽araññā nikkhamitvā anupubbena gacchanto sāvatthito avidūre jetavanapiṭṭhivihāraṃ
analyzed: abhabbaḥ bhavissāmi kim me pabbajjāya gihī hutvā mātā pitaro posetvā dānam da tvā  sagga parāyaṇaḥ bhavissāmi iti cintetvā araññā vāsam tassa therassa niyyādetvā puna divase  araññā nikkhamitvā anupubbena gacchantaḥ sāvatthitaḥ avidūre jetavana piṭṭhi vihāram
translated: I shall not be able to do so now. What have I to do with the monk’s state? I will become a layman again, support my mother and father, give alms,🔽and make merit.” So he turned back the novice and went his way.🔽The next day he left the forest and gradually made his way to the Jetavana monastery,

original: pāpuṇi. Tattha dve maggā ahesuṃ. Tesu eko maggo jetavanaṃ gacchati, eko sāvatthiṃ.
analyzed: tattha dve maggāḥ ahesum tesu ekaḥ maggaḥ jetavanam gacchati ekaḥ sāvatthim
translated: which was not far from Sāvatthi. There were two roads leading to the Jetavana monastery, one from the Jetavana to Sāvatthi and one from Sāvatthi to the Jetavana.

original: So tattheva ṭhatvā “kiṃ nu kho paṭhamaṃ mātāpitaro passāmi, udāhu dasabala”nti cintetvā
analyzed: saḥ tattha iva ṭhatvā kim nu kho paṭhamam mātā pitaro passāmi udāhu dasabalanti cintetvā
translated: Standing there, he thought to himself, “Whom shall I see first, my mother and father or the Buddha?”

analyzed: mayā mātā pitaro ciram diṭṭha pubbāḥ itas paṭṭhāya pana me buddha dassanam dullabham
translated: “I have seen my mother and father many times, but it will be difficult for me to see the Buddha again.

analyzed: bhavissati tasmai ajjam eva sammāsambuddham disvā dhammam sutvā sve pāto uva mātā pitaro
translated: Therefore I will see the Buddha this very day, hear the Law, and tomorrow I will see my mother and father.”

analyzed: passissāmi iti sāvatthi maggam pahāya sāyanha samaye jetavanam pāvisi tam divasam pana

analyzed: so tassa āgamana kāle mātu uposaka suttena mātā pitūnam guṇam vaṇṇesi so pana bhikkhu  ṭhatvā satthussa dhamma katham suṇantaḥ cintesi aham gihī hutvā mātā pitaro paṭijaggitum
translated: At the time of his arrival the Teacher preached the Matuposathasuttanta, extolling the virtues of mother and father.🔽This monk stood at the edge of the assembly and listened to the discourse of the Teacher.🔽“As a layman,” thought he, “I am able to minister to my mother and father.”

original: sakkomīti cintesiṃ, satthā pana ‘pabbajitova samāno paṭijaggito upakārako mātāpitūna’nti
analyzed: sakkomi iti cintesim satthā pana pabbajitaḥ iva samānaḥ paṭijaggitaḥ upakārakaḥ mātā pitūnam anti
translated: “The monk who has entered the Order,” said the Teacher, “is able to minister to his mother and father.

original: vadati. Sacāhaṃ satthāraṃ adisvā gato, evarūpāya pabbajjāya parihīno bhaveyyaṃ. Idāni
analyzed: vadati sacā aham satthāram a disvā gataḥ evarūpāya pabbajjāya parihīnaḥ bhaveyyam idāni
translated: “If I go away without seeing the Teacher, I shall lose such an opportunity for going forth as this. But now

translated: I have gone forth, and I am no longer a layman. I can support my parents.”

analyzed: saḥ salākaggam gantvā salāka bhattam ca iva salāka yāgum ca gaṇhitvā dvādasa vassāni araññe  vuttha bhikkhu pārājika ppattaḥ viya ahosi saḥ pātova sāvatthiyam pavisitvā kim nu
translated: He went to the place where the tickets were distributed, and taking a ticket for rice-gruel and a ticket for rice, he remained in the forest twelve years,

analyzed: kho paṭhamam yāgum gaṇhissāmi udāhu mātā pitaro passissāmi iti cintetvā
translated: just as a monk who has committed a Pārājikā offense remains in the forest. He entered Sāvatthi in the morning, and as he entered the city, he thought to himself, “Which shall I see first, my parents or the Teacher?”

analyzed: mātā pitūnam santikam tuccha hatthena gantum ayuttam ti cintetvā yāgum gahetvā etesam  porāṇaka geha dvāram gataḥ mātā pitaropissa yāgu bhikkham caritvā para bhittim nissāya
translated: Then he thought to himself, “It is not proper for me to go empty-handed to my poor parents.” So he took the rice-gruel and went to the old house in which his parents lived.

original: viharanti. So upagantvā nisinnake disvā uppannasoko assupuṇṇehi nettehi tesaṃ avidūre
analyzed: viharanti saḥ upagantvā nisinnake disvā uppanna sokaḥ assu puṇṇehi nettehi tesam avidūre
translated: His parents had gone out begging for rice-gruel and were living in a neighboring village. He went to the place where they were living, and seeing them seated there, he was overcome with grief and sat down weeping, his eyes filled with tears.

original: aṭṭhāsi. Te taṃ disvāpi na sañjāniṃsu. Atha mātā “bhikkhatthāya ṭhito bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: te tam disvā api na sañjāniṃsu atha mātā bhikkha tthāya ṭhitaḥ bhavissati iti

analyzed: saññāya bhante tumhākam dātabba yuttakam natthi aticchatha āha saḥ tassā katham
translated: and said to him, “Venerable sir, we have nothing suitable to give you. Please go elsewhere.” When he heard her say this,

analyzed: sutvā hadaya pūram sokam gahetvā assu puṇṇehi nettehi tattha iva aṭṭhāsi dutiyam pi tatiyam pi

analyzed: aticchatha ati vuccamānaḥ api athassa pitā mātaram āha gaccha bhadde
translated: but he stood there each time. Then his father said to his mother, “Go, my dear,

analyzed: jānāhi puttaḥ nu kho no esa iti sā uṭṭhāya upagantvā olokentī sañjānitvā pāda mūle
translated: and find out if this is our son.” She got up and went to him. When she saw him, she recognized him, and she fell at his feet

translated: and lamented. His father did the same. There was great sorrow.

analyzed: saḥ api mātā pitaraḥ disvā saka bhāvena saṇṭhātum a sakkontaḥ assūni pavattesi saḥ sokam
translated: When he saw his mother and father, he was unable to control himself and burst into tears. He endured his sorrow,

analyzed: adhivāsetvā ammatātā mā cintayittha aham vaḥ posessāmi iti mātā pitaraḥ assāsetvā
translated: comforted his mother and father, saying, “Mother, Father, do not worry. I will support you,”

analyzed: yāgum pāyetvā ekamante nisīdāpetvā puna bhikkham āharitvā te bhojetvā attanaḥ atthāya
translated: After giving them rice-gruel, he sat down to one side and had them brought more alms-food. After feeding them, he himself

analyzed: bhikkham pariyesitvā tesam santikam gantvā puna bhattena āpucchitvā pacchā sayam paribhuñjati
translated: looked for alms-food. After going to them, he asked for more food, and afterwards he himself ate.

analyzed: so tatas paṭṭhāya iminā niyāmena mātā pitaro paṭijaggati attanā laddhāni pakkhika bhatta ādīni
translated: From then on he looked after his parents in this way. The daily food he received,

translated: after giving it to them, he himself ate what he received by going on alms-round. If he did not receive anything, he did not eat.🔽He gave them whatever he received, even the rains-residence-gift and other things. After they had eaten, he took the old rags,

analyzed: iti saḥ mātā pitaraḥ aparabhāge kisaḥ uppaṇḍu paṇḍuka jātaḥ dhamani santhata gatto
translated: Thus, while looking after his parents, he became thin, pale, wasted away, and his body became covered with veins.

analyzed: ahosi atha nam sandiṭṭha sambhattā bhikkhū pucchiṃsu āvuso pubbe tava sarīra vaṇṇo
translated: The monks who had seen him before asked him, “Brother, formerly your bodily complexion was beautiful;

analyzed: sobhati idāni pana kisaḥ uppaṇḍu paṇḍuka jātaḥ dhamani santhata gattaḥ te nu kho

translated: The arrow passed through his left side and came out at his right. When the deer saw that he had been shot, he was frightened and ran away. But the wise Suvannasāma, though he had been shot,🔽went on his way, as if he were tired, and sat down on the bank of a lake. The king, seeing that he had gone a long way,

original: anavasumbhitvā satiṃ paccupaṭṭhāpetvā saṇikaṃ otāretvā vālukaṃ viyūhitvā ṭhapetvā
analyzed: an avasumbhitvā satim paccupaṭṭhāpetvā saṇikam otāretvā vālukam viyūhitvā ṭhapetvā
translated: without stirring up the dust, he set his mindfulness to work, and slowly drew out the arrow. Then he spread out the sand, and having set the arrow upright,

original: disaṃ vavatthapetvā mātāpitūnaṃ vasanaṭṭhānadisābhāgena sīsaṃ katvā rajatapaṭṭavaṇṇāya🔽vālukāya suvaṇṇapaṭimā viya nipajjitvā satiṃ paccupaṭṭhāpetvā “imasmiṃ himavantappadese
analyzed: disam vavatthapetvā mātā pitūnam vasanaṭṭhāna disā bhāgena sīsam katvā rajata paṭṭa vaṇṇāya  vālukāya suvaṇṇa paṭimā viya nipajjitvā satim paccupaṭṭhāpetvā imasmin himavanta ppadese
translated: he fixed his direction, and placing his head in the direction of his parents’ dwelling-place, he lay down like a golden image,

original: mama verī nāma natthi, mayhaṃ mātāpitūnañca verī nāma natthī”ti mukhena lohitaṃ chaḍḍetvā
analyzed: mama verī nāma natthi mayham mātā pitūnam ca verī nāma natthi iti mukhena lohitam chaḍḍetvā
translated: and set his mindfulness to work, thinking: “In this region of the Himalayas there is no enemy of mine, nor of my parents.” Then he spat out blood from his mouth,

original: rājānaṃ adisvāva paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājānam paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and without looking at the king, he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Ko nu maṃ usunā vijjhi, pamattaṃ udahārakaṃ;
analyzed: kaḥ nu mama usunā vijjhi pamattam uda hārakam
translated: “Who is it that has pierced me with an arrow, me who am heedless and a prey to passion?

original: Khattiyo brāhmaṇo vesso, ko maṃ viddhā nilīyasī”ti.
analyzed: khattiyaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ vesso kaḥ mama viddhā nilīyasi iti
translated: Is it a warrior, a brahman, or a peasant? Who is it that has pierced me and fled away?”

original: Tattha pamattanti mettābhāvanāya anupaṭṭhitasatiṃ. Idañhi so sandhāya tasmiṃ khaṇe attānaṃ pamattaṃ nāma akāsi. Viddhāti vijjhitvā.
analyzed: tattha pamattam ti mettā bhāvanāya anupaṭṭhita satim idam hi saḥ sandhāya tasmin khaṇe attānam pamattam nāma akāsi viddhā ati vijjhitvā
translated: Herein, heedless means his mindfulness was not established in the development of loving-kindness. For at that moment he made himself heedless. He has pierced means he has pierced me.

original: Evañca pana vatvā puna attano sarīramaṃsassa abhakkhasammatabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā puna attanaḥ sarīra maṃsassa a bhakkha sammata bhāvam dassetum dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Having so spoken, he spoke the second stanza in order to show that his own flesh was not fit to be eaten:

original: “Na me maṃsāni khajjāni, cammenattho na vijjati;
analyzed: na me maṃsāni khajjāni cammena atthaḥ na vijjati
translated: “My flesh is not to be eaten, nor is there need of my skin;

original: Atha kena nu vaṇṇena, viddheyyaṃ maṃ amaññathā”ti.
analyzed: atha kena nu vaṇṇena viddhā iyyam mama amaññatha ati
translated: But for what reason, I pray you, have you pierced me with your dart?”

original: Dutiyagāthaṃ vatvā tameva nāmādivasena pucchanto āha –
analyzed: dutiya gātham vatvā tam eva nāma ādi vasena pucchantaḥ āha
translated: Having spoken the second stanza, he spoke the third stanza in order to question him as to his name and so on:

original: “Ko vā tvaṃ kassa vā putto, kathaṃ jānemu taṃ mayaṃ;
analyzed: kaḥ vā tvam kassa vā putto katham jānemu tam mayam
translated: “Who are you, and whose son? How may we know you?

original: Puṭṭho me samma akkhāhi, kiṃ maṃ viddhā nilīyasī”ti.
analyzed: puṭṭhaḥ me samma akkhāhi kim mama viddhā nilīyasi iti
translated: When questioned, good sir, tell me why you stand there piercing me.”

original: Tattha amaññathāti ayaṃ puriso kena kāraṇena maṃ vijjhitabbanti amaññitthāti attho.
analyzed: tattha amaññatha ati ayam puriso kena kāraṇena mam vijjhitabbanti amaññittha ati attho
translated: Herein, amaññath means this man thought: “For what reason should I be pierced?”

original: Evañca pana vatvā tuṇhī ahosi. Taṃ sutvā rājā “ayaṃ mayā visapītena sallena vijjhitvā
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā tuṇhī ahosi tam sutvā rājā ayam mayā visa pītena sallena vijjhitvā
translated: Having so spoken, he became silent. Having heard that, the king thought: “This man, though pierced by me with a poisoned dart,

original: pātitopi neva maṃ akkosati na paribhāsati, mama hadayaṃ sambāhanto viya piyavacanena
analyzed: pātitaḥ api na iva mam akkosati na paribhāsati mama hadayam piya vacanena
translated: does not revile me nor abuse me, but as if he were soothing my heart, with pleasant words

original: samudācarati, gacchissāmissa santika”nti cintetvā gantvā tassa santike ṭhitova dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: samudācarati gacchissāmi issa santikanti cintetvā gantvā tassa santike ṭhitaḥ uva dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: “If he does so, I will go to him.” So he went and stood near him and spoke two stanzas:🔽I am the king of Kasi,

original: “Rājāhamasmi kāsīnaṃ, pīḷiyakkhoti maṃ vidū;
analyzed: rājā aham asmi kāsīnam mama vidū
translated: The people know me as Piliyakkha;🔽Because of greed I have left the kingdom

original: Lobhā raṭṭhaṃ pahitvāna, migamesaṃ carāmahaṃ.
analyzed: lobhāḥ raṭṭham pahitvāna migamesam carām aham
translated: And am roaming about hunting deer.🔽I am skilled in archery,

original: “Issatthe casmi kusalo, daḷhadhammoti vissuto;
analyzed: casmi kusalaḥ daḷha dhammaḥ ti vissutaḥ
translated: And am well known as Dalhadhamma;🔽Even a nāga would not escape me

original: Nāgopi me na mucceyya, āgato usupātana”nti.
analyzed: nāgaḥ upi me na mucceyya āgataḥ usu pātananti
translated: If he came within the range of my arrows.

original: Tattha rājāhamasmīti evaṃ kirassa vitakko ahosi “devāpi nāgāpi manussabhāsāya kathentiyeva,
analyzed: tattha rājā aham asmi iti evam kirassa vitakkaḥ ahosi devāḥ api nāgāḥ api manussa bhāsāya kathentiyā iva
translated: Herein, the king thought thus: “Gods, nāgas, and human beings speak the human speech.

original: ahametaṃ devoti vā nāgoti vā manussoti vā na jānāmi. Sace kujjheyya, nāseyya maṃ,
analyzed: aham etam devaḥ iti vā nāgaḥ iti vā manussaḥ iti vā na jānāmi sace kujjheyya na āseyya mama
translated: I do not know whether this one is a god, a nāga, or a human being. If he becomes angry, he will destroy me.

original: ‘rājā’ti vutte pana abhāyanto nāma natthī”ti. Tasmā attano rājabhāvaṃ jānāpetuṃ paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: rājā ati vutte pana abhāyantaḥ nāma natthi iti tasmai attanaḥ rāja bhāvam paṭhamam
translated: But when one says ‘king,’ there is no one who does not make way for him.” Therefore, in order to make known his own royal status, he said first,

original: “rājāhamasmī”ti āha. Lobhāti migamaṃsalobhena. Migamesanti migaṃ esanto. Carāmahanti
analyzed: rājā aham asmi iti āha migam aṃsa lobhena migam esanti migam carāmahanti
translated: “I am the king.” Because of greed: because of greed for deer meat. Roaming about hunting deer: seeking deer.

original: carāmi ahaṃ. Dutiyaṃ gāthaṃ pana attano balaṃ dīpetukāmo evamāha. Tattha issattheti
analyzed: carāmi aham dutiyam gātham pana attanaḥ balam dīpetu kāmaḥ evam āha tattha issattha iti
translated: I go about. But in the second stanza he said this in order to show his own strength.

original: dhanusippe. Daḷhadhammoti daḷhadhanuṃ sahassatthāmadhanuṃ oropetuñca āropetuñca samattho.
analyzed: dhanu sippe daḷha dhammaḥ ti daḷha dhanum sahassatthāma dhanum oropetum ca āropetum ca samatthaḥ
translated: I am a man. But in the second verse he says, “I am a man,” in order to show his own strength. Herein, in archery means in the art of archery. I am strong means I am able to draw and shoot a strong bow, a thousand-arrow bow.

original: Iti rājā attano balaṃ vaṇṇetvā tassa nāmagottaṃ pucchanto āha –
analyzed: iti rājā attanaḥ balam vaṇṇetvā tassa nāma gottam pucchantaḥ āha
translated: Thus the king, having extolled his own strength, asked his name and clan, saying,

original: “Ko vā tvaṃ kassa vā putto, kathaṃ jānemu taṃ mayaṃ;
analyzed: kaḥ vā tvam kassa vā putto katham jānemu tam mayam
translated: “Who are you? Whose son? How shall we know you?

original: Pituno attano cāpi, nāmagottaṃ pavedayā”ti.
analyzed: pitunaḥ ca api nāma gottam pavedayāti
translated: Tell us the name and clan of your father and yourself.”

original: Tattha pavedayāti kathaya.
analyzed: tattha pavedaya ati kathaya
translated: Herein, tell us means speak.

original: Taṃ sutvā mahāsatto “sacāhaṃ ‘devanāgakinnarakhattiyādīsu aññatarohamasmī’ti katheyyaṃ, saddaheyyeva esa, saccameva panassa kathetuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti cintetvā evamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsatto sacā aham deva nāga kinnara khattiya ādīsu aññataraḥ ham asmi iti katheyyam saddaheyya iva esa saccam eva pana assa kathetum vaṭṭati iti cintetvā evam āha
translated: Hearing this, the Great Being thought, “If I were to say, ‘I am one of the gods, nāgas, kinnaras, or khattiyas,’ he would not believe me. But it is right that I should tell him the truth.” So he said,

original: “Nesādaputto bhaddante, sāmo iti maṃ ñātayo;
analyzed: nesāda putto bhaddante sāmaḥ iti mama ñātayaḥ
translated: “I am the son of a hunter, sire, and my relatives call me Sāma.

original: Āmantayiṃsu jīvantaṃ, svajjevāhaṃ gato saye.
analyzed: āmantayiṃsu jīvantam svajjā iva aham gataḥ saye
translated: They called me while I was alive, but now I have gone to sleep.

original: “Viddhosmi puthusallena, savisena yathā migo;
analyzed: viddhaḥ asmi puthusallena sa visena yathā migo
translated: I am pierced by a sharp arrow, as if by a poisonous snake,

original: Sakamhi lohite rāja, passa semi paripluto.🔽“Paṭivāmagataṃ sallaṃ, passa dhimhāmi lohitaṃ;
analyzed: sakamhi lohite rāja passa semi pariplutaḥ  paṭivāma gatam sallam passa dhimhāmi lohitam
translated: In my own blood, O king, I see I am sinking down.🔽The arrow has turned back, I see, and blood is flowing from me.

original: Āturo tyānupucchāmi, kiṃ maṃ viddhā nilīyasi.
analyzed: ātura tya anupucchāmi kim mama viddhā nilīyasi
translated: I am sick, I ask you: why do you stand there looking at me?

original: “Ajinamhi haññate dīpi, nāgo dantehi haññate;
analyzed: ajinamhi haññate dīpi nāgaḥ dantehi haññate
translated: The deer is killed by the net, the elephant by the hook,

original: Atha kena nu vaṇṇena, viddheyyaṃ maṃ amaññathā”ti.
analyzed: atha kena nu vaṇṇena viddhā iyyam mama amaññatha ati
translated: But by what colour did you think I should be hit?

original: Tattha jīvantanti maṃ ito pubbe jīvamānaṃ “ehi sāma, yāhi sāmā”ti ñātayo āmantayiṃsu.
analyzed: tattha jīvantam ti mam itas pubbe jīvamānam ehi sāma yāhi sāma ati ñātayaḥ āmantayiṃsu
translated: Here, “living” means that before this I was living, and my relatives called me, saying, “Come, so-and-so, go, so-and-so.”

original: Svajjevāhaṃ gatoti so ahaṃ ajja evaṃ gato maraṇamukhe sampatto, paviṭṭhoti attho.🔽Sayeti sayāmi. Pariplutoti nimuggo. Paṭivāmagatanti dakkhiṇapassena pavisitvā vāmapassena🔽niggatanti attho. Passāti olokehi maṃ. Dhimhāmīti niṭṭhubhāmi, idaṃ so satiṃ paccupaṭṭhāpetvā
analyzed: su ajjā iva aham gataḥ iti saḥ aham ajja evam gataḥ maraṇa mukhe sampatto paviṭṭho ti attho  sayā iti paripluto ti nimuggo dakkhiṇa passena pavisitvā vāma passena  niggatanti attho passa ati olokehi mam dhimhāmi iti niṭṭhubhāmi idam so satim paccupaṭṭhāpetvā
translated: “I have gone just today” means that today I have gone thus, I have reached the mouth of death, I have entered it, is the meaning.🔽“I lie” means I lie down. “Sinking down” means submerged. “Turned back” means entered by the right side and gone out by the left side.🔽“Look at me” means look at me. “I am spitting” means I am spitting out. This he said without trembling, having established mindfulness,

original: avikampamānova lohitaṃ mukhena chaḍḍetvā āha. Āturo tyānupucchāmī”ti bāḷhagilāno
analyzed: a vikampamānaḥ iva lohitam mukhena chaḍḍetvā āha āturaḥ tya anupucchāmi iti bāḷha gilānaḥ
translated: after ejecting the blood from his mouth. “I am sick, I ask you” means I am very sick, I am asking you.

original: hutvā ahaṃ taṃ anupucchāmi. Nilīyasīti etasmiṃ vanagumbe nilīno acchasi. Viddheyyanti
analyzed: hutvā aham tam anupucchāmi nilīyasi iti etasmin vana gumbe nilīnaḥ acchasi
translated: “I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.

original: vijjhitabbaṃ. Amaññathāti amaññittha.🔽Rājā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā yathābhūtaṃ anācikkhitvā musāvādaṃ kathento āha –🔽“Migo upaṭṭhito āsi, āgato usupātanaṃ;
analyzed: vijjhitabbam amaññatha ati amaññittha  rājā tassa vacanam sutvā yathābhūtam an ācikkhitvā musāvādam kathentaḥ āha  migaḥ upaṭṭhitaḥ āsi āgataḥ usupātanam
translated: “I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.

original: Taṃ disvā ubbijī sāma, tena kodho mamāvisī”ti.
analyzed: tam disvā ubbijī sāma tena kodhaḥ mama āvisi iti
translated: “I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.

original: Tattha āvisīti ajjhotthari. Tena kāraṇena me kodho uppannoti dīpeti.
analyzed: tattha āvisi iti ajjhotthari tena kāraṇena me kodhaḥ uppannaḥ ti dīpeti
translated: “I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.

analyzed: atha nam mahāsatto kim vadesi mahā rāja imasmin himavante mam disvā palāyana migo nāma natthi iti vatvā āha
translated: “I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.

original: Na maṃ migā uttasanti, araññe sāpadānipi.
analyzed: na mam migāḥ uttasanti araññe
translated: “I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.🔽“I will shoot you,” said the other.

original: “Bhīrū kimpurisā rāja, pabbate gandhamādane;
analyzed: bhīrū kimpurisā rāja pabbate gandhamādane
translated: “I will shoot you,”

original: Sammodamānā gacchāma, pabbatāni vanāni ca.
analyzed: sammodamānāḥ gacchāma pabbatāni vanāni ca
translated: We go about together, over mountains and through the forest.

original: “Na maṃ migā uttasanti, araññe sāpadānipi;
analyzed: na mam migāḥ uttasanti araññe
translated: “No deer are afraid of me, not even the wild ones in the forest;

original: Atha kena nu vaṇṇena, utrāsanti migā mama”nti.
analyzed: atha kena nu vaṇṇena utrāsanti migāḥ mamanti
translated: But why is it that the deer are afraid of me?”

original: Tattha na maṃ migāti bho mahārāja, yato kālato paṭṭhāya ahaṃ attānaṃ sarāmi, yato🔽kālato paṭṭhāya ahaṃ viññubhāvaṃ patto asmi bhavāmi, tato kālato paṭṭhāya maṃ disvā
analyzed: tattha na mam migāti bho mahā rāja yatas kālataḥ paṭṭhāya aham attānam sarāmi yatas  kālataḥ paṭṭhāya aham viññu bhāvam pattaḥ asmi bhavāmi tatas kālataḥ paṭṭhāya mama disvā
translated: Herein, no deer are afraid of me: Great king, since the time I can remember myself, since the time I attained the state of being wise,

original: migā nāma na uttasanti. Sāpadānipīti vāḷamigāpi. Yato nidhinti yato kālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: migāḥ nāma naḥ uttasanti vāḷa migāḥ api yatas yatas kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: since then, when the deer see me, they are not afraid. Not even the wild ones: even the wild deer. Since the time I took up

original: ahaṃ vākacīraṃ parihariṃ. Bhīrū kimpurisāti mahārāja, migā tāva tiṭṭhantu, kimpurisā🔽nāma atibhīrukā honti. Ye imasmiṃ gandhamādanapabbate viharanti, tepi maṃ disvā na
analyzed: aham vāka cīram pariharim bhīrū kimpurisā ati mahā rāja migā tāva tiṭṭhantu kimpurisā  nāma atibhīrukāḥ honti ye imasmin gandhamādana pabbate viharanti te pi mam disvā na
translated: the bark-cloth: since the time I took up the bark-cloth garment. The timid kinnara: Great king, let the deer alone; the kinnara🔽are extremely timid. Even those who live on this Gandhamadana Mountain, when they see me, are not afraid; but we go about together,

original: uttasanti, atha kho mayaṃ aññamaññaṃ sammodamānā gacchāma. Utrāsanti migā mamanti
analyzed: uttasanti atha kho mayam aññamaññam sammodamānāḥ gacchāmaḥ utrāsanti migāḥ mamanti
translated: over mountains and through the forest. But why is it that the deer are afraid of me?

original: mamaṃ disvā migā utrāseyyuṃ, kena kāraṇena tvaṃ maṃ saddahāpessasīti dīpeti.
analyzed: disvā migāḥ utrāseyyum kena kāraṇena tvam mamam saddahāpessasi iti dīpeti
translated: “If they see me, the deer will flee. For what reason will you believe me?”

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “mayā imaṃ niraparādhaṃ vijjhitvā musāvādo kathito, saccameva kathayissāmī”ti cintetvā āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā mayā imam niraparādham vijjhitvā musāvādaḥ kathitaḥ saccam eva kathayissāmi iti cintetvā āha
translated: Hearing this, the king thought, “I have shot this innocent deer and told a lie. I will tell the truth.” So he said:

original: “Na taṃ tasa migo sāma, kiṃ tāhaṃ alikaṃ bhaṇe;
analyzed: na tam migaḥ sāma kim tā aham alikam bhaṇe
translated: “Not that the deer was frightened, but that I was frightened;

original: Kodhalobhābhibhūtāhaṃ, usuṃ te taṃ avassaji”nti.
analyzed: kodha lobha abhibhūtā aham usum te tam avassajinti
translated: Overcome by anger and greed, I shot you with my arrow.”

original: Tattha na taṃ tasāti na taṃ disvā migo tasa, na bhītoti attho. Kiṃ tāhanti kiṃ te🔽evaṃ kalyāṇadassanassa santike ahaṃ alikaṃ bhaṇissāmi. Kodhalobhābhibhūtāhanti kodhena🔽ca lobhena ca abhibhūto hutvā ahaṃ. So hi paṭhamameva migesu uppannena kodhena “mige🔽vijjhissāmī”ti dhanuṃ āropetvā ṭhito pacchā bodhisattaṃ disvā tassa devatādīsu aññatarabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tattha na tam tasāti na tam disvā migo tasa na attho kim te  evam kalyāṇa dassanassa santike aham alikam bhaṇissāmi kodha lobha abhibhūtā ahanti kodhena  ca lobhena ca abhibhūtaḥ hutvā aham saḥ hi paṭhamam eva migesu uppannena kodhena mige  vijjhissāmi iti dhanum āropetvā ṭhitaḥ pacchā bodhisattam disvā tassa devatā ādīsu aññatara bhāvam
translated: Herein, not that the deer was frightened means not that the deer was frightened on seeing me, but that I was frightened. What will I say?

original: ajānanto “pucchissāmi na”nti lobhaṃ uppādesi, tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: a jānantaḥ pucchissāmi nanti lobham uppādesi tasmai evam āha
translated: Overcome by anger and greed means having become overcome by anger and greed. For he, having first taken up his bow and stood there thinking, “I will shoot a deer,” on seeing the Bodhisatta later on, not knowing that he was one of the gods or the like, aroused greed, thinking, “I will ask him.” Therefore he said, “Overcome by anger and greed, I shot you with my arrow.”

original: Evañca pana vatvā “nāyaṃ suvaṇṇasāmo imasmiṃ araññe ekakova vasissati, ñātakehipissa bhavitabbaṃ, pucchissāmi na”nti cintetvā itaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā na ayam suvaṇṇasāmaḥ imasmim araññe ekakaḥ uva vasissati ñātakehi pi issa bhavitabbam pucchissāmi na nti cintetvā itaram gātham āha
translated: Having said this, he thought to himself, “This golden-hued deer will not live alone in the forest. He must have relatives. I will ask him.” So he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Kuto nu sāma āgamma, kassa vā pahito tuvaṃ;
analyzed: kutas nu sāma āgamma kassa vā pahitaḥ tuvam
translated: “From what place hast thou come, Sāma? By whom wast thou sent?

original: ‘Udahāro nadiṃ gaccha’, āgato migasammata”nti.
analyzed: uda hāraḥ nadim gaccha āgataḥ
translated: ‘Go to the river for water,’ thus hast thou come, O deer approved of all.

original: Tattha sāmāti mahāsattaṃ ālapati. Āgammāti kuto desā imaṃ vanaṃ āgamitvā “amhākaṃ
analyzed: tattha sāma iti mahāsattam ālapati āgamma iti kutas desāḥ imam vanam āgamitvā amhākam
translated: Herein, Sāma is an address to the Great Being. From what place hast thou come? From what country hast thou come to this forest?

original: udahāro udakaṃ āharituṃ nadiṃ gacchā”ti kassa vā pahitokena puggalena pesito hutvā
analyzed: uda hāraḥ udakam āharitum nadim gacchāti kassa vā pahitokena puggalena pesitaḥ hutvā
translated: By whom wast thou sent? By what person wast thou sent, saying, “Go to the river for water”?

original: tuvaṃ imaṃ migasammataṃ āgatoti attho.
analyzed: tuvam imam miga sammatam āgato ti attho
translated: Thus hast thou come, O deer approved of all. The meaning is, thus hast thou come, O deer approved of all men.

original: So tassa kathaṃ sutvā mahantaṃ dukkhavedanaṃ adhivāsetvā mukhena lohitaṃ chaḍḍetvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ tassa katham sutvā mahantam dukkha vedanam adhivāsetvā mukhena lohitam chaḍḍetvā gātham āha
translated: Having heard his words, the Bodhisatta endured great pain, spat blood from his mouth, and spoke the third stanza:

original: “Andhā mātāpitā mayhaṃ, te bharāmi brahāvane;
analyzed: andhāḥ mātā pitā te bharāmi brahā vane
translated: “My father and my mother are blind, and I support them in the forest.

original: Tesāhaṃ udakāhāro, āgato migasammata”nti.
analyzed: udaka āhāraḥ āgataḥ
translated: For them I go to bring the water, thus have I come, O deer approved of all.

original: Tattha bharāmīti mūlaphalādīni āharitvā posemi.
analyzed: tattha bharāmi iti mūla phala ādīni āharitvā posemi
translated: Herein, I support them means I nourish them by bringing them roots, fruits, and so forth.

original: Evañca pana vatvā mahāsatto mātāpitaro ārabbha vilapanto āha –
analyzed: evañca pana vatvā mahāsattaḥ mātā pitaraḥ ārabbha vilapantaḥ āha
translated: Having said this, the Great Being, lamenting his parents, said:

original: “Atthi nesaṃ usāmattaṃ, atha sāhassa jīvitaṃ;
analyzed: atthi nesam usāmattam atha sāhassa jīvitaṃ
translated: “They have not yet had their fill, and yet their lives are at an end.

original: Udakassa alābhena, maññe andhā marissare.
analyzed: udakassa alābhena maññe andhā marissare
translated: I think that they will die of thirst, not having obtained water.”

original: “Na me idaṃ tathā dukkhaṃ, labbhā hi pumunā idaṃ;
analyzed: na me idam tathā dukkham labbhā hi pumunā idam
translated: “This is not so much my sorrow, for this is the lot of man;

original: Yañca ammaṃ na passāmi, taṃ me dukkhataraṃ ito.
analyzed: yam ca ammam na passāmi tam me dukkhataram itas
translated: But that I shall not see my mother, that is my greatest sorrow.

original: “Na me idaṃ tathā dukkhaṃ, labbhā hi pumunā idaṃ;
analyzed: na me idam tathā dukkham labbhā hi pumunā idam
translated: “This is not so much my sorrow, for this is the lot of man;

original: Yañca tātaṃ na passāmi, taṃ me dukkhataraṃ ito.
analyzed: yat ca tātam na passāmi tam me dukkhataram itas
translated: But that I shall not see my father, that is my greatest sorrow.

original: “Sā nūna kapaṇā ammā, cirarattāya rucchati;
analyzed: sā nūna kapaṇā ammā cira rattāya rucchati
translated: “Surely that poor mother of mine will die of grief after a long time,

original: Aḍḍharatteva ratte vā, nadīva avasucchati.
analyzed: aḍḍharattā iva ratte vā nadī iva avasucchati
translated: As if it were at midnight or at dawn, the river has suddenly dried up.

original: “So nūna kapaṇo tāto, cirarattāya rucchati;
analyzed: saḥ nūna kapaṇaḥ tātaḥ cira rattāya rucchati
translated: “Surely that poor father of mine will die of grief after a long time,

original: Aḍḍharatteva ratte vā, nadīva avasucchati.
analyzed: aḍḍharattā iva ratte vā nadī iva avasucchati
translated: As if it were at midnight or at dawn, the river has suddenly dried up.

original: “Uṭṭhānapādacariyāya, pādasambāhanassa ca;
analyzed: uṭṭhāna pāda cariyāya pāda sambāhanassa ca
translated: “By rising early and by walking on foot, by the rubbing of his feet,

original: Sāma tātavilapantā, hiṇḍissanti brahāvane.
analyzed: sāma tāta vilapantāḥ hiṇḍissanti brahā vane
translated: Lamenting, ‘Mother! Father!’ he will wander in the great forest.

original: Idampi dutiyaṃ sallaṃ, kampeti hadayaṃ mamaṃ;
analyzed: idam pi dutiyam sallam kampeti hadayam mamam
translated: This is the second dart that pierces my heart,

original: Yañca andhe na passāmi, maññe hissāmi jīvita”nti.
analyzed: yañca andhe na passāmi maññe hissāmi jīvitanti
translated: I do not see any hope for them, I think they will die.”

original: Tattha usāmattanti bhojanamattaṃ. “Usā”ti hi bhojanassa nāmaṃ tassa ca atthitāya.
analyzed: tattha usā mattanti bhojana mattam usā ti hi bhojanassa nāmam tassa ca atthitāya
translated: Herein, just enough to live on means just enough food. For “usā” is a name for food, and because of its presence

analyzed: jīvitanti cha divasa mattam jīvitanti attho idam āharitvā ṭhapitam phala aphalam
translated: one thousand days of life means six days of life. The meaning is that he said this referring to the fruit that he had brought and set aside.

original: sandhāyāha. Atha vā usāti usmā. Tenetaṃ dasseti – tesaṃ sarīre usmāmattaṃ atthi,🔽atha mayā ābhatena phalāphalena sāhassa jīvitaṃ atthīti. Marissareti marissantīti
analyzed: sandhāya āha atha vā usā ati usmā tena itam dasseti tesam sarīre usmāmattam atthi  atha mayā ābhatena phalāphalena sāhassa jīvitam atthi iti marissara iti marissanti iti
translated: Or alternatively, usā means heat. By this he shows that there is just enough heat in their bodies

analyzed: maññāmi pumunā ati purisena evarūpam hi dukkham purisena labhitabbam eva ati attho cira rattāya
translated: to live for one thousand days. They will die means I think they will die. By a man means the meaning is that such suffering can be experienced only by a man. For a long time

analyzed: rucchati iti cira rattam rodissati aḍḍha ratte vāti majjhima ratte vā ratte vāti pacchima ratte

analyzed: vā avasucchati iti kunnadī viya sussissati iti attho uṭṭhāna pāda cariyāya ati mahā rāja
translated: He will dry up means the meaning is that he will dry up like a small stream. By rising up and walking about means, Great King,

analyzed: aham divā api dve tayaḥ vāre uṭṭhāya attanaḥ uṭṭhāna vīriyena tesam pāda cariyaṃ  karomi hattha pāde sambāhāmi idāni mam a disvā mamatthāya te parihīna cakkhukā sāmatātā ati
translated: I, rising up at night and day, two or three times, by my own energy,🔽do the duties of a slave to them, I wash their feet, I rub their hands and feet, now they will be lost, they will wander about in this forest region,
