analyzed: vilapantā kaṇṭakehi vijjhiyamānā viya imasmin vana padese hiṇḍissanti vicarissanti iti
translated: as if they were being pierced with thorns, weeping, “Our dear brother!”

original: attho. Dutiyaṃ sallanti paṭhamaviddhavisapītasallato sataguṇena sahassaguṇena satasahassaguṇena
analyzed: dutiyam sallanti paṭhama viddha visa pīta sallato sataguṇena sahassa guṇena sata sahassa guṇena
translated: The second dart is a hundred times, a thousand times, a hundred thousand times more painful than the first dart, the dart of poison drunk by the bitten man.

analyzed: dukkhataram idam dutiyam tesam a dassana soka sallam
translated: The second dart is the dart of grief at not seeing them.

analyzed: rājā tassa vilāpam sutvā ayam accantam brahmacārī dhamme ṭhitaḥ mātā pitaraḥ bharati

analyzed: idāni evam dukkha ppattaḥ api tesam yeva vilapati evam guṇa sampanne nāma mayā aparādhaḥ

analyzed: kataḥ katham nu kho imam samassāseyyanti cintetvā niraye paccana kāle rajjam kim

analyzed: karissati iminā paṭijaggita niyāmena iva assa mātā pitaraḥ paṭijaggissāmi imassa maraṇam pi
translated: I will look after him in the same way as his parents do. His death will be like his not dying.”

original: amaraṇaṃ viya bhavissatī”ti sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā āha –
analyzed: amaraṇam viya bhavissati iti sanniṭṭhānam katvā āha
translated: After making this decision, he said:

translated: “Do not weep so much, Sāmā, you who are so lovely to behold.

translated: I will be a worker and support you in the great forest.

original: “Issatthe casmi kusalo, daḷhadhammoti vissuto;
analyzed: casmi kusalaḥ daḷha dhammaḥ ti vissutaḥ
translated: “I am skilled in the art of archery, and I am well known as a strong man.

original: Ahaṃ kammakaro hutvā, bharissaṃ te brahāvane.
analyzed: aham kamma karaḥ hutvā bharissam te brahā vane
translated: I will be a worker and support you in the great forest.

original: “Migānaṃ vighāsamanvesaṃ, vanamūlaphalāni ca;
analyzed: migānam vighāsam anvesam vana mūla phalāni ca
translated: “Searching for food for the deer and for forest roots and fruits,

original: Ahaṃ kammakaro hutvā, bharissaṃ te brahāvane.

translated: I will be a worker and support you in the great forest.

translated: I will support you in that way, as your mother and father did.”

analyzed: tattha bharissam te iti te tava mātā pitaraḥ bharissāmi migānan ti sīha ādīnam migānam

analyzed: vighāsam anvesantaḥ idam saḥ thūla thūle mige vadhitvā madhura maṃsena

analyzed: tava mātā pitaraḥ bharissāmi iti vatvā mā mahā rāja amhe nissāya pāṇa vadham kari iti

analyzed: saḥ hi heṭṭhā ettakam kathentaḥ nirassāsaḥ viya ahosi idāni panassa visavegena madditā  bhavaṅga citta santati hadaya rūpam nissāya pavatti kathā mukham pihitam
translated: For he had been speaking so long that he was exhausted. But now, as if he had been struck by a poisoned arrow,🔽the current of his life-continuum consciousness ceased to flow, and the flow of his speech was interrupted. He closed his mouth,

original: Te pana niruddhā, sarīraṃ thaddhaṃ jātaṃ. So taṃ disvā “niruddho dāni sāmo”ti sokaṃ🔽saddhāretuṃ asakkonto ubho hatthe matthake ṭhapetvā mahāsaddena paridevi. Tamatthaṃ

Expounding this matter, the Teacher related this story of the past.

original: “Āguṃ kira mahārāja, akari kammadukkaṭaṃ;
analyzed: āgum kira mahā rāja akari kamma dukkaṭam
translated: “A crime has been committed, sire, a wicked deed has been done.

original: Adūsakā pitāputtā, tayo ekūsunā hatā.
analyzed: a dūsakā pitāputtā tayo ekūsunā hatā
translated: Three people have been killed by one arrow: a father, a son, and one who was guiltless.

original: “Ehi taṃ anusikkhāmi, yathā te sugatī siyā;
analyzed: ehi tam anusikkhāmi yathā te sugatī siyā
translated: “Come, I will instruct you how you may go to a good bourne.

original: Dhammenandhe vane posa, maññehaṃ sugatī tayā”ti.
analyzed: dhammena andhe vane posa maññā iham sugatī tayā ati
translated: Feed the blind in the Dhammenadha Wood, and I think you will go to a good bourne.”

original: Tattha raññovāti raññoyeva. Āguṃ kirāti mahārāja, tvaṃ mahāparādhaṃ mahāpāpaṃ akari.
analyzed: tattha āgum kirāti mahā rāja tvam mahā aparādham mahā pāpam akari
translated: Herein, the king himself is the king’s own self. A crime has been committed, sire: a great offence, a great crime has been done by you, sire.

analyzed: dukkaṭanti yam katam dukkaṭam hoti tam lāmaka kammam akari adūsakā ati niddosā pitāputtā ti

analyzed: mātā ca pitā ca putto ca ime tayaḥ janāḥ eka ausunā hatā tasmin hi hate tad paṭibaddhā
translated: these three people, mother, father, and son, have been killed by one arrow. For when he was killed,

analyzed: tassa mātā pitaraḥ api hatā ava honti anusikkhāmi iti sikkhāpemi anusāsāmi posā ati sāmassa
translated: his mother and father were killed too, as if they were bound to him. I will instruct: I will teach, I will instruct. Feed:

analyzed: ṭhāne ṭhatvā sineham paccupaṭṭhāpetvā sāmaḥ viya te ubho andhe posehi maññā iham su gatī
translated: standing in the place of a master, and having set up affection for them as if for a blind man, feed them as if they were a blind man. I think you will go to a good bourne:

original: tayāti evaṃ tayā sugatiyeva gantabbā bhavissatīti ahaṃ maññāmi.
analyzed: tayā ti evam tayā sugatiyā iva gantabbā bhavissati iti aham maññāmi
translated: I think that in this way you will have to go to a good bourne.

original: So devatāya vacanaṃ sutvā “ahaṃ kira tassa mātāpitaro posetvā saggaṃ gamissāmī”ti
analyzed: saḥ devatāya vacanam sutvā aham kira tassa mātā pitaro posetvā saggam gamissāmi iti
translated: Hearing the words of the deity, the king thought to himself, “So it is, then. By supporting the parents of the youth, I shall go to heaven.”

original: saddahitvā “kiṃ me rajjena, teyeva posessāmī”ti daḷhaṃ adhiṭṭhāya balavaparidevaṃ
analyzed: saddahitvā kim me rajjena teyā iva posessāmi iti daḷham adhiṭṭhāya balava paridevam
translated: And he said, “What need have I of sovereignty? I will support them.” And he made a firm resolve.

original: paridevanto sokaṃ tanukaṃ katvā “suvaṇṇasāmo mato bhavissatī”ti nānāpupphehi tassa
analyzed: paridevantaḥ sokam tanukam katvā suvaṇṇa sāmaḥ mataḥ bhavissati iti nānā pupphehi tassa
translated: And he wept and lamented. But he dried his tears, and with many flowers he worshipped the body of the youth,

original: sarīraṃ pūjetvā udakena siñcitvā tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā
analyzed: sarīram pūjetvā udakena siñcitvā tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā
translated: sprinkling it with water. Then he walked around it three times, keeping it on his right, and he worshipped it at the four corners.

original: tena pūritaṃ udakaghaṭaṃ ādāya domanassappatto dakkhiṇadisābhimukho agamāsi. Tamatthaṃ
analyzed: tena pūritam udaka ghaṭam ādāya domanassa pattaḥ dakkhiṇa disā abhimukhaḥ agamāsi tam attham
translated: And taking the water-pot which he had filled, he went away in a state of great dejection, in a southerly direction.

original: pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: Expounding this matter, the Master said:

original: “Sa rājā paridevitvā, bahuṃ kāruññasañhitaṃ;
analyzed: sa rājā paridevitvā bahum kāruñña sañhitam
translated: “The king, having wept and lamented,🔽And having filled a water-pot with water,

original: Udakakumbhamādāya, pakkāmi dakkhiṇāmukho”ti.
analyzed: udaka kumbham ādāya pakkāmi dakkhiṇā mukho ti
translated: Went away in a southerly direction.”

original: Pakatiyāpi mahāthāmo rājā pānīyaghaṭaṃ ādāya gacchanto assamapadaṃ koṭṭento viya
analyzed: pakatiyā api mahāthāmaḥ rājā pānīya ghaṭam ādāya gacchantaḥ assama padam koṭṭentaḥ viya
translated: Now the king was a man of great strength. As he went along, carrying the water-pot, he seemed to cleave the earth with his tread.

original: pavisitvā dukūlapaṇḍitassa paṇṇasālādvāraṃ sampāpuṇi. Dukūlapaṇḍito anto nisinnova
analyzed: pavisitvā dukūlapaṇḍitassa paṇṇa sālā dvāram sampāpuṇi dukūlapaṇḍitaḥ antar nisinnaḥ uva
translated: And he entered the hermitage, and came to the door of the leaf-hut of Dukūla the Wise. Dukūla the Wise was sitting within the hut,

original: tassa padasaddaṃ sutvā “nāyaṃ sāmassa padasaddo, kassa nu kho”ti pucchanto gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tassa pada saddam sutvā na ayam sāmassa pada saddo kassa nu kha iti pucchantaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: On hearing the sound of his footsteps, he thought: “This is not the sound of my master’s footsteps. Whose are they?” And he asked two questions:

original: “Kassa nu eso padasaddo, manussasseva āgato;
analyzed: kassa nu eso pada saddaḥ manussassa iva āgataḥ
translated: “Whose are these footsteps that come, the footsteps of a human being?

original: Neso sāmassa nigghoso, ko nu tvamasi mārisa.
analyzed: na isaḥ sāmassa nigghosaḥ kaḥ nu tvam asi mārisa
translated: This is not the voice of my master. Who are you, sir?”

original: “Santañhi sāmo vajati, santaṃ pādāni neyati;
analyzed: santam hi sāmaḥ vajati santam pādāni na iyati
translated: “For he who is calm walks, and he who is calm sets his feet down.

original: Neso sāmassa nigghoso, ko nu tvamasi mārisā”ti.
analyzed: na iso sāmassa nigghosaḥ kaḥ nu tvam asi mārisa iti
translated: This is not the voice of my master. Who are you, sir?”

original: Tattha manussassevāti nāyaṃ sīhabyagghadīpiyakkhanāgakinnarānaṃ, āgacchato pana manussassevāyaṃ
analyzed: tattha manussassa iva ati na ayam sīha byaggha dīpi yakkha nāga kinnarānam āgacchataḥ pana manussassa iva ayam
translated: Herein, the footsteps of a human being: this is not the footsteps of a lion, tiger, leopard, elephant, or kinnara, but the footsteps of a human being who is coming. This is not the voice of my master.

original: padasaddo, neso sāmassāti. Santaṃ hīti upasamayuttaṃ eva. Vajatīti caṅkamati. Neyatīti patiṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: pada saddaḥ sāmassa ati santam hi iti upasama yuttam eva vajati iti caṅkamati na iyati iti patiṭṭhāpeti
translated: For he who is calm: endowed with calm. Walks: he walks up and down. Sets his feet down: he places his feet down.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “sacāhaṃ attano rājabhāvaṃ akathetvā ‘mayā tumhākaṃ putto mārito’ti
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā sacā aham attanaḥ rāja bhāvam a kathetvā mayā tumhākam putto māritaḥ iti
translated: On hearing this, the king thought: “If I do not tell him my own rank and say ‘I have killed your son,’

original: vakkhāmi, ime kujjhitvā mayā saddhiṃ pharusaṃ kathessanti. Evaṃ me tesu kodho uppajjissati,
analyzed: vakkhāmi ime kujjhitvā mayā saddhim pharusam kathessanti evam me tesu kodhaḥ uppajjissati
translated: they will be angry and will speak harshly to me. In that case anger will arise in me,

original: atha ne viheṭhessāmi, taṃ mama akusalaṃ bhavissati, ‘rājā’ti pana vutte abhāyantā
analyzed: atha ne viheṭhessāmi tam mama akusalam bhavissati rājā ati pana vutte abhāyantā
translated: “If I do not, it will be my misfortune. But if I say that I am a king, they will not believe me.🔽Therefore I will first tell them that I am a king.”

original: nāma natthi, tasmā rājabhāvaṃ tāva kathessāmī”ti cintetvā pānīyamāḷake pānīyaghaṭaṃ
analyzed: nāma na atthi tasmā rāja bhāvam tāva kathessāmi iti cintetvā pānīya māḷake pānīya ghaṭam
translated: So he placed a water-pot in the drinking-hall,

original: ṭhapetvā paṇṇasālādvāre ṭhatvā āha –
analyzed: ṭhapetvā paṇṇasālā dvāre ṭhatvā āha
translated: and standing at the door of the leaf-hut, he said:🔽“I am the king of Kasi,

original: “Rājāhamasmi kāsīnaṃ, pīḷiyakkhoti maṃ vidū;
analyzed: rājā aham asmi kāsīnam mama vidū
translated: and they call me Piliyakkha.🔽Because of my greed I have left my kingdom

original: Lobhā raṭṭhaṃ pahitvāna, migamesaṃ carāmahaṃ.
analyzed: lobhāḥ raṭṭham pahitvāna migamesam carām aham
translated: and am wandering about hunting deer.🔽“I am skilled in archery,

original: “Issatthe casmi kusalo, daḷhadhammoti vissuto;
analyzed: casmi kusalaḥ daḷha dhammaḥ ti vissutaḥ
translated: and I am known as Dalhadhamma.🔽Even an elephant would not escape

original: Nāgopi me na mucceyya, āgato usupātana”nti.
analyzed: nāgaḥ upi me na mucceyya āgataḥ usu pātananti
translated: if it came within the range of my arrows.”

original: Dukūlapaṇḍitopi tena saddhiṃ paṭisanthāraṃ karonto āha –🔽“Svāgataṃ te mahārāja, atho te adurāgataṃ;
analyzed: dukūlapaṇḍitaḥ api tena saddhim paṭisanthāram karontaḥ āha  svāgatam te mahā rāja atho te adurāgatam
translated: The wise Dukūla, in welcoming him, said:🔽“Welcome to you, great king,🔽and may you have a safe return.

original: Issarosi anuppatto, yaṃ idhatthi pavedaya.
analyzed: issarā asi an uppattaḥ yam idha atthi pavedaya
translated: You are the lord, you have come;🔽tell me what you want.🔽“Here are tinduka fruits,

original: “Tindukāni piyālāni, madhuke kāsumāriyo;
analyzed: tindukāni piyālāni madhuke
translated: piyal fruits, madhuka fruits, and kāsumāri fruits;

original: Phalāni khuddakappāni, bhuñja rāja varaṃ varaṃ.
analyzed: phalāni khudda kappāni bhuñja rāja varam varam
translated: eat the best of these fruits, O king.”🔽“Here is cool water

original: “Idampi pānīyaṃ sītaṃ, ābhataṃ girigabbharā;
analyzed: idam pi pānīyam giri gabbharā
translated: brought from the mountain caves;

original: Tato piva mahārāja, sace tvaṃ abhikaṅkhasī”ti;
analyzed: tatas piva mahā rāja sace tvam abhikaṅkhasi iti
translated: Then drink, great king, if you so wish.”

original: Tassattho sattigumbajātake kathito. Idha pana “girigabbharā”ti migasammataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Sā hi nadī girigabbharā nikkhantattā “girigabbharā” tveva jātā.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ sattigumba jātake kathitaḥ idha pana girigabbharā ti miga sammatam sandhāya vuttam sā hi nadī girigabbharā nikkhanta ttā girigabbharā tu eva jātā
translated: The meaning of this verse has been told in the Sattigumbajātaka. Here, however, it is said with reference to the “mountain-cavern” which is accepted by the deer. For that river is called “mountain-cavern” because it flows out of a mountain-cavern.

original: Evaṃ tena paṭisanthāre kate rājā “putto vo mayā mārito”ti paṭhamameva vattuṃ ayuttaṃ, ajānanto viya kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpetvā kathessāmī”ti cintetvā āha –
analyzed: evam tena paṭisanthāre kate rājā puttaḥ vaḥ mayā māritaḥ iti paṭhamam eva vattum ayuttam a jānantaḥ viya katham samuṭṭhāpetvā kathessāmi iti cintetvā āha
translated: When the hospitality was thus offered, the king thought: “It is not proper for me to say at once: ‘Your son has been killed by me.’ As if I did not know, I will begin a conversation and then tell it.” He said:

original: “Nālaṃ andhā vane daṭṭhuṃ, ko nu vo phalamāhari;
analyzed: na alam andhāḥ vane daṭṭhum kaḥ nu vaḥ phalam āhari
translated: “Blind men cannot see in the forest. Who has brought you the fruit?

original: Anandhassevayaṃ sammā, nivāpo mayha khāyatī”ti.🔽Tattha nālanti tumhe andhā imasmiṃ vane kiñci daṭṭhuṃ na samatthā. Ko nu vo phalamāharīti
analyzed: sammā nivāpaḥ khāyati iti  tattha na alanti tumhe andhāḥ imasmim vane kiñci daṭṭhum na samatthā kaḥ nu vo phalam āhari iti
translated: It seems to me that this is a well-arranged storehouse for the blind.”🔽Herein, blind men means: you are blind men, unable to see anything in this forest. Who has brought you the fruit?

original: ko nu tumhākaṃ imāni phalāphalāni āhari. Nivāpoti ayaṃ sammā nayena upāyena kāraṇena
analyzed: kaḥ nu tumhākam imāni phalāphalāni ayam sammā nayena upāyena kāraṇena
translated: Who has brought you these fruits and other things? Storehouse means: this is a well-arranged storehouse by a good method, by a reason,

original: kato khāditabbayuttakānaṃ parisuddhānaṃ phalāphalānaṃ nivāpo sannicayo anandhassa
analyzed: kataḥ khāditabba yuttakānam parisuddhānam phala aphalānam nivāpaḥ sannicayaḥ an andhassa
translated: a store, a collection, of fruits and roots that are fit to be eaten and are pure, and which are not reserved for another.

original: viya mayhaṃ khāyati paññāyati upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: viya mayham khāyati paññāyati upaṭṭhāti
translated: The heap, the store, the collection of fruits and roots and so on, which are fit to be eaten, is seen, is known, is manifest to me, as if it were in front of me.

original: Taṃ sutvā dukūlapaṇḍito “mahārāja, na mayaṃ phalāphalāni āharāma, putto pana no āharatī”ti dassento gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā dukūlapaṇḍitaḥ mahā rāja na mayam phala aphalāni āharāma putto pana no āharati iti dassentaḥ gāthā dvayam āha
translated: Hearing this, Dukūlapaṇḍita, in order to show that he did not bring the fruits and roots, but his son did, spoke two stanzas:

original: “Daharo yuvā nātibrahā, sāmo kalyāṇadassano;
analyzed: daharaḥ yuvā na ati brahā sāmaḥ kalyāṇa dassanaḥ
translated: “A youth, young, not tall, dark, of pleasant appearance,

original: Dīghassa kesā asitā, atho sūnaggavellitā.
analyzed: dīghassa kesāḥ asitāḥ atho sūnagga vellitā
translated: With long, black, curly hair,

original: “So have phalamāharitvā, ito ādāya kamaṇḍaluṃ;
analyzed: saḥ have phalam āharitvā itas ādāya kamaṇḍalum
translated: “Having brought the fruits, taking the water-pot,

original: Nadiṃ gato udahāro, maññe na dūramāgato”ti.
analyzed: nadim gataḥ uda hāraḥ maññe na dūram āgato ti
translated: Having gone to the river, he is not far from here, I think.”

original: Tattha nātibrahāti nātidīgho nātirasso. Sūnaggavellitāti sūnasaṅkhātāya maṃsakoṭṭanapotthaniyā
analyzed: tattha na ati brahā ati na ati dīghaḥ na ati rassaḥ sūnagga vellitā ati sūna saṅkhātāya maṃsa koṭṭana potthaniyā
translated: Herein, not tall means not too tall, not too short. Curly hair means bent like the tip of the nose.

original: aggaṃ viya vinatā. Kamaṇḍalunti ghaṭaṃ. Na dūramāgatoti idāni na dūraṃ āgato, āsannaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: aggam viya vinatā kamaṇḍalum ti ghaṭam na dūram āgataḥ iti idāni na dūram āgataḥ āsanna ṭhānam
translated: Water-pot means a pot. Not far from here means not far from here now, he will have come to a place near here.

original: āgato bhavissatīti maññāmīti attho.
analyzed: āgataḥ bhavissati iti maññāmi iti attho
translated: This is the meaning.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā āha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā āha
translated: Hearing this, the king said:

original: “Ahaṃ taṃ avadhiṃ sāmaṃ, yo tuyhaṃ paricārako;
analyzed: aham tam avadhim sāmam yaḥ tuyham paricārako
translated: “I killed him, I killed the one who served you,

original: Yaṃ kumāraṃ pavedetha, sāmaṃ kalyāṇadassanaṃ.
analyzed: yam kumāram pavedetha sāmam kalyāṇa dassanam
translated: The boy whom you may tell, the one who is lovely to behold.”

original: “Dīghassa kesā asitā, atho sūnaggavellitā;
analyzed: dīghassa kesāḥ asitāḥ atho sūnagga vellitā
translated: “His hair is long, unkempt, and matted,

original: Tesu lohitalittesu, seti sāmo mahā hato”ti.
analyzed: tesu lohita littesu sa iti sāmaḥ mahā
translated: And on his body, covered with blood, lies the slain Sāma.”

original: Tattha avadhinti visapītena sarena vijjhitvā māresiṃ. Pavedethāti kathetha. Setīti migasammatānadītīre vālukāpuline sayati.
analyzed: tattha visa pītena sarena vijjhitvā māresim pavedetha ati kathetha sa iti iti migasammatā nadī tīre vālukā puline sayati
translated: Herein, I killed him means I killed him by piercing him with a poisoned arrow. You may tell means you may speak. Lies means he lies on a sand-bank on the bank of the river called Migasammatā.

original: Dukūlapaṇḍitassa pana avidūre pārikāya paṇṇasālā hoti. Sā tattha nisinnāva rañño
analyzed: dukūlapaṇḍitassa pana avidūre pārikāya paṇṇa sālā hoti sā tattha nisinnā ava raññaḥ
translated: But not far from Dukūlapaṇḍita there was a leaf-hut of Pārikā. Sitting there,

original: vacanaṃ sutvā taṃ pavattiṃ sotukāmā attano paṇṇasālato nikkhamitvā rajjukasaññāya
analyzed: vacanam sutvā tam pavattim sotu kāmāḥ attanaḥ paṇṇa sālataḥ nikkhamitvā rajjuka saññāya
translated: she heard the king’s words. Desiring to hear the news, she came out of her leaf-hut and, thinking it was a rope,

original: dukūlapaṇḍitassa santikaṃ gantvā āha –
analyzed: dukūlapaṇḍitassa santikam gantvā āha
translated: she went to Dukūlapaṇḍita and said:

original: “Kena dukūla mantesi, ‘hato sāmo’ti vādinā;
analyzed: kena dukūla mantesi hataḥ sāma uti vādinā
translated: “By whom was Dukūla killed, the one who said, ‘Sāma is dead’?

original: ‘Hato sāmo’ti sutvāna, hadayaṃ me pavedhati.
analyzed: sutvāna hadayam me
translated: Having heard, ‘Sāma is dead,’ my heart is torn asunder.”

original: “Assatthasseva taruṇaṃ, pavāḷaṃ māluteritaṃ;
analyzed: taruṇam pavāḷam māluta īritam
translated: “By a young Assattha tree, a coral tree shaken by the wind,

original: ‘Hato sāmo’ti sutvāna, hadayaṃ me pavedhatī”ti.
analyzed: hataḥ sāma uti sutvāna hadayam me pavedhati iti
translated: Having heard, ‘Sāma is dead,’ my heart is torn asunder.”

original: Tattha vādināti “mayā sāmo hato”ti vadantena. Pavāḷanti pallavaṃ. Māluteritanti vātena pahaṭaṃ.
analyzed: tattha vādinā ati mayā sāmaḥ hataḥ iti vadantena pavāḷanti pallavam vātena pahaṭam
translated: Herein, the speaker is the one who said, “I killed Sāmā.” The creeper is a tendril. The wind-tossed is shaken by the wind.

original: Dukūlapaṇḍito ovadanto āha –
analyzed: dukūlapaṇḍitaḥ ovadantaḥ āha
translated: The Wise One of the Dukūla spoke this verse of advice:

original: “Pārike kāsirājāyaṃ, so sāmaṃ migasammate;
analyzed: pārike kāsi rājā ayam saḥ sāmam miga sammate
translated: “To the King of Kāsi, Pāri, this Sāmā, a deer, was dear;

original: Kodhasā usunā vijjhi, tassa mā pāpamicchimhā”ti.
analyzed: kodhasā usunā vijjhi tassa mā pāpam icchimha ati
translated: He pierced her with an arrow out of anger. We do not wish her harm.”

original: Tattha migasammateti migasammatānadītīre. Kodhasāti migesu uppannena kodhena. Mā pāpamicchimhāti tassa mayaṃ ubhopi pāpaṃ mā icchimhā.
analyzed: tattha migasammatā iti migasammatā nadī tīre kodhasā ati migesu uppannena kodhena mā pāpam icchimha ati tassa mayam ubho pi pāpam mā icchimha
translated: Herein, a deer was dear means on the bank of the deer-approved river. Out of anger means out of anger towards the deer. We do not wish her harm means we both do not wish her harm.

original: Puna pārikā āha –
analyzed: puna pārikā āha
translated: Again, Pāri spoke this verse:

original: “Kicchā laddho piyo putto, yo andhe abharī vane;
analyzed: kicchā laddhaḥ piyaḥ puttaḥ yaḥ andhe abharī vane
translated: “A dear son, hard-won, whom I brought to the blind in the forest,

original: Taṃ ekaputtaṃ ghātimhi, kathaṃ cittaṃ na kopaye”ti.
analyzed: tam eka puttam ghātimhi katham cittam na kopayeti
translated: I have killed my only son. How can I not be angry?”

original: Tattha ghātimhīti ghātake.
analyzed: tattha ghātimhi iti ghātake
translated: Herein, I have killed means I have killed the killer.

original: Dukūlapaṇḍito āha –
analyzed: āha
translated: The Wise One of the Dukūla spoke this verse:

original: “Kicchā laddho piyo putto, yo andhe abharī vane;
analyzed: kicchā laddhaḥ piyaḥ puttaḥ yaḥ andhe abharī vane
translated: “A dear son, hard-won, whom I brought to the blind in the forest,

original: Taṃ ekaputtaṃ ghātimhi, akkodhaṃ āhu paṇḍitā”ti.
analyzed: tam eka puttam ghātimhi akkodham āhu paṇḍita ati
translated: I have killed my only son. The wise say non-anger is best.”

original: Tattha akkodhanti kodho nāma nirayasaṃvattaniko, tasmā taṃ kodhaṃ akatvā puttaghātakamhi akkodho eva kattabboti paṇḍitā āhu kathenti.
analyzed: tattha akkodhanti kodhaḥ nāma niraya saṃvattaniko tasmā tam kodham a katvā putta ghātakamhi akkodhaḥ eva kattabbo ti paṇḍitāḥ āhu kathenti
translated: Herein, akkodha means anger is hell-conducive, therefore, without doing that anger, it is only non-anger that should be done in the case of the slayer of a son, thus the wise say, thus they speak.

original: Evañca pana vatvā te ubhohi hatthehi uraṃ paharitvā mahāsattassa guṇe vaṇṇetvā bhusaṃ parideviṃsu. Atha ne rājā samassāsento āha –
analyzed: evañca pana vatvā te ubhohi hatthehi uram paharitvā mahāsattassa guṇe vaṇṇetvā bhusam parideviṃsu atha ne rājā samassāsentaḥ āha
translated: Having spoken thus, they beat their breasts with both hands, and after extolling the Great Being’s virtues, they lamented much. Then the king, consoling them, said:

original: “Mā bāḷhaṃ paridevetha, ‘hato sāmo’ti vādinā;
analyzed: mā bāḷham paridevetha hataḥ sāma uti vādinā
translated: “Do not lament too much, saying: ‘Sāma has been killed’;

original: Ahaṃ kammakaro hutvā, bharissāmi brahāvane.
analyzed: aham kamma karaḥ hutvā bharissāmi brahā vane
translated: I will be a worker and support them in the forest.

original: “Issatthe casmi kusalo, daḷhadhammoti vissuto;
analyzed: casmi kusalaḥ daḷha dhammaḥ ti vissutaḥ
translated: “I am skilled in archery, and am well-known as Daḷhadhammo;

original: Ahaṃ kammakaro hutvā, bharissāmi brahāvane.
analyzed: aham kamma karaḥ hutvā bharissāmi brahā vane
translated: I will be a worker and support them in the forest.

original: “Migānaṃ vighāsamanvesaṃ, vanamūlaphalāni ca;
analyzed: migānam vighāsam anvesam vana mūla phalāni ca
translated: “Seeking the livelihood of deer, and forest roots and fruits;

original: Ahaṃ kammakaro hutvā, bharissāmi brahāvane”ti.
analyzed: aham kamma karaḥ hutvā bharissāmi brahā vanā iti
translated: I will be a worker and support them in the forest.”

original: Tattha vādināti tumhe “sāmo hato”ti vadantena mayā saddhiṃ “tayā no evaṃ guṇasampanno
analyzed: tattha vādinā ati tumhe sāmaḥ hato ti vadantena mayā saddhim tayā no evam guṇa sampanno
translated: Herein, vādin means with you saying: “Sāma has been killed,” I will be a worker and support them in the forest.

original: putto mārito, idāni ko amhe bharissatī”tiādīni vatvā mā bāḷhaṃ paridevetha, ahaṃ🔽tumhākaṃ kammakaro hutvā sāmo viya tumhe bharissāmīti.
analyzed: puttaḥ māritaḥ idāni kaḥ amhe bharissati iti ādīni vatvā mā bāḷham paridevetha aham  tumhākam kammakaraḥ hutvā sāmaḥ viya tumhe bharissāmi iti
translated: “Our son is dead, who will support us now?” and so on. Then the king said, “Do not grieve so much. I will support you as Sāma did.🔽” Thus the king consoled them, saying, “Do not worry. I have no use for the kingship. I will support you as long as I live.”

original: Evaṃ rājā “tumhe mā cintayittha, na mayhaṃ rajjenattho, ahaṃ vo yāvajīvaṃ bharissāmī”ti te assāsesi. Te tena saddhiṃ sallapantā āhaṃsu –
analyzed: evam rājā tumhe mā cintayittha na mayham aham vaḥ yāvajīvam bharissāmi iti te assāsesi te tena saddhim sallapantāḥ āhaṃsu
translated: As they talked with him, they said:

original: “Nesa dhammo mahārāja, netaṃ amhesu kappati;
analyzed: na isa dhammaḥ mahā rāja na itam amhesu kappati
translated: “This is not the way, great king, this is not proper for us;

original: Rājā tvamasi amhākaṃ, pāde vandāma te maya”nti.
analyzed: rājā tvam asi amhākam pāde vandāma te
translated: You are our king, we pay homage at your feet.”

original: Tattha dhammoti sabhāvo kāraṇaṃ vā. Netaṃ amhesu kappatīti etaṃ tava kammakaraṇaṃ🔽amhesu na kappati na sobhati. “Pāde vandāma te maya”nti idaṃ pana te pabbajitaliṅge🔽ṭhitāpi puttasokena samabbhāhatāya ceva nihatamānatāya ca vadiṃsu. “Rañño vissāsaṃ
analyzed: tattha dhammaḥ ti sabhāvaḥ kāraṇam vā na itam amhesu kappati iti etam tava kamma karaṇam  amhesu na kappati na sobhati pāde vandāma te mayanti idam pana te pabbajita liṅge  ṭhitā api putta sokena samabbhāhatāya ca iva nihata mānatāya ca vadiṃsu raññaḥ vissāsam
translated: Here “way” means nature or reason. “This is not proper for us” means this service you render to us is not proper, it does not befit you.🔽“We pay homage at your feet” — this they said because they were overcome with grief for their son and because they had lost their pride, even though they were still in the robes of the ascetic life.

original: uppādetuṃ evamāhaṃsū”tipi vadanti.
analyzed: vadanti
translated: They said this, it is said, in order to inspire confidence in the king.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā ativiya tussitvā “aho acchariyaṃ, evaṃ dosakārake nāma mayi pharusavacanamattampi natthi, paggaṇhantiyeva mama”nti cintetvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā tussitvā aho acchariyam evam dosa kārake nāma mayi pharusa vacana mattam pi natthi paggaṇhantiyā iva cintetvā gātham āha
translated: The king was delighted beyond measure when he heard this. “How wonderful!” thought he. “Even though I have done them wrong, they have not a harsh word for me, but only praise.” And he spoke this verse:

original: “Dhammaṃ nesādā bhaṇatha, katā apacitī tayā;
analyzed: dhammam nesādāḥ bhaṇatha katā apacitī tayā
translated: “O fishermen, speak the truth. You have done me a service.
