translated: then gods and men said: ‘It is wonderful, sirs, that such a one, even though the knowledge of the Buddhas has not arisen in the world,

original: mahājanassa buddhakiccaṃ sādhayamānā lokasmiṃ vicakkhaṇā uppajjantī”ti evaṃ tassa
analyzed: mahājanassa buddha kiccam sādhayamānāḥ lokasmiṃ vicakkhaṇāḥ uppajjanti iti evam tassa
translated: is wise in the world, accomplishing the work of a Buddha for the great multitude.’

original: guṇakathaṃ kathesunti attho. “Yathā ahū”tipi pāṭho. Tassattho – yathā ahu nimirājā
analyzed: guṇa katham kathesunti atthaḥ yathā ahu iti pi pāṭhaḥ tassa atthaḥ yathā ahu nimi rājā
translated: This is the meaning. The reading ‘yathā ahu’ is also correct. The meaning is: ‘As the wise King Nimi

original: paṇḍito kusalatthikoyeva, tathārūpā mahājanassa buddhakiccaṃ sādhayamānā uppajjanti
analyzed: tathārūpāḥ mahājanassa buddha kiccam sādhayamānāḥ uppajjanti
translated: was desirous of doing what was wholesome, so wise ones arise, accomplishing the work of a Buddha for the great multitude.

original: vicakkhaṇā. Yaṃ tesaṃ uppannaṃ, taṃ accheraṃ vata lokasminti. Iti satthā sayameva
analyzed: vicakkhaṇāḥ yam tesam uppannam tam vata lokasmin ti iti satthā sayam eva
translated: That they arise is wonderful in the world.’ Thus the Teacher, who was himself wonderful,

original: acchariyajāto evamāha. Sabbavidehānanti sabbavideharaṭṭhavāsīnaṃ. Katamaṃ sūti etesu
analyzed: evam āha sabba videhānam ti sabba videha raṭṭha vāsīnam katamam etesu
translated: said this. ‘Of all the people’ means of all the inhabitants of the kingdom of all the people. ‘Which is better’ means of these two,

original: dvīsu katamaṃ nu kho mahapphalanti attho.
analyzed: dvīsu katamam nu kho mahapphalanti attho
translated: “Which of the two is more fruitful?”

original: So kira pannarasīuposathadivase uposathiko hutvā sabbābharaṇāni omuñcitvā sirisayanapiṭṭhe🔽nipannova dve yāme niddaṃ okkamitvā pacchimayāme pabuddho pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā “ahaṃ🔽mahājanassa aparimāṇaṃ dānampi demi, sīlampi rakkhāmi, dānassa nu kho mahantaṃ phalaṃ,
analyzed: so kira pannarasī uposatha divase uposathikaḥ hutvā sabba ābharaṇāni omuñcitvā siri sayana piṭṭhe  nipannaḥ uva dve yāme niddam okkamitvā pacchima yāme pabuddhaḥ pallaṅkam ābhujitvā aham  mahājanassa aparimāṇam dānam pi demi sīlam pi rakkhāmi dānassa nu kho mahantam phalam
translated: On the fifteenth day of the moon’s increase, having observed the Uposatha, he removed all his ornaments, and lying down on his bed of state,

original: udāhu brahmacariyassā”ti cintetvā attano kaṅkhaṃ chindituṃ nāsakkhi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe
analyzed: udāhu brahmacariyassa ati cintetvā attanaḥ kaṅkham chinditum na asakkhi tasmin khaṇe
translated: he fell asleep and slept two watches of the night. When he awoke, he sat up cross-legged and thought to himself, “I give abundant gifts to the people and I observe the moral law. But which is the more fruitful, the giving of gifts or the keeping of the moral law?” He was unable to solve this problem himself. At that moment

original: sakkassa bhavanaṃ uṇhākāraṃ dassesi. Sakko āvajjento taṃ tathā vitakkentaṃ disvā
analyzed: sakkassa bhavanam uṇhākāram dassesi sakkaḥ āvajjentaḥ tam tathā vitakkentam disvā
translated: Sakka’s palace became hot. Sakka observed what was taking place and saw that the king was thinking thus.

original: “kaṅkhamassa chindissāmī”ti ekakova sīghaṃ āgantvā sakalanivesanaṃ ekobhāsaṃ katvā
analyzed: kaṅkhamassa chindissāmi iti ekakaḥ uva sīgham āgantvā sakala nivesanam eka ubhāsam katvā
translated: “I will solve his problem for him,” thought Sakka. So he came quickly, all alone, and lighting up the entire palace with his radiance,

original: sirigabbhaṃ pavisitvā obhāsaṃ pharitvā ākāse ṭhatvā tena puṭṭho byākāsi. Tamatthaṃ
analyzed: siri gabbham pavisitvā obhāsam pharitvā ākāse ṭhatvā tena puṭṭhaḥ byākāsi tam attham
translated: he entered the king’s bed-chamber, and standing in the air, he solved the king’s problem.

original: pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: To relate this event, the Teacher related the following story.

original: “Tassa saṅkappamaññāya, maghavā devakuñjaro;
analyzed: tassa saṅkappam aññāya maghavā deva kuñjaraḥ
translated: Knowing his thought, Maghavana, the lord of the gods,

original: Sahassanetto pāturahu, vaṇṇena vihanaṃ tamaṃ.
analyzed: sahassanettaḥ vaṇṇena vihanam tamam
translated: With a thousand eyes appeared, his radiance outshining the darkness of the sky.

original: “Salomahaṭṭho manujindo, vāsavaṃ avacā nimi;
analyzed: vāsavam avaca nimi
translated: The lord of men, with hair bristling, addressed Vāsava:

original: Devatā nusi gandhabbo, adu sakko purindado.
analyzed: devatā nusi gandhabbaḥ adu sakkaḥ purindadaḥ
translated: “Are you a deity, a gandhabba, or Sakka, the giver of men’s desires?”

original: “Na ca me tādiso vaṇṇo, diṭṭho vā yadi vā suto;
analyzed: na ca me tādisaḥ vaṇṇaḥ diṭṭhaḥ vā yadi vā sutaḥ
translated: “I have never seen or heard of one with such a form as yours;

original: Ācikkha me tvaṃ bhaddante, kathaṃ jānemu taṃ mayaṃ.
analyzed: ācikkha me tvam bhaddante katham jānemu tam mayam
translated: Tell me, good sir, how may I know you?”

original: “Salomahaṭṭhaṃ ñatvāna, vāsavo avacā nimiṃ;
analyzed: saloma haṭṭham ñatvāna vāsavaḥ avaca nimim
translated: Knowing that his hair was bristling, Vāsava addressed Nimi:

original: Sakkohamasmi devindo, āgatosmi tavantike;
analyzed: sakkaḥ ham asmi devindo āgataḥ smi tava antike
translated: “I am Sakka, the lord of the gods, come into your presence;

original: Alomahaṭṭho manujinda, puccha pañhaṃ yamicchasi.
analyzed: a loma haṭṭhaḥ manujinda puccha pañham yam icchasi
translated: Without bristling, lord of men, ask me the question you desire.”

original: “So ca tena katokāso, vāsavaṃ avacā nimi;
analyzed: saḥ ca tena kata ukāsaḥ vāsavam avacā nimi
translated: Having been thus addressed, he addressed Vāsava:

original: Pucchāmi taṃ mahārāja, sabbabhūtānamissara;
analyzed: pucchāmi tam mahā rāja sabba bhūta anamissara
translated: “I ask you, great king, the lord of all beings,

original: ‘Dānaṃ vā brahmacariyaṃ vā, katamaṃsu mahapphalaṃ’.
analyzed: dānam vā brahmacariyam vā katamaṃsu mahat phalam
translated: ‘Is it generosity or the holy life that bears the greater fruit?’”

original: “So puṭṭho naradevena, vāsavo avacā nimiṃ;
analyzed: saḥ puṭṭhaḥ naradevena vāsavaḥ avacā nimim
translated: Having been asked by the lord of men, Vāsava addressed Nimi:

original: Vipākaṃ brahmacariyassa, jānaṃ akkhāsijānato.
analyzed: vipākam brahmacariyassa jānam akkhāsi jānataḥ
translated: Knowing the result of the holy life, he declared what he knew.

original: “Hīnena brahmacariyena, khattiye upapajjati;
analyzed: hīnena brahmacariyena khattiye upapajjati
translated: “By a lowly holy life one is reborn as a khattiya;

original: Majjhimena ca devattaṃ, uttamena visujjhati.
analyzed: majjhimena ca devattam uttamena visujjhati
translated: and by the medium, rebirth among the gods, and by the superior, purification.

original: “Na hete sulabhā kāyā, yācayogena kenaci;
analyzed: na ha ite sulabhā kāyāḥ yāca yogena kenacid
translated: “These bodies are not easily obtained by anyone through mere devotion.

original: Ye kāye upapajjanti, anāgārā tapassino”ti.
analyzed: ye kāye upapajjanti anāgārā tapassino ti
translated: Those who are born in bodies, homeless ones who are ascetics.”

original: Tattha salomahaṭṭhoti bhikkhave, so nimirājā obhāsaṃ disvā ākāsaṃ olokento taṃ dibbābharaṇapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ
analyzed: tattha salomahaṭṭho ti bhikkhave saḥ nimi rājā obhāsam disvā ākāsam olokento tam dibba ābharaṇa paṭimaṇḍitam
translated: Herein, with hair standing on end: monks, when King Nimi saw the light, he looked up into the sky and saw the divine ornament

original: disvāva bhayena lomahaṭṭho hutvā “devatā nusi gandhabbo”tiādinā pucchi. Alomahaṭṭhoti
analyzed: disvā ava bhayena lomahaṭṭhaḥ hutvā devatā gandhabba uti ādinā pucchi a lomahaṭṭhaḥ iti
translated: and, seeing it, he was frightened and his hair stood on end. He asked, “Is it a god or a gandhabba?” etc. Without hair standing on end:

original: nibbhayo ahaṭṭhalomo hutvā puccha, mahārājāti. Vāsavaṃ avacāti tuṭṭhamānaso hutvā
analyzed: nibbhayaḥ ahaṭṭhalomaḥ hutvā puccha mahā rājā ati vāsavam avaca ati tuṭṭha mānasaḥ hutvā
translated: without fear, without hair standing on end, he asked. Great king:

original: sakkaṃ avoca. Jānaṃ akkhāsijānatoti bhikkhave, so sakko atīte attanā paccakkhato
analyzed: sakkam avoca jānam bhikkhave so sakkaḥ atīte attanā paccakkhataḥ
translated: he spoke to Sakka with a glad mind. He declared what he knew to one who knew: monks, Sakka knew the result of the life of chastity, which he had seen for himself in the past.

original: diṭṭhapubbaṃ brahmacariyassa vipākaṃ jānanto tassa ajānato akkhāsi.
analyzed: diṭṭha pubbam brahmacariyassa vipākam jānantaḥ tassa a jānataḥ akkhāsi
translated: He declared it to Nimi, who did not know.

original: Hīnenātiādīsu puthutitthāyatane methunaviratimattaṃ sīlaṃ hīnaṃ nāma, tena khattiyakule
analyzed: puthu tittha āyatane methuna virati mattam sīlam hīnam nāma tena khattiya kule
translated: In the case of the inferior, etc., virtue consisting merely in abstinence from sexual intercourse in the case of the various sectarian disciplines is called “inferior.” By means of that one is born in the khattiya class,

original: upapajjati. Jhānassa upacāramattaṃ majjhimaṃ nāma, tena devattaṃ upapajjati. Aṭṭhasamāpattinibbattanaṃ
analyzed: upapajjati jhānassa upacāra mattam majjhimam nāma tena devattam upapajjati aṭṭha samāpatti nibbattanam
translated: and he is reborn there. The medium kind is the mere access to jhāna; by it he is reborn as a ‘god of the group of thirty-three.’ The superior kind is the arousing of the eight attainments;

original: pana uttamaṃ nāma, tena brahmaloke nibbattati, taṃ bāhirakā nibbānanti kathenti.
analyzed: pana uttamam nāma tena brahmaloke nibbattati tam bāhirakāḥ nibbānanti kathenti
translated: by it he is reborn in the Brahmā-world. That is what outsiders call ‘Nibbāna.’

original: Tenāha “visujjhatī”ti. Imasmiṃ pana buddhasāsane parisuddhasīlassa bhikkhuno aññataraṃ
analyzed: tena āha visujjhati iti imasmim pana buddha sāsane parisuddha sīlassa bhikkhuno aññataram
translated: That is why it is said, ‘It is purified.’ But in this Dispensation of the Buddha, when a bhikkhu of purified virtue aspires to a particular divine world,

original: devanikāyaṃ patthentassa brahmacariyacetanā hīnatāya hīnaṃ nāma, tena yathāpatthite
analyzed: devanikāyam patthentassa brahmacariya cetanā hīna tāya hīnam nāma tena yathā patthite
translated: his aspiration is called ‘inferior’ because his intention of living the life of purity is inferior. By it he is reborn in the divine world he has aspired to.

original: devaloke nibbattati. Parisuddhasīlassa bhikkhuno aṭṭhasamāpattinibbattanaṃ majjhimaṃ
analyzed: deva loke nibbattati parisuddha sīlassa bhikkhuno aṭṭha samāpatti nibbattanam majjhimam
translated: When a bhikkhu of purified virtue arouses the eight attainments,

original: nāma, tena brahmaloke nibbattati. Parisuddhasīlassa vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattuppatti
analyzed: nāma tena brahma loke nibbattati parisuddha sīlassa vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahatta uppatti
translated: that is called ‘medium.’ By it he is reborn in the Brahmā-world. When a bhikkhu of purified virtue develops insight and reaches Arahantship,

original: uttamaṃ nāma, tena visujjhatīti. Iti sakko “mahārāja, dānato sataguṇena sahassaguṇena
analyzed: uttamam nāma tena visujjhati iti iti sakkaḥ mahā rāja dānataḥ sataguṇena sahassaguṇena
translated: that is called ‘superior.’ By it he is purified. That is why it is said, ‘It is purified.’ So Sakka said, ‘Great king, a hundredfold, a thousandfold,

original: satasahassaguṇena brahmacariyavāsova mahapphalo”ti vaṇṇeti. Kāyāti brahmaghaṭā. Yācayogenāti
analyzed: sata sahassa guṇena brahmacariya vāsaḥ uva mahapphalaḥ ti vaṇṇā iti kāyā ati brahmaghaṭā yāca yogena ati
translated: “The Body” is the Brahmas’ “Jar.”🔽“By the method of asking” means by the method of asking for gifts, by the method of giving sacrifices.

original: yācanayuttakena yaññayuttakena vāti ubhayatthāpi dāyakassevetaṃ nāmaṃ. Tapassinoti tapanissitakā.
analyzed: yācana yuttakena yañña yuttakena vā ati ubhayattha api dāyakassa iva etam nāmam tapassinaḥ ti tapa nissitakā
translated: “The ascetics” are those who are devoted to mortification.

original: Imāya gāthāya brahmacariyavāsasseva mahapphalabhāvaṃ dīpetvā idāni ye atīte mahādānaṃ datvā kāmāvacaraṃ atikkamituṃ nāsakkhiṃsu, te rājāno dassento āha –
analyzed: imāya gāthāya brahmacariya vāsassa iva mahapphala bhāvam dīpetvā idāni ye atīte mahā dānam da tvā kāmāvacaram atikkamitum na asakkhiṃsu te rājānaḥ dassentaḥ āha
translated: Having thus shown that the life of chastity is of great fruit, the Master now said, “In the past, kings who gave great gifts and were unable to transcend the sense-sphere, were as follows”:

original: “Dudīpo sāgaro selo, mujakindo bhagīraso;
analyzed: dudīpaḥ sāgaraḥ selaḥ mujakindaḥ bhagīrasaḥ
translated: “Dudīpa, Sāgara, Sela, Mujakinda, Bhagīraso,

original: Usindaro kassapo ca, asako ca puthujjano.
analyzed: usindaraḥ kassapaḥ ca asakaḥ ca puthujjanaḥ
translated: Usindara, Kassapa, Asaka, and Puthujjana.

original: “Ete caññe ca rājāno, khattiyā brāhmaṇā bahū;
analyzed: ete caññe ca rājānaḥ khattiyāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ bahū
translated: “These and other kings, many Khattiyas and Brahmins,

original: Puthuyaññaṃ yajitvāna, petattaṃ nātivattisu”nti.🔽Tassattho – mahārāja, pubbe bārāṇasiyaṃ dudīpo nāma rājā dānaṃ datvā maraṇacakkena
analyzed: puthuyaññam yajitvāna petattam na ativattisunti  tassa atthaḥ mahā rāja pubbe bārāṇasiyam dudīpaḥ nāma rājā dānam da tvā maraṇa cakkena
translated: Having sacrificed in the Puthu sacrifice, did not transcend the state of petas.”🔽The meaning is as follows: “Great king, in the past, in Bārāṇasī, a king named Dudīpa, having given a gift, was beheaded by the Wheel of Death and was reborn in the sense-sphere.

original: chinno kāmāvacareyeva nibbatti. Tathā sāgarādayo aṭṭhāti ete ca aññe ca bahū rājāno
analyzed: chinno nibbatti tathā sāgara ādayaḥ ete ca aññe ca bahū rājāno
translated: Likewise, Sāgara and the other eight, and many other kings,

original: ceva khattiyā brāhmaṇā ca puthuyaññaṃ yajitvāna anekappakāraṃ dānaṃ datvā kāmāvacarabhūmisaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: ca iva khattiyāḥ brāhmaṇā ca puthu yaññam yajitvāna aneka ppakāram dānam da tvā kāmāvacara bhūmi saṅkhātam
translated: and Khattiyas and Brahmins, having performed various sacrifices and given various gifts,🔽did not go beyond the state of petas, which is included in the plane of sensual desire.

original: petattaṃ nātivattiṃsūti attho. Kāmāvacaradevatā hi rūpādino kilesavatthussa kāraṇā
analyzed: na ativattiṃsu iti attho kāma avacara devatā hi rūpa ādinaḥ kilesa vatthussa kāraṇā
translated: The meaning is that they did not go beyond the state of petas, which is included in the plane of sensual desire. For the deities of the plane of sensual desire, because of the objects of defilement such as visible forms, etc.,

original: paraṃ paccāsīsanato kapaṇatāya “petā”ti vuccanti. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: param paccāsīsanataḥ kapaṇa tāya petā ati vuccanti vuttam pi ca itam
translated: are called “petas” because of their wretchedness in being dependent on others for their gratification. And this is said:

original: “Ye adutiyā na ramanti ekikā, vivekajaṃ ye na labhanti pītiṃ;
analyzed: ye adutiyāḥ na ramanti ekikāḥ viveka jam ye na labhanti pītim
translated: “Those who do not delight in solitude, who do not find the joy born of seclusion,

original: Kiñcāpi te indasamānabhogā, te ve parādhīnasukhā varākā”ti.
analyzed: kiñca api te inda samāna bhogā te para adhīna sukhā
translated: though they enjoy the pleasures of Indra, are wretched, their happiness dependent on others.”

original: Evampi dānaphalato brahmacariyaphalasseva mahantabhāvaṃ dassetvā idāni brahmacariyavāsena petabhavanaṃ atikkamitvā brahmaloke nibbattatāpase dassento āha –
analyzed: evam pi dāna phalataḥ brahmacariya phalassa iva mahanta bhāvam dassetvā idāni brahmacariya vāsena peta bhavanam atikkamitvā brahma loke nibbatta tāpase dassentaḥ āha
translated: Having thus shown that the fruit of the life of celibacy is greater than the fruit of generosity, the Exalted One now said the following verses in order to show that the ascetics who were reborn in the Brahma-world after transcending the state of petas by living the life of celibacy

original: “Atha yīme avattiṃsu, anāgārā tapassino;
analyzed: atha yīme avattiṃsu anāgārā tapassinaḥ
translated: “Then these ascetics who lived the life of celibacy,

original: Sattisayo yāmahanu, somayāmo manojavo.
analyzed: satti sayaḥ yāma hanu soma yāmaḥ manaḥ javaḥ
translated: Sattisayo, Yāmahanu, Somayāma, and Manojava,

original: “Samuddo māgho bharato ca, isi kālapurakkhato;
analyzed: samuddaḥ māghaḥ bharataḥ ca isi kālapurakkhataḥ
translated: Samuddo, Māgho, Bharato, and the sage Kālapurakkhato,

original: Aṅgīraso kassapo ca, kisavaccho akatti cā”ti.
analyzed: aṅgīrasaḥ kassapaḥ ca kisavacchaḥ ca ati
translated: Aṅgīraso, Kassapo, Kisavaccho, and Akatti,

original: Tattha avattiṃsūti kāmāvacaraṃ atikkamiṃsu. Tapassinoti sīlatapañceva samāpattitapañca
analyzed: tattha avattiṃsu iti kāmāvacaram atikkamiṃsu tapassinaḥ ti sīla tapañca iva samāpatti tapañca
translated: “They crossed over” means they went beyond the sense-desire world. “Ascetics” means those who are devoted to virtue and to the five jhānas.

original: nissitā. Sattisayoti yāmahanuādayo satta bhātarova sandhāyāha. Aṅgīrasādīhi catūhi
analyzed: nissitā satti sayā iti yāma hanu ādayo satta sandhāya āha aṅgīrasa ādīhi catūhi
translated: “The seven-edged” means the seven-edged thunderbolt. He says this in reference to his brothers. Together with Aṅgīrasa and the other four,

original: saddhiṃ ekādasete avattiṃsu atikkamiṃsūti attho.
analyzed: saddhim ekādasā ite avattiṃsu atikkamiṃsu iti attho
translated: these eleven crossed over, went beyond.

original: Evaṃ tāva sutavaseneva dānaphalato brahmacariyavāsasseva mahapphalataṃ vaṇṇetvā idāni attanā diṭṭhapubbaṃ āharanto āha –
analyzed: evam tāva suta vasena iva dāna phalataḥ brahmacariya vāsassa iva mahapphalatam vaṇṇetvā idāni attanā diṭṭha pubbam āharantaḥ āha
translated: Thus far he has extolled the great fruit of the life of celibacy as compared with the fruit of giving, by means of what he has heard. Now, in order to bring forward what he has seen, he says:

original: “Uttarena nadī sīdā, gambhīrā duratikkamā;
analyzed: uttarena nadī sīdā gambhīrā duratikkamā
translated: “To the north of the river Sīdā, deep and hard to cross,

original: Naḷaggivaṇṇā jotanti, sadā kañcanapabbatā.
analyzed: naḷaggi vaṇṇā jotanti sadā kañcana pabbatā
translated: shine like reeds, the golden mountains.

original: “Parūḷhakacchā tagarā, rūḷhakacchā vanā nagā;
translated: “The Tagaras with their bushy tails, the bushy-tailed forest trees,

original: Tatrāsuṃ dasasahassā, porāṇā isayo pure.
analyzed: tatra āsum dasa sahassā porāṇāḥ isayaḥ pure
translated: there were ten thousand ancient seers in the past.

original: “Ahaṃ seṭṭhosmi dānena, saṃyamena damena ca;
analyzed: aham seṭṭhaḥ asmi dānena saṃyamena damena ca
translated: “I am the best in giving, in self-control and in restraint,

original: Anuttaraṃ vataṃ katvā, pakiracārī samāhite.
analyzed: anuttaram vatam katvā pakira cārī samāhite
translated: having made the unsurpassed vow, I go forth, being concentrated.

original: “Jātimantaṃ ajaccañca, ahaṃ ujugataṃ naraṃ;
analyzed: jātimantam ajaccan ca aham uju gatam naram
translated: “I will pay homage beyond measure to the one who is well-born, the young man,

original: Ativelaṃ namassissaṃ, kammabandhū hi māṇavā.
analyzed: ativelam namassissam kamma bandhū hi māṇavā
translated: for young men are bound by their actions.

original: “Sabbe vaṇṇā adhammaṭṭhā, patanti nirayaṃ adho;
analyzed: sabbe vaṇṇāḥ a dhamma ṭṭhāḥ patanti nirayam adhas
translated: “All castes, if they stand in unrighteousness, fall down into hell;

original: Sabbe vaṇṇā visujjhanti, caritvā dhammamuttama”nti.
analyzed: sabbe vaṇṇāḥ visujjhanti caritvā dhammam uttamanti
translated: All castes, if they live righteously, are purified, having lived righteously.”

original: Tattha uttarenāti mahārāja, atīte uttarahimavante dvinnaṃ suvaṇṇapabbatānaṃ antare
analyzed: tattha uttarena ati mahā rāja atīte uttara himavante dvinnam suvaṇṇa pabbatānam antare
translated: Herein, “in the North” means, Great King, in the past, between two golden mountains in the Northern Himalayas,

original: pavattā sīdā nāma nadī gambhīrā nāvāhipi duratikkamā ahosi. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Sā hi atisukhumodakā,
analyzed: pavattā sīdā nāma nadī gambhīrā duratikkamā ahosi kim kāraṇā sā hi ati sukhuma udakā
translated: there was a river called Sīdā which flowed. It was deep and difficult to cross even by boat. Why was that? Because that water was very fine,

original: sukhumattā udakassa antamaso morapiñcha-mattampi tattha patitaṃ naṃ saṇṭhāti, osīditvā
analyzed: sukhumattā udakassa antamasaḥ morapiñcha mattam pi tattha patitam naṃ saṇṭhāti osīditvā
translated: so fine that even a feather of a peacock falling into it did not float, but sank

original: heṭṭhātalameva gacchati. Teneva sā sīdā nāma ahosi. Te pana tassā tīresu kañcanapabbatā🔽sadā naḷaggivaṇṇā hutvā jotanti obhāsanti. Parūḷhakacchā tagarāti tassā pana nadiyā
analyzed: heṭṭhā talam eva gacchati tena iva sā sīdā nāma ahosi te pana tassā tīresu kañcana pabbatā  sadā naḷaggi vaṇṇāḥ hutvā jotanti tassā pana nadiyā
translated: and went to the bottom. Therefore it was called Sīdā. But those golden mountains on its banks🔽always shone and glowed like a flame of fire. Parūḷhakacchā tagarāti but on the banks of that river

original: tīre kacchā parūḷhatagarā ahesuṃ tagaragandhasugandhino. Rūḷhakacchā vanā nagāti
analyzed: tīre kacchā parūḍha tagarāḥ ahesum tagara gandha sugandhinaḥ rūḍha kacchāḥ vanāḥ
translated: the sand was parūḷha tagara, fragrant with the scent of tagara. Rūḷhakacchā vanā nagāti

original: ye tattha aññepi pabbatā, tesampi antare kacchā rūḷhavanā ahesuṃ, pupphaphalūpagarukkhasañchannāti
analyzed: ye tattha aññe pi pabbatā tesam pi antare kacchāḥ rūḷha vanāḥ ahesum puppha phala upaga rukkha sañchannā ati
translated: and in the spaces between the mountains there were ravines covered with thick jungle, and the trees were laden with flowers and fruits.

original: attho. Tatrāsunti tasmiṃ evaṃ ramaṇīye bhūmibhāge dasasahassā isayo ahesuṃ. Te sabbepi
analyzed: tatra asunti tasmin evam ramaṇīye bhūmi bhāge dasa sahassāḥ isayaḥ ahesum te sabbe pi
translated: The meaning is that in such a delightful place there were ten thousand seers. All of them

original: abhiññāsamāpattilābhinova. Tesu bhikkhācāravelāya keci uttarakuruṃ gacchanti, keci
analyzed: abhiññā samāpatti lābhinaḥ va tesu bhikkhā cāra velāya keci uttarakurum gacchanti keci
translated: had attained the super-knowledges and the meditative attainments. At the time of going out for alms some of them went to Uttarakuru,

original: mahājambudīpe jambuphalaṃ āharanti, keci himavanteyeva madhuraphalāphalāni āharitvā
analyzed: mahā jambu dīpe jambu phalam āharanti keci āharitvā
translated: some brought rose-apples from the great Rose-apple Land, some brought sweet fruits from the Himalayas and ate them,

original: khādanti, keci jambudīpatale taṃ taṃ nagaraṃ gacchanti. Ekopi rasataṇhābhibhūto natthi,🔽jhānasukheneva vītināmenti. Tadā eko tāpaso ākāsena bārāṇasiṃ gantvā sunivattho supāruto
analyzed: khādanti keci jambudīpa tale tam tam nagaram gacchanti ekaḥ api rasa taṇhā abhibhūtaḥ natthi  tadā ekaḥ tāpasaḥ ākāsena bārāṇasim gantvā sunivatthaḥ supārutaḥ
translated: some went to this or that city in the Rose-apple Land. There was not one of them who was overcome by craving for tastes,🔽but all of them spent their time with the happiness of jhāna. At that time a certain ascetic went through the air to Bārāṇasī, and after going there, he entered the city in the morning to beg for alms, well-clothed and well-attired.

original: piṇḍāya caranto purohitassa gehadvāraṃ pāpuṇi. So tassa upasame pasīditvā antonivesanaṃ
analyzed: piṇḍāya caranto purohitassa geha dvāram pāpuṇi saḥ tassa upasame pasīditvā antonivesanam
translated: While going on continuous alms round, he reached the door of the chaplain’s house. He was pleased with his calm, and invited him into the house,

original: ānetvā bhojetvā katipāhaṃ paṭijagganto vissāse uppanne “bhante, tumhe kuhiṃ vasathā”ti
analyzed: ānetvā bhojetvā katipāham paṭijaggantaḥ vissāse uppanne bhante tumhe kuhim vasatha ati
translated: He brought him to his own house, fed him, and took care of him for several days. When he had gained the man’s confidence, he asked him, “Venerable sir, where do you live?”

original: pucchi. “Asukaṭṭhāne nāmāvuso”ti. “Kiṃ pana tumhe ekakova tattha vasatha, udāhu aññepi
analyzed: pucchi asuka ṭṭhāne nāma āvuso ti kim pana tumhe ekakaḥ uva tattha vasatha udāhu aññe pi
translated: “In such and such a place, my good man.” “But do you live there alone, or are there others with you?”

original: atthī”ti? “Kiṃ vadesi, āvuso, tasmiṃ padese dasasahassā isayo vasanti, sabbeva abhiññāsamāpattilābhino”ti.
analyzed: atthi iti kim vadesi āvuso tasmin padese dasa sahassāḥ isayaḥ vasanti sabbe eva abhiññā samāpatti lābhino ti
translated: “What do you say, my good man? In that place there are ten thousand seers, all of whom have attained the supernormal powers and the meditative absorptions.”

original: Tassa tesaṃ guṇaṃ sutvā pabbajjāya cittaṃ nami. Atha naṃ so āha – “bhante, mampi🔽tattha netvā pabbājethā”ti. “Āvuso, tvaṃ rājapuriso, na taṃ sakkā pabbājetu”nti.🔽“Tena hi, bhante, ajjāhaṃ rājānaṃ āpucchissāmi, tumhe svepi āgaccheyyāthā”ti. So adhivāsesi.
analyzed: tassa tesam guṇam sutvā pabbajjāya cittam nami atha nam saḥ āha bhante mam pi  tattha netvā pabbājetha ati āvuso tvam rāja purisaḥ na tam sakkā pabbājetun ti  tena hi bhante ajja aham rājānam āpucchissāmi tumhe sve api āgaccheyyātha ati saḥ adhivāsesi
translated: When he heard of their virtues, he became desirous of the going forth. He said to the seer, “Venerable sir,🔽take me there and give me the going forth.” “My good man, you are a man of the royal court. I cannot give you the going forth.”🔽“Well then, venerable sir, I will ask the king today. You may come tomorrow.” The seer assented.

original: Itaropi bhuttapātarāso rājānaṃ upasaṅkamitvā “icchāmahaṃ, deva, pabbajitu”nti āha.
analyzed: itaraḥ api bhutta pāta rāsaḥ rājānam upasaṅkamitvā icchāmaham deva pabbajitunti āha
translated: The other, after he had eaten his breakfast, went to the king and said, “Your majesty, I wish to go forth.”

original: “Kiṃ kāraṇā pabbajissasī”ti? “Kāmesu dosaṃ nekkhamme ca ānisaṃsaṃ disvā”ti. “Tena
analyzed: kim kāraṇā pabbajissasi iti kāmesu dosam nekkhamme ca ānisaṃsam disvā ati tena
translated: “What is the reason for your going forth?” “Seeing the danger in sense pleasures and the benefit in renunciation.” “But what is the danger in sense pleasures and the benefit in renunciation?”

original: hi pabbajāhi, pabbajitopi maṃ dasseyyāsī”ti. So “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā attano gehaṃ🔽gantvā puttadāraṃ anusāsitvā sabbaṃ sāpateyyaṃ dassetvā attano pabbajitaparikkhāraṃ
analyzed: hi pabbajāhi pabbajitaḥ api mama dasseyyāsi iti saḥ sādhu uti sampaṭicchitvā attanaḥ geham  gantvā putta dāram anusāsitvā sabbam sāpateyyam dassetvā attano pabbajita parikkhāram
translated: “What is the reason for your going forth?” “I have seen the danger in sensual desires and the benefit in renunciation.” “Well then, go forth, and show me to others.” “Very well,” he replied, and he went to his own house.

original: gahetvā tāpasassa āgamanamaggaṃ olokentova nisīdi. Tāpasopi tatheva ākāsenāgantvā🔽antonagaraṃ pavisitvā tassa gehaṃ pāvisi. So taṃ sakkaccaṃ parivisitvā “bhante, mayā🔽kathaṃ kātabba”nti āha. So taṃ bahinagaraṃ netvā hatthe ādāya attano ānubhāvena tattha
analyzed: gahetvā tāpasassa āgamana maggaṃ olokento iva nisīdi tāpasaḥ api tathā iva ākāsena āgantvā  antonagaram pavisitvā tassa geham pāvisi saḥ tam sakkaccam parivisitvā bhante mayā  katham kātabban ti āha saḥ tam bahi nagaram netvā hatthe ādāya attanaḥ ānubhāvena tattha
translated: There he instructed his wife and children, showed them his property, took his requisites for going forth, and sat down waiting for the ascetic to come. The ascetic came as before through the air, entered the city, and went to the house.

original: netvā pabbājetvā punadivase taṃ tattheva ṭhapetvā bhattaṃ āharitvā datvā kasiṇaparikammaṃ
analyzed: netvā pabbājetvā puna divase tam tattha iva ṭhapetvā bhattam āharitvā da tvā kasiṇa parikammam
translated: The householder served him respectfully and said, “Venerable sir, what am I to do?” The ascetic took him out of the city, led him to the place by his psychic power, gave him the going forth, and left him there the next day. He brought him food and taught him the preliminary work on the kasiṇa.

original: ācikkhi. So katipāheneva abhiññāsamāpattiyo nibbattetvā sayameva piṇḍāya carati.
analyzed: ācikkhi so kati pāhena iva abhiññā samāpattiyaḥ nibbattetvā sayam eva piṇḍāya carati
translated: In a few days the ascetic developed the supernormal powers and higher knowledges and went about for alms by himself.

original: So aparabhāge “ahaṃ rañño attānaṃ dassetuṃ paṭiññaṃ adāsiṃ, dassessāmassa attāna”nti
analyzed: saḥ aparabhāge aham raññaḥ attānam dassetum paṭiññam adāsim dassessāmassa attānan ti
translated: In course of time he thought to himself, “I promised the king to show him my companions. I will show him my companions.”

original: cintetvā tāpase vanditvā ākāsena bārāṇasiṃ gantvā bhikkhaṃ caranto rājadvāraṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: cintetvā tāpase vanditvā ākāsena bārāṇasim gantvā bhikkham carantaḥ rājadvāram pāpuṇi
translated: So he paid obeisance to the seer, and flying through the air, he went to Benares and entered the city for alms.

original: Rājā taṃ disvā sañjānitvā antonivesanaṃ pavesetvā sakkāraṃ katvā “bhante, kuhiṃ vasathā”ti
analyzed: rājā tam disvā sañjānitvā antonivesanam pavesetvā sakkāram katvā bhante kuhim vasatha iti
translated: The king saw him and recognized him. He caused him to enter the palace and entertained him with the greatest honor. Then he asked him, “Reverend Sir, where do you live?”

original: pucchi. “Uttarahimavantapadese kañcanapabbatantare pavattāya sīdānadiyā tīre, mahārājā”ti.
analyzed: uttara himavanta padese kañcana pabbata antare pavattāya sīdānadiyā tīre mahārājā ati
translated: “In the northern part of the Himālayas, Great King, in a cleft of the Golden Mountain, on the bank of the Sīdānadi River.”🔽“But, Reverend Sir, do you live there alone, or are there others with you?”

original: “Kiṃ pana, bhante, ekakova tattha vasatha, udāhu aññepi atthī”ti. “Kiṃ vadesi, mahārāja,🔽tattha dasasahassā isayo vasanti, sabbeva abhiññāsamāpattilābhino”ti? Rājā tesaṃ🔽guṇaṃ sutvā sabbesaṃ bhikkhaṃ dātukāmo ahosi. Atha naṃ rājā āha – “bhante, ahaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: kim pana bhante ekakaḥ uva tattha vasatha udāhu aññe pi atthi iti kim vadesi mahā rāja  tattha dasa sahassāḥ isayaḥ vasanti sabbe eva abhiññā samāpatti lābhino ti rājā tesam  guṇam sutvā sabbesam bhikkham dātu kāmo ahosi atha nam rājā āha bhante aham tesam
translated: “What say you, Great King?

original: isīnaṃ bhikkhaṃ dātukāmomhi, kiṃ karomī”ti? “Mahārāja, te isayo jivhāviññeyyarase
analyzed: isīnam bhikkham dātu kāmo asmi kim karomi iti mahā rāja te isayaḥ jivhā viññeyya rase
translated: There are ten thousand seers living there, all of whom have attained the super-knowledges and the meditative ecstasies.” When the king heard the virtues of these seers, he desired to give alms to them all. So he said to the seer, “Reverend Sir, I desire to give alms to these seers. What shall I do?”🔽“Great King, these seers are not permitted to eat any food except that which is brought by the wind.

original: agiddhā, na sakkā idhānetu”nti. “Bhante, tumhe nissāya te bhojessāmi, upāyaṃ me ācikkhathā”ti.
analyzed: agiddhāḥ na sakkā idha ānetunti bhante tumhe nissāya te bhojessāmi upāyam me ācikkhatha ati
translated: “They are not greedy, sire, they cannot be brought here.” “Revered sir, I will entertain them through you. Tell me the means.”

original: “Tena hi, mahārāja, sace tesaṃ dānaṃ dātukāmosi, ito nikkhamitvā sīdānadītīre vasanto
analyzed: tena hi mahā rāja sace tesam dānam dātu kāmo asi itas nikkhamitvā sīdānadī tīre vasantaḥ
translated: “Well then, sire, if you wish to give them a gift, go out from here and dwell on the bank of the Sīdā River.

original: tesaṃ dānaṃ dehī”ti.
analyzed: dānam dehi iti
translated: Give them a gift there.”

original: So “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā sabbūpakaraṇāni gāhāpetvā caturaṅginiyā senāya saddhiṃ
analyzed: saḥ sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā sabba upakaraṇāni gāhāpetvā caturaṅginiyā senāya saddhim
translated: He agreed, saying, “Very well,” and taking all the requisites, he went out with his fourfold army

original: nikkhamitvā attano rajjasīmaṃ pāpuṇi. Atha naṃ tāpaso attano ānubhāvena saddhiṃ senāya
analyzed: nikkhamitvā attanaḥ rajja sīmam pāpuṇi atha nam tāpasaḥ attanaḥ ānubhāvena saddhim senāya
translated: and reached the border of his kingdom. Then the ascetic, by his own power, led him with his army

original: sīdānadītīraṃ netvā nadītīre khandhāvāraṃ kārāpetvā ākāsena attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: sīdānadī tīram netvā nadī tīre khandhāvāram kārāpetvā ākāsena attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānam
translated: to the bank of the Sīdā River and had a camp made on the bank of the river. He himself went by air to his own dwelling place

original: gantvā punadivase paccāgami. Atha naṃ rājā sakkaccaṃ bhojetvā “sve, bhante, dasasahasse
analyzed: gantvā puna divase paccāgami atha nam rājā sakkaccam bhojetvā sve bhante dasa sahasse
translated: and returned the next day. Then the king entertained him respectfully and said, “Revered sir, tomorrow bring the ten thousand seers

original: isayo ādāya idheva āgacchathā”ti āha. So “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā gantvā punadivase
analyzed: ādāya idhā iva āgacchatha iti āha saḥ sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā gantvā punar divase
translated: and come here.” He agreed, saying, “Very well,” and went and returned the next day🔽with the seers.

original: bhikkhācāravelāya tesaṃ isīnaṃ ārocesi “mārisā, bārāṇasirājā ‘tumhākaṃ bhikkhaṃ dassāmī’ti
analyzed: bhikkhā cāra velāya tesam isīnaṃ ārocesi mārisā bārāṇasi rājā tumhākam bhikkham dassāmi iti
translated: and announced to the seers the time for going for alms, saying: “Sirs, the King of Benares has come🔽and is sitting on the bank of the Sīhapapātā River, saying: ‘I will give you alms.’

original: āgantvā sīdānadītīre nisinno sve vo nimanteti, tassānukampāya khandhāvāraṃ gantvā
analyzed: āgantvā sīda nadī tīre nisinnaḥ sve vaḥ nimantā iti tassa anukampāya khandhāvāram gantvā
translated: Out of compassion for him, go to the storehouse and

original: bhikkhaṃ gaṇhathā”ti. Te “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā ākāsena gantvā khandhāvārassa avidūre
analyzed: bhikkham gaṇhatha ati te sādhu uti sampaṭicchitvā ākāsena gantvā khandhāvārassa avidūre
translated: take your alms.” They agreed, saying: “Very well,” and went through the air and alighted

original: otariṃsu. Rājā te disvā paccuggamanaṃ katvā khandhāvāraṃ pavesetvā paññattāsanesu
analyzed: otariṃsu rājā te disvā paccuggamanam katvā khandhāvāram pavesetvā paññatta āsanesu
translated: not far from the storehouse. The King, seeing them, went out to meet them, took them into the storehouse,

original: nisīdāpetvā isigaṇaṃ paṇītenāhārena santappetvā tesaṃ iriyāpathe pasanno svātanāyapi
analyzed: nisīdāpetvā isi gaṇam paṇītena āhārena santappetvā tesam iriyāpathe pasannaḥ
translated: and seated them on prepared seats. After serving the group of seers with excellent food, he was pleased with their deportment and invited them

original: nimantesi. Etenupāyena dasannaṃ tāpasasahassānaṃ dasavassasahassāni dānaṃ adāsi.
analyzed: nimantesi etena upāyena dasannam tāpasa sahassānam dasa vassa sahassāni dānam adāsi
translated: for the next day. In this way he gave alms for ten thousand years to ten thousand ascetics.

original: Dadanto ca tasmiṃyeva padese nagaraṃ māpetvā sassakammaṃ kāresi. Na kho pana, mahārāja,
analyzed: dadantaḥ ca tasmin yeva padese nagaram māpetvā sassa kammam kāresi na kho pana mahā rāja
translated: And while giving, he had a city built in that very place and had rice cultivated. But, great king,

original: tadā so rājā añño ahosi, atha kho ahaṃ seṭṭhosmi dānena, ahameva hi tadā dānena seṭṭho
analyzed: tadā saḥ rājā aññaḥ ahosi atha kho aham seṭṭhaḥ asmi dānena aham eva hi tadā dānena seṭṭhaḥ
translated: at that time the King was not another, but I myself was he. For I am the best in giving.

original: hutvā taṃ mahādānaṃ datvā imaṃ petalokaṃ atikkamitvā brahmaloke nibbattituṃ nāsakkhiṃ.
analyzed: hutvā tam mahā dānam da tvā imam peta lokam atikkamitvā brahma loke nibbattitum na asakkhim
translated: and having given that great gift, he was unable to transcend this world of the gods and be reborn in the Brahma-world.

original: Mayā dinnaṃ pana dānaṃ bhuñjitvā sabbeva te tāpasā kāmāvacaraṃ atikkamitvā brahmaloke
analyzed: mayā dinnam pana dānam bhuñjitvā sabbe iva te tāpasā kāmāvacaram atikkamitvā brahma loke
translated: But all those ascetics, having eaten the gift given by me, transcended the sense-desire world and were reborn in the Brahma-world.

original: nibbattā, imināpetaṃ veditabbaṃ “brahmacariyavāsova mahapphalo”ti.
analyzed: nibbattā iminā apetam veditabbam brahmacariya vāsaḥ uva mahapphalā ti
translated: By this it should be understood that “the life of celibacy is of great fruit.”

original: Evaṃ dānena attano seṭṭhabhāvaṃ pakāsetvā itarehi tīhi padehi tesaṃ isīnaṃ guṇaṃ
analyzed: evam dānena attano seṭṭha bhāvam pakāsetvā itarehi tīhi padehi tesam isīnam guṇam
translated: Having thus shown his own pre-eminence by means of the gift, he shows the virtue of those seers by means of the other three phrases.

original: pakāseti. Tattha saṃyamenāti sīlena. Damenāti indriyadamena. Anuttaranti etehi guṇehi🔽nirantaraṃ uttamaṃ vataṃ samādānaṃ caritvā. Pakiracārīti gaṇaṃ pakiritvā paṭikkhipitvā
analyzed: pakāseti tattha saṃyamena ati sīlena damena ati indriya damena anuttaranti etehi guṇehi  nirantaram uttamam vatam samādānam caritvā pakira cārī iti gaṇam pakiritvā paṭikkhipitvā
translated: Therein, by self-control means by virtue. By restraint means by restraint of the senses. By the unsurpassed means by the unsurpassed life of celibacy.

original: pahāya ekacārike, ekībhāvaṃ gateti attho. Samāhiteti upacārappanāsamādhīhi samāhitacitte.
analyzed: pahāya ekacārike ekībhāvam gatā iti attho samāhitā iti upacāra ppanā samādhīhi samāhita citte
translated: Having practiced the life of celibacy, which is unsurpassed by these virtues, having gone forth means having gone forth, having rejected, having abandoned the group, having gone forth alone. Having gone forth means having gone forth alone, having gone forth by oneself, is the meaning. Having concentrated means having concentrated the mind by means of access concentration and absorption concentration.

original: Evarūpe ahaṃ tapassino upaṭṭhahinti dasseti. Ahaṃ ujugatanti ahaṃ, mahārāja, tesaṃ
analyzed: evarūpe aham tapassinaḥ upaṭṭhahinti dasseti aham uju gatanti aham mahā rāja tesam
translated: I served such ascetics as these means I served such ascetics as these. I was upright means, Great King, I was upright, I was straight, I was not crooked.

original: dasasahassānaṃ isīnaṃ antare kāyavaṅkādīnaṃ abhāvena ujugataṃ ekampi naraṃ hīnajacco🔽vā hotu jātisampanno vā, jātiṃ avicāretvā tesaṃ guṇesu pasannamānaso hutvā sabbameva
analyzed: dasa sahassānam isīnam antare kāya vaṅka ādīnam abhāvena uju gatam ekam pi naram  vā hotu jāti sampannaḥ vā jātim a vicāretvā tesam guṇesu pasanna mānasaḥ hutvā sabbam eva
translated: “I will honor, I will always honor, even the lowliest man, if he be upright, among the ten thousand sages, because he is free from the crookedness of body, etc.

original: ativelaṃ namassissaṃ, niccakālameva namassissanti vadati. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Kammabandhū
analyzed: ativelam namassissam niccakālam eva namassissanti vadati kim kāraṇā kamma bandhū
translated: Let him be of low birth or of high birth, I will honor him, without regard to his birth, if my mind be pleased with his virtues.” Why? “For, prince, men are bound by their deeds.”

original: hi māṇavāti, sattā hi nāmete kammabandhū kammapaṭisaraṇā, teneva kāraṇena sabbe vaṇṇāti veditabbā.🔽Evañca pana vatvā “kiñcāpi, mahārāja, dānato brahmacariyameva mahapphalaṃ, dvepi🔽panete mahāpurisavitakkāva, tasmā dvīsupi appamattova hutvā dānañca dehi, sīlañca
analyzed: hi māṇava ati sattāḥ hi nāma ete kamma bandhū kamma paṭisaraṇā tena iva kāraṇena sabbe vaṇṇā ati veditabbā  evañca pana vatvā kiñca api mahā rāja dānataḥ brahmacariyam eva mahapphalam  pana ite mahāpurisa vitakkā va tasmai appamattaḥ uva hutvā dānañca dehi sīlañca
translated: For men are bound by their deeds, they are the heirs of their deeds. For this reason all men should be regarded as equal.

original: rakkhāhī”ti taṃ ovaditvā sakaṭṭhānameva gato. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: rakkhāhi iti tam ovaditvā saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ tam attham pakāsento satthā āha
translated: Having thus spoken, the Teacher said, “Although, O king, the life of chastity is more fruitful than the giving of gifts, both are the thoughts of the Great Man. Therefore be not remiss in either. Give alms and observe the moral precepts.” So saying, he instructed the king, and then departed and returned to his own place of abode. Expounding this matter, the Master said,🔽Having thus spoken, Magha’s son,

original: “Idaṃ vatvāna maghavā, devarājā sujampati;🔽Vedehamanusāsitvā, saggakāyaṃ apakkamī”ti.
analyzed: idam vatvāna maghavā deva rājā su jampati 🔽veda iham anusāsitvā sagga kāyam apakkamīti
translated: The king of gods, the husband of Sujā,🔽Having instructed the king of Videha, departed to the world of the gods.

original: Tattha apakkamīti pakkami, sudhammādevasabhāyaṃ nisinnameva attānaṃ dassesīti attho.
analyzed: tattha apakkami iti pakkami sudhammādeva sabhāyam nisinnam eva attānam dassesi iti attho
translated: Herein, he went away means he went away and showed himself sitting in the Sudhamma Assembly.🔽Then the hosts of gods said to him, “Great king, did you not appear? Where did you go? “

original: Atha naṃ devagaṇā āhaṃsu “mahārāja, nanu na paññāyittha, kuhiṃ gatatthā”ti? “Mārisā🔽mithilāyaṃ nimirañño ekā kaṅkhā uppajji, tassa pañhaṃ kathetvā taṃ rājānaṃ nikkaṅkhaṃ
analyzed: atha nam deva gaṇāḥ āhaṃsu mahā rāja nanu na paññāyittha kuhim gatattha ati mārisā  mithilāyam nimi raññaḥ ekā kaṅkhā uppajji tassa pañham kathetvā tam rājānam nikkaṅkham
translated: “Friends,🔽a doubt arose in King Nimi of Mithila, and after answering his question and making the king free from doubt, I came back.”

original: katvā āgatomhī”ti vatvā puna taṃ kāraṇaṃ gāthāya kathetuṃ āha –
analyzed: katvā āgataḥ asmi iti vatvā punar tam kāraṇam gāthāya kathetum āha
translated: Then he spoke this verse to tell that reason again:

original: “Imaṃ bhonto nisāmetha, yāvantettha samāgatā;
analyzed: imam bhontaḥ nisāmetha yāvantā itthā samāgatā
translated: “Listen to this, you who have come here,

original: Dhammikānaṃ manussānaṃ, vaṇṇaṃ uccāvacaṃ bahuṃ.
analyzed: dhammikānam manussānam vaṇṇam uccāvacam bahum
translated: To the many high and low praises Of righteous men.

original: “Yathā ayaṃ nimirājā, paṇḍito kusalatthiko;
analyzed: yathā ayam nimi rājā paṇḍitaḥ kusalatthiko
translated: “As this King Nimi, wise and skilled in profit,

original: Rājā sabbavidehānaṃ, adā dānaṃ arindamo.
analyzed: rājā sabba videhānam adāḥ dānam arindamaḥ
translated: The king of all Videhas, the tamer of men, gave a gift.

original: “Tassa taṃ dadato dānaṃ, saṅkappo udapajjatha;
analyzed: tassa tam dadataḥ dānam saṅkappaḥ udapajjatha
translated: “As he was giving the gift, a thought arose in him:

original: Dānaṃ vā brahmacariyaṃ vā, katamaṃ su mahapphala”nti.
analyzed: dānam vā brahmacariyam vā katamat su mahapphalanti
translated: ‘Is it giving or is it the holy life that has the greater fruit? ‘”

original: Tattha imanti dhammikānaṃ kalyāṇadhammānaṃ manussānaṃ mayā vuccamānaṃ sīlavasena
analyzed: tattha imanti dhammikānam kalyāṇa dhammānam manussānam mayā vuccamānam sīla vasena
translated: Herein, listen to this means listen to this that I shall tell of the virtue of righteous men of good Dhamma.

original: uccaṃ dānavasena avacaṃ bahuṃ imaṃ vaṇṇaṃ nisāmetha suṇāthāti attho. Yathā ayanti
analyzed: uccam dāna vasena avacam bahum imam vaṇṇam nisāmetha suṇātha ati atthaḥ yathā ayanti
translated: and I have spoken much praise of him as a giver. Listen to this description of him, hear it.🔽As to how:

original: ayaṃ nimirājā yathā ativiya paṇḍitoti.
analyzed: ayam nimi rājā yathā
translated: this King Nimi is exceedingly wise.

original: Iti so aparihāpetvā rañño vaṇṇaṃ kathesi. Taṃ sutvā devasaṅghā rājānaṃ daṭṭhukāmā🔽hutvā “amhākaṃ nimirājā ācariyo, tassovāde ṭhatvā taṃ nissāya amhehi ayaṃ dibbasampatti
analyzed: iti saḥ a parihāpetvā raññaḥ vaṇṇam kathesi tam sutvā deva saṅghāḥ rājānam daṭṭhu kāmāḥ  hutvā amhākam nimi rājā ācariyo tassa uvāde ṭhatvā tam nissāya amhehi ayam dibba sampatti
translated: Thus he spoke the King’s praise without omitting anything. When the assembly of gods heard it, they became eager to see the King.

original: laddhā, mayaṃ daṭṭhukāmamhā, taṃ pakkosāpehi, mahārājā”ti vadiṃsu. Sakko “sādhū”ti
analyzed: laddhāḥ mayam daṭṭhu kāmamhā tam pakkosāpehi mahā rāja ati vadiṃsu sakko sādhu iti
translated: They made an offering and said, “Our teacher is King Nimi. We have attained this divine fortune by standing by his advice and relying on him. We are eager to see him. Summon him, Great King.” Sakka agreed, saying, “Very well.”

original: sampaṭicchitvā mātaliṃ pakkosāpetvā “samma mātali, vejayantarathaṃ yojetvā mithilaṃ
analyzed: sampaṭicchitvā mātalim pakkosāpetvā samma mātali vejayanta ratham yojetvā mithilam
translated: He summoned Mātali and said, “My good Mātali, harness the Vejayanta chariot and go to Mithilā.

original: gantvā nimirājānaṃ dibbayāne āropetvā ānehī”ti āha. So “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā rathaṃ
analyzed: gantvā nimi rājānam dibba yāne āropetvā ānehi iti āha saḥ sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā ratham
translated: Take King Nimi up in the divine vehicle and bring him here.” He agreed and harnessed the chariot and set out.

original: yojetvā pāyāsi. Sakkassa pana devehi saddhiṃ kathentassa mātaliṃ āṇāpentassa ca rathaṃ
analyzed: yojetvā pāyāsi sakkassa pana devehi saddhim kathentassa mātalim āṇāpentassa ca rathaṃ
translated: But while Sakka was talking with the gods and giving Mātali instructions, the chariot was not harnessed.

original: yojentassa ca manussagaṇanāya māso atikkanto. Iti nimirañño puṇṇamāyaṃ uposathikassa
analyzed: yojentassa ca manussa gaṇanāya māsaḥ atikkantaḥ iti nimi raññaḥ puṇṇamāyam uposathikassa
translated: and a month passed by in his driving about. Thus on the day of the full moon of the month of Phagguna,

original: pācīnasīhapañjaraṃ vivaritvā mahātale nisīditvā amaccagaṇaparivutassa sīlaṃ paccavekkhantassa
analyzed: pācīna sīha pañjaram vivaritvā mahā tale nisīditvā amacca gaṇa parivutassa sīlam paccavekkhantassa
translated: King Nimi, after opening the eastern door of the lion-house, sat down on the terrace surrounded by his ministers, and as he was reflecting on the moral precepts,

original: pācīnalokadhātuto uggacchantena candamaṇḍalena saddhiṃyeva so ratho paññāyati. Manussā
analyzed: pācīna lokadhātutaḥ uggacchantena canda maṇḍalena saddhiṃyeva saḥ ratho paññāyati manussā
translated: the chariot appeared to him together with the moon rising from the eastern world-sphere. The people,

original: bhuttasāyamāsā gharadvāresu nisīditvā sukhakathaṃ kathentā “ajja dve candā uggatā”ti
analyzed: bhutta sāya māsāḥ ghara dvāresu nisīditvā sukha katham kathentāḥ ajja dve candā uggatā ati
translated: after eating their evening meal, sat down at the doors of their houses and, as they were talking pleasantly, said, “Two moons have risen.”

original: āhaṃsu. Atha nesaṃ sallapantānaññeva ratho pākaṭo ahosi. Mahājano “nāyaṃ, cando,
analyzed: āhaṃsu atha nesam sallapantānam aññā iva rathaḥ pākaṭaḥ ahosi mahā janaḥ na ayam cando
translated: While they were talking, the chariot became visible. The people said, “This is not the moon,

original: ratho”ti vatvā anukkamena sindhavasahassayutte mātalisaṅgāhake vejayantarathe ca
analyzed: ratho ti vatvā anukkamena sindhava sahassa yutte mātali saṅgāhake vejayanta rathe ca
translated: this is a chariot.” As the chariot of Matali, the charioteer of Sakka, drawn by a thousand thoroughbred horses, gradually became visible,

original: pākaṭe jāte “kassa nu kho idaṃ dibbayānaṃ āgacchatī”ti cintetvā “na kassaci aññassa,
analyzed: pākaṭe jāte kassa nu kho idam dibba yānam āgacchati iti cintetvā na kassaci aññassa
translated: they thought, “To whom does this divine vehicle belong?” They concluded, “It belongs to no one else but our king,

original: amhākaṃ rājā dhammiko, sakkena vejayantaratho pesito bhavissati, amhākaṃ raññova
analyzed: amhākam rājā dhammikaḥ sakkena vejayantaratho pesitaḥ bhavissati amhākam raññā uva
translated: who is righteous. It must be the chariot of Vejayanta sent by Sakka. It belongs to our king.

original: anucchaviko”ti tuṭṭhappahaṭṭho gāthamāha –
analyzed: anucchavikā iti tuṭṭha ppahaṭṭhaḥ gātham āha
translated: and he was pleased and delighted, and he spoke this verse:

original: “Abbhuto vata lokasmiṃ, uppajji lomahaṃsano;
analyzed: abbhutaḥ vata lokasmin uppajji lomahaṃsanaḥ
translated: “Wonderful indeed in the world, one who causes the hairs to stand on end has appeared;

original: Dibbo ratho pāturahu, vedehassa yasassino”ti.
analyzed: dibbaḥ rathaḥ pāturahu veda ihassa yasassinaḥ ti
translated: The celestial chariot has come forth, for the famous one of Videha.”

original: Tattha abbhutoti abhūtapubbo. Acchariyoti te vimhayavasenevamāhaṃsu.
analyzed: tattha abbhutoti abhūta pubbaḥ acchariyoti te vimhaya vasena ivam āhaṃsu
translated: Therein, wonderful means previously non-existent. Amazing means they spoke thus out of wonder.

original: Tassa pana mahājanassa evaṃ kathentasseva mātali vātavegena āgantvā rathaṃ nivattetvā
analyzed: tassa pana mahā janassa evam kathentassa iva mātali vāta vegena āgantvā ratham nivattetvā
translated: But while that great crowd was speaking thus, Mātali, having come with the speed of the wind, turned the chariot around,

original: sīhapañjaraummāre pacchābhāgena ṭhapetvā ārohaṇasajjaṃ katvā ārohaṇatthāya rājānaṃ
analyzed: sīha pañjara aummāre pacchā bhāgena ṭhapetvā ārohaṇa sajjam katvā ārohaṇa tthāya rājānam
translated: and having placed it behind the lion-netted rampart, having made it ready for mounting, he invited the king

original: nimantesi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: nimantesi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: to mount it. Expounding that matter, the Teacher said:

original: “Devaputto mahiddhiko, mātali devasārathi;
analyzed: deva puttaḥ mahiddhikaḥ mātali deva sārathi
translated: “The deva-son of great power, Mātali, the deva-charioteer,

original: Nimantayittha rājānaṃ, vedehaṃ mithilaggahaṃ.
analyzed: nimantayittha rājānam vedeham mithila ggaham
translated: invited the king, the lord of Videha, the one who had his abode in Mithilā.

original: “Ehimaṃ rathamāruyha, rājaseṭṭha disampati;🔽Devā dassanakāmā te, tāvatiṃsā saindakā;
analyzed: ehi imam ratham āruyha rāja seṭṭha disampati  devā dassana kāmā te tāvatiṃsā saindakā
translated: “Having mounted this chariot, O king, best of kings, lord of the land,🔽the devas, the Tāvatiṃsas, the Saindakā,

original: Saramānā hi te devā, sudhammāyaṃ samacchare”ti.
analyzed: saramānāḥ hi te devā sudhammā ayam samacchara iti
translated: the devas, longing to see you, have assembled in Sudhammā.”

original: Tattha mithilaggahanti mithilāyaṃ patiṭṭhitagehaṃ, catūhi vā saṅgahavatthūhi mithilāyaṃ saṅgāhakaṃ. Samacchareti taveva guṇakathaṃ kathentā nisinnāti.🔽Taṃ sutvā rājā “adiṭṭhapubbaṃ devalokañca passissāmi, mātalissa ca me saṅgaho kato
analyzed: tattha mithila ggahanti mithilāyam patiṭṭhita geham catūhi vā saṅgaha vatthūhi mithilāyam saṅgāhakam tava iva guṇa katham kathentā nisinnā ati  tam sutvā rājā adiṭṭha pubbam deva lokañca passissāmi mātalissa ca me saṅgahaḥ kato
translated: The king replied, “I will go to Mithilā, to the house of the king of the Videhans.”

original: bhavissati, gacchissāmī”ti cintetvā antepurañca mahājanañca āmantetvā “ahaṃ nacirasseva
analyzed: bhavissati gacchissāmi iti cintetvā antepuram ca mahājanam ca āmantetvā aham nacirassa iva
translated: When the king heard this, he thought to himself, “I will see the city of the gods, which I have never seen before, and I will have the opportunity to make the acquaintance of Mātali. I will go.” So he summoned his court and the people of the city and said to them, “I will return soon.

original: āgamissāmi, tumhe appamattā dānādīni puññāni karothā”ti vatvā rathaṃ abhiruhi. Tamatthaṃ
analyzed: āgamissāmi tumhe appamattāḥ dāna ādīni puññāni karotha ati vatvā ratham abhiruhi tam attham
translated: In the meantime, be diligent in the performance of works of charity and the like.” So saying, he mounted his chariot.

original: pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: To make this clear, the Master said,

original: “Tato rājā taramāno, vedeho mithilaggaho;
analyzed: tatas rājā taramānaḥ vedehaḥ mithilaggahaḥ
translated: “Then the king of the Videhans, the lord of Mithilā,

original: Āsanā vuṭṭhahitvāna, pamukho rathamāruhi.
analyzed: āsanā vuṭṭhahitvāna pamukhaḥ ratham āruhi
translated: Arose from his seat and mounted his chariot.

original: “Abhirūḷhaṃ rathaṃ dibbaṃ, mātali etadabravi;
analyzed: abhirūḍham ratham dibbam mātali etat abravi
translated: When he had mounted his chariot, Mātali said to him,

original: Kena taṃ nemi maggena, rājaseṭṭha disampati;
analyzed: kena tam nemi maggena rāja seṭṭha disampati
translated: “By what road shall I take you, king of kings,

original: Yena vā pāpakammantā, puññakammā ca ye narā”ti.
analyzed: yena vā pāpa kammantā puñña kammā ca ye
translated: By which you may see the good and the evil deeds of men?”

original: Tattha pamukhoti uttamo, abhimukho vā, mahājanassa piṭṭhiṃ datvā ārūḷhoti attho.
analyzed: tattha pamukhaḥ ti uttamaḥ abhimukhaḥ vā mahājanassa piṭṭhim da tvā ārūḷhaḥ
translated: Herein, the foremost is the best, or else facing, the meaning is that he mounted giving his back to the great crowd.

original: Yena vāti yena maggena gantvā yattha pāpakammantā vasanti, taṃ ṭhānaṃ sakkā daṭṭhuṃ,
analyzed: yena vāti yena maggena gantvā yattha pāpa kammantāḥ vasanti tam ṭhānam sakkā daṭṭhum
translated: By which way, by which road, having gone to where there are evil-doers, that place can be seen,

original: yena vā gantvā ye puññakammā narā vasanti, tesaṃ ṭhānaṃ sakkā daṭṭhuṃ, etesu dvīsu
analyzed: yena vā gantvā ye puñña kammāḥ narāḥ vasanti tesam ṭhānam sakkā daṭṭhum etesu dvīsu
translated: or else by which way having gone to where there are meritorious people, their place can be seen, in these two

original: kena maggena taṃ nemi. Idaṃ so sakkena anāṇattopi attano dūtavisesadassanatthaṃ āha.
analyzed: kena maggena tam nemi idam saḥ sakkena an āṇattaḥ api attanaḥ dūta visesa dassana attham āha
translated: by which road will you take me? This he said although it was not pointed out to him by Sakka, in order to show his own special skill as a charioteer.

original: Atha naṃ rājā “mayā dve ṭhānāni adiṭṭhapubbāni, dvepi passissāmī”ti cintetvā āha –
analyzed: atha nam rājā mayā dve ṭhānāni a diṭṭha pubbāni dve api passissāmi iti cintetvā āha
translated: Then the King, thinking “I have never seen either of these two places before, I will see both,” said:

original: “Ubhayeneva maṃ nehi, mātali devasārathi;
analyzed: ubhayena iva mam nehi mātali deva sārathi
translated: “Take me by both ways, Mātali, charioteer of the gods,

original: Yena vā pāpakammantā, puññakammā ca ye narā”ti.
analyzed: yena vā pāpa kammantā puñña kammā ca ye
translated: To where there are evil-doers, and to where there are meritorious people.”

original: Tato mātali “dvepi ekapahāreneva na sakkā dassetuṃ, pucchissāmi na”nti pucchanto puna gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas mātali dve api eka pahārena iva na sakkā dassetum pucchissāmi pucchantaḥ puna gātham āha
translated: Then Mātali thought “It is not possible to show both at one time, I will ask him,” and asking, he spoke this verse:

original: “Kena taṃ paṭhamaṃ nemi, rājaseṭṭha disampati;
analyzed: kena tam paṭhamam nemi rāja seṭṭha
translated: “By which way first will you go, King, lord of the land?

original: Yena vā pāpakammantā, puññakammā ca ye narā”ti.
analyzed: yena vā pāpa kammantā puñña kammā ca ye
translated: To where there are evil-doers, or to where there are meritorious people?”

original: Nirayakaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: niraya kaṇḍam
translated: The Hell-Realm

original: Tato rājā “ahaṃ avassaṃ devalokaṃ gamissāmi, nirayaṃ tāva passissāmī”ti cintetvā anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tatas rājā aham avassam deva lokam gamissāmi nirayam tāva passissāmi iti cintetvā anantaram gātham āha
translated: Then the king thought, “I am sure to go to the world of the gods, but first I will see the hell realm.” Accordingly he spoke the next verse:

original: “Niraye tāva passāmi, āvāse pāpakamminaṃ;🔽Ṭhānāni luddakammānaṃ, dussīlānañca yā gatī”ti.
analyzed: niraye tāva passāmi āvāse pāpa kamminaṃ  ṭhānāni ludda kammānam dussīlānam ca yā gatī iti
translated: I will see the hell realm, the abode of evil-doers,🔽The places where the butchers and the wicked go.

original: Tattha yā gatīti yā etesaṃ nibbatti, tañca passāmīti.
analyzed: tattha yā gati iti yā etesam nibbatti tat ca passāmi iti
translated: “The places where they go” means the place where they are reborn; I will see that.

original: Athassa vetaraṇiṃ nadiṃ tāva dassesi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: athassa vetaraṇim nadim tāva dassesi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: Then Mātali showed him the river Vaitaraṇi. Expounding that situation, the Master said:

original: “Dassesi mātali rañño, duggaṃ vetaraṇiṃ nadiṃ;
analyzed: dassesi mātali raññaḥ duggam vetaraṇim nadim
translated: Mātali showed the king the river Vaitaraṇi,

original: Kuthitaṃ khārasaṃyuttaṃ, tattaṃ aggisikhūpama”nti.
analyzed: kuthitam khāra saṃyuttam tattam

analyzed: viya pīḷenti lohitam pakkuthitam sandati kadāci tayo pabbatā samuṭṭhāya pīḷenti
translated: Two mountains rise up and crush them like a pair of tongs. Their blood boils and flows out. Sometimes three mountains rise up and crush them.

original: Kadāci cattāro pabbatā samuṭṭhāya tāsaṃ sarīraṃ pīḷenti. Tenāha “khandhātivattantī”ti.
analyzed: kadāci cattāro pabbatā samuṭṭhāya tāsam sarīram pīḍenti tena āha khandhā ativattanti iti
translated: Sometimes four mountains rise up and crush their bodies. That is why it is said, “The mountains rise up and crush them.”

original: Kolitthiyāyoti kule patiṭṭhitā kuladhītaro. Asataṃ acārunti asaññatakammaṃ kariṃsu.🔽Dittarūpāti saṭharūpā dhuttajātikā hutvā. Pati vippahāyāti attano patiṃ pajahitvā.
analyzed: kolitthiyāyaḥ ti kule patiṭṭhitā kula dhītaraḥ asatam acārunti asaññata kammam kariṃsu  dittarūpā ati saṭha rūpā dhutta jātikā hutvā pati vippahāya ati attanaḥ patim pajahitvā
translated: “Women of good families”: women of good families who have gone forth. “They did what was evil and wicked”: they did what was not in accordance with the Teaching.🔽“They were adulteresses”: they were adulteresses, of loose character. “They abandoned their husbands”: they abandoned their husbands.

original: Acārunti agamaṃsu. Ratikhiḍḍahetūti kāmaratihetu ceva khiḍḍāhetu ca. Ramāpayitvāti
analyzed: acārunti agamaṃsu rati khiḍḍa hetū iti kāma rati hetu ca iva khiḍḍā hetu ca ramāpayitvā ati
translated: “They did what was wicked”: they went to a bad destination. “For the sake of pleasure and amusement”: for the sake of sensual pleasure and amusement. “They amused themselves”:

original: parapurisehi saddhiṃ attano cittaṃ ramāpayitvā idha upapannā. Atha tāsaṃ sarīraṃ
analyzed: para purisehi saddhim attanaḥ cittam ramāpayitvā idha upapannāḥ atha tāsam sarīram
translated: they amused their minds with other men. They were reborn here. Then the mountains

original: ime khandhātivattanti sajotibhūtāti.
analyzed: ime khandhā ativattanti sajoti bhūtā ati
translated: rise up and crush them.

original: “Pāde gahetvā kissa ime puneke, avaṃsirā narake pātayanti;
analyzed: pāde gahetvā kissa ime punar eke avaṃsirāḥ narake pātayanti
translated: “Why do they seize them by the feet and throw them headlong into hell?

original: Bhayañhi maṃ vindati sūta disvā, pucchāmi taṃ mātali devasārathi;
analyzed: bhayan hi mam vindati sūta disvā pucchāmi tam mātali deva sārathi
translated: I ask you, O Mātali, charioteer of the gods,

original: Ime nu maccā kimakaṃsu pāpaṃ, yeme janā avaṃsirā narake pātayanti.
analyzed: ime nu matcā pāpam ye ime janāḥ avaṃsirāḥ narake pātayanti
translated: What evil have these mortals done, that they are hurled headlong into hell?

original: “Tassa puṭṭho viyākāsi, mātali devasārathi;
analyzed: tassa puṭṭhaḥ mātali deva sārathi
translated: “Asked, he answered, Mātali, charioteer of the gods,

original: Vipākaṃ pāpakammānaṃ, jānaṃ akkhāsijānato.
analyzed: vipākam pāpa kammānam jānam
translated: Knowing, he declared the result of evil deeds, knowing.

original: “Ye jīvalokasmiṃ asādhukammino, parassa dārāni atikkamanti;
analyzed: ye jīva lokasmiṃ a sādhu kamminaḥ parassa dārāni atikkamanti
translated: “Those who in the world of the living are not good, who transgress the wives of others,

original: Te tādisā uttamabhaṇḍathenā, teme janā avaṃsirā narake pātayanti.
analyzed: te tādisāḥ tā ime janāḥ avaṃsirāḥ narake pātayanti
translated: Such are they, the best of thieves, and they are hurled headlong into hell.

original: “Te vassapūgāni bahūni tattha, nirayesu dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayanti;
analyzed: te vassa pūgāni bahūni tattha nirayesu dukkham vedanam vedayanti
translated: “For many a year they experience pain in the hells,

analyzed: na hi pāpa kārissa bhavanti tāṇāḥ sakehi kammehi purakkhatassa
translated: For the doer of evil has no protection, he is overcome by his own deeds;

analyzed: te ludda kammā pasavetva pāpam tā ime janāḥ avaṃsirāḥ narake pātayanti iti
translated: Having committed evil deeds, they are hurled headlong into hell.”

analyzed: tattha naraka iti jalita aṅgāra puṇṇe mahā āvāṭe te kira vajam a pavisantiyaḥ gāvaḥ
translated: There, in hell, means in a great pit filled with burning coals. They, it seems, enter the iron cauldron like cows.

analyzed: niraya pālehi nānā vudhāni gahetvā vijjhiyamānā pothiyamānā yadā tam narakam upagacchanti
translated: When they come to that hell, the warders of hell, armed with various weapons, pierce them and cleave them.

analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā mātalisaṅgāhakaḥ tam nirayam antaradhāpetvā ratham puratas pesetvā micchādiṭṭhikānam paccanaṭṭhānam nirayam dassesi tena puṭṭhaḥ ca ssa viyākāsi
translated: Having said this, the charioteer caused that hell to disappear, sent the chariot forward, and showed the hell where those of wrong view are cooked. He asked about it and the charioteer explained.

analyzed: vissāsa kammāni iti tāya diṭṭhiyā vissāsena tad nissitāḥ hutvā nānāvidhāni pāpa kammāni

translated: “These people” means these people experience such suffering.

analyzed: iti raññaḥ micchādiṭṭhikānam paccana nirayam ācikkhi deva loke pi deva gaṇāḥ raññaḥ āgamana maggam

analyzed: sakkā cirāyitunti raññaḥ eka pahārena iva catūsu disāsu bahū niraye dassetvā gātham āha

analyzed: tassa atthaḥ mahā rāja imam pāpa kammīnam sattānam āvāsam disvā ludda kammānam ca ṭhānāni  tayā viditāni dussīlānam ca yā gati nibbatti sā api te viditā idāni devarājassa santike
translated: The meaning is: “Great king, having seen this abode of wicked beings and the places of the hunters,🔽and having known the destiny, the rebirth, of the unvirtuous, now go, go to the presence of the King of the Gods

analyzed: ahosi sā tena brāhmaṇena aṭṭha salākabhattāni saṅghassa pariccattāni  ahesum saḥ geham gantvā sve paṭṭhāya ekekassa bhikkhussa ekekam kahāpaṇa gghanakam  katvā aṭṭha salākabhattāni sampādeyyāsi iti brāhmaṇiṃ āha sā sāmi bhikkhu nāma
translated: She was given eight portions of food by that brahmin.🔽When he got home he said to his wife, “From tomorrow on you must provide eight portions of food, making one kahāpaṇa for each bhikkhu.”

analyzed: veḷuriyā arucirā citrā dhārayanti su nimmitā
translated: Well-constructed.🔽“There are eight pillars, well-fashioned,

original: “Aṭṭhaṃsā sukatā thambhā, sabbe veḷuriyāmayā;
analyzed: aṭṭhaṃsā sukatā thambhā sabbe veḷuriyāmayā
translated: All of beryl,🔽Where the Thirty-Three Gods

analyzed: devā tāvatiṃsā sabbe inda purohitā
translated: All with Indra as their chief.🔽“They all agree in thinking

analyzed: attham deva manussānam cintayantā samacchare
translated: For the benefit of gods and men;🔽When one enters, the king

translated: Rejoices with the gods.

original: Tattha idanti nipātamattaṃ, devasabhaṃ addasāti attho. Passesāti passa esā. Veḷuriyā🔽rucirāti ruciraveḷuriyā. Citrāti nānāratanavicitrā. Dhārayantīti imaṃ sabhaṃ ete
analyzed: tattha idam ti nipāta mattam deva sabham addasā ati attho passa isā ati passe esā veḷuriyā  rucirā ati citrā ati nānā ratana vicitrā dhārayanti iti imam sabham ete
translated: There, the word idha is merely an indeclinable; the meaning is: ‘I saw the hall of the gods.’ Passesā: pass esā. Beryl:🔽Lovely: lovely beryl. Variegated: variegated with various gems. Well-constructed: these well-fashioned pillars, etc.,

original: aṭṭhaṃsādibhedā sukatā thambhā dhārayanti. Indapurohitāti indaṃ purohitaṃ purecārikaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhaṃsa ādi bhedā thambhāḥ dhārayanti inda purohitā ati indam purohitam purecārikam
translated: support this hall. With Indra as their chief: with Indra as their chief, their leader, their forerunner.

original: katvā parivāretvā ṭhitā devamanussānaṃ atthaṃ cintayantā acchanti. Pavisetenāti iminā
analyzed: katvā parivāretvā ṭhitāḥ deva manussānam attham cintayantāḥ acchanti pavisa etena ati iminā
translated: and stood around him, thinking of the welfare of the gods and men. “Enter” means

original: maggena yattha devā aññamaññaṃ anumodantā acchanti, taṃ ṭhānaṃ devānaṃ anumodanaṃ pavisa.🔽Devāpi kho tassāgamanamaggaṃ olokentāva nisīdiṃsu. Te “rājā āgato”ti sutvā dibbagandhavāsapupphahatthā
analyzed: maggena yattha devāḥ aññam aññam anumodantāḥ acchanti tam ṭhānam devānam anumodanam pavisa  devā api kho tassa āgamana maggam olokentā ava nisīdiṃsu te rājā āgataḥ iti sutvā dibba gandha vāsa puppha hatthā
translated: enter the place where the gods sit rejoicing in one another’s good fortune.

original: yāva cittakūṭadvārakoṭṭhakā paṭimaggaṃ gantvā mahāsattaṃ dibbagandhamālādīhi pūjayantā
analyzed: yāva cittakūṭa dvāra koṭṭhakā paṭimaggam gantvā mahāsattam dibba gandha mālā ādīhi pūjayantā
translated: The gods, too, sat looking down the road by which the king was coming. When they heard that the king had come, they went out to meet him as far as the gate of Cittakūṭa, bearing celestial perfumes, garlands, and flowers, and paid homage to the Great Being with celestial perfumes, garlands, and the like.

original: sudhammādevasabhaṃ ānayiṃsu. Rājā rathā otaritvā devasabhaṃ pāvisi. Devā āsanena
analyzed: sudhammādevasabham ānayiṃsu rājā rathau otaritvā devasabham pāvisi devāḥ āsanena
translated: They then led him to the Sudhamma Assembly Hall. The king alighted from his chariot and entered the assembly hall. The gods invited him to be seated.

original: nimantayiṃsu. Sakkopi āsanena ceva kāmehi ca nimantesi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: nimantayiṃsu sakko api āsanena ca iva kāmehi ca nimantesi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: Sakka, too, invited him to be seated and offered him celestial pleasures. Expounding this matter, the Master said:🔽“The gods rejoiced to see

original: “Taṃ devā paṭinandiṃsu, disvā rājānamāgataṃ;
analyzed: tam devā disvā rājānam āgatam
translated: The king who had come to their realm;🔽‘Welcome, great king, and well done!🔽You have come a long way.

original: Svāgataṃ te mahārāja, atho te adurāgataṃ;
analyzed: svāgatam te mahā rāja atho te adurāgatam
translated: Now sit down, great king,

original: Nisīda dāni rājīsi, devarājassa santike.
analyzed: nisīda dāni rājīsi devarājassa santike
translated: In the presence of the king of the gods.’

original: “Sakkopi paṭinandittha, vedehaṃ mithilaggahaṃ;
analyzed: sakko api mithila ggaham
translated: Sakka welcomed him, the lord of Videha, the lord of Mithila,

original: Nimantayittha kāmehi, āsanena ca vāsavo.
analyzed: nimantayittha kāmehi āsanena ca vāsavaḥ
translated: And Vāsava invited him with sensual pleasures and with a seat.

original: “Sādhu khosi anuppatto, āvāsaṃ vasavattinaṃ;
analyzed: sādhu kho asi an uppattaḥ āvāsam vasa vattinam
translated: “You have come well, indeed, to the abode of the powerful one;

original: Vasa devesu rājīsi, sabbakāmasamiddhisu;
analyzed: vasa devesu rājīsi sabba kāma samiddhisu
translated: Live among the gods, O king, in the enjoyment of all desires fulfilled;

original: Tāvatiṃsesu devesu, bhuñja kāme amānuse”ti.
analyzed: tāvatiṃsesu devesu bhuñja kāme amānusa iti
translated: Among the Thirty-Three gods, enjoy divine sensual pleasures.”

original: Tattha paṭinandiṃsūti sampiyāyiṃsu, haṭṭhatuṭṭhāva hutvā sampaṭicchiṃsu. Sabbakāmasamiddhisūti sabbesaṃ kāmānaṃ samiddhiyuttesu.
analyzed: tattha paṭinandiṃsu iti sampiyāyiṃsu haṭṭha tuṭṭhā va hutvā sampaṭicchiṃsu sabba kāma samiddhisu iti sabbesam kāmānam samiddhi yuttesu
translated: There, they welcomed him means they were pleased, they accepted him with delight and satisfaction. In the enjoyment of all desires fulfilled means in the enjoyment of all desires fulfilled.

original: Evaṃ sakkena dibbakāmehi ceva āsanena ca nimantito rājā paṭikkhipanto āha –
analyzed: evam sakkena dibba kāmehi ca iva āsanena ca nimantitaḥ rājā paṭikkhipantaḥ āha
translated: Thus, the king, having been invited by Sakka with divine sensual pleasures and with a seat, refused, saying:

original: “Yathā yācitakaṃ yānaṃ, yathā yācitakaṃ dhanaṃ;
analyzed: yathā yācitakam yānam yathā yācitakam dhanam
translated: “Just as a vehicle is sought, just as wealth is sought,

original: Evaṃ sampadamevetaṃ, yaṃ parato dānapaccayā.
analyzed: evam sampadam evā itam yam paratas dāna paccayā
translated: So is this prosperity, which is dependent on gifts from others.

original: “Na cāhametamicchāmi, yaṃ parato dānapaccayā;
analyzed: na ca aham etam icchāmi yam paratas dāna paccayā
translated: “I do not desire this, which is dependent on gifts from others;

original: Sayaṃkatāni puññāni, taṃ me āveṇikaṃ dhanaṃ.
analyzed: sayaṃkatāni puññāni tam me āveṇikam dhanam
translated: My own-made merits are my unique wealth.

original: “Sohaṃ gantvā manussesu, kāhāmi kusalaṃ bahuṃ;
analyzed: sā uham gantvā manussesu kāhāmi kusalam bahum
translated: “So I will go among humans and do much good;

original: Dānena samacariyāya, saṃyamena damena ca;
analyzed: dānena sama cariyāya saṃyamena damena ca
translated: By giving, by good conduct, by restraint, and by self-control;

original: Yaṃ katvā sukhito hoti, na ca pacchānutappatī”ti.
analyzed: yam katvā sukhitaḥ hoti na ca pacchā anutappati iti
translated: Having done which he is happy, and does not repent in the future.”

original: Tattha yaṃ parato dānapaccayāti yaṃ parato tassa parassa dānapaccayā tena dinnattā
analyzed: tattha yam paratas dāna paccayā ati yam paratas tassa parassa dāna paccayā tena dinna ttā
translated: Herein, that which is dependent on the giving of another is that which is obtained by me through the giving of another, because it is given by him,

original: labbhati, taṃ yācitakasadisaṃ hoti, tasmā nāhaṃ etaṃ icchāmi. Sayaṃkatānīti yāni🔽pana mayā attanā katāni puññāni, tameva mama parehi asādhāraṇattā āveṇikaṃ dhanaṃ
analyzed: labbhati tam yācitaka sadisam hoti tasmā na aham etam icchāmi sayaṃkatāni iti yāni  pana mayā attanā katāni puññāni tam eva mama parehi a sādhāraṇa ttā āveṇikam dhanam
translated: it is similar to the gift of a supplicant, therefore I do not desire it. Those which are self-made are those which are made by me myself,

original: anugāmiyadhanaṃ. Samacariyāyāti tīhi dvārehi samacariyāya. Saṃyamenāti sīlarakkhaṇena.
analyzed: anugāmiya dhanam sama cariyāya ati tīhi dvārehi sama cariyāya saṃyamena ati sīla rakkhaṇena
translated: that alone is my unique wealth, because it is not shared with others, it is the wealth which follows. By good conduct: by good conduct through the three doors. By restraint: by the protection of virtue.

original: Damenāti indriyadamena.
analyzed: damena ati indriya damena
translated: By control: by the control of the senses.

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto devānaṃ madhurasaddena dhammaṃ desesi. Dhammaṃ desentoyeva manussagaṇanāya
analyzed: evam mahāsattaḥ devānam madhura saddena dhammam desesi dhammam desentaḥ yeva manussa gaṇanāya
translated: Thus the Great Being taught the Dhamma to the gods with a sweet voice. Teaching the Dhamma in this way, he remained for seven days according to human reckoning,

original: satta divasāni ṭhatvā devagaṇaṃ kosetvā devagaṇamajjhe ṭhitova mātalissa guṇaṃ kathento āha –
analyzed: satta divasāni ṭhatvā deva gaṇam kosetvā deva gaṇa majjhe ṭhitaḥ uva mātalissa guṇam kathentaḥ āha
translated: and after having gladdened the assembly of gods, he remained in the midst of the assembly of gods and spoke about the virtues of Mātali, saying:

original: “Bahūpakāro no bhavaṃ, mātali devasārathi;
analyzed: bahu upakāraḥ naḥ bhavam mātali deva sārathi
translated: “You are a great benefactor to us, Bhavamātali, charioteer of the gods,

original: Yo me kalyāṇakammānaṃ, pāpānaṃ paṭidassayī”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ me kalyāṇa kammānam pāpānam paṭidassayi iti
translated: who has shown me the good deeds and the bad.”

original: Tattha yo me kalyāṇakammānaṃ, pāpānaṃ paṭidassayīti yo esa mayhaṃ kalyāṇakammānaṃ devānañca ṭhānāni pāpakammānaṃ nerayikānañca pāpāni ṭhānāni dassesīti attho.
analyzed: tattha yaḥ me kalyāṇa kammānam pāpānam paṭidassayi iti yaḥ esa mayham kalyāṇa kammānam devānam ca ṭhānāni pāpa kammānam nerayikānam ca pāpāni ṭhānāni dassesi iti atthaḥ
translated: “He who has shown me the places of good deeds and of evil deeds,” i.e., he who has shown me the places of the gods for good deeds and the places of the hells for evil deeds.

original: Saggakaṇḍaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: sagga kaṇḍam niṭṭhitam
translated: The section on heaven is finished.

original: Atha rājā sakkaṃ āmantetvā “icchāmahaṃ, mahārāja, manussalokaṃ gantu”nti āha. Sakko
analyzed: atha rājā sakkam āmantetvā icchāmaham mahā rāja manussa lokam gantunti āha sakkaḥ
translated: Then the king addressed Sakka, saying, “Great king, I wish to go to the world of men.” Sakka
