analyzed: tena hi samma mātali nimi rājānam tattha iva mithilam nehi iti āha saḥ sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā
translated: said, “Well then, dear Mātali, take King Nimi to Mithilā.” He agreed, saying, “Very well,”

original: rathaṃ upaṭṭhāpesi. Rājā devagaṇehi saddhiṃ sammoditvā deve nivattāpetvā rathaṃ abhiruhi.
analyzed: ratham upaṭṭhāpesi rājā deva gaṇehi saddhim sammoditvā deve nivattāpetvā ratham abhiruhi
translated: and prepared the chariot. The king, after exchanging greetings with the hosts of gods, sent the gods away and mounted the chariot.

original: Mātali rathaṃ pesento pācīnadisābhāgena mithilaṃ pāpuṇi. Mahājano dibbarathaṃ disvā
analyzed: mātali ratham pesentaḥ pācīna disā bhāgena mithilam pāpuṇi mahā janaḥ dibba ratham disvā
translated: Mātali, driving the chariot, reached Mithilā in the eastern direction. The great multitude, seeing the divine chariot,

original: “rājā no āgato”ti pamudito ahosi. Mātali mithilaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tasmiṃyeva sīhapañjare
analyzed: rājā no āgataḥ iti pamuditaḥ ahosi mātali mithilam padakkhiṇam katvā tasmin yeva sīha pañjare
translated: was delighted, thinking, “Our king has come.” Mātali, after circumambulating Mithilā, stopped the chariot in the very same lion’s seat

original: mahāsattaṃ otāretvā “gacchāmahaṃ, mahārājā”ti āpucchitvā sakaṭṭhānameva gato. Mahājanopi
analyzed: mahāsattam otāretvā gacchāmaham mahā rāja iti āpucchitvā saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ mahā janaḥ api
translated: The Great Being took him down, and after asking his permission, went back to his own place. The people

original: rājānaṃ parivāretvā “kīdiso, deva, devaloko”ti pucchi. Rājā devatānañca sakkassa🔽ca devarañño sampattiṃ vaṇṇetvā “tumhepi dānādīni puññāni karotha, evaṃ tasmiṃ devaloke
analyzed: rājānam parivāretvā kīdisaḥ deva deva lokaḥ iti pucchi rājā devatānam ca sakkassa  ca deva rañño sampattim vaṇṇetvā tumhe api dāna ādīni puññāni karotha evam tasmin deva loke
translated: gathered round the king and asked him, “What is the world of the gods like, your majesty?” The king described the glory of the gods and of Sakka,

original: nibbattissathā”ti mahājanassa dhammaṃ desesi.
analyzed: nibbattissatha ati mahājanassa dhammaṃ desesi
translated: king of the gods, and preached the Dhamma to the people, saying, “Do you also perform works of merit such as charity, and you will be reborn in that world of the gods.”

original: So aparabhāge kappakena palitassa jātabhāve ārocite palitaṃ suvaṇṇasaṇḍāsena uddharāpetvā
analyzed: saḥ aparabhāge kappakena palitassa jāta bhāve ārocite palitam suvaṇṇa saṇḍāsena uddharāpetvā
translated: Later, when the royal priest announced that the king’s hair was turning gray, the king had the gray hairs pulled out with a golden tweezers,

original: hatthe ṭhapetvā kappakassa gāmavaraṃ datvā pabbajitukāmo hutvā puttassa rajjaṃ paṭicchāpesi.
analyzed: hatthe ṭhapetvā kappakassa gāma varam da tvā pabbajitu kāmaḥ hutvā puttassa rajjam paṭicchāpesi
translated: placed in his hand, and gave the royal priest a choice village. Then, desiring to retire from the world, he made over the kingdom to his son.

original: Tena ca “kasmā, deva, pabbajissasī”ti vutte –
analyzed: tena ca kasmā deva pabbajissasi iti vutte
translated: When the latter asked him, “Why do you retire from the world, father?” he replied,

original: “Uttamaṅgaruhā mayhaṃ, ime jātā vayoharā;
analyzed: uttamaṅgaruhā ime jātāḥ vayaḥ harā
translated: “These gray hairs have appeared on my head, the sign of old age;

original: Pāhubhūtā devadūtā, pabbajjāsamayo mamā”ti. –
analyzed: pāhu bhūtā deva dūtā pabbajjā samayaḥ mama ati
translated: The messengers of the gods have come to me, and it is time for me to retire from the world.”

original: Gāthaṃ vatvā purimarājāno viya pabbajitvā tasmiṃyeva ambavane viharanto cattāro brahmavihāre
analyzed: gātham vatvā purima rājānaḥ viya pabbajitvā tasmin yeva ambavane viharantaḥ cattāraḥ brahmavihāre
translated: Having recited this verse, he went forth into the homeless state, and while dwelling in that very mango grove, he developed the four divine abodes.

original: bhāvetvā brahmalokūpago ahosi. Tassevaṃ pabbajitabhāvaṃ āvikaronto satthā osānagāthamāha –
analyzed: bhāvetvā brahma loka upagaḥ ahosi tassa ivam pabbajita bhāvam āvikarontaḥ satthā osāna gātham āha
translated: Afterward he was reborn in the Brahma-world. In the last line of the Stanza the Teacher refers to the fact that the king went forth into the homeless state.

original: “Idaṃ vatvā nimirājā, vedeho mithilaggaho;
analyzed: idam vatvā nimi rājā vedehaḥ mithila ggahaḥ
translated: Having thus spoken, King Nimi, the Videhan, the lord of Mithila,

original: Puthuyaññaṃ yajitvāna, saṃyamaṃ ajjhupāgamī”ti.
analyzed: puthuyaññam yajitvāna saṃyamam ajjhupāgami iti
translated: Having sacrificed the great sacrifice, entered upon the life of self-control.

original: Tattha idaṃ vatvāti “uttamaṅgaruhā mayha”nti imaṃ gāthaṃ vatvā. Puthuyaññaṃ yajitvānāti mahādānaṃ datvā. Saṃyamaṃ ajjhupāgamīti sīlasaṃyamaṃ upagato.
analyzed: tattha idam vatvā iti uttama aṅgaruhā mayhanti imam gātham vatvā mahā dānam da tvā saṃyamam ajjhupāgami iti sīla saṃyamam upagataḥ
translated: Having thus spoken, having recited this verse, “The choicest of all beings am I,” he sacrificed the great sacrifice, that is, he gave abundant gifts, and entered upon the life of self-control, that is, he undertook the self-control of morality.

original: Putto panassa kāḷārajanako nāma taṃ vaṃsaṃ upacchindi.
analyzed: puttaḥ panassa kāḷārajanakaḥ nāma tam vaṃsam upacchindi
translated: But his son, named Kāḷārajanaka, cut off that line of kings.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi tathāgato mahābhinikkhamanaṃ
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi tathāgataḥ mahā abhinikkhamanam
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time the Tathāgata has gone forth into homelessness;

original: nikkhantoyevā”ti vatvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi “tadā sakko anuruddho ahosi, mātali ānando,
analyzed: nikkhantaḥ yā iva ati vatvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā sakkaḥ anuruddhaḥ ahosi mātali ānando
translated: in a previous state of existence also he went forth into homelessness.” So saying, he related in detail the Jātaka of the Past, of which the following is the Stanza, “The choicest of all beings am I.” At that time Sakka was Anuruddha, and Mātali was Ānanda.

original: caturāsīti khattiyasahassāni buddhaparisā, nimirājā pana ahameva sammāsambuddho ahosi”nti.
analyzed: caturāsīti khattiya sahassāni buddha parisā nimi rājā pana aham eva sammāsambuddhaḥ ahosin ti
translated: So said the Exalted One, and the monks rejoiced and were delighted at his words.

original: Nimijātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.
analyzed: nimi jātaka vaṇṇanā catutthā
translated: The Story of the Birth of Nimi is ended.

original: [542] 5. Umaṅgajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Birth of Udaya

original: Pañcālo sabbasenāyāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto paññāpāramiṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: pañcālaḥ sabba senāya ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ paññāpāramiṃ ārabbha kathesi
translated: Once upon a time when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta came to life as a prince, and when he grew up he was known as Prince Udaya.🔽When he was twenty years old, his father died, and he was anointed king.🔽He was a king of great wisdom, and he had a minister named Udayabhaddhi.

original: Ekadivasañhi bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ sannisinnā tathāgatassa paññāpāramiṃ vaṇṇayantā
analyzed: eka divasam hi bhikkhū dhamma sabhāyam sannisinnāḥ tathāgatassa paññāpāramim vaṇṇayantā
translated: One day the king was sitting in the judgment-hall, and the minister came and sat down by him.

original: nisīdiṃsu “mahāpañño, āvuso, tathāgato puthupañño gambhīrapañño hāsapañño javanapañño
analyzed: nisīdiṃsu mahā paññaḥ āvuso tathāgataḥ puthu paññaḥ gambhīra paññaḥ hāsa paññaḥ javana paññaḥ
translated: “What is the cause, my lord,” said he, “of the great prosperity of your kingdom?”🔽“It is the result of my wisdom, my good friend.”🔽“But what is the cause of your wisdom?”🔽“It is the result of my learning.”🔽“But what is the cause of your learning?”

original: tikkhapañño nibbedhikapañño parappavādamaddano, attano paññānubhāvena kūṭadantādayo
analyzed: tikkha paññaḥ nibbedhika pañño para pavāda maddanaḥ attano paññā anubhāvena kūṭadanta ādayaḥ
translated: “It is the result of my going to school.”🔽“But what is the cause of your going to school?”🔽“It is the result of my being born in a good family.”🔽“But what is the cause of your being born in a good family?”

original: brāhmaṇe, sabhiyādayo paribbājake, aṅgulimālādayo core, āḷavakādayo yakkhe, sakkādayo
analyzed: brāhmaṇe sabhiya ādayo paribbājake aṅguli mālā ādayo core āḷavaka ādayo yakkhe sakka ādayo
translated: “It is the result of my having been virtuous in a former life.”🔽“But what is the cause of your being virtuous?”🔽“It is the result of my having been charitable in a former life.”🔽“But what is the cause of your being charitable?”🔽“It is the result of my having been contented in a former life.”

original: deve, bakādayo brahmāno ca dametvā nibbisevane akāsi, bahujanakāye pabbajjaṃ datvā

original: cattāro aggikkhandhā mahāpākārappamāṇā uṭṭhāya pajjalanti. Tesaṃ majjhe khajjopanakappamāṇo

translated: Here “in a state of confusion” means that they are in a state of confusion because of the loss of their prosperity and are in a state of misfortune. “They do not abandon the Dhamma” means that they do not abandon the Dhamma of the lineage or the Dhamma of good conduct.

original: Puna rājā tassa vīmaṃsanatthaṃ khattiyamāyaṃ kathento imaṃ gāthamāha –

translated: “By any means, whether gentle or harsh,

translated: The Great Being, in order to show him the tree-parable, spoke this verse:🔽“He who would break a branch of that tree,

translated: Is a wicked man, a traitor to his friend.”

analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā mahā rāja yadi paribhutta rukkhassa sākham bhañjantaḥ api mitta dubbhī
translated: Having said this, he continued: “Great king, if one who breaks a branch of a tree which he has enjoyed is a traitor to his friend,

analyzed: hoti yehi tumhehi mama pitā uḷāre issariye patiṭṭhāpitaḥ aham ca mahantena anuggahena

analyzed: an uggahito tesu tumhesu a parajjhantaḥ aham katham nāma mitta dubbhaḥ na bhaveyyanti
translated: if I were to be disloyal to you, how could I be a traitor to my friends?”

translated: Thus he declared his own loyalty, and reproving the king’s conduct, he spoke this verse:

translated: “He who knows the truth of him who has removed his doubts,

original: Tattha arājayuttoti mahārāja, etassa kuṭṭharogo uppanno, so rājānaṃ pattuṃ ayutto,

translated: Herein, not for the sake of victory means that, Great King, this disease of his has arisen, and he is not fit to approach the King,

original: chupanānucchaviko na hoti. Tumhe ca “pukkusassa ūru muduko”ti yebhuyyena tassa ūrumhi
analyzed: na hoti tumhe ca pukkusassa ūru yebhuyyena tassa ūrumhi
translated: he is not worthy of a seat. And you, thinking that Pukkusati’s thigh was soft,

original: nipajjatha. So panesa vaṇabandhapilotikāya phasso, devāti.
analyzed: nipajjatha saḥ pana isa vaṇa bandha pilotikāya phassaḥ deva ati
translated: and lie down. But this is the touch of a bandage-cloth, Sire.’

original: Rājā tampi oloketvā “saccaṃ pukkusā”ti pucchitvā “saccaṃ devā”ti vutte tampi bandhanāgāraṃ pavesāpesi. Paṇḍito kāmindassapi rahassaṃ kathento imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā tam pi oloketvā saccam pukkusa ati pucchitvā saccam deva ati vutte tam pi bandhanāgāram pavesāpesi paṇḍitaḥ kāmindassa api rahassam kathentaḥ imam gātham āha
translated: The King looked at him and asked, ‘Is it true that you are Pukkusati? ‘ ‘It is true, Sire.’ The King had him put into the prison. The Wise One, speaking in secret to Kāmindā, spoke this verse:

original: “Ābādhoyaṃ asabbhirūpo, kāmindo naradevena phuṭṭho;
analyzed: ābādhaḥ ayam a sabbhirūpaḥ kāmindaḥ naradevena phuṭṭhaḥ
translated: ‘This sickness is not good, Kāmindā, the King of men is seized with it;

original: Puttassa rahogato asaṃsi, guyhaṃ pātukataṃ sutaṃ mameta”nti. ;
analyzed: puttassa rahaḥ gataḥ asaṃsi guyham pātu katam sutam mama etat ti
translated: He told his son in secret, he heard what was hidden from him.’

original: Tattha asabbhirūpoti yena so ābādhena phuṭṭho ummattakasunakho viya viravati, so naradevayakkhābādho asabbhijātiko lāmako, rājakulaṃ pavisituṃ na yutto, mahārājāti vadati.
analyzed: tattha a sabbhirūpaḥ ti yena saḥ ābādhena phuṭṭhaḥ ummattaka sunakhaḥ viya viravati saḥ naradeva yakkha ābādhaḥ a sabbhijātikaḥ lāmakaḥ rājakulam pavisitum na yuttaḥ mahā rājā iti vadati
translated: Herein, not good means that the sickness with which he was seized was of a kind to make him howl like a mad dog, and it was a sickness of a kind to be seized by a human-god-demon, it was a low-class sickness, unfit to enter a royal court, he said ‘Great King’.

original: Rājā tampi oloketvā “saccaṃ kāmindā”ti pucchitvā “saccaṃ devā”ti vutte tampi bandhanāgāraṃ pavesāpesi. Paṇḍito devindassapi rahassaṃ kathento imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā tam pi oloketvā saccam kāminda ati pucchitvā saccam deva ati vutte tam pi bandhanāgāram pavesāpesi paṇḍitaḥ devindassa api rahassam kathentaḥ imam gātham āha
translated: The King looked at him and asked, ‘Is it true that you are Kāmindā? ‘ ‘It is true, Sire.’ The King had him put into the prison. The Wise One, speaking in secret to Devindā, spoke this verse:

original: “Aṭṭhavaṅkaṃ maṇiratanaṃ uḷāraṃ, sakko te adadā pitāmahassa;
analyzed: aṭṭhavaṅkam maṇi ratanam uḷāram sakko te adadā pitāmahassa
translated: “A precious gem of eight angles, a wondrous thing, Sakka, thy sire, gave to thy grandsire.

original: Devindassa gataṃ tadajja hatthaṃ, mātucca rahogato asaṃsi;
analyzed: devindassa gatam tat ajja hattham mātuḥ ca rahaḥ gataḥ
translated: That gem, approved as auspicious, today is in the hand of Indra, the King of Gods. Thou didst not tell thy mother of it in secret.

original: Guyhaṃ pātukataṃ sutaṃ mameta”nti. ;
analyzed: guyham pātukatam sutam
translated: I heard thee speak of it, though thou didst think it hidden.”

original: Tattha pitāmahassāti tava pitāmahassa kusarājassa. Tadajja hatthanti taṃ maṅgalasammataṃ maṇiratanaṃ ajja devindassa hatthagataṃ, mahārājāti.
analyzed: tattha pitāmahassa ati tava pitāmahassa kusa rājassa tat ajja hattham ti tam maṅgala sammatam maṇi ratanam ajja devindassa hattha gatam mahā rāja ati
translated: Herein, his grandsire means thy grandsire, King Kusā. That gem, approved as auspicious, today is in the hand of Indra, the King of Gods, great king.

original: Rājā tampi oloketvā “saccaṃ devindā”ti pucchitvā “saccaṃ devā”ti vutte tampi bandhanāgāraṃ
analyzed: rājā tam pi oloketvā saccam devinda ati pucchitvā saccam deva ati vutte tam pi bandhanāgāram
translated: The king looked at him and asked, “Is it true, Indra?” “It is true, your majesty.” Then he had him also put into the prison-house.

original: pavesāpesi. Evaṃ “bodhisattaṃ vadhissāmā”ti cintetvā sabbepi te bandhanāgāraṃ paviṭṭhā.
analyzed: evam bodhisattam vadhissāma ati cintetvā sabbe api te bandhanāgāram paviṭṭhā
translated: Thus all of them who had thought, “We will kill the Bodhisatta,” were put into the prison-house.

original: Bodhisatto “mahārāja, iminā kāraṇenāhaṃ ‘attano guyhaṃ parassa na kathetabba’nti
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ mahā rāja iminā kāraṇena aham attanaḥ guyham parassa na kathetabbanti
translated: The Bodhisatta said, “Great king, it is for this reason that I say, ‘One’s own secret should not be told to another.’

original: vadāmi, vadantā pana mahāvināsaṃ pattā”ti vatvā uttari dhammaṃ desento imā gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: vadāmi vadantā pana mahā vināsam pattā iti vatvā uttari dhammaṃ desentaḥ imā gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: But those who tell it come to great destruction.” So saying, he preached the Law further by pronouncing these verses:

original: “Guyhassa hi guyhameva sādhu, na guyhassa pasatthamāvikammaṃ;
analyzed: guyhassa hi guyham eva sādhu na guyhassa pasattham āvikammam
translated: “For a secret is well kept only by a secret, not by revealing it.

original: Anipphannatā saheyya dhīro, nipphannova yathāsukhaṃ bhaṇeyya.
analyzed: a nipphanna tā saheyya dhīraḥ nipphannaḥ uva yathāsukham bhaṇeyya
translated: The wise man should keep it to himself until it is accomplished; when it is accomplished, he may speak as he likes.

original: “Na guyhamatthaṃ vivareyya, rakkheyya naṃ yathā nidhiṃ;
analyzed: na guyham attham vivareyya rakkheyya nam yathā nidhim
translated: “One should not reveal a secret purpose; one should guard it as one does one’s wealth.

original: Na hi pātukato sādhu, guyho attho pajānatā.
analyzed: na hi pātukato sādhu guyhaḥ atthaḥ pajānatā
translated: For it is not good to make known a secret purpose, if one is wise.

original: “Thiyā guyhaṃ na saṃseyya, amittassa ca paṇḍito;
analyzed: thiyā guyham na saṃseyya amittassa ca paṇḍitaḥ
translated: “One should not confide in a woman, nor in an enemy, nor in a fool, nor in a friend who is not tried.

original: Yo cāmisena saṃhīro, hadayattheno ca yo naro.
analyzed: yaḥ ca āmisena saṃhīraḥ ca yaḥ naro
translated: And one should not confide in a person who is greedy for gain, nor in one whose heart is set on sensual pleasures.

original: “Guyhamatthaṃ asambuddhaṃ, sambodhayati yo naro;
analyzed: guyhamattham asambuddham sambodhayati yaḥ naraḥ
translated: “The person who reveals a secret purpose that has not been accomplished

original: Mantabhedabhayā tassa, dāsabhūto titikkhati.
analyzed: manta bheda bhayā tassa dāsa bhūtaḥ titikkhati
translated: is a slave to him who knows it; out of fear of divulging the secret, he endures it.

original: “Yāvanto purisassatthaṃ, guyhaṃ jānanti mantinaṃ;
analyzed: yāvantaḥ purisassa attham guyham jānanti mantinam
translated: “As many as know the secret purpose of a man who conspires,

original: Tāvanto tassa ubbegā, tasmā guyhaṃ na vissaje.
analyzed: tāvantaḥ tassa ubbegā tasmai guyham na vissaje
translated: so many are his enemies; therefore one should not confide in others.

original: “Vivicca bhāseyya divā rahassaṃ, rattiṃ giraṃ nātivelaṃ pamuñce;
analyzed: vivicca bhāseyya divā rahassam rattim giram na ativelam pamuñce
translated: “One should speak a secret by day in a secluded place; at night one should not utter a word beyond the proper time.

original: Upassutikā hi suṇanti mantaṃ, tasmā manto khippamupeti bheda”nti. ;
analyzed: upassutikāḥ hi suṇanti mantam tasmā mantaḥ khippam upeti bhedanti
translated: For eavesdroppers listen to the secret talk; therefore a secret quickly reaches a breach.”

original: Tattha amittassa cāti itthiyā ca paccatthikassa ca na katheyya. Saṃhīroti yo ca yena🔽kenaci āmisena saṃhīrati upalāpati saṅgahaṃ gacchati, tassapi na saṃseyya. Hadayatthenoti🔽yo ca amitto mittapatirūpako mukhena aññaṃ katheti, hadayena aññaṃ cinteti, tassapi🔽na saṃseyya. Asambuddhanti parehi aññātaṃ. “Asambodha”ntipi pāṭho, paresaṃ bodhetuṃ
analyzed: tattha amittassa ca ati itthiyā ca paccatthikassa ca na katheyya saṃhīraḥ iti yaḥ ca yena  kenacid āmisena saṃhīrati saṅgaham gacchati tassa api na hadayatthena iti  yaḥ ca amittaḥ mitta patirūpakaḥ mukhena aññam katheti hadayena aññam cinteti tassa api  na saṃseyya a sambuddha nti parehi aññātam paresam bodhetum

In one who is a hypocrite: in one who is a foe in the guise of a friend, who speaks otherwise than he ponders, who is a deceiver. In one who is unawakened: unknown to others. The reading “asambodha” is also correct. In one who is not awakened by others: in one who has not been awakened by others.

original: ayuttanti attho. Titikkhatīti tassa akkosampi paribhāsampi pahārampi dāso viya hutvā🔽adhivāseti. Mantinanti mantitaṃ, mantīnaṃ vā antare yāvanto jānantīti attho. analyzed: ayuttam ti attho titikkhati iti tassa akkosam pi paribhāsam pi pahāram pi dāsaḥ viya hutvā 🔽adhivāseti mantinanti mantitam mantīnam vai antare yāvantaḥ jānanti iti tāvanto ti 🔽te guyha jānanake paṭicca tattakā tassa ubbegā santāsāḥ uppajjanti na vissajeti na 🔽vissajjeyya param na jānāpeyya vivicca ati sace divā rahassam mantetu kāmaḥ hoti vivittam

original: okāsaṃ kāretvā suppaṭicchannaṭṭhāne manteyya. Nātivelanti rattiṃ rahassaṃ kathento
analyzed: okāsam kāretvā suppaṭicchanna ṭṭhāne manteyya na ativelanti rattim rahassam kathento
translated: and then he should recite it in a well-concealed place. He should not speak too long.

original: pana ativelaṃ mariyādātikkantaṃ mahāsaddaṃ karonto giraṃ nappamuñceyya. Upassutikā
analyzed: pana ativelam mariyādā atikkantam mahā saddam karontaḥ giram na ppamuñceyya upassutikā
translated: If he recites a secret at night, he should not speak too long, transgressing the bounds, making a great noise, and not let his voice out.🔽There are eavesdroppers.

original: hīti mantanaṭṭhānaṃ upagantvā tirokuṭṭādīsu ṭhatvā sotāro. Tasmāti mahārāja, tena🔽kāraṇena so manto khippameva bhedamupāgamīti.
analyzed: hi iti mantana ṭṭhānam upagantvā tirokuṭṭa ādīsu ṭhatvā sotāro mahā rāja tena  kāraṇena saḥ manto khippam eva bhedam upāgami iti
translated: Therefore, Your Majesty, that recitation quickly broke up.”

original: Rājā mahāsattassa kathaṃ sutvā “ete sayaṃ rājaverino hutvā paṇḍitaṃ mama veriṃ karontī”ti
analyzed: rājā mahāsattassa katham sutvā ete sayam rāja verinaḥ hutvā paṇḍitam mama verim karonti iti
translated: The king, having heard the Great Being’s words, thought: “These are my own royal enemies, who are making the wise man my enemy.”

original: kujjhitvā “gacchatha ne nagarā nikkhamāpetvā sūlesu vā uttāsetha, sīsāni vā tesaṃ🔽chindathā”ti āṇāpesi. Tesu pacchābāhaṃ bandhitvā catukke catukke kasāhi pahārasahassaṃ
analyzed: kujjhitvā gacchatha ne nagarā nikkhamāpetvā sūlesu vā uttāsetha sīsāni vā tesaṃ  chindatha ati āṇāpesi tesu pacchābāham bandhitvā catukke catukke kasāhi pahāra sahassam
translated: He became angry and ordered: “Go and banish them from the city, impale them, or cut off their heads.”

original: datvā nīyamānesu paṇḍito “deva, ime tumhākaṃ porāṇakā amaccā, khamatha nesaṃ aparādha”nti
analyzed: da tvā nīyamānesu paṇḍitaḥ devaḥ ime tumhākam porāṇakāḥ amaccāḥ khamatha aparādhanti
translated: While they were being led away, bound behind the back, and beaten with whips at every crossroad a thousand times, the wise man said: “Your Majesty, these are your old ministers. Forgive their offense.”

original: rājānaṃ khamāpesi. Rājā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā “sādhū”ti te pakkosāpetvā tasseva dāse
analyzed: rājānam khamāpesi rājā tassa vacanam sutvā sādhu iti te pakkosāpetvā tassa iva dāse
translated: and asked the king to forgive them. The king, hearing his words, said, “Very well,” and summoned the four wise men and made them slaves to the brahman.

original: katvā adāsi. So pana te tattheva bhujisse akāsi. Rājā “tena hi mama vijite mā vasantū”ti
analyzed: katvā adāsi saḥ pana te tattha iva bhujisse akāsi rājā tena hi mama vijite mā vasantu uti
translated: But the brahman made them his own servants. The king said, “Well then, let them not dwell in my realm.”

original: pabbājanīyakammaṃ āṇāpesi. Paṇḍito “khamatha, deva, etesaṃ andhabālānaṃ dosa”nti
analyzed: pabbājanīya kammaṃ āṇāpesi paṇḍitaḥ khamatha deva etesam andha bālānam dosanti
translated: And he ordered that they be banished. The wise man said, “Forgive them, your majesty, for the fault of these blind fools.”

original: khamāpetvā tesaṃ ṭhānantarāni puna pākatikāni kāresi. Rājā “paccāmittesupi tāvassa
analyzed: khamāpetvā tesam ṭhāna antarāni puna pākatikāni kāresi rājā pacca amittesu pi tāvassa
translated: And he asked forgiveness for them. He restored them to their former rank. The king thought, “He has such love even for his enemies.

original: evarūpā mettā bhavati, aññesu janesu kathaṃ na bhavissatī”ti paṇḍitassa ativiya pasanno🔽ahosi. Tato paṭṭhāya cattāro paṇḍitā uddhatadāṭhā viya sappā nibbisā hutvā kiñci
analyzed: evarūpā mettā bhavati aññesu janesu katham na bhavissati iti paṇḍitassa ativiya pasanno  ahosi tatas paṭṭhāya cattāro paṇḍitāḥ uddhata dāṭhāḥ viya sappāḥ nibbisāḥ hutvā kiñci
translated: How much more will he have for other people?” And he became exceedingly pleased with the wise man.

original: kathetuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu.
analyzed: kathetum na asakkhiṃsu
translated: From that time on, the four wise men, like snakes whose fangs had been drawn, were crestfallen and could not say a word.

original: Pañcapaṇḍitapañho niṭṭhito.🔽Niṭṭhitā ca paribhindakathā.
analyzed: pañcapaṇḍita pañhaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ  niṭṭhitā ca paribhinda kathā
translated: The questions of the five wise men are ended.🔽And so is the story of the brahman who broke up the friendship.

original: Yuddhaparājayakaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: yuddha parājaya kaṇḍam
translated: The Book of the Warring Clans

original: Tato paṭṭhāya paṇḍitova rañño atthañca dhammañca anusāsati. So cintesi “rañño setachattamattameva,
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya paṇḍitaḥ uva rañño atthañca dhammañca anusāsati so cintesi rañño seta chatta mattam eva
translated: From that time on the wise man alone advised the king in what was for his good and his welfare. He thought to himself, “The king has only the white parasol.

original: rajjaṃ pana ahameva vicāremi, mayā appamattena bhavituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti. So nagare mahāpākāraṃ🔽nāma kāresi, tathā anupākārañca dvāraṭṭālake antaraṭṭālake udakaparikhaṃ kaddamaparikhaṃ
analyzed: rajjam pana aham eva vicāremi mayā appamattena bhavitum vaṭṭati iti saḥ nagare mahā pākāram  nāma kāresi tathā an upākāram ca dvāra aṭṭālake antaraṭṭālake udaka parikham kaddama parikham
translated: But I alone rule the kingdom. It behooves me to be diligent.” He caused a great wall to be built around the city,🔽and likewise an inner and an outer wall. Between the inner and outer walls he caused three moats to be dug, one filled with water, one with mud, and one with dry earth.

original: sukkhaparikhanti tisso parikhāyo kāresi, antonagare jiṇṇagehāni paṭisaṅkharāpesi,
analyzed: sukkhaparikhanti tissaḥ parikhāyaḥ kāresi antonagare jiṇṇa gehāni paṭisaṅkharāpesi
translated: Within the city he had the dilapidated houses repaired.

original: mahāpokkharaṇiyo kāretvā tāsu udakanidhānaṃ kāresi, nagare sabbakoṭṭhāgārāni dhaññassa🔽pūrāpesi, himavantappadesato kulupakatāpasehi kudrūsakumudabījāni āharāpesi, udakaniddhamanāni
analyzed: mahā pokkharaṇiyaḥ kāretvā tāsu udaka nidhānam kāresi nagare sabba koṭṭhāgārāni dhaññassa  pūrāpesi himavanta ppadesataḥ kulupaka tāpasehi kudrūsa kumuda bījāni āharāpesi udaka niddhamanāni
translated: He had great lotus-tanks dug, and caused them to be filled with water. In the city he had all the granaries filled with grain.

original: sodhāpetvā tattha ropāpesi, bahinagarepi jiṇṇasālāpaṭisaṅkharaṇakammaṃ kāresi. Kiṃ
analyzed: sodhāpetvā tattha ropāpesi bahi nagare pi jiṇṇa sālā paṭisaṅkharaṇa kammam kāresi kim
translated: He caused the seeds of the kudrūsaka and kumuda plants to be brought from the Himalaya country by ascetics who were skilled in gathering medicinal herbs. He had the water-tanks cleaned, and caused the seeds to be planted therein.🔽Outside the city he had the dilapidated houses repaired.

original: kāraṇā? Anāgatabhayapaṭibāhanatthaṃ. Tato tato āgatavāṇijakepi “sammā, tumhe kuto
analyzed: kāraṇā anāgata bhaya paṭibāhana attham tatas tatas āgata vāṇijake pi sammā tumhe kutas
translated: Why? In order to ward off future danger. The merchants who came from various places he asked, “Where do you come from?”

original: āgatatthā”ti pucchitvā “asukaṭṭhānato”ti vutte “tumhākaṃ raññā kiṃ piya”nti pucchitvā
analyzed: āgata ttha ati pucchitvā asuka ṭṭhānato ti vutte tumhākam raññā kim piyanti pucchitvā
translated: When they said, “From such and such a place,” he asked, “What does your king like?”

original: “asukaṃ nāmā”ti vutte tesaṃ sammānaṃ kāretvā uyyojetvā attano ekasate yodhe pakkosāpetvā🔽“sammā, mayā dinne paṇṇākāre gahetvā ekasatarājadhāniyo gantvā ime paṇṇākāre attano
analyzed: asukam nāma ati vutte tesam sammānam kāretvā uyyojetvā attano eka sate yodhe pakkosāpetvā  sammā mayā dinne paṇṇa ākāre gahetvā eka sata rājadhāniyaḥ gantvā ime paṇṇa ākāre

analyzed: tasmin khaṇe raññaḥ mātā calākadevī nāma avidūre nisinnā ahosi sā raññaḥ dubbinicchita bhāvam
translated: At that moment the king’s mother, Queen Calā, was sitting not far away. She knew that the king had made a bad decision.

original: ñatvā “tāta, imaṃ aḍḍaṃ ñatvāva suṭṭhu vinicchita”nti āha. “Amma, ahaṃ ettakaṃ jānāmi.
analyzed: ñatvā tāta imam aḍḍam ñatvā ava suṭṭhu vinicchitan ti āha amma aham ettakam jānāmi
translated: “Dear, having understood this matter, you should decide it well.” “Mother, I know this much.

original: Sace tumhe uttaritaraṃ jānātha, tumheva vinicchinathā”ti. Sā “evaṃ karissāmī”ti vatvā
analyzed: sace tumhe uttaritaram jānātha tumhā iva vinicchinatha ati sā evam karissāmi iti vatvā
translated: She agreed to do so, and she had the man summoned.

original: taṃ purisaṃ pakkosāpetvā “ehi, tāta, tava hatthagatāni tīṇipi bhūmiyaṃ ṭhapehī”ti
analyzed: tam purisam pakkosāpetvā ehi tāta tava hattha gatāni tīṇi pi bhūmiyam ṭhapehi iti
translated: “Come, dear,” she said, “put down on the ground the three things you have here.”

original: paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapāpetvā “tāta, tvaṃ udake vuyhamāno imassa kiṃ kathesī”ti pucchitvā
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā tāta tvam udake vuyhamānaḥ imassa kim kathesi iti pucchitvā
translated: She had them put down one by one, and then she asked, “Dear, when you were being carried away in the water, what did you say?”🔽“I said this, my lady.”🔽“Well then, take what pleases you.”

original: “idaṃ nāmayye”ti vutte “tena hi tava ruccanakaṃ gaṇhā”ti āha. So sahassatthavikaṃ
analyzed: idam nāmayya iti vutte tena hi tava ruccanakam gaṇhāti āha saḥ sahassa tthavikam
translated: He took the thousand pieces of money.

original: gaṇhi. Atha naṃ sā thokaṃ gatakāle pakkosāpetvā “tāta, sahassaṃ te ruccatī”ti pucchitvā🔽“āma, ruccatī”ti vutte “tāta, tayā ‘ito yaṃ mayhaṃ ruccati, taṃ dassāmī’ti imassa
analyzed: gaṇhi atha nam sā thokam gata kāle pakkosāpetvā tāta sahassam te ruccati iti pucchitvā  āma ruccati iti vutte tāta tayā itas yam mayham ruccati tam dassāmi iti imassa
translated: After he had gone a little way, she called him back and asked him, “Dear, do you like the thousand pieces of money?”🔽“Yes, I like them.”🔽“Dear, you said, ‘I will give her what pleases her.’ Did you say this or not?”

original: vuttaṃ, na vutta”nti pucchitvā “vuttaṃ devī”ti vutte “tena hi imaṃ sahassaṃ etassa
analyzed: vuttam na vuttanti pucchitvā vuttam devi iti vutte tena hi imam sahassam etassa
translated: “I said it, your majesty.”🔽“Well then, give the thousand pieces of money to him.”

original: dehī”ti vatvā dāpesi. So rodanto paridevanto adāsi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe rājā amaccā ca tussitvā
analyzed: dehi iti vatvā dāpesi saḥ rodantaḥ paridevantaḥ adāsi tasmin khaṇe rājā amaccā ca tussitvā
translated: He gave them to him weeping and lamenting.

original: sādhukāraṃ pavattayiṃsu. Tato paṭṭhāya tassā paṇḍitabhāvo sabbattha pākaṭo jāto.
analyzed: sādhukāram pavattayiṃsu tatas paṭṭhāya tassā paṇḍita bhāvo sabbattha pākaṭaḥ jāto
translated: and they gave her the name of “Wise Woman.” From that time on her wisdom became well known everywhere.

original: Taṃ sandhāya videharājā “mātā ekādasī rañño”ti āha.
analyzed: tam sandhāya videha rājā mātā ekādasī rañño ti āha
translated: In reference to her the king of the Videhas said, “The mother is the eleventh king.”

original: Khatyāti khattiyā. Acchinnaraṭṭhāti cūḷanibrahmadattena acchinditvā gahitaraṭṭhā.
analyzed: khatyā ati khattiyā acchinna raṭṭhā ati cūḷani brahmadattena a chinditvā gahita raṭṭhā
translated: Khattiyas: nobles. Their kingdom was taken away: they were seized by Culla-Nimi-Brahmadatta and their kingdom was taken away.

original: Byathitāti maraṇabhayabhītā aññaṃ gahetabbagahaṇaṃ apassantā. Pañcāliyaṃ vasaṃ gatāti
analyzed: byathitā ati maraṇa bhaya bhītā aññam gahetabba gahaṇam a passantā pañcāliyam vasam gatā ati
translated: Terrified: afraid of death. Having no other refuge: having no other refuge to go to. They went to live in the land of the Pañcālas.

original: etassa pañcālarañño vasaṃ gatāti attho. Sāmivacanatthe hi etaṃ upayogavacanaṃ. Yaṃvadā
analyzed: etassa pañcāla raññaḥ vasam gatā ati sāmi vacana atthe hi etam upayoga vacanam yaṃvadā
translated: They went to live in the land of this king of the Pañcālas. For this is a locative of dependence in the sense of “master.”

original: takkarāti yaṃ mukhena vadanti, taṃ rañño kātuṃ sakkontāva. Vasino gatāti pubbe sayaṃvasino
analyzed: takkarā ati yam mukhena vadanti tam rañño kātum sakkontā ava vasinaḥ gatā ti pubbe sayaṃvasinaḥ
translated: Whatever: whatever they said with their mouths. They were able to do for the king: they were able to do it.🔽They went to live: formerly they lived by themselves.

original: idāni panassa vasaṃ gatāti attho. Tisandhīti paṭhamaṃ hatthipākārena parikkhittā,
analyzed: idāni pana assa vasam gatā ti attho ti sandhī iti paṭhamam hatthi pākārena parikkhittā
translated: But now they went to live under his control. Three ramparts: first they were surrounded by an elephant rampart,

original: tato rathapākārena, tato assapākārena, tato yodhapattipākārena parikkhittāti imehi
analyzed: tatas ratha pākārena tatas assa pākārena tatas yodha patti pākārena parikkhittā ati imehi
translated: then by a chariot rampart, then by a horse rampart, then by a foot soldier rampart.

original: catūhi saṅkhepehi tisandhīhi parivāritā. Hatthirathānañhi antaraṃ eko sandhi, rathaassānaṃ
analyzed: catūhi saṅkhepehi ti sandhīhi parivāritāḥ hatthi rathānam hi antaram ekaḥ sandhiḥ ratha assānam
translated: and surrounded by four trenches with three moats between them. For between the elephants and the chariots there is one moat, between the chariots and the horses there is one moat,

original: antaraṃ eko sandhi, assapattīnaṃ antaraṃ eko sandhi. Parikhaññatīti khanīyati. Imañhi
analyzed: antaram ekaḥ sandhi assapattīnam antaram ekaḥ sandhi parikhaññati iti khanīyati iman hi
translated: between the horses and the infantry there is one moat. ‘They are digging’ means they are digging. For

original: idāni uppāṭetvā gaṇhitukāmā viya samantato khananti. Uddhaṃ tārakajātāvāti tāta,🔽yāya senāya samantā parivāritā, sā anekasatasahassadaṇḍadīpikāhi uddhaṃ tārakajātā
analyzed: idāni uppāṭetvā gaṇhitu kāmāḥ samantataḥ khananti uddham tārakajātā avāti tāta  yāya senāya samantā parivāritā sā aneka sata sahassa daṇḍa dīpikāhi uddham tāraka jātā
translated: they are digging all around as if they wanted to dig it up and take it away. ‘Above, like a constellation of stars’ means, dear,

original: viya khāyati. Vijānāhīti tāta mahosadhapaṇḍita, avīcito yāva bhavaggā añño tayā sadiso
analyzed: viya khāyati vijānāhi iti tāta mahosadha paṇḍita avīcitaḥ yāva bhavaggāḥ añño tayā sadisaḥ
translated: the army that surrounds it appears as if it were above, like a constellation of stars with its many hundreds of thousands of torches. ‘Know’ means, dear Mahosadha, there is no one else who is so wise as you are, from the Avīci hell up to the highest realm of existence.

original: upāyakusalo paṇḍito nāma natthi, paṇḍitabhāvo nāma evarūpesu ṭhānesu paññāyati, tasmā
analyzed: upāya kusalaḥ paṇḍitaḥ nāma natthi paṇḍita bhāvaḥ nāma evarūpesu ṭhānesu paññāyati tasmā
translated: There is no one else who is so skilled in means. Wisdom is known to be such in these matters. Therefore

original: tvameva jānāhi, kathaṃ amhākaṃ ito dukkhā pamokkho bhavissatīti.
analyzed: tvam eva jānāhi katham amhākam itas dukkhā pamokkhaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: you alone know how we can be freed from this suffering.”

original: Imaṃ rañño kathaṃ sutvā mahāsatto cintesi “ayaṃ rājā ativiya maraṇabhayabhīto, gilānassa
analyzed: imam rañño katham sutvā mahāsatto cintesi ayam rājā ativiya maraṇa bhaya bhītaḥ gilānassa
translated: Having heard this speech of the king, the Great Being thought: “This king is extremely afraid of death, and he is sick.

original: kho pana vejjo paṭisaraṇaṃ, chātassa bhojanaṃ, pipāsitassa pānīyaṃ, imassapi maṃ
analyzed: kho pana vejjo paṭisaraṇam chātassa bhojanam pipāsitassa pānīyam imassa api maṃ
translated: “This king has no other refuge than myself, as a physician is the only refuge for the sick, as food is the only refuge for the hungry, as drink is the only refuge for the thirsty.

original: ṭhapetvā aññaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ natthi, assāsessāmi na”nti. Atha mahāsatto manosilātale🔽nadanto sīho viya “mā bhāyi, mahārāja, rajjasukhaṃ anubhava, ahaṃ leḍḍuṃ
analyzed: ṭhapetvā aññam paṭisaraṇam natthi assāsessāmi atha mahāsattaḥ manosilā tale  nadantaḥ sīhaḥ mā bhāyi mahā rāja rajja sukham anubhava aham leḍḍum
translated: I will comfort him.” Then the Great Being, like a lion roaring on a mountain top,🔽said, “Do not fear, O king, enjoy the pleasures of sovereignty. I will take this army of eighteen akkhos, like a crow taking a clod,

original: Gahetvā kākaṃ viya, dhanuṃ gahetvā makkaṭaṃ viya ca, imaṃ aṭṭhārasaakkhobhaṇisaṅkhaṃ senaṃ udare bandhasāṭakānampi assāmikaṃ katvā palāpessāmī”ti vatvā navamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: gahetvā kākam viya dhanum gahetvā makkaṭam viya ca imam aṭṭhārasa akkhobhaṇi saṅkham senam udare bandha sāṭakānam pi assāmikam katvā palāpessāmi iti vatvā navamam gātham āha
translated: like a monkey taking a branch, and will make it flee, leaving not even a garment behind.” And he spoke the ninth stanza:

original: “Pāde deva pasārehi, bhuñja kāme ramassu ca;
analyzed: pāde deva pasārehi bhuñja kāme ramassu ca
translated: “Stretch forth thy feet, O king, and eat, and enjoy thy pleasures;

original: Hitvā pañcāliyaṃ senaṃ, brahmadatto palāyitī”ti.
analyzed: hitvā pañcāliyam senam brahmadattaḥ palāyiti iti
translated: Brahmadatta, leaving the army of the five hundred, hath fled.”

original: Tassattho – “deva, tvaṃ yathāsukhaṃ attano rajjasukhasaṅkhāte te pāde pasārehi, pasārento
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ deva tvam yathāsukham attanaḥ rajja sukha saṅkhāte te pāde pasārehi pasārentaḥ
translated: The meaning is this: “O king, stretch forth thy feet as thou listest, and enjoy the pleasures of sovereignty.

original: ca saṅgāme cittaṃ akatvā bhuñja, kāme ramassu ca, esa brahmadatto imaṃ senaṃ chaḍḍetvā palāyissatī”ti.
analyzed: ca saṅgāme cittam a katvā bhuñja kāme ramassu ca esa brahmadattaḥ imam senam chaḍḍetvā palāyissati iti
translated: Stretching them forth, eat, and enjoy thy pleasures. This Brahmadatta will leave this army and flee.”

original: Evaṃ paṇḍito rājānaṃ samassāsetvā vanditvā rājanivesanā nikkhamitvā nagare chaṇabheriṃ
analyzed: evam paṇḍitaḥ rājānam samassāsetvā vanditvā rāja nivesanā nikkhamitvā nagare chaṇa bherim
translated: Having thus consoled the king, he saluted him, left the royal palace, and in the city had the drum of the gods beaten.

original: carāpetvā nāgare āha – “ambho, tumhe mā cintayittha, sattāhaṃ mālāgandhavilepanapānabhojanādīni
analyzed: nāgare āha ambho tumhe mā cintayittha mālā gandha vilepana pāna bhojana ādīni
translated: The wise man, having thus consoled the king, saluted him and went out of the palace. He had the royal drum beaten in the city and said to the people: “Do not worry, my friends. For seven days prepare garlands, perfumes, ointments, drinks, food, etc.,

original: sampādetvā chaṇakīḷaṃ paṭṭhapetha. Tattha tattha manussā yathārūpaṃ mahāpānaṃ pivantu,
analyzed: sampādetvā chaṇa kīḷam paṭṭhapetha tattha tattha manussāḥ yathārūpam mahā pānam pivantu
translated: and arrange a festival. There let the people drink as much as they like,

original: gandhabbaṃ karontu, vādentu vaggantu seḷentu nadantu naccantu gāyantu apphoṭentu,
analyzed: gandhabbam karontu vādentu vaggantu seḷentu nadantu naccantu gāyantu apphoṭentu
translated: let them make love, let them sing, let them laugh, let them dance, let them play, let them enjoy themselves.

original: paribbayo pana vo mama santakova hotu, ahaṃ mahosadhapaṇḍito nāma, passissatha me
analyzed: paribbayaḥ pana vaḥ mama santakaḥ uva hotu aham mahosadhapaṇḍitaḥ nāma passissatha me
translated: But all the expenses will be met by me. I am the wise man called Mahosadha. You will see my

original: ānubhāva”nti. Te tathā kariṃsu. Tadā gītavāditādisaddaṃ bahinagare ṭhitā suṇanti,
analyzed: te tathā tadā gīta vādita ādi saddam bahi nagare ṭhitā suṇanti
translated: power.” They did as he said. At that time those who were outside the city heard the sound of singing, music, etc.,

original: cūḷadvārena manussā nagaraṃ pavisanti. Ṭhapetvā paṭisattuṃ diṭṭhaṃ diṭṭhaṃ na gaṇhanti,
analyzed: cūḷadvārena manussāḥ nagaram pavisanti ṭhapetvā paṭisattum diṭṭham diṭṭham na gaṇhanti
translated: and people entered the city through the side-door. Except for the king, no one took what he saw.

original: tasmā sañcāro na chijjati, nagaraṃ paviṭṭhamanussā chaṇakīḷanissitaṃ janaṃ passanti.
analyzed: tasmā sañcāraḥ na chijjati nagaram paviṭṭha manussāḥ chaṇa kīḷa nissitam janam passanti
translated: Therefore the traffic was not interrupted. People who entered the city saw the people engaged in the festival.

original: Cūḷanibrahmadattopi nagare kolāhalaṃ sutvā amacce evamāha – “ambho, amhesu aṭṭhārasaakkhobhaṇiyā
analyzed: cūḷani brahmadattaḥ api nagare kolāhalam sutvā amacce evam āha ambho amhesu aṭṭhārasa akkhobhaṇiyā
translated: The younger Brahmadatta, hearing the uproar in the city, said to his ministers, “What is the meaning of this, sirs?”🔽

original: senāya nagaraṃ parivāretvā ṭhitesu nagaravāsīnaṃ bhayaṃ vā sārajjaṃ vā natthi, ānanditā🔽somanassappattā apphoṭenti nadanti seḷenti naccanti gāyanti, kiṃ nāmeta”nti? Atha
analyzed: senāya nagaram parivāretvā ṭhitesu nagara vāsīnam bhayam vā sārajjam vā na atthi ānanditā  somanassa pattāḥ apphoṭenti nadanti seḷenti naccanti gāyanti kim nāma itanti atha
translated: The younger Brahmadatta, hearing the uproar in the city, said to his ministers, “Sirs, while we are standing round the city with an army of eighteen akkhobhiyas, the citizens have no fear or trembling, but are

original: naṃ upanikkhittakapurisā musāvādaṃ katvā evamāhaṃsu “deva, mayaṃ ekena kammena cūḷadvārena🔽nagaraṃ pavisitvā chaṇanissitaṃ mahājanaṃ disvā pucchimhā ‘ambho, sakalajambudīparājāno
analyzed: naṃ upanikkhittaka purisāḥ musā vādam katvā evam āhaṃsu deva ekena kammena cūḷadvārena  nagaram pavisitvā chaṇa nissitam mahā janam disvā pucchimhā ambho sakala jambudīpa rājāno
translated: joyful and happy, clapping their hands, shouting, laughing, dancing, singing, and making merry. What is the reason for this?” Then the spies, lying, said to him, “Your majesty, we entered the city through the small gate on some business,

original: āgantvā tumhākaṃ nagaraṃ parikkhipitvā ṭhitā, tumhe pana atipamattā, kiṃ nāmeta’nti?
analyzed: āgantvā tumhākam nagaram parikkhipitvā ṭhitā tumhe pana atipamattā kim nāma etat ti
translated: saw a great crowd of people gathered at the execution ground, and asked them, ‘Sirs, the kings of all Jambudīpa have come and are standing, surrounding your city, but you are over-indulgent. What is the reason for this?’

original: Te evamāhaṃsu ‘ambho, amhākaṃ rañño kumārakāle eko manoratho ahosi sakalajambudīparājūhi
analyzed: te evam āhaṃsu ambho amhākam raññaḥ kumāra kāle ekaḥ manorathaḥ ahosi sakala jambudīpa rājūhi
translated: They said, ‘Sirs, when our king was a prince, he had one wish: that the kings of all Jambudīpa should come and pay homage to him.

original: nagare parivārite chaṇaṃ karissāmīti, tassa ajja manoratho matthakaṃ patto, tasmā
analyzed: nagare parivārite chaṇam karissāmi iti tassa ajja manorathaḥ matthakam patto tasmā
translated: “Today the king’s wish is fulfilled. Therefore

analyzed: chaṇa bherim cara a petvā sayam mahā tale mahā pānam pivati iti
translated: he is having the drum of proclamation beaten and is himself drinking strong drink in the great hall.”

original: Rājā tesaṃ kathaṃ sutvā kujjhitvā senaṃ āṇāpesi – “bhonto, gacchatha, khippaṃ ito
analyzed: rājā tesam katham sutvā kujjhitvā senam āṇāpesi bhonto gacchatha khippam itas
translated: When the king heard their talk, he was angry, and he gave orders to the army, saying, “Go,

original: cito ca nagaraṃ avattharitvā parikhaṃ bhinditvā pākāraṃ maddantā dvāraṭṭālake bhindantā
analyzed: cito ca nagaram avattharitvā parikham bhinditvā pākāram maddantā dvāra aṭṭālake bhindantā
translated: men, and quickly surround the city on all sides, break through the rampart, and demolish the walls.

original: nagaraṃ pavisitvā sakaṭehi kumbhaṇḍāni viya mahājanassa sīsāni gaṇhatha, videharañño
analyzed: nagaram pavisitvā sakaṭehi kumbhaṇḍāni viya mahā janassa sīsāni gaṇhatha videha rañño
translated: Break down the gate-towers, enter the city, and seize the heads of the people, as though they were so many pots and pans, in carts and wagons.

original: sīsaṃ āharathā”ti. Taṃ sutvā sūrayodhā nānāvudhahatthā dvārasamīpaṃ gantvā paṇḍitassa🔽purisehi sakkharavālukakalalasiñcanapāsāṇapatanādīhi upaddutā paṭikkamanti. “Pākāraṃ
analyzed: sīsam āharatha ati tam sutvā sūra yodhāḥ nānā vudha hatthāḥ dvāra samīpam gantvā paṇḍitassa  purisehi sakkhara vāluka kalala siñcana pāsāṇa patana ādīhi upaddutā paṭikkamanti pākāram
translated: Bring me the head of the king of Videha.” When the brave warriors heard this, they went to the gate with various weapons in their hands, but they were driven back by the men of the wise king,

original: bhindissāmā”ti parikhaṃ otiṇṇepi antaraṭṭālakesu ṭhitā ususattitomarādīhi vijjhantā
analyzed: bhindissāma ati parikham otiṇṇe api antaraṭṭālakesu ṭhitāḥ usu satti tomara ādīhi vijjhantā
translated: who pelted them with clods of earth, sand, potsherds, and stones, and with water from the water-carrying vessels. “We will break through the rampart,” said they, and they entered the moat, but they were pierced by the men who stood in the inner gate-towers with arrows, spears, and other missiles.

original: mahāvināsaṃ pāpenti. Paṇḍitassa yodhā cūḷanibrahmadattassa yodhe hatthavikārādīni🔽dassetvā nānappakārehi akkosanti paribhāsanti tajjenti. “Tumhe kilamantā bhattaṃ
analyzed: mahā vināsam pāpenti paṇḍitassa yodhā cūḷani brahmadattassa yodhe hattha vikāra ādīni  dassetvā nānā pakārehi akkosanti paribhāsanti tajjenti tumhe kilamantāḥ bhattaṃ
translated: and brought about their great destruction. The wise warriors, having shown the various ways of fighting, such as the hand-fight, etc.,

original: alabhantā thokaṃ pivissatha khādissathā”ti surāpiṭṭhakāni ceva macchamaṃsasūlāni
analyzed: a labhantā thokam pivissatha khādissatha ati surā piṭṭhakāni ca iva maccha maṃsa sūlāni
translated: insulted, abused and threatened the other warriors, saying: “You are tired, you have not received your food, you will drink a little and eat a little.” And having spread out the liquor-cakes and the meat-skewers,

original: ca pasāretvā sayameva pivanti khādanti, anupākāre caṅkamanti. Itare kiñci kātuṃ asakkontā🔽cūḷanibrahmadattassa santikaṃ gantvā “deva, ṭhapetvā iddhimante aññehi niddharituṃ
analyzed: ca pasāretvā sayam eva pivanti khādanti an upākāre caṅkamanti itare kiñci kātum a sakkontā  cūḷani brahmadattassa santikam gantvā deva ṭhapetvā iddhimante aññehi niddharitum
translated: they themselves drank and ate, and walked about without any restraint. The others, being unable to do anything,

analyzed: āgamissati mama pana kāmena palobhetvā nagaram netvā gaṇhana atthāya āgatena bhavitabbam

original: Taṃ anāgatabhayaṃ diṭṭhaṃ bhavissati paṇḍitenā”ti tassa tamatthaṃ āvajjetvā bhītatasitassa
analyzed: tam anāgata bhayam diṭṭham bhavissati paṇḍitena ati tassa tam attham āvajjetvā bhīta tasitassa
translated: And when he had thus reflected, he sat down, trembling with fear.

original: nisinnakāle cattāro paṇḍitā āgamiṃsu. Rājā senakaṃ pucchi “senaka, ruccati te uttarapañcālanagaraṃ🔽gantvā cūḷanirājassa dhītu ānayana”nti? Kiṃ kathetha mahārāja, na hi siriṃ āgacchantiṃ🔽daṇḍena paharitvā palāpetuṃ vaṭṭati. Sace tumhe tattha gantvā taṃ gaṇhissatha, ṭhapetvā
analyzed: nisinna kāle cattāraḥ paṇḍitāḥ āgamiṃsu rājā senakam pucchi senaka ruccati te uttara pañcāla nagaram  gantvā cūḍanirājassa ānayananti kim kathetha mahā rāja na hi sirim āgacchantiṃ  daṇḍena paharitvā palāpetum vaṭṭati sace tumhe tattha gantvā tam gaṇhissatha ṭhapetvā
translated: Then the four wise men came, and the king asked Senaka, “Senaka, do you approve of my going to the city of Uttarāpañcāla and bringing back the daughter of Cūḷanirājan?”🔽“What do you say, great king? It is not right to drive away Fortune when she comes, striking her with a stick. If you go there and take her, there will be no one equal to you on the face of the earth, except Cūḷanibbāhadatta.

original: cūḷanibrahmadattaṃ añño tumhehi samo jambudīpatale na bhavissati. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Jeṭṭharājadhītāya🔽gahitattā. So hi “sesarājāno mama manussā, vedeho ekova mayā sadiso”ti sakalajambudīpe
analyzed: cūḷani brahmadattam aññaḥ tumhehi samaḥ jambudīpa tale na bhavissati kim kāraṇā jeṭṭha rāja dhītāya  gahita ttā saḥ hi sesa rājānaḥ mama manussāḥ vedehaḥ ekaḥ iva mayā sadisaḥ ti sakala jambudīpe
translated: And why? Because you have taken the eldest daughter of the king.🔽For he thinks, ‘The other kings are my subjects, but the king of Videha is my equal.’ He is ready to give you his daughter, the most beautiful woman in all the world. Do his bidding.

original: uttamarūpadharaṃ dhītaraṃ tumhākaṃ dātukāmo jāto, karothassa vacanaṃ. Mayampi tumhe
analyzed: uttama rūpa dharam dhītaram tumhākam dātu kāmo jātaḥ karothassa vacanam mayam pi tumhe
translated: We too will go with you.

original: nissāya vatthālaṅkāre labhissāmāti. Rājā sesepi pucchi. Tepi tatheva kathesuṃ. Tassa
analyzed: nissāya vattha alaṅkāre labhissāma ati rājā sese api pucchi te pi tathā iva kathesum tassa
translated: The king asked the others, and they gave the same answer.

original: tehi saddhiṃ kathentasseva kevaṭṭabrāhmaṇo attano nivāsagehā nikkhamitvā “rājānaṃ
analyzed: tehi saddhim kathentassa iva kevaṭṭa brāhmaṇaḥ attanaḥ nivāsa gehāt nikkhamitvā rājānam
translated: While he was talking with them, the fisherman-brahman came out of his house, and thinking, “I will go and summon the king,”

original: āmantetvā gamissāmī”ti āgantvā “mahārāja, na sakkā amhehi papañcaṃ kātuṃ, gamissāma
analyzed: āmantetvā gamissāmi iti āgantvā mahā rāja na sakkāḥ amhehi papañcam kātum gamissāma
translated: he came and said, “Great king, we cannot make any delay; we must go.

original: mayaṃ narindā”ti āha. Rājā tassa sakkāraṃ katvā taṃ uyyojesi. Mahāsatto tassa gamanabhāvaṃ
analyzed: mayam narinda iti āha rājā tassa sakkāram katvā tam uyyojesi mahāsatto tassa gamana bhāvaṃ
translated: ” The king honored him and sent him away. The Great Being, knowing that he was going,

original: ñatvā nhatvā alaṅkaritvā rājupaṭṭhānaṃ āgantvā rājānaṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
analyzed: ñatvā nhatvā alaṅkaritvā rāja upaṭṭhānam āgantvā rājānam vanditvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: bathed, adorned himself, went to the royal presence, saluted the king, and sat down on one side.

original: Rājā cintesi “putto me mahosadhapaṇḍito mahāmantī mantapāraṅgato atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ
analyzed: rājā cintesi puttaḥ me mahosadha paṇḍitaḥ mahā mantī manta pāraṅgataḥ atīta anāgata paccuppannam
translated: The king thought, “My son is a great scholar, a great counselor, a master of counsel, who knows the past, the future, and the present.

original: atthaṃ jānāti. Amhākaṃ tattha gantuṃ yuttabhāvaṃ vā ayuttabhāvaṃ vā paṇḍito jānissatī”ti.
analyzed: attham jānāti amhākam tattha gantum yutta bhāvam vā ayutta bhāvam vā paṇḍitaḥ jānissati iti
translated: He will know whether it is proper for us to go there or not.”

original: So attanā paṭhamaṃ cintitaṃ avatvā rāgaratto mohamūḷho hutvā taṃ pucchanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ attanā paṭhamam cintitam avatvā rāga rattaḥ moha mūḍhaḥ hutvā tam pucchantaḥ gātham āha
translated: Without first thinking it out for himself, the king, being infatuated with love and confused by delusion, asked the Great Being, and spoke this verse:

original: “Channañhi ekāva matī sameti, ye paṇḍitā uttamabhūripattā;
analyzed: channan hi ekā ava matī sameti ye paṇḍitāḥ uttama bhūri pattā
translated: “For one and the same is our opinion, O Channa, of those who are wise and have attained the highest and the most,

original: Yānaṃ ayānaṃ atha vāpi ṭhānaṃ, mahosadha tvampi matiṃ karohī”ti.
analyzed: yānam a yānam atha vā api ṭhānam mahosadha tvam pi matim karohi iti
translated: Whether it is a question of going or of staying. Do you, O Mahosadha, make up your mind.”

original: Tattha channanti paṇḍita, kevaṭṭabrāhmaṇassa ca mama ca imesañca catunnanti channaṃ
analyzed: tattha channanti paṇḍita kevaṭṭa brāhmaṇassa ca mama ca imesam ca catunnanti channaṃ
translated: Herein, Channa is the wise one. The brahmin Kevatta and I and these four, we are the six.

original: amhākaṃ ekāva mati ekoyeva ajjhāsayo gaṅgodakaṃ viya yamunodakena saṃsandati sameti.
analyzed: amhākam ekā ava mati ekoyā iva ajjhāsayaḥ gaṅgā udakam viya yamunā udakena saṃsandati sameti
translated: One and the same is our opinion, our intention, which is like the water of the Ganges mingling with the water of the Yamuna.

original: Ye mayaṃ chapi janā paṇḍitā uttamabhūripattā, tesaṃ no channampi cūḷanirājadhītu
analyzed: ye janāḥ paṇḍitāḥ uttama bhūri pattā tesam no
translated: We six are wise and have attained the highest and the most. To us, O Channa, it is agreeable to fetch the girl Culla-Nirati.

original: ānayanaṃ ruccatīti. Ṭhānanti idheva vāso. Matiṃ karohīti amhākaṃ ruccanakaṃ nāma
analyzed: ānayanam ruccati iti idhā iva vāsaḥ matim karohi iti amhākam ruccanakam nāma
translated: Staying is staying here. Make up your mind. Our opinion is

original: appamāṇaṃ, tvampi cintehi, kiṃ amhākaṃ āvāhatthāya tattha yānaṃ, udāhu ayānaṃ, adu
analyzed: appamāṇam tvam pi cintehi kim amhākam āvāha atthāya tattha yānam udāhu a yānam adu
translated: immeasurable. Do you think, too, whether it is agreeable to us to go there to fetch her or whether it is not agreeable, or

original: idheva vāso ruccatīti.
analyzed: idhā iva vāsaḥ ruccati iti
translated: whether it is agreeable to stay here.

original: Taṃ sutvā paṇḍito “ayaṃ rājā ativiya kāmagiddho andhabālabhāvena imesaṃ catunnaṃ vacanaṃ gaṇhāti, gamane dosaṃ kathetvā nivattessāmi na”ni cintetvā catasso gāthāyo abhāsi –
analyzed: tam sutvā paṇḍitaḥ ayam rājā kāma giddhaḥ andha bāla bhāvena imesam catunnam vacanam gaṇhāti gamane dosam kathetvā nivattessāmi cintetvā catassaḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsi
translated: Having heard that, the wise man thought: “This king is very much infatuated with love, and he accepts the words of these four men as if he were a blind fool. I will tell him the danger of going and make him turn back.” Having thus thought, he spoke four stanzas:

original: “Jānāsi kho rāja mahānubhāvo, mahabbalo cūḷanibrahmadatto;
analyzed: jānāsi khalu rāja mahā anubhāvaḥ mahat balaḥ cūḍani brahmadattaḥ
translated: “You know, O king, that the powerful, the mighty Cūḷanibbāhadatta,

original: Rājā ca taṃ icchati māraṇatthaṃ, migaṃ yathā okacarena luddo.
analyzed: rājā ca tam icchati māraṇa attham migam yathā okacarena luddaḥ
translated: And the king wants to kill you, just as a hunter kills a deer with a trap.

original: “Yathāpi maccho baḷisaṃ, vaṅkaṃ maṃsena chāditaṃ;
analyzed: yathā api macchas baḷisam vaṅkam maṃsena chāditam
translated: “Just as a fish, covered with meat, swallows a hook,

original: Āmagiddho na jānāti, maccho maraṇamattano.
analyzed: āma giddhaḥ na jānāti macchaḥ maraṇa mattano
translated: The fish, infatuated with the bait, does not know his own death.

original: “Evameva tuvaṃ rāja, cūḷaneyyassa dhītaraṃ;
analyzed: evam eva tuvam rāja cūḷaneyyassa dhītaram
translated: “Even so, O king, you, infatuated with love, for the daughter of Cūḷanemi,

original: Kāmagiddho na jānāsi, macchova maraṇamattano.
analyzed: kāma giddhaḥ na jānāsi maccha uva maraṇam attano
translated: Do not know your own death, just as the fish does not know his own death.

original: “Sace gacchasi pañcālaṃ, khippamattaṃ jahissasi;
analyzed: sace gacchasi pañcālam khippa mattam jahissasi
translated: “If you go to Pañcāla, you will quickly lose your life,

original: Migaṃ panthānubandhaṃva, mahantaṃ bhayamessatī”ti.
analyzed: migam panthā anubandham iva mahantam bhayam essati iti
translated: Just as a great danger will come to the deer that follows the path.”

original: Tattha rājāti videhaṃ ālapati. Mahānubhāvoti mahāyaso. Mahabbaloti aṭṭharasaakkhobhaṇisaṅkhena
analyzed: tattha rājā ati videham ālapati mahā anubhāvaḥ iti mahā yasaḥ mahā balo ti aṭṭharasa akkhobhaṇi saṅkhena
translated: Here, the king is addressed. Powerful means great fame. Mighty means eighteen akkhobhani-sankha.

original: balena samannāgato. Māraṇatthanti māraṇassa atthāya. Okacarenāti okacārikāya migiyā.
analyzed: balena samannāgataḥ māraṇa atthanti māraṇassa atthāya okacarena ati okacārikāya migiyā
translated: and he was endowed with strength. For the purpose of killing: for the purpose of killing. The doe: the doe who was a hunter’s snare.

original: Luddo hi ekaṃ migiṃ sikkhāpetvā rajjukena bandhitvā araññaṃ netvā migānaṃ gocaraṭṭhāne
analyzed: luddaḥ hi ekam migim sikkhāpetvā rajjukena bandhitvā araññam netvā migānam gocara ṭṭhāne
translated: For a hunter, having trained a doe, binds her with a rope and takes her to the forest, and he places her in a place where deer come for grazing.

original: ṭhapesi. Sā bālamigaṃ attano santikaṃ ānetukāmā sakasaññāya rāgaṃ janentī viravati.
analyzed: ṭhapesi sā bāla migam attanaḥ santikam ānetu kāmā saka saññāya rāgam janentī viravati
translated: She, desiring to bring a foolish deer into her presence, out of the perception of her own self, generates passion and cries out.

original: Tassā saddaṃ sutvā bālamigo migagaṇaparivuto vanagumbe nipanno sesamigīsu saññaṃ🔽akatvā tassā saddassavanasaṃsaggena baddho vuṭṭhāya nikkhamitvā gīvaṃ ukkhipitvā
analyzed: tassā saddam sutvā bāla migaḥ miga gaṇa parivutaḥ vana gumbe nipanno sesa migīsu saññam  a katvā tassā sadda savana saṃsaggena baddhaḥ vuṭṭhāya nikkhamitvā gīvam ukkhipitvā
translated: Hearing her sound, the foolish deer, lying in the forest with a herd of deer, not paying attention to the other deer,🔽bound by the connection of hearing her sound, gets up and goes out, raising his neck,

original: kilesavasena taṃ migiṃ upagantvā luddassa passaṃ datvā tiṭṭhati. Tamenaṃ so tikhiṇāya🔽sattiyā vijjhitvā jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpeti. Tattha luddo viya cūḷanirājā, okacārikā viya
analyzed: kilesa vasena tam migim upagantvā luddassa passam datvā tiṭṭhati tam enam saḥ tikhiṇāya  sattiyā vijjhitvā jīvita kkhayam pāpeti tattha luddaḥ viya cūḷanirājā oka cārikā viya
translated: and out of defilement, he approaches the doe and stands, giving himself into the hunter’s hand. Then he, with a sharp🔽spear, pierces him and brings him to the end of his life. There, like the hunter, the younger brother of King Bimbisāra; like the doe,

original: assa dhītā, luddassa hatthe āvudhaṃ viya kevaṭṭabrāhmaṇo. Iti yathā okacarena luddo
analyzed: assa dhītā luddassa hatthe kevaṭṭa brāhmaṇaḥ iti yathā okacarena luddaḥ
translated: his daughter; like the weapon in the hunter’s hand, the fisherman-brāhmaṇa. Thus, just as the doe, by the hunter,

original: migaṃ māraṇatthāya icchati, evaṃ sopi rājā taṃ icchatīti attho.
analyzed: migam māraṇa tthāya icchati evam saḥ api rājā tam icchati iti
translated: He wishes to kill the deer, so too does the king wish that.

original: Āmagiddhoti byāmasatagambhīre udake vasantopi tasmiṃ baḷisassa vaṅkaṭṭhānaṃ chādetvā
analyzed: āma giddhaḥ ti byāma sata gambhīre udake vasantaḥ api tasmin baḷisassa vaṅka ṭṭhānam chādetvā
translated: Addicted to bait: though living in water a hundred fathoms deep, he hides the hook-bend when it is placed there,

original: ṭhite āmasaṅkhāte āmise giddho hutvā baḷisaṃ gilati, attano maraṇaṃ na jānāti. Dhītaranti
analyzed: ṭhite āma saṅkhāte āmise giddhaḥ hutvā baḷisam gilati maraṇam na jānāti
translated: and being addicted to the bait called meat, he swallows the hook, not knowing his own death. Daughter:

original: cūḷanibāḷisikassa kevaṭṭabrāhmaṇassa vacanabaḷisaṃ chādetvā ṭhitaṃ āmisasadisaṃ.
analyzed: cūḷanibāḷisikassa kevaṭṭa brāhmaṇassa vacana baḷisam chādetvā ṭhitam āmisa sadisam
translated: like the bait called meat, hidden by the brahman fisherman Cūḷanibbāḷisika,

original: Tassa rañño dhītaraṃ kāmagiddho hutvā maccho attano maraṇasaṅkhātaṃ āmisaṃ viya na
analyzed: tassa raññaḥ dhītaram kāma giddhaḥ hutvā macchas attanaḥ maraṇa saṅkhātam āmisam viya na
translated: you, being addicted to love, do not know the bait called your own death.

original: jānāsi. Pañcālanti uttarapañcālanagaraṃ. Attanti attānaṃ. Panthānubandhanti yathā🔽gāmadvāramaggaṃ anubandhamigaṃ mahantaṃ bhayamessati, tañhi migaṃ māraṇatthāya āvudhāni
analyzed: jānāsi pañcālanti uttarapañcāla nagaram attanti attānam panthā anubandhanti yathā  gāma dvāra maggam anubandha migam mahantam bhayam essati tat hi migam māraṇa atthāya
translated: Pañcāla: the city of Uttarapāñcāla. Yourself:🔽yourself. Following the path: just as a deer following the path at the village gate will bring great fear, for when men go out with weapons to kill that deer,

original: gahetvā nikkhantesu manussesu ye ye passanti, te te mārenti, evaṃ uttarapañcālanagaraṃ
analyzed: gahetvā nikkhantesu manussesu ye ye passanti te te mārenti evam uttarapañcāla nagaram
translated: whichever they see, they kill it, so too the city of Uttarapāñcāla,

original: gacchantampi taṃ mahantaṃ maraṇabhayaṃ essati upagamissatīti.
analyzed: gacchantam pi tam mahantam maraṇa bhayam essati upagamissati iti
translated: and the great fear of death will come upon him and overtake him.

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto catūhi gāthāhi rājānaṃ niggaṇhitvā kathesi. So rājā tena ativiya niggahitova🔽“ayaṃ maṃ attano dāsaṃ viya maññati, rājāti saññampi na karoti, aggarājena ‘dhītaraṃ
analyzed: evam mahāsatto catūhi gāthāhi rājānam niggaṇhitvā kathesi saḥ rājā tena niggahitaḥ uva  ayam mam attanaḥ dāsam viya maññati rājā ati saññam pi na karoti agga rājena dhītaram
translated: Thus the Great Being rebuked the king with four verses. The king was very much abashed.🔽“He thinks of me as his own slave, he does not even think of me as a king. The chief king sent me, thinking, ‘I will give my daughter to him.’

original: dassāmī’ti mama santikaṃ pesitaṃ ñatvā ekampi maṅgalapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ kathaṃ akathetvā
analyzed: dassāmi iti mama santikam pesitam ñatvā ekam pi maṅgala paṭisaṃyuttam katham a kathetvā
translated: But he does not say a single word about auspicious things.

original: maṃ ‘bālamigo viya, gilitabaḷisamaccho viya panthānubandhamigo viya, maraṇaṃ pāpuṇissatī’ti
analyzed: mam bāla migaḥ viya gilita baḷisa macchaḥ viya panthā anubandha migaḥ viya maraṇam pāpuṇissati iti
translated: He says to me, ‘You will meet death like a foolish deer, like a fish that has swallowed a hook, like a deer that follows the forest-fire along the path.’

original: vadatī”ti kujjhitvā anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vadati iti kujjhitvā anantaram gātham āha
translated: ” and in his anger he spoke the next verse:

original: “Mayameva bālamhase eḷamūgā, ye uttamatthāni tayī lapimhā;
analyzed: eḷamūgāḥ ye uttamatthāni tayī lapimhā
translated: “We are foolish, we are dumb, we are like sheep, in that we have asked you about the highest things.

original: Kimeva tvaṃ naṅgalakoṭivaḍḍho, atthāni jānāsi yathāpi aññe”ti.
analyzed: kim eva tvam naṅgala koṭi vaḍḍhaḥ atthāni jānāsi yathā api aññā iti
translated: What have you to do with plough-handles? Do you know the highest things as well as others?”

original: Tattha bālamhaseti bālāmha. Eḷamūgāti lālamukhā mayameva. Uttamatthānīti uttamaitthiratanapaṭilābhakāraṇāni.
analyzed: tattha bālamhasā iti bālāmhaḥ eḷamūgā ati lālamukhā uttamatthāni iti uttama aitthi ratana paṭilābha kāraṇāni
translated: Herein, we are foolish means we are fools. We are dumb means we are like sheep. The highest things means the reasons for obtaining the highest treasure.

original: Tayī lavimhāti tava santike kathayimhā. Kimevāti garahatthe nipāto. Naṅgalakoṭivaḍḍhoti
analyzed: tayī tava santike kathayimhā kim evā ti gara hatthe nipātaḥ
translated: Tayi lavimha, we spoke to you. Kimeva, what? Is a particle of contempt. Nangalakoṭivaḍḍho,

original: gahapatiputto daharakālato paṭṭhāya naṅgalakoṭiṃ vahantoyeva vaḍḍhati, tamatthaṃ
analyzed: gahapati putto dahara kālataḥ paṭṭhāya naṅgala koṭim vahanto yeva vaḍḍhati tam attham
translated: the son of a house-holder, from the time he was a boy, grew up carrying the end of the plough. With reference to that fact,

original: sandhāya “tvaṃ gahapatikammameva jānāsi, na khattiyānaṃ maṅgalakamma”nti iminā adhippāyenevamāha.
analyzed: sandhāya tvam gahapati kammam eva jānāsi na khattiyānam maṅgala kamman ti iminā adhippāyena evam āha
translated: with the intention, “You know only the work of a house-holder, not the auspicious work of the nobles,” he spoke thus.

original: Aññeti yathā kevaṭṭo vā senakādayo vā aññe paṇḍitā imāni khattiyānaṃ maṅgalatthāni
analyzed: aññe iti yathā kevaṭṭaḥ vā senaka ādayaḥ vā aññe paṇḍitāḥ imāni khattiyānam maṅgala tthāni
translated: Añña, others, as the wise Kevatta, Senaka, and others, know these to be auspicious for the nobles,

original: jānanti, tathā tvaṃ tāni kiṃ jānāsi, gahapatikammajānanameva tavānucchavikanti.
analyzed: jānanti tathā tvam tāni kim jānāsi gahapati kamma jānanam eva tava anucchavikam ti
translated: in the same way, do you know them? Knowing only the work of a house-holder is not worthy of you.

original: Iti naṃ akkositvā paribhāsitvā “gahapatiputto mama maṅgalantarāyaṃ karoti, nīharatha na”nti nīharāpetuṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: iti nam akkositvā paribhāsitvā gahapati puttaḥ mama maṅgala antarāyam karoti nīharatha gātham āha
translated: Thus, after reviling and abusing him, “The son of a house-holder is an obstacle to my auspicious ceremony. Take him away,” he had him taken away, and spoke the stanza:

original: “Imaṃ gale gahetvāna, nāsetha vijitā mama;
analyzed: imam gale na āsetha vijitāḥ mama
translated: “Taking him by the neck, drive him out of my kingdom,

original: Yo me ratanalābhassa, antarāyāya bhāsatī”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ me antarāyāya bhāsati iti
translated: he who speaks to me as an obstacle to my obtaining the jewel.”

original: So rañño kuddhabhāvaṃ ñatvā “sace kho pana maṃ koci rañño vacanaṃ gahetvā hatthe
