analyzed: vatvā kim deva aññāya anācārāya dussīlāya bhariyāya ānītāya tatas pi ekakena iva
translated: ‘What is the use of another wife, sire, who is unchaste and immoral? I would rather have her who was brought by one bird alone.

original: carituṃ vara’nti vutte ‘samma, ahaṃ ekaṃ sakuṇikaṃ sīlācārasampannaṃ assosiṃ, tava
analyzed: caritum varanti vutte samma aham ekam sa kuṇikam sīla ācāra sampannam assosim tava
translated: ‘I have heard of a certain bird-catcher who was virtuous and well-conducted, and who had a wife like yours.

original: bhariyāya sadisameva. Cūḷanirājassa hi sayanapālikā sāḷikā evarūpā, tvaṃ tattha gantvā
analyzed: bhariyāya sadisam eva cūḷani rājassa hi sayana pālikā sāḷikā evarūpā tvam tattha gantvā
translated: For the wife of Cūḷanirāj, the keeper of the king’s bed-chamber, was such a one. Go there,

original: tassā manaṃ pucchitvā okāsaṃ kāretvā sace te ruccati, āgantvā amhākaṃ ācikkha. Athāhaṃ
analyzed: tassāḥ manam pucchitvā okāsam kāretvā sace te ruccati āgantvā amhākam ācikkha atha aham
translated: and find out her wishes and get her consent. If she agrees, come and tell me. Then

original: vo vivāhaṃ katvā mahantena parivārena taṃ ānessāmā’ti vatvā maṃ idha pahiṇi, tenamhi
analyzed: vaḥ vivāham katvā mahantena parivārena tam ānessāma ati vatvā mam idha pahiṇi
translated: I will marry you and take you away with a great retinue.’ So he sent me here,

original: kāraṇenāgato”ti vatvā gāthaṃ āha –
analyzed: kāraṇena āgatā iti vatvā gātham āha
translated: and that is why I have come.” And he spoke the verse:

original: “Tassā kāmā hi sammatto, āgatosmi tavanti ke;
analyzed: tassā kāmā hi sammattaḥ āgataḥ asmi tavanti ke
translated: “I have come to you, my dear, because I heard that she was willing;

original: Sace kareyya okāsaṃ, ubhayova vasāmase”ti.
analyzed: sace kareyyaḥ okāsam ubhayā uva vasāmasa iti
translated: If she will give me a chance, we will both live together.”

original: Sā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā somanassappattā ahosi. Evaṃ santepi attano piyabhāvaṃ ajānāpetvā anicchamānā viya āha –
analyzed: sā tassa vacanam sutvā somanassa pattā ahosi evam sante pi attanaḥ piya bhāvam a jānāpetvā an icchamānā viya āha
translated: When she heard his words, she was delighted. But even so, not wishing to show her love, she said as if unwilling:

original: “Suvova suviṃ kāmeyya, sāḷiko pana sāḷikaṃ;
analyzed: suvā uva suvim kāmeyya sāḷikaḥ pana sāḷikam
translated: “A Suva might love a Suvi, and a Sāli might love a Sāli;

original: Suvassa sāḷikāyeva, saṃvāso hoti kīdiso”ti.
analyzed: suvassa sāḷikāya iva saṃvāsaḥ hoti kīdisaḥ iti
translated: But what sort of a life would it be for a Suva to live with a Sāli?”

original: Tattha suvoti samma suvapaṇḍita, suvova suviṃ kāmeyya. Kīdisoti asamānajātikānaṃ
analyzed: tattha suvaḥ ti samma suva paṇḍita suvaḥ uva suvim kāmeyya kīdisaḥ iti asamāna jātikānam
translated: There, “Good son” means “good son, wise one.” “A good son would seek a good daughter” . “What kind of” means what kind of living together is there between those of unequal birth?

original: saṃvāso nāma kīdiso hoti. Suvo hi samānajātikaṃ suviṃ disvā cirasanthavampi sāḷikaṃ
analyzed: saṃvāsaḥ nāma kīdisaḥ hoti suvaḥ hi samāna jātikam suvim disvā cira santhavam pi sāḷikam
translated: For a good son, seeing a good daughter of equal birth, would abandon even long-standing rice,

original: jahissati, so piyavippayogo mahato dukkhāya bhavissati, asamānajātikānaṃ saṃvāso nāma na sametīti.
analyzed: jahissati saḥ piya vippayogaḥ mahataḥ dukkhāya bhavissati asamāna jātikānam saṃvāsaḥ nāma na sameti iti
translated: and that separation from the beloved will be a great sorrow, and living together between those of unequal birth does not agree.

original: Itaro taṃ sutvā “ayaṃ maṃ na paṭikkhipati, parihārameva karoti, addhā maṃ icchissati, nānāvidhāhi naṃ upamāhi saddahāpessāmī”ti cintetvā āha –
analyzed: itaraḥ tam sutvā ayam mama na paṭikkhipati parihāram eva karoti addhā mama icchissati nānāvidhāhi nam upamāhi saddahāpessāmi iti cintetvā āha
translated: The other, having heard that, thought, “He does not reject me, he only makes an excuse, surely he will want me, I will convince him with various similes.” He said:

original: “Yoyaṃ kāme kāmayati, api caṇḍālikāmapi;
analyzed: yaḥ ayam kāme kāmayati api caṇḍālikām api
translated: “He who desires sensual pleasures, even a low-caste woman,

original: Sabbo hi sadiso hoti, natthi kāme asādiso”ti.
analyzed: sabbaḥ hi sadisaḥ hoti na atthi kāme asādiso ti
translated: for all are equal in this, there is no unequal in sensual pleasures.”

original: Tattha caṇḍālikāmapīti caṇḍālikaṃ api. Sadisoti cittasadisatāya sabbo saṃvāso sadisova hoti. Kāmasmiñhi cittameva pamāṇaṃ, na jātīti.
analyzed: tattha caṇḍālikām api iti caṇḍālikam api sadisaḥ iti citta sadisatāya sabbaḥ saṃvāso sadisaḥ uva hoti kāmasmin hi cittam eva pamāṇam na jāti iti
translated: There, “even a low-caste woman” means even a low-caste woman. “Equal” means that all living together is equal by the equality of mind. For in sensual pleasures, mind alone is the measure, not birth.

original: Evañca pana vatvā manussesu tāva nānājātikānaṃ samānabhāvadassanatthaṃ atītaṃ āharitvā dassento anantaraṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā manussesu tāva nānā jātikānam samāna bhāva dassana attham atītam āharitvā dassentaḥ anantaram gātham āha
translated: Having said this, in order to show that even among men of different races there is a common nature, he related the past, and in order to show this he uttered the following stanza:

original: “Atthi jampāvatī nāma, mātā sivissa rājino;
analyzed: atthi jampāvatī nāma mātā sivissa rājino
translated: “There was a woman named Jampati, the mother of King Sivi;

original: Sā bhariyā vāsudevassa, kaṇhassa mahesī piyā”ti.
analyzed: sā bhariyā vāsudevassa kaṇhassa mahesī piyāti
translated: She was the wife of Vasudeva, the beloved queen of the dark one.”

original: Tattha jampāvatīti sivirañño mātā jampāvatī nāma caṇḍālī ahosi. Sā kaṇhāyanagottassa
analyzed: tattha jappāvatī iti siviraññaḥ mātā jampāvatī nāma caṇḍālī ahosi sā kaṇhāyana gottassa
translated: Herein, Jampati was the name of the mother of King Sivi. She was a female outcast. She was the beloved queen of the eldest of the ten brothers of the Kanhayanagotta,

original: dasabhātikānaṃ jeṭṭhakassa vāsudevassa piyā mahesī ahosi. So kirekadivasaṃ dvāravatito🔽nikkhamitvā uyyānaṃ gacchanto nagaraṃ pavisantiṃ ekamante ṭhitaṃ abhirūpaṃ ekaṃ caṇḍālikaṃ🔽disvāva paṭibaddhacitto hutvā “kiṃ jātikā”ti pucchāpetvā “caṇḍālajātikā”ti sutvāpi
analyzed: dasa bhātikānam jeṭṭhakassa vāsudevassa piyā mahesī ahosi saḥ kira eka divasam dvāravatitaḥ  nikkhamitvā uyyānam gacchantaḥ nagaram pavisantim eka mante ṭhitam abhirūpam ekam caṇḍālikam  disvā ava paṭibaddha cittaḥ hutvā kim jātikā ati pucchāpetvā caṇḍāla jātikā ati sutvā api
translated: Vasudeva. It is said that one day, as he was going out of the city of Dvaravati to the pleasure garden, he saw a beautiful female outcast🔽standing in a corner as she was entering the city. He became love-stricken. He asked, “What is her caste?” When he was told, “She is of the outcast caste,”

original: paṭibaddhacittatāya asāmikabhāvaṃ pucchāpetvā “asāmikā”ti sutvā taṃ ādāya tato nivattitvā
analyzed: paṭibaddha citta tāya asāmika bhāvam pucchā apetvā asāmikā ati sutvā tam ādāya tatas nivattitvā
translated: he asked again, “Is she married?” When he was told, “She is not married,” he took her with him, turned back,🔽and

original: nivesanaṃ netvā aggamahesiṃ akāsi. Sā siviṃ nāma puttaṃ vijāyi. So pitu accayena
analyzed: nivesanam netvā agga mahesim akāsi sā sivim nāma puttam vijāyi saḥ pitu accayena
translated: and made her his chief consort. She gave birth to a son named Sivi. After his father’s death,

original: dvāravatiyaṃ rajjaṃ kāresi. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Iti so imaṃ udāharaṇaṃ āharitvā “evarūpopi nāma khattiyo caṇḍāliyā saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ
analyzed: dvāravatiyam rajjam kāresi tam sandhāya itam vuttam  iti saḥ imam udāharaṇam āharitvā evarūpaḥ api nāma khattiyaḥ caṇḍāliyā saddhim saṃvāsam
translated: he reigned in Dvāravatī. This is what was meant.

original: kappesi, amhesu tiracchānagatesu kiṃ vattabbaṃ, aññamaññaṃ saṃvāsarocanaṃyeva pamāṇa”nti
analyzed: kappesi amhesu tiracchāna gatesu kim vattabbam aññam aññam pamāṇam ti
translated: Thus, having related this story, he said, “Even such a noble, a warrior, had intercourse with a caṇḍāla woman. What can be said of us, animals? The only criterion is the mutual desire for intercourse.”

original: vatvā aparampi udāharaṇaṃ āharanto āha –
analyzed: vatvā aparam pi udāharaṇam āharantaḥ āha
translated: Having said this, he related another story:

original: “Raṭṭhavatī kimpurisī, sāpi vacchaṃ akāmayi;
analyzed: raṭṭhavatī kimpurisī sā api vaccham akāmayi
translated: “Raṭṭhavatī, a kinnarī, desired a calf;

original: Manusso migiyā saddhiṃ, natthi kāme asādiso”ti.
analyzed: manussaḥ migiyā saddhim na atthi kāme asādiso ti
translated: A human being with a deer, there is no equal in desire.”

original: Tattha vacchanti evaṃnāmakaṃ tāpasaṃ. Kathaṃ pana sā taṃ kāmesīti? Atītasmiñhi eko
analyzed: tattha vacchanti evaṃnāmakam tāpasam katham pana sā tam kāmesi iti atītasmin hi ekaḥ
translated: Here, “calf” is the name of an ascetic. But how did she desire him? In the past, a certain

original: brāhmaṇo kāmesu ādīnavaṃ disvā mahantaṃ yasaṃ pahāya isipabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā himavante
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ kāmesu ādīnavam disvā mahantam yasam pahāya isi pabbajjam pabbajitvā himavante
translated: brahmin, seeing the danger in sensual pleasures, renounced great fame, went forth as an ascetic, and lived in the Himalayas,

original: paṇṇasālaṃ māpetvā vasi. Tassa paṇṇasālato avidūre ekissā guhāya bahū kinnarā vasanti.
analyzed: paṇṇa sālam māpetvā vasi tassa paṇṇa sālataḥ avidūre ekissā guhāya bahū kinnarāḥ vasanti
translated: having a leaf hut built. Not far from his leaf hut, in a certain cave, many kinnaras lived.

original: Tattheva eko makkaṭako dvāre vasati. So jālaṃ vinetvā tesaṃ sīsaṃ bhinditvā lohitaṃ
analyzed: tattha iva ekaḥ makkaṭakaḥ dvāre vasati saḥ jālam vinetvā tesam sīsam bhinditvā lohitam
translated: A certain monkey lived at the door of the cave. He trained the net, broke their heads, and drank their blood.

original: pivati. Kinnarā nāma dubbalā honti bhīrukajātikā. Sopi makkaṭako ativisālo. Te tassa
analyzed: pivati kinnarāḥ nāma dubbalāḥ honti bhīruka jātikā saḥ api makkaṭakaḥ ati visālaḥ te tassa
translated: Now there was a certain monkey who lived at the gate. He would break the net, and then he would tear their heads open and drink their blood. The Kinnaras are weak and timid by nature, and this monkey was very large. They were unable to do anything to him.

original: kiñci kātuṃ asakkontā taṃ tāpasaṃ upasaṅkamitvā katapaṭisanthārā āgatakāraṇaṃ puṭṭhā🔽“deva, eko makkaṭako jīvitaṃ no hanati, tumhe ṭhapetvā amhākaṃ aññaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ
analyzed: kiñci kātum a sakkontā tam tāpasam upasaṅkamitvā kata paṭisanthārā āgata kāraṇam puṭṭhā  devaḥ ekaḥ makkaṭakaḥ jīvitam no hanati tumhe ṭhapetvā amhākam aññam paṭisaraṇam
translated: So they went to the hermit and paid obeisance to him. When he asked them the reason for their coming,🔽they said, “Sir, a certain monkey is killing us. We see no refuge for us but you. Kill him and give us peace.”

original: na passāma, taṃ māretvā amhākaṃ sotthibhāvaṃ karohī”ti āhaṃsu. Taṃ sutvā tāpaso “apetha🔽na mādisā pāṇātipātaṃ karontī”ti apasādesi. Tesu raṭṭhavatī nāma kinnarī abhirūpā
analyzed: na passāma tam māretvā amhākam sotthi bhāvam karohi iti āhaṃsu tam sutvā tāpasaḥ apetha  na mā adisā pāṇa atipātam karonti iti apasādesi tesu raṭṭhavatī nāma kinnarī abhirūpā
translated: When he heard this, the hermit said, “Go away. Those like me do not kill living beings.”

original: pāsādikā asāmikā ahosi. Te taṃ alaṅkaritvā tāpasassa santikaṃ netvā “deva, ayaṃ te
analyzed: pāsādikā asāmikā ahosi te tam alaṅkaritvā tāpasassa santikam netvā deva ayam te
translated: Now there was a certain she-Kinnara named Ratthapala who was beautiful and shapely and had no husband. They adorned her and took her to the hermit, saying, “Sir, let her be your attendant. Kill our enemy.”

original: pādaparicārikā hotu, amhākaṃ paccāmittaṃ vadhehī”ti āhaṃsu. Tāpaso taṃ disvāva paṭibaddhacitto
analyzed: pāda paricārikā hotu amhākam pacca amittam vadhehi iti āhaṃsu tāpaso tam disvā ava paṭibaddha citto
translated: When the hermit saw her, he was smitten with love.

original: hutvā tāya saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ kappetvā guhādvāre ṭhatvā gocaratthāya nikkhantaṃ makkaṭakaṃ
analyzed: hutvā tāya saddhim saṃvāsam kappetvā guhā dvāre ṭhatvā gocara tthāya nikkhantam makkaṭakam
translated: and after he had lived with her in companionship, he killed the monkey, who had gone out for food, by throwing a stone at him as he was standing at the door of the cave.

original: muggarena pothetvā jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpesi. So tāya saddhiṃ samaggavāsaṃ vasanto puttadhītāhi
analyzed: muggarena pothetvā jīvita kkhayam pāpesi saḥ tāya saddhim samagga vāsam vasantaḥ putta dhītāhi
translated: He lived in companionship with her, and they had sons and daughters.🔽He died there, and so she made him her lover.

original: vaḍḍhitvā tattheva kālamakāsi. Evaṃ sā taṃ kāmesi. Suvapotako imaṃ udāharaṇaṃ āharitvā
analyzed: vaḍḍhitvā tattha iva kālam akāsi evam sā tam kāmesi su vapotakaḥ imam udāharaṇam āharitvā
translated: The good parrot, having told this story,

original: “vacchatāpaso tāva manusso hutvā tiracchānagatāya kinnariyā saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ kappesi,
analyzed: vaccha tāpasaḥ tāva manusso hutvā tiracchāna gatāya kinnariyā saddhim saṃvāsam kappesi
translated: “The ascetic Vacchi, being a human being, lived in companionship with a female Kinnara who was an animal.🔽What then of us? We are both animals.”

original: kimaṅgaṃ pana amhākaṃ? Mayañhi ubho pakkhinova tiracchānagatāvā”ti dīpento “manusso
analyzed: kim aṅgam pana amhākam mayam hi ubho pakkhino iva tiracchāna gatau āti dīpentaḥ manusso
translated: He said, “A human being

original: migiyā saddhi”nti āha. Evaṃ manussā tiracchānagatāhi saddhiṃ samaggavāsaṃ vasanti,
analyzed: migiyā saddhinti āha evam manussā tiracchānagatāhi saddhim samagga vāsam vasanti
translated: with a female deer,” in order to show that human beings live in companionship with animals,

original: natthi kāme asādiso nāma, cittameva pamāṇanti kathesi.
analyzed: natthi kāme asādisaḥ nāma cittam eva pamāṇam ti kathesi
translated: and that there is no such thing as a suitable object of desire, that the mind is the only measure.

original: Sā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā “sāmi, cittaṃ nāma sabbakālaṃ ekasadisaṃ na hoti, piyavippayogassa bhāyāmī”ti āha. Sopi suvapotako itthimāyāsu kusalo, tena taṃ vīmaṃsanto puna gāthamāha –
analyzed: sā tassa vacanam sutvā sāmi cittam nāma sabba kālam eka sadisam na hoti piya vippayogassa bhāyāmi iti āha saḥ api itthi māyāsu kusalaḥ tena tam vīmaṃsantaḥ puna gātham āha
translated: She replied, “Husband, the heart is not always the same. I fear separation from one dear.” The young man was skilled in the wiles of women. He tested her, and spoke this verse:

original: “Handa khvāhaṃ gamissāmi, sāḷike mañjubhāṇike;
analyzed: handa khvā aham gamissāmi sāḷike mañjubhāṇike
translated: “Well, I will go, O Sāḷika, you who speak so sweetly;

original: Paccakkhānupadañhetaṃ, atimaññasi nūna ma”nti.
analyzed: atimaññasi nūna manti
translated: This is the sign of rejection, you surely despise me.”

original: Tattha paccakkhānupadaṃ hetanti yaṃ tvaṃ vadesi, sabbametaṃ paccakkhānassa anupadaṃ,
analyzed: tattha paccakkha anupadam ha etat ti yam tvam vadesi sabbam etam paccakkhānassa anupadam
translated: Herein, this is the sign of rejection is the reason why you say all this.

original: paccakkhānakāraṇaṃ paccakkhānakoṭṭhāso panesa. Atimaññasi nūna manti “nūna maṃ icchati
analyzed: paccakkhāna kāraṇam paccakkhāna koṭṭhāsaḥ pana esa atimaññasi nūna manti nūna mam icchati
translated: The sign of rejection is the cause of rejection, the section on the sign of rejection. You surely despise me means you surely want to leave me.

original: aya”nti tvaṃ maṃ atikkamitvā maññasi, mayhaṃ sāraṃ na jānāsi. Ahañhi rājapūjito,
analyzed: tvam mam atikkamitvā maññasi mayham sāram na jānāsi ahan hi rāja pūjitaḥ
translated: You think I am not worth much. I am honored by the king.

original: na mayhaṃ bhariyā dullabhā, aññaṃ bhariyaṃ pariyesissāmīti.
analyzed: na mayham bhariyā dullabhā aññam bhariyam pariyesissāmi iti
translated: A wife is not hard for me to get. I will look for another wife.”

original: Sā tassa vacanaṃ sutvāva bhijjamānahadayā viya tassa saha dassaneneva uppannakāmaratiyā anuḍayhamānā viya hutvāpi attano itthimāyāya anicchamānā viya hutvā diyaḍḍhaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sā tassa vacanam sutvā ava bhijjamāna hadayā viya tassa saha dassanena iva uppanna kāma ratiyā anuḍayhamānā viya hutvā api attanaḥ itthi māyāya an icchamānā viya hutvā diyaḍḍham gātham āha
translated: She, having heard his words, as if her heart were breaking, as if she were burning with the love that arose in her at the very sight of him, as if she were unwilling to be a woman, spoke half a stanza:

original: “Na sirī taramānassa, mādhara suvapaṇḍita;
analyzed: na sirī taramānassa mā adhara su va paṇḍita
translated: “Not glory, O you who are hasty, O you who are wise, O you who are good,

original: Idheva tāva acchassu, yāva rājāna dakkhasi;
analyzed: idhā iva tāva acchassu yāva rājāna dakkhasi
translated: Stay here for a while, until you see the king;

original: Sossi saddaṃ mudiṅgānaṃ, ānubhāvañca rājino”ti.
analyzed: sossi saddam mudiṅgānam ānubhāvañca
translated: Listen to the sound of the drums, and the majesty of the king.”

original: Tattha na sirīti samma suvapaṇḍita, taramānassa sirī nāma na hoti, taramānena katakammaṃ
analyzed: tattha na sirī iti samma su va paṇḍita taramānassa sirī nāma na hoti taramānena kata kammam
translated: Herein, not glory: O you who are wise, O you who are good, glory is not for one who is hasty. What is done by one who is hasty

original: na sobhati, “gharāvāso ca nāmesa atigaruko”ti cintetvā tuletvā kātabbo. Idheva tāva
analyzed: na sobhati ghara āvāsaḥ ca nāma īsa ati garukaḥ iti cintetvā tuletvā kātabbaḥ idhā iva tāva
translated: does not shine. “And this household life is a great affliction,” thinking thus, weighing it up, it should be done. Stay here for a while,🔽until you see our king who is endowed with great glory. Listen to the sound of the drums,

original: acchassu, yāva mahantena yasena samannāgataṃ amhākaṃ rājānaṃ passissasi. Sossīti
analyzed: acchassu yāva mahantena yasena samannāgatam amhākam rājānam passissasi sossi iti
translated: and the majesty of the king.

original: sāyanhasamaye kinnarisamānalīlāhi uttamarūpadharāhi nārīhi vajjamānānaṃ mudiṅgānaṃ
analyzed: sāyanha samaye kinnari samāna līlāhi uttama rūpa dharāhi nārīhi vajjamānānam mudiṅgānam
translated: At the time of evening, the drums are beaten by women who are endowed with the highest beauty, who are like Kinnara women.

original: aññesañca gītavāditānaṃ saddaṃ tvaṃ suṇissasi, rañño ca ānubhāvaṃ mahantaṃ sirisobhaggaṃ
analyzed: aññesam ca gīta vāditānam saddam tvam suṇissasi rañño ca ānubhāvam mahantam siri sobhaggam
translated: and you will hear the sound of other songs and musical instruments, and you will see the great majesty and glory of the King.”

original: passissasi. “Samma, kiṃ tvaṃ turitosi, kiṃ lesampi na jānāsi, acchassu tāva, pacchā jānissāmā”ti.
analyzed: passissasi samma kim tvam turito asi kim lesam pi na jānāsi acchassu tāva pacchā jānissāma ati
translated: “What is the matter, my dear? Do you not know even the meaning of the word ‘wait’? Wait a little, and afterwards we will know.”

original: Atha te sāyanhasamanantare methunasaṃvāsaṃ kariṃsu, samaggā sammodamānā piyasaṃvāsaṃ🔽vasiṃsu. Atha naṃ suvapotako “na idānesā mayhaṃ rahassaṃ guhissati, idāni naṃ pucchitvā
analyzed: atha te sāyanha samanantare methuna saṃvāsam kariṃsu samaggā sammodamānā piya saṃvāsam  vasiṃsu atha nam suva potakaḥ na idānī isā mayham rahassam guhissati idāni nam pucchitvā
translated: Then, in the evening, they had sexual intercourse, and they lived together in harmony and mutual appreciation.🔽Then the young parrot thought, “Now she will not keep my secret. I must ask her and then go.” So he said, “Sāḷikā.”

original: gantuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti cintetvā “sāḷike”ti āha. “Kiṃ, sāmī”ti? “Ahaṃ kiñci te vattukāmomhī”ti.
analyzed: gantum vaṭṭati iti cintetvā sāḷikā iti āha kim sāmi iti aham kiñci te vattu kāmaḥ omhi iti
translated: “What is it, my dear?” “I want to tell you something.”

original: “Vada, sāmī”ti. “Hotu, ajja amhākaṃ maṅgaladivaso, aññatarasmiṃ divase jānissāmī”ti.
analyzed: vada sāmi iti hotu ajja amhākam maṅgala divasaḥ aññatarasmin divase jānissāmi iti
translated: “Tell me, my dear.” “Well, today is an auspicious day for us. On another day I will know.”

original: “Sace maṅgalapaṭisaṃyuttā kathā bhavissati, kathehi. No ce, mā kathehi sāmī”ti. “Maṅgalakathāvesā,
analyzed: sace maṅgala paṭisaṃyuttā kathā bhavissati kathehi no ce mā kathehi sāmi iti maṅgala kathā vesā
translated: “If the conversation will be about auspicious things, then tell me. If not, then do not tell me, my dear.” “This is a conversation about auspicious things.

original: bhadde”ti. “Tena hi kathehī”ti. Atha naṃ “bhadde, sace sotukāmā bhavissasi, kathessāmi
analyzed: bhadda iti tena hi kathehi iti atha nam bhadde sace sotu kāmā bhavissasi kathessāmi
translated: “Well then, tell me.” “If you wish to hear, I will tell you.”

original: te”ti vatvā taṃ rahassaṃ pucchanto diyaḍḍhaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tā iti vatvā tam rahassam pucchantaḥ diyaḍḍham gātham āha
translated: And asking her the secret, he spoke the first half of the stanza:

original: “Yo nu khvāyaṃ tibbo saddo, tirojanapade suto;
analyzed: yaḥ nu khvā ayam tibbaḥ saddaḥ tirojanapade sutaḥ
translated: “This loud report that is heard in the distant land,

original: Dhītā pañcālarājassa, osadhī viya vaṇṇinī;
analyzed: dhītā pañcāla rājassa osadhī viya vaṇṇinī
translated: The daughter of the King of Pañcāla, fair as a medicinal herb,

original: Taṃ dassati videhānaṃ, so vivāho bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: tam dassati videhānam saḥ vivāhaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: He will give her to the Videhans, that will be the marriage.”

original: Tassattho – yo nu kho ayaṃ saddo tibbo bahalo, tirojanapade suto pararaṭṭhesu janapadesu
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yaḥ nu kho ayam saddaḥ tibbaḥ bahalaḥ tiro janapade sutaḥ para raṭṭhesu janapadesu
translated: The meaning is: This loud report, this great noise, is heard in the distant land, in the countries of other kings,

original: vissuto paññāto pākaṭo patthaṭo. Kinti? Dhītā pañcālarājassa osadhītārakā viya virocamānā
analyzed: vissutaḥ paññātaḥ pākaṭaḥ patthaṭaḥ kinti dhītā pañcāla rājassa osadhī tārakā viya virocamānā
translated: is spread about, is well known, is manifest, is clear. What is it? There is a daughter of the King of Pañcāla, shining like a medicinal herb,

original: tāya eva samānavaṇṇinī atthi, taṃ so videhānaṃ dassati, so vivāho bhavissati. Yo
analyzed: tāya eva samāna vaṇṇinī atthi tam saḥ videhānam dassati saḥ vivāhaḥ bhavissati yaḥ
translated: having a complexion like hers. He will give her to the Videhans. That will be the marriage.

original: so evaṃ patthaṭo saddo, ahaṃ taṃ sutvā cintesiṃ “ayaṃ kumārikā uttamarūpadharā, videharājāpi
analyzed: saḥ evam patthaṭaḥ saddaḥ aham tam sutvā cintesim ayam kumārikā uttama rūpa dharā videha rājā api
translated: That loud report, having heard it, I thought: “This maiden is of the highest beauty. The King of the Videhans

original: cūḷanirañño paṭisattu ahosi. Aññe bahū rājāno cūḷanibrahmadattassa vasavattino santi,
analyzed: cūḷaniḥ aññaḥ ahosi aññe bahū rājānaḥ cūḷani brahmadattassa vasa vattino santi
translated: was the adversary of King Cūḷanīrañña. There are many other kings who are vassals of Cūḷanībrahmadatta,

original: tesaṃ adatvā kiṃ kāraṇā videhassa dhītaraṃ dassatī”ti?
analyzed: tesam a datvā kim kāraṇā videhassa dhītaram dassati iti
translated: why should he give his daughter to the king of Videha without giving her to them?”

original: Sā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā evamāha – “sāmi, kiṃ kāraṇā maṅgaladivase avamaṅgalaṃ kathesī”ti?
analyzed: sā tassa vacanam sutvā evam āha sāmi kim kāraṇā maṅgala divase avamaṅgalam kathesi iti
translated: When she heard his words, she said, “Husband, why did you speak of an evil omen on the day of the good omen?”

original: “Ahaṃ, bhadde, ‘maṅgala’nti kathemi, tvaṃ ‘avamaṅgala’nti kathesi, kiṃ nu kho eta”nti?
analyzed: aham bhadde maṅgalanti kathemi tvam avamaṅgalanti kathesi kim nu kho etat ti
translated: “My dear, I spoke of a good omen, you spoke of an evil omen. What does this mean?”

analyzed: sāmi amittānam pi tesam evarūpā maṅgala kiriyā mā hotu uti kathehi tāva bhadda iti
translated: “Husband, let not such an auspicious ceremony as this be for our enemies.” “Tell me, my dear.”

original: “Sāmi, na sakkā kathetu”nti. “Bhadde, tayā viditaṃ rahassaṃ mama akathitakālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: sāmi na sakkā kathetunti bhadde tayā viditam rahassam mama a kathita kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: “Husband, I cannot tell.” “My dear, since you did not tell me the secret that you knew,

analyzed: natthi amhākam samagga saṃvāso ti sā tena nippīḷiyamānā tena hi sāmi suṇāhi iti
translated: there has been no harmony between us.” She, being pressed by him, said, “Then, husband, listen,”

original: vatvā imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vatvā imam gātham āha
translated: and spoke this verse:

original: “Ediso mā amittānaṃ, vivāho hotu mādhara;

translated: “May such a marriage as this be for our enemies, not for us,

original: Yathā pañcālarājassa, vedehena bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: yathā pañcāla rājassa vedehena bhavissati iti
translated: as will be between the king of Pañcāla and the king of Videha.”

original: Imaṃ gāthaṃ vatvā puna tena “bhadde, kasmā evarūpaṃ kathaṃ kathesī”ti vutte “tena hi suṇāhi, ettha dosaṃ te kathessāmī”ti vatvā imaṃ gāthamāha –

translated: After he had spoken this verse, the king asked her, “My dear, why do you talk in this way?” She replied, “Well then, listen, I will tell you the meaning of this.” So saying, she spoke the second verse:

original: “Ānayitvāna vedehaṃ, pañcālānaṃ rathesabho;
analyzed: ānayitvāna veda iham pañcālānam rathesabho
translated: “The prince of Pañcāla, having brought🔽The king of Videha, will kill him;

analyzed: tatas nam ghātayissati nassa sakhī bhavissati iti  tattha tatas nam ghātayissati iti yadā saḥ imam nagaram āgataḥ bhavissati tadā tena saddhim  sakhibhāvam mittadhammam na karissati daṭṭhum pissa dhītaram na dassati ekaḥ kirassa
translated: He will be his friend.”

analyzed: pana attha dhamma anusāsakaḥ mahosadhapaṇḍitaḥ nāma atthi tena saddhim tam ghātessati
translated: Herein, he will kill him means that when he comes to this city, he will not make friends with him, he will not befriend him, he will not show him his daughter. It is said that he has a wise counselor named Mahosadha, and he will kill him together with him.

original: Te ubho jane ghātetvā jayapānaṃ pivissāmāti kevaṭṭo raññā saddhiṃ mantetvā taṃ gaṇhitvā āgantuṃ gatoti.
analyzed: te ubho jane ghātetvā jaya pānam pivissāma ati kevaṭṭaḥ raññā saddhim mantetvā tam gaṇhitvā āgantum gataḥ ti
translated: After killing both of them, we will drink the victory-cup.” So the fisherman consulted with the king and went to capture him.

analyzed: evam sā guyham antam nissesam katvā suva paṇḍitassa kathesi tam sutvā suva paṇḍito
translated: Thus she told the whole secret to Suvaṇṇapaṇḍita. When he heard it, Suvaṇṇapaṇḍita said:

analyzed: ācariyaḥ kevaṭṭaḥ upāya kusalaḥ acchariyam tassa rañño evarūpena upāyena
translated: “The teacher Kevatta is skilled in means. It is wonderful how the king has been killed by such a means.”

original: kevaṭṭaṃ vaṇṇetvā “evarūpena avamaṅgalena amhākaṃ ko attho, tuṇhībhūtā sayāmā”ti🔽vatvā āgamanakammassa nipphattiṃ ñatvā taṃ rattiṃ tāya saddhiṃ vasitvā “bhadde, ahaṃ
analyzed: kevaṭṭam vaṇṇetvā evarūpena avamaṅgalena amhākam kaḥ atthaḥ tuṇhībhūtā sayāma ati  vatvā āgamana kammassa nipphattim ñatvā tam rattim tāya saddhim vasitvā bhadde aham
translated: After praising Kevatta, he said, “What have we to do with such an inauspicious woman? We will remain silent.”

original: siviraṭṭhaṃ gantvā manāpāya bhariyāya laddhabhāvaṃ sivirañño deviyā ca ārocessāmī”ti
analyzed: siviraṭṭham gantvā manāpāya bhariyāya laddha bhāvam siviraññaḥ deviyā ca ārocessāmi iti
translated: After learning the result of his mission, he spent that night with her. Then he said, “My dear, I will go to the Sivi country and tell the Sivi king and his queen that I have obtained a lovely wife.”

original: gamanaṃ anujānāpetuṃ āha –
analyzed: gamanam āha
translated: After obtaining their permission to go, he said:

original: “Handa kho maṃ anujānāhi, rattiyo sattamattiyo;
analyzed: handa kho mama anujānāhi rattiyaḥ sattamattiyaḥ
translated: “Please give me permission for seven nights,

original: Yāvāhaṃ sivirājassa, ārocemi mahesino;
analyzed: yāvā aham sivi rājassa ārocemi mahesinaḥ
translated: So that I may inform the Sivi king, the great queen,

analyzed: laddhaḥ ca me āvasathaḥ sāḷikāya upantikanti  tattha mahesino ti mahesiyā ca sa āvasathaḥ ti vasana ṭṭhānam upantikam ti atha ne etha
translated: That I have obtained a dwelling place, a neighbor for Sāḷikā.”

original: tassā santikaṃ gacchāmā”ti vatvā aṭṭhame divase idhānetvā mahantena parivārena taṃ
analyzed: tassā santikam gacchāma ati vatvā aṭṭhame divase idha ānetvā mahantena parivārena tam
translated: Here, “the great queen” means “his great queen.” “Dwelling place” means “a place to live.” “Neighbor” means “a neighbor.” Then he said, “Come, let us go to her.” After saying this, on the eighth day he brought her here with a great retinue.

original: gahetvā gamissāmi, yāva mamāgamanaṃ, tāva mā ukkaṇṭhīti.
analyzed: gahetvā gamissāmi yāva mama āgamanam tāva mā ukkaṇṭhī iti
translated: I will take her with me. Do not worry until I return.”

translated: Hearing this, Sālikā, though unwilling to be separated from him, was unable to refuse his request. She spoke the next verse:

translated: “Well then, I give you leave, seven nights and seven days;

translated: Here, I think you will come back to me when I am dead means: if you do not return to me within seven nights, I shall consider that I am dead. You will come back to me when I am dead. Therefore, do not make a fuss.

analyzed: itaraḥ api bhadde kim vadesi mayham pi aṭṭhame divase tam a passantassa kutas jīvitan ti

translated: After going a little way toward the country of Sivi, he turned back and went to Mithilā. He descended from the shoulder of the Great Being and🔽when questioned by the Great Being, who had taken him up to the upper terrace of the palace, he told him all that had happened.

original: ārocesi. Sopissa purimanayeneva sabbaṃ sakkāramakāsi. Tamatthaṃ pakāsento satthā āha –
analyzed: ārocesi saḥ upissa purima nayena iva sabbam sakkāram akāsi tam attham pakāsentaḥ satthā āha
translated: The Great Being also did all that was necessary in the same way as before. Expounding this matter, the Master said:

analyzed: tatas ca kho so gantvāna mādharaḥ su va paṇḍito
translated: “Then the wise Suvâma went and told

analyzed: mahosadhassa akkhāsi sāḷikā vacanam idam ti
translated: Mahosadha all that Sâlikâ had said.”

analyzed: tattha sāḷikā vacanam idam ti idam sāḷikāya vacanan ti sabbam vitthāretvā kathesi iti
translated: Herein, all that Sâlikâ had said is all that she had said, beginning with “I am a woman of the Vamsa caste.”

original: Suvakhaṇḍaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: suva khaṇḍam niṭṭhitam
translated: The Suvâma chapter is ended.

original: Mahāumaṅgakaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: mahā umaṅga kaṇḍam
translated: The Mahâummagga chapter

analyzed: tam sutvā mahāsatto cintesi rājā mama an icchamānassa iva gamissati gantvā ca pana
translated: When the Great Being heard this, he thought, “The king will go, though he does not wish to, and when he has gone,

analyzed: mahā vināsam pāpuṇissati atha mayham evarūpassa nāma yasadāyakassa raññaḥ vacanam
translated: he will meet with great destruction. But if I tell him, ‘The king, who is so famous,🔽will not listen to me, and he will go, and when he has gone, he will meet with great destruction,’ and if he goes,

analyzed: hadaye katvā tassa saṅgaham na akāsi iti garahā api uppajjissati mādise paṇḍite vijjamāne
translated: and that he did not take him into his confidence, and that he did not make him his heir.🔽“Why should he perish when there is a wise man like me?

original: kiṃkāraṇā esa nassissati, ahaṃ rañño puretarameva gantvā cūḷaniṃ disvā suvibhattaṃ
analyzed: kiṃkāraṇā esa nassissati aham rañño puretaram eva gantvā cūḷanim disvā su vibhattam
translated: I will go to the king and show him the plan.

analyzed: mahā umaṅgam kāretvā cūḷaniraññaḥ dhītaram abhisiñcitvā amhākam raññopāda paricārikam  katvā aṭṭhārasa akkhobhaṇi saṅkhehi balehi eka sata rājūsu parivāretvā ṭhitesu eva amhākam
translated: and I will consecrate the daughter of the king of Cūḷanika, and make her a concubine to our king,

original: rājānaṃ rāhumukhato candaṃ viya mocetvā ādāyāgamanaṃ nāma mama bhāro”ti. Tassevaṃ
analyzed: rājānam rāhu mukhataḥ candam viya mocetvā ādāya āgamanam nāma mama tassa evam
translated: and I will place our king in the midst of eighteen armies, each consisting of eighteen divisions, and surrounded by a hundred kings, and I will deliver our king as the moon from the jaws of Rāhu, and bring him back. This is my task.”🔽While he was thus reflecting, a thrill of joy passed through his body.

original: cintentassa sarīre pīti uppajji. So pītivegena udānaṃ udānento imaṃ upaḍḍhagāthamāha –
analyzed: cintentassa sarīre pīti uppajji saḥ pīti vegena udānam udānentaḥ imam upaḍḍha gātham āha
translated: He uttered a cry of joy, and recited the first half of the stanza:

original: “Yasseva ghare bhuñjeyya bhogaṃ, tasseva atthaṃ puriso careyyā”ti.
analyzed: yassa iva ghare bhuñjeyya bhogam tassa iva attham puriso careyya ati

translated: “A man of no worth” is one of no good qualities, one of no good family, one who is shameless, like the brahmin fisherman. “Do not make friendship with him” means

original: katvā tassa vacanaṃ gaṇhi. Dukkhoti evarūpena saddhiṃ saṅgamo nāma ekavārampi kato
analyzed: katvā tassa vacanam dukkho ti evarūpena saddhim saṅgamaḥ nāma eka vāram pi kataḥ
translated: do not make friendship with such a person. But you, Kevatta, made friendship with Kevatta and accepted his word. “Painful” means that association with such a person, even if done only once,

original: idhalokepi paralokepi mahādukkhāvahanato dukkho nāma hoti. Yadevāti yaṃ eva, ayameva
analyzed: idha loke pi para loke pi mahā dukkha āvahanato dukkhaḥ nāma hoti yat eva ati yam eva ayam eva
translated: is called painful because it brings about great suffering in this world and in the next world. “Whatever” means that very thing.

original: vā pāṭho. Sukhoti idhalokepi paralokepi sukhoyeva.
analyzed: vā idha loke pi para loke pi
translated: “Pleasant” means that it is pleasant both in this world and in the next world.

original: Atha naṃ “puna evarūpaṃ karissatī”ti suṭṭhutaraṃ niggaṇhanto pubbe raññā kathitakathaṃ āharitvā dassento –
analyzed: atha nam puna evarūpam karissati iti suṭṭhutaram niggaṇhantaḥ pubbe raññā kathita katham āharitvā dassentaḥ
translated: Then, in order to restrain him even more, thinking “He will do this again,” he brought up and showed the story told by the king in the past.

original: “Bālo tuvaṃ eḷamūgosi rāja, yo uttamatthāni mayī lapittho;
analyzed: bālo tuvam eḷamūgaḥ asi rāja yaḥ uttama tthāni mayī
translated: “You are a fool, a blockhead, O King, who to me, the best of men,

original: Kimevahaṃ naṅgalakoṭivaḍḍho, atthāni jānāmi yathāpi aññe.
analyzed: kim eva aham naṅgala koṭi vaḍḍhaḥ atthāni jānāmi yathā api aññe
translated: Has spoken thus. Why should I not know the meaning as well as others?

original: “Imaṃ gale gahetvāna, nāsetha vijitā mama;
analyzed: imam gale na āsetha vijitāḥ mama
translated: “Take me by the neck and lead me out, O King,

original: Yo me ratanalābhassa, antarāyāya bhāsatī”ti. –
analyzed: yaḥ me antarāyāya bhāsati iti
translated: Who speak to hinder me from gaining the jewel.”

original: Imā dve gāthā vatvā “mahārāja, ahaṃ gahapatiputto, yathā tava aññe senakādayo paṇḍitā
analyzed: imāḥ dve gāthāḥ vatvā mahā rāja aham gahapati puttaḥ yathā tava aññe senaka ādayaḥ paṇḍitā
translated: Having spoken these two stanzas, he said: “Great King, I am a son of a householder. As your other wise men, Senaka and the others,

original: atthāni jānanti, tathā kimeva ahaṃ jānissaṃ, agocaro esa mayhaṃ, gahapatisippamevāhaṃ
analyzed: atthāni jānanti tathā kim eva aham jānissam agocaraḥ esa mayham gahapati sippam eva aham
translated: Know the meaning, why should I know it? This is not my province. I know only the duties of a householder.

original: jānāmi, ayaṃ attho senakādīnaṃ paṇḍitānaṃ pākaṭo hoti, ajja te aṭṭhārasaakkhobhaṇisaṅkhāya
analyzed: jānāmi ayam atthaḥ senaka ādīnam paṇḍitānam pākaṭaḥ hoti ajja te aṭṭhārasa akkhobhaṇi saṅkhāya
translated: This meaning is clear to the wise men, Senaka and the others. Today, surrounded by your army of eighteen akkhobhiṇi divisions,

original: senāya parivāritassa senakādayo avassayā hontu, maṃ pana gīvāyaṃ gahetvā nikkaḍḍhituṃ
analyzed: senāya parivāritassa senaka ādayaḥ avassayā hontu mam pana gīvāyam gahetvā nikkaḍḍhitum
translated: Let Senaka and the others be your advisers. But you have ordered me to be taken by the neck and led out.

original: āṇāpesi, idāni maṃ kasmā pucchasī”ti evaṃ suniggahitaṃ niggaṇhi.
analyzed: āṇāpesi idāni mam kasmā pucchasi iti evam su niggahitam niggaṇhi
translated: Why do you ask me now?” Thus he rebuked him well.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā cintesi “paṇḍito mayā kathitadosameva katheti. Pubbeva hi idaṃ anāgatabhayaṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā cintesi paṇḍitaḥ mayā kathita dosam eva katheti pubbā iva hi idam anāgata bhayam
translated: When the king heard this, he thought, “The wise man speaks just as I have said. He knew this danger in the future,

original: jāni, tena maṃ ativiya niggaṇhāti, na kho panāyaṃ ettakaṃ kālaṃ nikkammakova acchissati,
analyzed: jāni tena mama ativiya niggaṇhāti na kho pana ayam ettakam kālam nikkammakaḥ uva acchissati
translated: and therefore he has restrained me so much. But he will not remain shut up so long.

original: avassaṃ iminā mayhaṃ sotthibhāvo kato bhavissatī”ti. Atha naṃ pariggaṇhanto dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: iminā mayham sotthi bhāvaḥ kataḥ bhavissati iti atha nam pariggaṇhantaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: I am sure he has done this for my welfare.” Then, in order to test him, he spoke two stanzas:

original: “Mahosadha atītena, nānuvijjhanti paṇḍitā,
analyzed: mahosadha atītena na anuvijjhanti paṇḍitā
translated: “The wise do not pursue the past,

original: Kiṃ maṃ assaṃva sambaddhaṃ, patodeneva vijjhasi.
analyzed: kim mam sambaddham patodena iva vijjhasi
translated: Why do you pierce me as if I were a hide with a needle?🔽“If you see a way of escape,

original: “Sace passasi mokkhaṃ vā, khemaṃ vā pana passasi;
analyzed: sace passasi mokkham vā khemam vā pana passasi
translated: or if you see a place of safety,

original: Teneva maṃ anusāsa, kiṃ atītena vijjhasī”ti.
analyzed: tena iva mama anusāsa kim atītena vijjhasi iti
translated: Then advise me accordingly; why do you pierce me with the past?”

original: Tattha nānuvijjhantīti atītadosaṃ gahetvā mukhasattīhi na vijjhanti. Assaṃva sambaddhanti
analyzed: tattha na anuvijjhanti iti atīta dosam gahetvā mukha sattīhi na vijjhanti assam va sambaddhanti
translated: Herein, do not pursue the past means they do not pierce with the goad of speech, having taken up a past fault. Why do you pierce me as if I were a hide with a needle?

original: sattusenāya parivutattā suṭṭhu bandhitvā ṭhapitaṃ assaṃ viya kiṃ maṃ vijjhasi. Teneva
analyzed: sattu senāya parivuta ttā suṭṭhu bandhitvā ṭhapitam assam viya kim mama vijjhasi tena iva
translated: means why do you pierce me as if I were a hide well fastened and placed, having been surrounded with seven thongs? If you see a way of escape means if you see a way of escape for me, a way of escape from this danger. Or if you see a place of safety means or if you see a place of safety for me, a place of safety from this danger.

original: manti evaṃ te mokkho bhavissati, evaṃ khemanti teneva sotthibhāvena maṃ anusāsa assāsehi,
analyzed: manti evam te mokkhaḥ bhavissati evam khemanti tena iva sotthi bhāvena mama anusāsa assāsehi
translated: “If you can do this, then you will be saved, and you will be safe. Therefore advise me, comfort me,

original: tañhi ṭhapetvā aññaṃ me paṭisaraṇaṃ natthīti.
analyzed: tat hi ṭhapetvā aññam me paṭisaraṇam natthi iti
translated: for, except you, I have no other refuge.”

original: Atha naṃ mahāsatto “ayaṃ rājā ativiya andhabālo, purisavisesaṃ na jānāti, thokaṃ kilametvā pacchā tassa avassayo bhavissamī”ti cintetvā āha –
analyzed: atha nam mahāsattaḥ ayam rājā ativiya andha bālo purisa visesam na jānāti thokam kilametvā pacchā tassa avassayaḥ bhavissami iti cintetvā āha
translated: Then the Great Being thought, “This king is exceedingly foolish and blind; he does not know a man of distinction. I will make him toil a little, and afterwards I will be his refuge.” So he said,

original: “Atītaṃ mānusaṃ kammaṃ, dukkaraṃ durabhisambhavaṃ;
analyzed: atītam mānusam kammam dukkaram durabhisambhavam
translated: “The deeds of men in the past were hard to do and hard to accomplish;

original: Na taṃ sakkopi mocetuṃ, tvaṃ pajānassu khattiya.
analyzed: na tam sakkopi mocetum tvam pajānassu khattiya
translated: Even Sakka could not deliver him, you must understand, O king.

original: “Santi vehāyasā nāgā, iddhimanto yasassino;
analyzed: santi vehāyasāḥ nāgāḥ iddhimantaḥ yasassinaḥ
translated: “There are dragons in the sky, powerful and glorious;

original: Tepi ādāya gaccheyyuṃ, yassa honti tathāvidhā.
analyzed: te pi ādāya gaccheyyum yassa honti tathāvidhā
translated: They also could carry him away, if he were such a one.

original: “Santi vehāyasā assā, iddhimanto yasassino;
analyzed: santi vehāyasāḥ assāḥ iddhimantaḥ yasassinaḥ
translated: “There are horses in the sky, powerful and glorious;

original: Tepi ādāya gaccheyyuṃ, yassa honti tathāvidhā.
analyzed: te pi ādāya gaccheyyum yassa honti tathāvidhā
translated: They also could carry him away, if he were such a one.

original: “Santi vehāyasā pakkhī, iddhimanto yasassino;
analyzed: santi vehāyasā pakkhī iddhimantaḥ yasassinaḥ
translated: “There are birds in the sky, powerful and glorious;

original: Tepi ādāya gaccheyyuṃ, yassa honti tathāvidhā.
analyzed: te pi ādāya gaccheyyum yassa honti tathāvidhā
translated: They also could carry him away, if he were such a one.

original: “Santi vehāyasā yakkhā, iddhimanto yasassino;
analyzed: santi vehāyasāḥ yakkhāḥ iddhimantaḥ yasassinaḥ
translated: “There are demons in the sky, powerful and glorious;

original: Tepi ādāya gaccheyyuṃ, yassa honti tathāvidhā.
analyzed: te pi ādāya gaccheyyum yassa honti tathāvidhā
translated: They would take him off, if he had such elephants.

original: “Atītaṃ mānusaṃ kammaṃ, dukkaraṃ durabhisambhavaṃ;
analyzed: atītam mānusam kammam dukkaram durabhisambhavam
translated: “Past human action, hard to do, hard to achieve,

original: Na taṃ sakkomi mocetuṃ, antalikkhena khattiyā”ti.
analyzed: na tam sakkomi mocetum antalikkhena khattiya ati
translated: I cannot deliver him, O prince, through the air.”

original: Tattha kammanti mahārāja, idaṃ ito tava mocanaṃ nāma atītaṃ, manussehi kattabbakammaṃ
analyzed: tattha kamman ti mahā rāja idam itas tava mocanam nāma atītam manussehi kattabba kammam
translated: Herein, action, great king, is past, human action,

original: atītaṃ. Dukkaraṃ durabhisambhavanti neva kātuṃ, na sambhavituṃ sakkā. Na taṃ sakkomīti
analyzed: atītam dukkaram durabhisambhavanti na iva kātum na sambhavitum sakkā na tam sakkomi iti
translated: past. Hard to do, hard to achieve: it cannot be done, it cannot be achieved. I cannot deliver him:

original: ahaṃ taṃ ito mocetuṃ na sakkomi. Tvaṃ pajānassu khattiyāti mahārāja, tvamevettha🔽kattabbaṃ jānassu. Vehāyasāti ākāsena gamanasamatthā. Nāgāti hatthino. Yassāti yassa
analyzed: aham tam itas mocetum na sakkomi tvam pajānassu khattiya ati mahā rāja tvam eva īttha  kattabbam jānassu vehāyasā ti ākāsena gamana samatthāḥ nāgāḥ ati hatthinaḥ yassa ati yassa
translated: I cannot deliver him from here. You know, O prince: great king, you yourself

original: rañño. Tathāvidhāti chaddantakule vā uposathakule vā jātā nāgā honti, taṃ rājānaṃ
analyzed: rañño tathāvidhā ati chaddanta kule vā uposatha kule vā jātāḥ nāgāḥ honti tam rājānam
translated: know what should be done here. Vehāyas: able to go through the air. Nāgā: elephants. Yassa: of which king. Tathāvidhā: elephants born in the Chaddanta or Uposatha families.

original: te ādāya gaccheyyuṃ. Assāti valāhakaassarājakule jātā assā. Pakkhīti garuḷhaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: te ādāya gaccheyyum assā ati valāhaka assa rāja kule jātā assā pakkhī iti garuḷham sandhāya āha
translated: They would take him off. Assā: horses born in the Valāhaka or Assarāja families. Pakkhī: he speaks of the garuḍa.

original: Yakkhāti sātāgirādayo yakkhā. Antalikkhenāti antalikkhena mocetuṃ na sakkomi, taṃ
analyzed: yakkha iti sātāgira ādayaḥ yakkhāḥ antalikkhena ati antalikkhena mocetum na sakkomi tam
translated: Yakkhas: Sātāgira and other yakkhas.

original: ādāya ākāsena mithilaṃ netuṃ na sakkomīti attho.
analyzed: ādāya ākāsena mithilam netum na sakkomi iti attho
translated: In the sky: I cannot carry him off through the sky. The meaning is: I cannot take him and carry him off to Mithilā through the air.

original: Rājā taṃ sutvā appaṭibhāno nisīdi. Atha senako cintesi “idāni rañño ceva amhākañca🔽ṭhapetvā paṇḍitaṃ aññaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ natthi, rājā panassa kathaṃ sutvā maraṇabhayatajjito
analyzed: rājā tam sutvā appaṭibhānaḥ nisīdi atha senakaḥ cintesi idāni rañño ca iva amhākam ca  ṭhapetvā paṇḍitam aññam paṭisaraṇam natthi rājā pana assa katham sutvā maraṇa bhaya tajjitaḥ
translated: When the king heard this, he sat down, unable to reply. Then Senaka thought, “Now there is no other refuge for the king and for me🔽except the wise man. But when the king heard his words, he was so terrified by the fear of death that he was unable to say anything. I will ask the wise man.”

original: kiñci vattuṃ na sakkoti, ahaṃ paṇḍitaṃ yācissāmī”ti. So yācanto dve gāthā abhāsi –
analyzed: kiñci vattum na sakkoti aham paṇḍitam yācissāmi iti saḥ yācantaḥ dve gāthāḥ abhāsi
translated: And asking, he spoke two stanzas:

original: “Atīradassī puriso, mahante udakaṇṇave;
analyzed: a tīra dassī purisaḥ mahante uda kaṇṇave
translated: “A man who sees no shore, in a great flood of water,

original: Yattha so labhate gādhaṃ, tattha so vindate sukhaṃ.
analyzed: yattha saḥ labhate gādham tattha saḥ vindate sukham
translated: where he finds a footing, there he finds happiness.

original: “Evaṃ amhañca rañño ca, tvaṃ patiṭṭhā mahosadha;
analyzed: evam amhan ca raññaḥ ca tvam patiṭṭhāḥ mahosadha
translated: “So you are the refuge of us and of the king, great doctor.

original: Tvaṃ nosi mantinaṃ seṭṭho, amhe dukkhā pamocayā”ti.
analyzed: tvam na usi mantinam seṭṭhaḥ amhe dukkhā pamocaya ati
translated: You are the best of counselors; deliver us from suffering.”

original: Tattha atīradassīti samudde bhinnanāvo tīraṃ apassanto. Yatthāti ūmivegabbhāhato
analyzed: tattha a tīra dassī iti samudde bhinna nāvaḥ tīram a passantaḥ yattha ati ūmi vega bhāhataḥ
translated: Herein, he sees no shore: he who, on a ship wrecked at sea, sees no shore. Where he finds a footing:

original: vicaranto yamhi padese patiṭṭhaṃ labhati. Pamocayāti pubbepi mithilaṃ parivāretvā
analyzed: vicarantaḥ yamhi padese patiṭṭham labhati pubbe pi mithilam parivāretvā
translated: and he asked the king to set him free.

original: ṭhitakāle tayāva pamocitamhā, idānipi tvameva amhe dukkhā mocehīti yāci.
analyzed: ṭhita kāle tvam eva amhe dukkhā mocehi iti yāci
translated: “You set me free before, when you surrounded Mithilā and besieged it. Now you must set me free again.”

original: Atha naṃ niggaṇhanto mahāsatto gāthāya ajjhabhāsi –
analyzed: atha nam niggaṇhantaḥ mahāsattaḥ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: Then the Great Being, in order to restrain him, spoke this verse:

original: “Atītaṃ mānusaṃ kammaṃ, dukkaraṃ durabhisambhavaṃ;
analyzed: atītam mānusam kammam dukkaram durabhisambhavam
translated: “The human deed of the past, difficult to do, difficult to accomplish,

original: Na taṃ sakkomi mocetuṃ, tvaṃ pajānassu senakā”ti.
analyzed: na tam sakkomi mocetum tvam pajānassu senakā ati
translated: I am not able to set you free. You must understand, Senaka.”

original: Tattha pajānassu senakāti senaka, ahaṃ na sakkomi, tvaṃ pana imaṃ rājānaṃ ākāsena mithilaṃ nehīti.
analyzed: tattha pajānassu senaka ati senaka aham na sakkomi tvam pana imam rājānam ākāsena mithilam nehi iti
translated: Herein, you must understand, Senaka, means, Senaka, I am not able, but you can take this king through the air to Mithilā.

original: Rājā gahetabbagahaṇaṃ apassanto maraṇabhayatajjito mahāsattena saddhiṃ kathetuṃ asakkonto “kadāci senakopi kiñci upāyaṃ jāneyya, pucchissāmi tāva na”nti pucchanto gāthamāha –
analyzed: rājā gahetabba gahaṇam a passantaḥ maraṇa bhaya tajjitaḥ mahāsattena saddhim kathetum a sakkontaḥ kadāci senakaḥ api kiñci upāyam jāneyya pucchissāmi tāva nanti pucchantaḥ gātham āha
translated: The king, not seeing any means of escape, terrified with the fear of death, unable to speak to the Great Being, thought, “Perhaps Senaka might know some means. I will ask him.” So he spoke this verse, asking:

original: “Suṇohi metaṃ vacanaṃ, passa senaṃ mahabbhayaṃ;
analyzed: suṇohi mā itam vacanam passa senam mahat bhayam
translated: “Listen to this speech of mine, see the great fear of Senaka.

original: Senakaṃ dāni pucchāmi, kiṃ kiccaṃ idha maññasī”ti.
analyzed: senakam dāni pucchāmi kim kiccam idha maññasi iti
translated: I now ask Senaka: what should be done here, do you think?”

original: Tattha kiṃ kiccanti kiṃ kātabbayuttakaṃ idha maññasi, mahosadhenamhi pariccatto, yadi tvaṃ jānāsi, vadehīti.
analyzed: tattha kim kiccanti kim kātabba yuttakam idha maññasi pariccattaḥ yadi tvam jānāsi vadehi iti
translated: “What is it you want done? What do you think should be done? I have been handed over to you, Mahosadha. If you know, tell me.”

original: Taṃ sutvā senako “maṃ rājā upāyaṃ pucchati, sobhano vā hotu mā vā, kathessāmi ekaṃ upāya”nti cintetvā gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā senakaḥ mam rājā upāyam pucchati sobhanaḥ vā hotu mā vā kathessāmi ekam upāyanti cintetvā gātham āha
translated: When Senaka heard this, he thought, “The king is asking me for a means. Whether it is good or not, I will tell him one means.” So he spoke this verse:

original: “Aggiṃ vā dvārato dema, gaṇhāmase vikantanaṃ;
analyzed: aggim vā dvārataḥ dema gaṇhāmase vikantanam
translated: “We can set fire to the door, or we can take up arms and fight.

original: Aññamaññaṃ vadhitvāna, khippaṃ hissāma jīvitaṃ;
analyzed: aññam aññam vadhitvāna khippam hissāma jīvitaṃ
translated: Having killed each other, we will quickly give up our lives.

original: Mā no rājā brahmadatto, ciraṃ dukkhena mārayī”ti.🔽Tattha dvāratoti dvāraṃ pidahitvā tattha aggiṃ dema. Vikantananti aññamaññaṃ vikantanaṃ
analyzed: mā naḥ rājā brahmadatto ciram dukkhena mārayi iti  tattha dvārato ti dvāram pidahitvā tattha aggim dema vikantanam ti aññam aññam vikantanam
translated: Let not King Brahmadatta, for a long time, kill us with sorrow.”

original: satthaṃ gaṇhāma. Hissāmāti jīvitaṃ khippaṃ jahissāma, alaṅkatapāsādoyeva no dārucitako bhavissati.
analyzed: sattham gaṇhāma hissāma ati jīvitam khippam jahissāma alaṅkata pāsādaḥ yā iva naḥ dāru citakaḥ bhavissati
translated: Here, “to the door” means we can set fire to the door after closing it. “Arms” means we can take up arms and fight each other. “Give up” means we will quickly give up our lives. The decorated palace will become our funeral pyre.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā anattamano “attano puttadārassa evarūpaṃ citakaṃ karohī”ti vatvā pukkusādayo pucchi. Tepi attano patirūpā bālakathāyeva kathayiṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ –
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā anattamanaḥ attano putta dārassa evarūpam citakam karohi iti vatvā pukkusa ādayo pucchi te pi attano pati rūpāḥ bāla kathāya iva kathayiṃsu tena vuttam
translated: When the king heard this, he was displeased, and said, “Make such a pyre for my own wife and children.” He then asked Pukkusāti and the others. They also told him stories suitable for children. Therefore it is said:

original: “Suṇohi metaṃ vacanaṃ, passa senaṃ mahabbhayaṃ;
analyzed: suṇohi mā itam vacanam passa senam mahat bhayam
translated: “Listen to my words, and see the great fear of the army.

original: Pukkusaṃ dāni pucchāmi, kiṃ kiccaṃ idha maññasi.
analyzed: pukkusam dāni pucchāmi kim kiccam idha maññasi
translated: Now I ask Pukkusāti, what do you think should be done here?

original: “Visaṃ khāditvā mīyāma, khippaṃ hissāma jīvitaṃ;
analyzed: visam khāditvā mīyāma khippam hissāma jīvitaṃ

translated: Herein, the divine magic is the divine magic here. Young men means young men attendants. By the way they made means by the way they made. By the way means by the decorated way.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā “alaṅkataumaṅgena kira gato, kīdiso nu kho umaṅgo”ti umaṅgaṃ daṭṭhukāmo
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā alaṅkata aumaṅgena kira gataḥ kīdisaḥ nu kho umaṅgo ti umaṅgam daṭṭhu kāmo
translated: Having heard that, the king thought: “He went by a decorated way, I wonder what sort of way it was?” and he became desirous of seeing the way.

original: ahosi. Athassa icchitaṃ ñatvā mahāsatto “rājā umaṅgaṃ daṭṭhukāmo, dassessāmissa umaṅga”nti dassento āha –
analyzed: ahosi athassa icchitam ñatvā mahāsattaḥ rājā umaṅgam daṭṭhu kāmaḥ dassessāmi issa umaṅgam iti dassentaḥ āha
translated: Then, having understood his wish, the Great Being thought: “The king is desirous of seeing the way, I will show him the way” and showing it, he said:

original: “Iṅgha passa mahārāja, umaṅgaṃ sādhu māpitaṃ;
analyzed: iṅgha passa mahā rāja umaṅgam sādhu māpitam
translated: “Come, look, Great King, at the way well made;

original: Hatthīnaṃ atha assānaṃ, rathānaṃ atha pattinaṃ;
analyzed: hatthīnam atha assānam rathānam atha pattinam
translated: Of elephants, of horses, of chariots, of foot-soldiers,

original: Ālokabhūtaṃ tiṭṭhantaṃ, umaṅgaṃ sādhu māpita”nti.
analyzed: āloka bhūtam tiṭṭhantam umaṅgam sādhu
translated: Standing as a light, the way well made.”

original: Tattha hatthīnanti iṭṭhakakammacittakammavasena katānaṃ etesaṃ hatthiādīnaṃ pantīhi upasobhitaṃ alaṅkatadevasabhāsadisaṃ ekobhāsaṃ hutvā tiṭṭhantaṃ umaṅgaṃ passa, devāti.
analyzed: tattha hatthīnam ti iṭṭhaka kamma cittakamma vasena katānam etesam hatthi ādīnam pantīhi upasobhitam alaṅkata deva sabhā sadisam eka ubhāsam hutvā tiṭṭhantam umaṅgam passa deva ati
translated: “Look, King, at the pleasure-ground, which is like the celestial hall, resplendent with its many paths, and which is all one blaze of light, being built of bricks and stucco in the form of elephants, horses, chariots, footmen, women, and men.”

original: Evañca pana vatvā “mahārāja, mama paññāya māpite candassa ca sūriyassa ca uṭṭhitaṭṭhāne
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā mahā rāja mama paññāya māpite candassa ca sūriyassa ca uṭṭhita ṭṭhāne
translated: And having so said, he opened the city gates, and said, “Great king, in my wisdom I have built a pleasure-ground, which is as conspicuous as the rising of the sun or moon,

original: viya pākaṭe alaṅkataumaṅge asītimahādvārāni catusaṭṭhicūḷadvārāni ekasatasayanagabbhe🔽anekasatadīpagabbhe ca passa, mayā saddhiṃ samaggo sammodamāno hutvā attano balena
analyzed: pākaṭe alaṅkataumaṅge asīti mahā dvārāni catur aṭṭhicūḷa dvārāni eka sata sayana gabbhe  aneka sata dīpa gabbhe ca passa mayā saddhim samaggaḥ sammodamānaḥ hutvā attanaḥ balena
translated: with eighty great gates, sixty-four lesser gates, a hundred chambers for couches,🔽and many hundreds of chambers for lamps. Enter the city of Upakarṇa with your army, in harmony and friendship with me.”

original: saddhiṃ upakārinagaraṃ pavisa, devā”ti nagaradvāraṃ vivarāpesi. Rājā ekasatarājaparivāro
analyzed: saddhim upakāri nagaram pavisa devāti nagara dvāram rājā eka sata rāja parivāraḥ
translated: The king, surrounded by a hundred kings,

original: nagaraṃ pāvisi. Mahāsatto pāsādā oruyha rājānaṃ vanditvā saparivāraṃ ādāya umaṅgaṃ
analyzed: nagaram pāvisi mahāsattaḥ pāsādāḥ oruyha rājānam vanditvā sa parivāram ādāya umaṅgam
translated: entered the city. The Great Being descended from the palace, saluted the king, and taking him and his retinue,

original: pāvisi. Rājā alaṅkatadevasabhaṃ viya umaṅgaṃ disvā bodhisattassa guṇe vaṇṇento āha –
analyzed: pāvisi rājā alaṅkata deva sabham viya umaṅgam disvā bodhisattassa guṇe vaṇṇentaḥ āha
translated: led them into the pleasure-ground. The king, seeing the pleasure-ground like the celestial hall, extolled the virtues of the Bodhisatta, and said:

original: “Lābhā vata videhānaṃ, yassimedisā paṇḍitā;
analyzed: vata videhānam paṇḍitā
translated: In whose domain such a wise one dwells,

original: Ghare vasanti vijite, yathā tvaṃsi mahosadhā”ti.
analyzed: ghare vasanti vijite yathā tvaṃsi mahosadhā ati
translated: In whose house, in whose realm, as thou, O great medicine!”

original: Tattha videhānanti evarūpānaṃ paṇḍitānaṃ ākarassa uṭṭhānaṭṭhānabhūtassa videhānaṃ🔽janapadassa lābhā vata. Yassimedisāti yassa ime evarūpā paṇḍitā upāyakusalā santike
analyzed: tattha videhānam ti evarūpānam paṇḍitānam ākarassa uṭṭhāna ṭṭhāna bhūtassa videhānam  janapadassa lābhā vata yassimedisā ati yassa ime evarūpā paṇḍitā upāya kusalā santike
translated: Herein, of those of Videha means of the people of Videha, the source and origin of such wise men.

original: vā ekaghare vā ekajanapade vā ekaraṭṭhe vā vasanti, tassapi lābhā vata. Yathā tvaṃsīti
analyzed: vā eka ghare vā eka janapade vā eka raṭṭhe vā vasanti vata yathā tvaṃsi iti
translated: How great the gain of those of Videha. In whose domain such a wise one dwells means how great the gain of those in whose vicinity, in whose house, in whose province, in whose realm, such wise men, skilled in means, dwell. As thou, O great medicine means

original: yathā tvaṃ asi, tādisena paṇḍitena saddhiṃyeva ekaraṭṭhe vā ekajanapade vā ekanagare🔽vā ekaghare vā vasituṃ labhanti. Tesaṃ videharaṭṭhavāsīnañceva mithilanagaravāsīnañca
analyzed: yathā tvam asi tādisena paṇḍitena saddhiṃyā iva eka raṭṭhe vā eka janapade vā eka nagare  vā eka ghare vā vasitum labhanti tesam videha raṭṭha vāsīnam ca iva mithilā nagara vāsīnam ca
translated: as thou art, one who is such, they gain the opportunity to dwell in the same province, in the same district, in the same city,

original: tayā saddhiṃ ekato vasituṃ labhantānaṃ lābhā vatāti vadati.
analyzed: tayā saddhim ekatas vasitum labhantānam lābhāḥ vata ati vadati
translated: in the same house, with such a wise man. He says that they gain the opportunity to dwell together with thee, both those who dwell in the Videha province and those who dwell in the city of Mithila.

original: Athassa mahāsatto ekasatasayanagabbhe dasseti. Ekassa dvāre vivaṭe sabbesaṃ vivarīyati.
analyzed: athassa mahāsatto eka sata sayana gabbhe dasseti ekassa dvāre vivaṭe sabbesam vivarīyati
translated: Then the Great Being showed himself in the chamber of the hundred-pillared hall. When the door of one was opened, all were opened.

original: Ekassa dvāre pidahite sabbesaṃ pidhīyati. Rājā umaṅgaṃ olokento purato gacchati,
analyzed: ekassa dvāre pidahite sabbesam pidhīyati rājā umaṅgam olokento puratas gacchati
translated: When one door was closed, all were closed. The king went forward looking at the sky,

original: paṇḍito pana pacchato. Sabbā senā umaṅgameva pāvisi. Rājā umaṅgato nikkhami. Paṇḍito
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ pana pacchatas sabbā senā umaṅgam eva pāvisi rājā umaṅgataḥ nikkhami paṇḍitaḥ
translated: but the wise man went behind. The whole army entered the Umaṅga. The king came out of the Umaṅga. The wise man

original: tassa nikkhantabhāvaṃ ñatvā sayaṃ nikkhamitvā aññesaṃ nikkhamituṃ adatvā umaṅgadvāraṃ
analyzed: tassa nikkhanta bhāvam ñatvā sayam nikkhamitvā aññesam nikkhamitum a datvā umaṅga dvāram
translated: knowing that he had come out, himself came out and without allowing the others to come out, closed the door of the Umaṅga

original: pidahanto āṇiṃ akkami. Tāvadeva asītimahādvārāni catusaṭṭhicūḷadvārāni ekasatasayanagabbhadvārāni🔽anekasatadīpagabbhadvārāni ca ekappahāreneva pidahiṃsu. Sakalo umaṅgo lokantariyanirayo
analyzed: pidahantaḥ āṇim akkami tāvat eva asīti mahā dvārāni catur aṭṭhicūḷa dvārāni eka sata sayana gabbha dvārāni  aneka sata dīpa gabbha dvārāni ca eka ppahārena iva sakalaḥ umaṅgaḥ lokantariya nirayaḥ
translated: and went on. Immediately the eighty great doors, the sixty-four small doors, the one hundred and one sleeping rooms,

original: viya andhakāro ahosi. Mahājano bhītatasito ahosi. Mahāsatto hiyyo umaṅgaṃ pavisanto
analyzed: viya andhakāraḥ ahosi mahā janaḥ bhīta tasitaḥ ahosi mahā sattaḥ hiyyas umaṅgam pavisantaḥ
translated: and the many hundreds of lamp rooms were closed at once. The whole Umaṅga became as dark as the hell of the world of darkness. The great crowd was frightened and terrified. The great being, when he entered the Umaṅga the day before,

original: yaṃ khaggaṃ vāluke ṭhapesi, taṃ gahetvā bhūmito aṭṭhārasahatthubbedhaṃ ākāsaṃ ullaṅghitvā
analyzed: yam khaggam vāluke ṭhapesi tam gahetvā bhūmitaḥ aṭṭhārasa hatthubbedham ākāsam ullaṅghitvā
translated: had placed his sword in the sand. He took it, stood on the ground, jumped up eighteen cubits into the air,

original: oruyha rājānaṃ hatthe gahetvā asiṃ uggiritvā tāsetvā “mahārāja, sakalajambudīpe rajjaṃ
analyzed: āruyha rājānam hatthe gahetvā asim uggiritvā tāsetvā mahā rāja sakala jambudīpe rajjam
translated: came down, seized the king by the hand, drew his sword, and frightened him, saying: “Great king, in all Jambudīpa you are the king,🔽but now you are not even the king of this Umaṅga.

original: kassa rajja”nti pucchi. So bhīto “tuyhameva paṇḍitā”ti vatvā “abhayaṃ me dehī”ti
analyzed: kassa rajjanti pucchi saḥ bhītaḥ tuyham eva paṇḍitā ati vatvā abhayam me dehi iti
translated: “Whose kingdom is it?”

original: āha. “Mā bhāyittha, mahārāja, nāhaṃ taṃ māretukāmatāya khaggaṃ parāmasiṃ, mama paññānubhāvaṃ
analyzed: āha mā bhāyittha mahā rāja na aham tam māretu kāma tāya khaggam mama paññā anubhāvam
translated: “Fear not, great king,” said he, “I did not whet my sword with the desire to slay thee, but to show thee the power of my wisdom.

original: dassetuṃ parāmasi”nti khaggaṃ rañño adāsi. Atha naṃ khaggaṃ gahetvā ṭhitaṃ “mahārāja,
analyzed: dassetum parāmasinti khaggam raññaḥ adāsi atha nam khaggam gahetvā ṭhitam mahā rāja
translated: ” And he gave the king his sword. Then as the king stood holding the sword, the Bodhisatta said, “Great king,

original: sace maṃ māretukāmosi, idāneva iminā khaggena mārehi. Atha abhayaṃ dātukāmo, abhayaṃ
analyzed: sace mam māretu kāmaḥ asi idānā iva iminā khaggena mārehi atha abhayam dātu kāmaḥ abhayam
translated: if thou wishest to slay me, slay me now with this sword. If thou wishest to give me safety,

original: dehī”ti āha. “Paṇḍita, mayā tuyhampi abhayaṃ dinnameva, tvaṃ mā cintayī”ti asiṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: dehi iti āha paṇḍita mayā abhayam dinnam eva tvam mā asim ṭhapetvā
translated: give me safety.” “Wise man,” said the king, “I have already given thee safety. Thou needst not fear.” And he laid aside his sword.

original: ubhopi aññamaññaṃ adubbhāya sapathaṃ kariṃsu.
analyzed: ubhau api aññam aññam a dubbhāya sapatham kariṃsu
translated: And the two, without mistrusting each other, made a solemn covenant.

original: Atha rājā bodhisattaṃ āha – “paṇḍita, evaṃ ñāṇabalasampanno hutvā rajjaṃ kasmā na
analyzed: atha rājā bodhisattam āha paṇḍitaḥ evam ñāṇa bala sampannaḥ hutvā rajjam kasmai na
translated: Then the king said to the Bodhisatta, “Wise man, having such power of wisdom, why dost thou not

original: gaṇhāsī”ti? “Mahārāja, ahaṃ icchamāno ajjeva sakalajambudīpe rājāno māretvā rajjaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhāsi iti mahā rāja aham icchamānaḥ ajjā iva sakala jambudīpe rājānaḥ māretvā rajjam
translated: take the kingdom upon thee?” “Great king, if I would, I could slay this day all the kings in all Jambudīpa, and take the kingdom🔽upon me.

original: gaṇheyyaṃ, paraṃ māretvā ca yasaggahaṇaṃ nāma paṇḍitehi na pasattha”nti. “Paṇḍita,🔽mahājano dvāraṃ alabhamāno paridevati, umaṅgadvāraṃ vivaritvā mahājanassa jīvitadānaṃ
analyzed: gaṇheyyam param māretvā ca yasa ggahaṇam nāma paṇḍitehi na pasatthanti paṇḍita  mahā janaḥ dvāram a labhamānaḥ paridevati umaṅga dvāram mahā janassa jīvita dānam
translated: “I would not kill another, nor would I take the glory of another.”🔽“The people, not being able to enter the city, are lamenting. Open the Umaṅga gate and give life to the people.”

original: dehī”ti. So dvāraṃ vivari, sakalo umaṅgo ekobhāso ahosi. Mahājano assāsaṃ paṭilabhi.
analyzed: dehi iti saḥ dvāram sakalaḥ umaṅgaḥ eka ubhāsaḥ ahosi mahā janaḥ assāsam paṭilabhi
translated: He opened the gate, and the whole of Umaṅga was illuminated. The people obtained relief.

original: Sabbe rājāno attano senāya saddhiṃ nikkhamitvā paṇḍitassa santikaṃ āgamiṃsu. So raññā🔽saddhiṃ visālamāḷake aṭṭhāsi. Atha naṃ te rājāno āhaṃsu “paṇḍita, taṃ nissāya jīvitaṃ
analyzed: sabbe rājānaḥ attano senāya saddhim nikkhamitvā paṇḍitassa santikam āgamiṃsu saḥ raññā  saddhim visālamāḷake aṭṭhāsi atha nam te rājānaḥ āhaṃsu paṇḍita tam nissāya jīvitaṃ
translated: All the kings, with their armies, left and came to the wise man. He stood in the palace with the king.

original: laddhaṃ, sace muhuttaṃ umaṅgadvāraṃ na vivarittha, sabbesaṃ no tattheva maraṇaṃ abhavissā”ti.
analyzed: laddham sace muhuttam umaṅga dvāram na sabbesam no tattha iva maraṇam abhavissāti
translated: Then those kings said, “Wise man, through you we obtained life. If you had not opened the Umaṅga gate for a moment, all of us would have died right there.”

original: “Na mahārājāno idāneva tumhehi maññeva nissāya jīvitaṃ laddhaṃ, pubbepi laddhaṃyevā”ti.
analyzed: na mahā rājāno idānā iva tumhehi maññā iva nissāya jīvitam laddham pubbe pi laddham yeva ati
translated: “Great kings, not only now did you obtain life through me, but in the past as well.”

original: “Kadā, paṇḍitā”ti? “Ṭhapetvā amhākaṃ nagaraṃ sakalajambudīpe rajjaṃ gahetvā uttarapañcālanagaraṃ
analyzed: kadā paṇḍitā ati ṭhapetvā amhākam nagaram sakala jambudīpe rajjam gahetvā uttarapañcāla nagaram
translated: “When, wise men?” “Except in our own city, in all the rest of Jambudīpa, and in the city of Uttarāpañcāla,

original: gantvā uyyāne jayapānaṃ pātuṃ surāya paṭiyattakālaṃ sarathā”ti? “Āma, paṇḍitā”ti.
analyzed: gantvā uyyāne jaya pānam pātum surāya paṭiyatta kālam āma paṇḍita ati
translated: having gone there, having drunk the victory-drink in the garden, at the time appointed for the wine, with the chariots.” “Yes, wise men.”

original: Tadā esa rājā kevaṭṭena saddhiṃ dummantitena visayojitāya surāya ceva macchamaṃsehi🔽ca tumhe māretuṃ kiccamakāsi. Athāhaṃ “mādise paṇḍite dharamāne ime anāthamaraṇaṃ
analyzed: tadā esa rājā kevaṭṭena saddhim dummantitena visayojitāya surāya ca iva maccha maṃsehi  ca tumhe māretum kiccam akāsi atha aham mādise paṇḍite dharamāne ime anātha maraṇam
translated: Then this king, together with the fisherman Dummantia, having mixed poison with the wine and with the fish-meat,🔽made an effort to kill you. Then I sent my own soldiers, thinking: ‘While such wise men as these are alive, let them not die a miserable death,

original: mā marantū”ti attano yodhe pesetvā sabbabhājanāni bhindāpetvā etesaṃ mantaṃ bhinditvā
analyzed: mā marantu iti attanaḥ yodhe pesetvā sabba bhājanāni bhindāpetvā etesam mantam bhinditvā
translated: having broken their spell,

original: tumhākaṃ jīvitadānaṃ adāsinti.
analyzed: tumhākam jīvita dānam adāsinti
translated: I gave you the gift of life.’

original: Te sabbepi ubbiggamānasā hutvā cūḷanirājānaṃ pucchiṃsu “saccaṃ kira, mahārājā”ti?
analyzed: te sabbe api ubbigga mānasāḥ hutvā cūḷani rājānam pucchiṃsu saccam kira mahā rāja ati
translated: All of them, their minds agitated, asked Cūḷanirājan: “Is it true, great king?”

original: “Āma, mayā kevaṭṭassa kathaṃ gahetvā kataṃ, saccameva paṇḍito kathetī”ti. Te sabbepi
analyzed: āma mayā kevaṭṭassa katham gahetvā katam saccam eva paṇḍitaḥ katheti iti te sabbe pi
translated: “Yes, having taken the fisherman’s advice, I did it. The wise man speaks the truth.” All of them

original: mahāsattaṃ āliṅgitvā “paṇḍita, tvaṃ sabbesaṃ no patiṭṭhā jāto, taṃ nissāya mayaṃ
analyzed: mahāsattam āliṅgitvā paṇḍita tvam sabbesam no patiṭṭhā jātaḥ tam nissāya mayam
translated: The king embraced the Great Being, and said, “Wise one, you have become the support of us all.

original: jīvitaṃ labhimhā”ti sabbapasādhanehi mahāsattassa pūjaṃ kariṃsu. Paṇḍito rājānaṃ
analyzed: jīvitam labhimha ati sabba pasādhanehi mahāsattassa pūjam kariṃsu paṇḍitaḥ rājānam
translated: Through you we have obtained life.” And with every sign of respect he paid homage to the Great Being. The Wise One said to the king,

original: āha – “mahārāja, tumhe mā cintayittha, pāpamittasaṃsaggasseva esa doso, ime rājāno
analyzed: āha mahā rāja tumhe mā cintayittha pāpa mitta saṃsaggassa iva esa dosaḥ ime rājānaḥ
translated: “Great king, do not worry. This is the fault of evil friends. You must forgive these kings.”

original: khamāpethā”ti. Rājā “mayā duppurisaṃ nissāya tumhākaṃ evarūpaṃ kataṃ, esa mayhaṃ
analyzed: khamāpetha ati rājā mayā duppurisam nissāya tumhākam evarūpam katam esa mayham
translated: The king said, “It was through my fault that you were treated in this way. This is my fault.

original: doso, khamatha me dosaṃ, puna evarūpaṃ na karissāmī”ti khamāpesi. Te aññamaññaṃ accayaṃ🔽desetvā samaggā sammodamānā ahesuṃ. Atha rājā bahūni khādanīyabhojanīyagandhamālādīni
analyzed: dosaḥ khamatha me dosam punar evarūpam na karissāmi iti khamāpesi te aññam aññam accayam  desetvā samaggā sammodamānāḥ ahesuṃ atha rājā bahūni khādanīya bhojanīya gandha mālā ādīni
translated: Forgive me my fault, and I will never do such a thing again.” They confessed their mutual fault,

original: āharāpetvā sabbehi saddhiṃ sattāhaṃ umaṅgeyeva kīḷitvā nagaraṃ pavisitvā mahāsattassa🔽mahāsakkāraṃ kāretvā ekasatarājaparivuto mahātale nisīditvā paṇḍitaṃ attano santike
analyzed: āharāpetvā sabbehi saddhim sattāham umaṅgeya iva kīḷitvā nagaram pavisitvā mahāsattassa  mahā sakkāram kāretvā eka sata rāja parivutaḥ mahā tale nisīditvā paṇḍitam santike
translated: and they became reconciled and friendly. Then the king had many kinds of food and drink, perfumes, garlands, and so on, brought, and for seven days they all played in the Umayor garden. Then they entered the city, and the king made great honor to the Great Being.

original: vasāpetukāmatāya āha –
analyzed: vasā petu kāma tāyai āha
translated: Seated in the great hall, surrounded by a hundred kings, he desired to have the Wise One live with him, and so he said:

original: “Vuttiñca parihārañca, diguṇaṃ bhattavetanaṃ;
analyzed: vuttiñca parihārañca diguṇam bhatta vetanam
translated: “I’ll give you a living and a gift, and double wages and food,

original: Dadāmi vipule bhoge, bhuñja kāme ramassu ca;
analyzed: dadāmi vipule bhoge bhuñja kāme ramassu ca
translated: And great wealth besides: enjoy yourself and take your pleasure,

original: Mā videhaṃ paccagamā, kiṃ videho karissatī”ti.
analyzed: mā videham paccagamā kim videhaḥ karissati iti
translated: Don’t go back to Videha: what can Videha do for you?”

original: Tattha vuttinti yasanissitaṃ jīvitavuttiṃ. Parihāranti gāmanigamadānaṃ. Bhattanti nivāpaṃ. Vetananti paribbayaṃ. Bhogeti aññepi te vipule bhoge dadāmi.
analyzed: tattha vuttim ti yasa nissitam jīvita vuttim parihāram ti gāma nigama dānam bhattam nti nivāpam vetanam ti paribbayam bhoge ti aññe api te vipule bhoge dadāmi
translated: Herein, a living means a living dependent on a family. A gift means a gift of a village or town. Food means a food-allotment. Wages means a maintenance-allotment. Great wealth besides means I’ll give you other great wealth besides.

analyzed: tattha ajja api tena vaṇṇena ati yathā cariyāya pubbe mam anubandhantaḥ mayā anāthena  saddhim ekatas iva bhuñjantaḥ sayantaḥ hattham paharitvā mahā hasitam hasi ajja api tathā iva  hasati duggata kāle viya mam maññati rahaḥ nandā deviyā saddhim
translated: “In spite of all my care” means that in spite of the care I have taken of him, he still behaves as he did in the past, when I was helpless and had no one to look after me.🔽“He is my constant foe” means that he still behaves as he did in the past, when I was in a bad way, and he would eat and sleep with me, and slap me on the hand and laugh a loud laugh.

original: mayi ajānāpetvā sahasāva pavisati. Iminā dosena taṃ ahirikaṃ anādaraṃ dakarakkhasassa dassāmīti.

original: Atha paribbājikā “mahārāja, tava sahāyakassa tāva eso doso hotu, purohito pana tava bahūpakāro”ti tassa guṇaṃ kathentī āha –
analyzed: atha paribbājikā mahā rāja tava sahāyakassa tāva esaḥ dosaḥ hotu purohito pana tava bahu upakāraḥ ti tassa guṇam kathentī āha
translated: Then the female wanderer said, “Great king, let this be the fault of your friend. But the chaplain has been very helpful to you.” And she spoke in praise of him:🔽He is skilled in all omens,

translated: Herein, in all omens means in all the omens such as “By this omen this will come to be, by this that.”🔽He is skilled means he is clever. analyzed: anāgatam paccuppannam sabbam attham pi passati

translated: Thus he spoke, extolling the virtues of the Great Being as if he were drawing out the orb of the moon.

original: viya tassa guṇe pākaṭe karissāmī”ti rājānaṃ gahetvā pāsādā oruyha rājaṅgaṇe āsanaṃ
analyzed: viya tassa guṇe pākaṭe karissāmi iti rājānam gahetvā pāsādāḥ oruyha rājaṅgaṇe āsanam
translated: Thus he told the story of the past in accordance with the circumstances of the present. Then the female Wanderer thought, “Even thus the virtues of the wise man are not made manifest. I will make them manifest, as if I were scattering oil on the surface of the ocean, in the midst of the inhabitants of the whole city.” So she took the king, and descending from the palace, she sat down in the royal court.

original: paññapetvā tattha nisīdāpetvā nāgare sannipātāpetvā puna rājānaṃ ādito paṭṭhāya dakarakkhasassa
analyzed: paññapetvā tattha nisīdāpetvā nāgare sannipātāpetvā punar rājānam āditas paṭṭhāya dakarakkhasassa

analyzed: pañham pucchitvā tena heṭṭhā kathita niyāmena iva kathita kāle nāgare āmantetvā āha
translated: When the question was asked in the way already described, he addressed the citizens:🔽“Listen to this, you people of Pañcāla,

analyzed: idam suṇātha pañcālā cūḷaneyyassa bhāsitam
translated: what Cūḷa-Nemi has said,

analyzed: paṇḍitam anurakkhanto pāṇam cajati duccajam

translated: “Such is wisdom, of great value, subtle, well thought out,

analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma hita tthāya samparāya sukhāya ca ati

translated: Herein, of great value is established on great value. For the good of this world and for the happiness of the next means it is for the good of this very individual existence and for the happiness of the next world.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva tathāgato paññavā, pubbepi paññavāyevā”ti jātakaṃ samodhānento osānagāthā āha –
